Title: Raipur in SC, makes UPA-era NIA Act a Centre-state conflict
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

NEW DELHI: The Congress government in Chhattisgarh on Wednesday made the National Investigation Agency (NIA) Act, enacted by Parliament in 2008 during the Congress-led UPA government to investigate terror and other crimes having national consequence, a Centre-state dispute alleging that the counter-terrorism law was illegally usurping police powers of the state.

The trigger for filing the suit to take on the Centre under a federal structure appeared to be the NIA’s decision to take over certain Naxal-related criminal cases.

The Bhupesh Baghel government’s Article 131 petition, settled by senior advocate Vivek Tankha, said, “NIA Act, in its present form, not only takes away the power of conducting investigation by the state through its police but also confers unfettered discretionary and arbitrary powers on the Union government. There are no rules governing the exercise of power (by the Union home ministry) which gives ample discretion to the Centre to exercise its power at any juncture without providing any reason or justification for the same.”

The NIA Act was passed by Parliament on December 31, 2008, in the immediate aftermath of the 26/11 terror attacks on Mumbai in order to break the silos in which intelligence and law-enforcement agencies worked and to facilitate a seamless response to crimes against the country.

Then Union home minister P Chidambaram had introduced the NIA Bill in Lok Sabha in December 2008. In the statement of object and reasons for introducing the bill to create NIA, Chidambaram had told Parliament, “Over the past several years, India has been the victim of largescale terrorism sponsored from across the borders. There have been innumerable incidents of terrorist attacks, not only in the militancy and insurgency affected areas and areas affected by Left wing extremism, but also in the form of terrorist attacks and bomb blasts etc in various parts of the hinterland and major cities.”

He had further said, “A large number of such incidents are found to have complex inter-state and international linkages, and possible connection with other activities like the smuggling of arms and drugs, pushing in and circulation of fake Indian currency, infiltration from across the borders etc. Keeping all these in view, it has for long been felt that there is need for setting up an agency at the central level for investigation of offences related to terrorism and certain other acts, which have national ramifications.”

The trigger for Chhattisgarh filing the suit seeking declaration that NIA Act was unconstitutional was the NIA’s request seeking transfer to itself several Naxal-related violent incidents. The state police appears to have completed investigations into them and did not want the NIA to take over the probe.

Citing that investigation into any crime by the central agency CBI required consent of the state government, Chhattisgarh said, “Provisions of the NIA Act leave no room for coordination and pre-condition of consent, in any form whatsoever, to be sought by the Centre from the state government, which clearly repudiates the idea of state sovereignty as envisaged under the Constitution.

“The provisions of NIA Act are such that once brought into motion, it completely takes away the power of the state government to investigate the offences which have been categorised as scheduled offences under the NIA Act and which have been committed within the jurisdiction of the state. NIA Act is not only unconstitutional but is also against the federal spirit envisaged under our constitutional scheme wherein both Centre and state are considered to be independent in their respective jurisdictions.”

Title: Top institutes will now be graded on gender equality
Content: NEW DELHI: When it comes to gender equality, does your institute measure up? You might know soon.The ministry of science and technology will grade higher educational institutions and research institutes that it funds on gender equality from this academic year. While 20 institutes, including some Indian Institutes of Technology (IITs) and National Institutes of Technology (NITs), have signed up to be part of the pilot, the grading system will eventually be rolled out across all institutes — over 90 — funded partially or fully by the ministry.The ratings — gold, silver and bronze — to STEM (science, tech, engineering, mathematics and medicine) institutes will be based on the number of women occupying science faculty positions in the institute, how well the institute recognises contributions by women scientists and the number of women fellows sent to Indian Academy of Sciences and Indian National Science Academy . Other parameters will include PhD awardees among women and how many women scientists returned after a sabbatical.While gold grade is for institutes where beacons of gender equality achievement and role models exist, silver grade is for those which have identified challenges and demonstrated impact. Bronze grade recognises institutes which are working to promote equality.“Our policy will initially include 20 institutes which will adopt a self-assessment process to develop an accreditation model to help identify gender gaps and barriers to progression faced by women in science based on interviews with them,” said Sanjay Mishra , head of KIRAN division at the department of science and technology (DST) which will give the ratings to institutions in collaboration with the British Council . The total budget of the project is Rs 8 crore, of which Rs 3 crore will be provided by the British Council.Explaining what they hope to achieve with this initiative, Mishra said, “Ratings like these will not only bring about a cultural and mindset change but also encourage top authorities like vice-chancellors and directors to take all possible action to recruit, retain and promote more women in the STEM sector.”“The project aims to engage, mentor, partner and support institutions as they work towards reaching the global best praxis for gender equality,” according to the DST policy, a copy of which is with TOI.“At present, a couple of IITs and some NITs have been included in the pilot. Later, we will grade other institutes with the ministry’s approval,” added Ashutosh Sharma , secretary, DST.The policy has been modelled after Athena SWAN (scientific women’s academic network), a charter that recognises and celebrates good practices in higher education and research institutions towards the advancement of gender equality in the UK.

Title: Your date with monsoon set to change with IMD’s fresh reference dates
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

NEW DELHI: You may soon have new ‘normal’ dates for onset and withdrawal of monsoon rains as the India Meteorological Department (IMD) is set to change the reference dates for the south-west monsoon while making its forecast for the 2020 season in April.

Though the normal onset date of summer monsoon for Kerala may remain the same as June 1, the IMD will change the reference dates for some regions as also the dates for withdrawal. The withdrawal date from north-west India may be delayed by nearly 10 days. It means the normal withdrawal date of the monsoon from north-west India (north Rajasthan, Punjab and Haryana) will be changed from September 1 to September 10.

“The IMD’s report is almost ready. We will implement it (new normal dates) from this year. It will not be changed for Kerala. But for other places, it’ll be changed. It’ll arrive early at few places and late at other places. Mostly, it’ll be late in central India. There will, however, not be a drastic change in arrival dates,” said Madhavan Rajeevan , secretary, ministry of earth sciences (MoES).

The central India division comprises 10 sub-divisions -- Chhattisgarh, Odisha , west Madhya Pradesh , east Madhya Pradesh, Vidarbha, central Maharashtra, Konkan and Goa, Gujarat region and Kutch and Saurashtra.

Arrival of monsoon in Kerala is considered as the onset date of monsoon for India even if it hits Andaman & Nicobar Islands a few days earlier.

India had been adhering to June 1 and September 1 as reference dates for onset and withdrawal of monsoon respectively ever since it was set in 1941. The four-month monsoon season is from June 1 to September 30.

The changes, based on analysis of historical data on changing rainfall pattern across the country, will help farmers, civic agencies, hydro-power plants and disaster management authorities in carrying out better planning of their works during the season.

Rajeevan, speaking on sidelines of the IMD’s 145th foundation day function here on Wednesday, noted that the marked change may be noticed in the ‘normal’ withdrawal date of monsoon from the north-west India. “It’ll be 10 days late,” he said.

Last year, the withdrawal of monsoon commenced on October 9 which was historically the most delayed withdrawal against the normal withdrawal date of September 1. Before 2019, the most delayed withdrawal was recorded in 1961 (October 1) followed by in 2007 (September 30).

The MoES secretary, however, did not specify whether climate change was behind the IMD’s move to change the ‘normal’ dates. He said the weather agency had noticed the changes in rainfall patterns over the year but did not revise the dates.

“It may not be climate change. It must be some systemic changes. I insisted that it should be brought out. We should not continue with the same climatology of 1940s to inform people about the monsoon rainfall,” said Rajeevan

Rajeevan said the IMD is also working on to predict “impact based forecast” in case of rainfall like what it did in the case of cyclone prediction where it even advised what the authorities were expected to do to minimise its impact.

Citing example of Uttarakhand floods of 2013, the MoES secretary said the IMD was satisfied with its prediction of heavy rainfall but it could not tell the authorities about its likely impact.

“Impact of heavy rainfall could be different for different cities or regions, depending on ground situation. Therefore, it is important to come out with an impact based forecast in case of heavy rainfalls or any other weather events,” said Rajeevan.

The changes will be the second such move by the IMD to bring a new benchmark as far as summer monsoon is concerned. Last year, the country got a new benchmark that categorises ‘status’ of its summer monsoon based on the amount of rains it gets compared to the ‘normal’ rainfall during June-September period.

This ‘normal’, derived as long period average (LPA) of 50 years, had been revised downward from 89 cm to 88 cm, reflecting decline in average rainfall in India.

Title: Most Desirable Woman on TV for 2019: Trina Saha
Content: I can’t believe it!” says an ecstatic Trina Saha, when we break it to her that she has bagged the title of Calcutta Times Most Desirable Woman on Television 2019. As the feeling sinks in, the bubbly actress settles down for a fun chat with us. Beautiful and talented — Trina has all the qualities to top the coveted list. The actress, who is currently seen in the megaserial Koler Bou, speaks to us about her desirability quotient, aspirations and journey so far. Excerpts…I’m overwhelmed. I need to pinch myself for it’s a dream come true. I’m thankful to those who have voted for me. I also want to thank all my fans from the bottom of my heart. I feel more responsible as an actor now.I’m a people’s person. I can mingle with people freely without harbouring any preconceived notions about them. That, I believe, is my best quality. Besides, I’m very grounded. I don’t let success rule my life. I credit my parents for instilling this quality in me. That apart, I can switch roles very easily. For instance, I can be a barir bouma one moment and a girl-next-door the other.He has to have a great sense of humour and should be able to make me laugh. My man should also have a strong personality. He should be able to clearly judge between what is right and what is wrong. If I make a mistake, he should be able to tell me that on my face. Also, it is important that he is loved by my friends and family. If you are accepted by both a five-year-old and a 70-year-old, you are quite desirable I’d say!My debut serial, Khokababu , was a huge hit. Till now, I have been a part of two megaserials, two films and two national advertisements. The work experience has been a learning process for me. I received two best actress awards in a span of two years, which I think acted as a huge motivation for me. It’s been a smooth journey so far.To me, the most desirable man in India is Shah Rukh Khan . Both his on-screen presence and his off-screen personality are simply amazing. He has balanced his career and personal life with a lot of grace. And he is witty too! Among the women, I look up to Vidya Balan . Not only is she a brilliant actress, she has also taught me how to take criticism in my stride. In Tollywood, Ritudi (Rituparna Sengupta) is a big inspiration. The energy with which she has been working all these years is remarkable.Absolutely! I can’t imagine being born and raised anywhere else. The City of Joy is both my comfort zone and my happy place.It’s been amazing. I believe if you stick to your values and are strong-headed, you can shine in life. I’m thankful that I didn’t have to face casting couch. It’s my talent that has helped me secure a place in the industry. I have assisted many filmmakers during the early years of my career. I have been trained in dance by Thankumani Kutty and Saroj Khan. So, being a choreographer is also on my wish list. I want to fulfill all my dreams in due course of time.Tollywood is a growing industry. Both the films that I have worked in boasted of a huge star cast. Password will remain the most special film to me because I got to work with Paramda ( Parambrata Chattopadhyay ) in it. I have a huge crush on him!

Title: Interested in diplomacy, but not in negotiating with US: Iran
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

NEW DELHI: Iranian foreign minister Javad Zarif on Wednesday said Tehran was interested in diplomacy but not in negotiating with the US which had not kept its word, indicating the bitterness and chill between the two nations. Zarif also said the killing of Iranian general Qassim Suleimani showed ignorance and arrogance.

Addressing the Raisina Dialogue here, Zarif, who was recently denied permission to visit the UN in New York, said 430 Indian cities saw protests against Suleimani's killing in a US drone strike on January 3. Indian government sources, however, said a few demonstrations took place only in Lucknow and Kargil.

On tensions with the US, Zarif said, “We are interested in diplomacy. We are not interested in negotiating with the US. The US did not keep its commitments under the nuclear deal. We had a deal and the US broke it. If we have a Trump deal, how long will it last?”

Zarif met Prime Minister Narendra Modi later on Wednesday evening. According to an official readout, Modi reaffirmed India’s commitment to its relationship with Iran. “He thanked the Iranian leadership for progress in Chahbahar project, including through designating it as a special economic zone,” the government said. Zarif met NSA Ajit Doval and will meet his counterpart S Jaishankar on Thursday.

Accusing the US of “ignorance and arrogance”, Zarif, who made the most of the platform provided by the dialogue, said the US was fuelling “mayhem” in West Asia. However, US officials have stressed they had clear indications that Suleimani was planning attacks against American interests.

“Suleimani was the single biggest threat to the Islamic State, it is now celebrating his killing," Zarif said. "The US didn't like Suleimani, although he was the single most effective force against the IS. If you don't believe me, see they are celebrating. Who are celebrating the death of Suleimani? Not ordinary people, but (Donald) Trump, (Mike) Pompeo and IS," he added.

Describing the shooting down of a Ukrainian airline as “unforgivable”, Zarif said, “The accidental shooting happened because there was a crisis. People made unforgivable mistakes.” Calling for a new coalition against IS, he said, “The current coalition used the basis of the coalition to kill the most effective anti-IS general.”

Zarif defended the resolution passed by the Iraqi parliament which sought removal of all foreign troops from Iraq. “The US hit two bases in Iraq to carry out operations in Iraq against an Iraqi guest. It was an unprovoked attack inside Iraq’s territory,” he said.

After the Europeans activated the dispute settlement mechanism of the Iranian nuclear deal, Zarif said he was uncertain the deal will survive at all. “It depends on Europe whether the deal will remain in place after the activation of the dispute resolution mechanism by France, Germany and the United Kingdom ,” he said.

Title: Congress: Govt favouring Adani group for Rs 45,000 crore sub deal
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

NEW DELHI: Congress on Wednesday alleged that the Modi government is looking to favour the Adani industrial group in a Rs 45,000 crore defence deal to manufacture submarines despite a negative opinion of the key Navy panel which decides on eligibility of bidders.

Addressing a press conference, AICC spokespersons Randeep Surjewala and Jaiveer Shergill said Navy received five responses to its offer for building six conventional submarines under Project 75-I.

“The offer of the joint venture of Adani Defence and Hindustan Shipyard Limited was rejected. Adani has no experience in manufacturing ships and submarines, and its only claim in favour of its bid was that it had experience in setting up and running power plants,” they said.

According to Congress, the “empowered committee” rejected Adani’s bid and on examination of manufacturing facilities, financial records and other criteria, it short-listed two entities – government-owned Mazagaon Dock Shipbuilders Limited and Larsen and Toubro .

“But the Central government and the defence ministry is now seeking to overrule the ‘empowered committee’ of Indian Navy by pressuring it to consider Adani defence. A decision is likely to be taken on Friday or Saturday,” Surjewala and Shergill claimed, calling it a case of “crony capitalism”.

Targeting the government, Surjewala said, “The Submarine Project 75-I is under a cloud of suspicion owing to allegations of favouritism, crony capitalism , violations of the DPP-2016 and an alleged over-ruling of Indian Navy and its empowered committee by the Narendra Modi government.”

“The government is flouting norms and the defence procurement procedure 2016 (DPP-2016) in awarding the contract to the Adani-HSL joint venture,” Surjewala said.

Congress alleged Adani has also flouted project norms. It said there was no official joint venture till the final closure of Expression of Interest on September 11, 2019, and the companies announced formation of a JV only on September 28. It cited media reports on company’s announcement of JV to back its claim.

“According to rules, the JV has to get the clearance from the Ministry of Defence. But it had not been taken at the time of submitting the EOI. The ‘credit rating’ has also been lowered to benefit the Adani JV. The norms say every entity bidding for a contract above Rs 1,000 crore should be categorised as ‘A’ but in this case it has been diluted to ‘BBB’,” Shergill alleged.

Title: Man earning Rs 7,000 gets tax notice to explain Rs 134cr transactions
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

BHOPAL: A 29-year-old youth from Bhind district of Madhya Pradesh is in shock after being handed an income-tax notice and told to explain transactions of Rs 134 crore made on a business account opened with his PAN number in Mumbai in 2011-12. Ravi Gupta says he had a salary of Rs 7,000 in those days, has no idea how the account was opened, and believes it to be a case of money laundering , which should be probed.

He says an even bigger shock awaited him when he began his own investigation into the firm — it led him to a few steps from the offices of fugitive jeweller Mehul Choksi and his nephew Nirav Modi, co-accused in the Rs 12,700-crore Punjab National Bank (PNB) fraud. Gupta alleged that the transactions were made by a Gujarat-based diamond trading company.

A senior I-T official said Gupta can file a complaint and seek a probe. Gupta, a resident of Bhind’s Mohana, has been told that transactions of Rs 134 crore were made in the account of the company with a private bank's branch in Mumbai between September 9, 2011, and February 13, 2012. The PAN card linked with this company belongs to Gupta.

“I was hardly 21 when these transactions were made. I had not been to Mumbai or Gujarat in 2011 or 2012. I was then working with a private firm in Indore, earning Rs 7,000 a month, which is non-taxable,” Gupta told TOI. “I have written to MP cyber cell, Maharashtra Police, PMO and I-T officers to clear me of this tax recovery case.”

He received the first tax notice on March 30, 2019, and told that his income for 2011-12 fiscal was taxable. “I ignored it since my salary that year was not taxable. Then, I got another one in July. Rattled, I began taking leave to conduct my own investigation. I started collecting details of the case,” said Gupta. He says he went to income-tax offices in Mumbai to tell them that he isn’t at fault and that the account was not his. “Now, the I-T department has threatened to attach my properties to recover the dues,” he said.

Gupta was summoned by I-T in December and told to bring account details, account opening form, PAN card, copy account verification form, service tax registration, TIN registration and firm registration in Gujarat. “I told them that I had nothing to do with the diamond company. The account had only my PAN card, that too with a forged signature. They should investigate how transactions of over Rs 100 crore were made from an account that didn’t have a local address,” Gupta said.

Title: RJD MLA: Nitish to form govt again
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

PATNA: RJD MLA Faraz Fatmi on Wednesday created ripples in the political circles by saying that chief minister Nitish Kumar will return to power in the state. He also criticized RJD’s CM face Tejashwi Prasad Yadav for his proposed ‘Pratirodh Yatra’ In Seemanchal area from January 16 against the Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA), National Population Register (NPR) and National Register of Citizens (NRC).

“When Nitish ji has already cleared his stand on the NRC by saying that it would not be implemented in Bihar, then what is the necessity of Tejashwi Yadav going to Seemanchal and begin a yatra on this sensitive and contentious issue,” the Keoti MLA said after attending a ‘Dahi-Chura' feast organized by JD(U)’s state president Bashishtha Narain Singh at his residence and attended by Nitish on the Makar Sankranti day on Wednesday.

Faraz’s statement assumes significance in an election year and indicated not only his inclination to join JD(U) led by Nitish but also the political churning going on among the legislators and leaders of different political parties, who will look for safer seat and side to swim through in the assembly polls due later this year.

When contacted, Faraz told TOI that even senior RJD leader like Raghuvansh Prasad Singh has said that Nitish will be the face in the 2020 assembly polls. “As of now in Bihar’s politics, Nitish is the biggest face compared to any other leader and he will form the next government,” said Faraz, whose father represented Darbhanga four times in Parliament.

RJD state spokesperson Chitranjan Gagan said Faraz has not been participating in any party activities since his father MAA Fatmi left RJD and joined JD(U). When asked if RJD will expel him from the party, Gagan said, “He is free to leave RJD.”

Senior Fatmi had joined the JD(U) in July 2019 after breaking his almost 30 years’ long political ties with RJD and its chief Lalu Prasad. Fatmi, who was Union minister in UPA-1 government between 2004 and 2009, left RJD in April after denial of party symbol to contest the 2019 Lok Sabha polls either from Darbhanga or Madhubani in Bihar.

After quitting the RJD, he filed his nomination papers from Madhubani Lok Sabha seat as a BSP candidate, but withdrew his papers fearing split in opposition votes as Congress rebel Shakeel Ahmed was also in the fray.

Title: Priest sodomises 7-year-old boy in temple area, arrested
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Varanasi: A minor boy was allegedly sodomised by a 65-year-old priest of a Hanuman temple in Gyanpur area of Bhadohi district on Wednesday. The police arrested the priest and probe is on.

According to reports, priest identified as Ramdas Tiwari, native of Kaushambi district, has been living at the temple in Purani Bazaar locality of Gyanpur Kotwali area for some time.

On Wednesday, he lured a seven-year-old boy promising him to give a kite. He took the boy to a secluded place in temple premises and allegedly sodomised him.

In the meantime, some local residents noticed it and caught hold him, and handed him to the police after thrashing him. The police said the priest was arrested. Probe iss on in case. tnn

Title: Joy and sorrow fly side by side on Uttarayan day
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Surat: The skies turned vibrant on Uttarayan day with revellers letting their purse strings loose to celebrate the year’s first festival amid pomp and show, literally.

War cries of ‘kai po chhe’ from terraces and in between mouthful of delicacies, Surtis’ fun quotient was sky high on Tuesday. From the crack of dawn, armies of kitists, armed with kites, horns, music systems and other paraphernalia raided the terraces wherever possible and enjoyed flying kites till dusk set in.

The bursting of crackers marked the end of the day’s festivities at night.

On the other hand, the day also brought sorrow to many households where revellers either met with accidents on the road, or fell of terraces while flying kites. A total of 49 calls went to the EMRI 108 emergency services for road accidents, 14 for fighting for kites, 26 for falling off terraces while flying kites and 19 for injury from deadly manja.

A 108 services spokesman said that maximum of 49 road accidents reported on the day came mainly from Ring Road and Rander Road. Maximum number of manja-related injuries were reported from Rander Road and the main road from Udhna Darwaja to Sachin where revellers were seen running in between traffic to catch loose kites or were hurt by dangling cut manjas while going on their vehicles.

The official also said that number of small group clashes were reported from Pandesara and Unn areas of the city on Tuesday.

On Wednesday, 108 emergency services recorded 16 road accidents, five clashes, 12 cases of falling off rooftops and other places and 12 manja-related cases.

The emergency services official said that compared to last year, the number of incidents this year have come down by 20 per cent at least and number of fatal incidents have reduced by more than 50 per cent.

Boxes

Hit and run case on Uttarayan day

Surat: A 34-year-old divyang primary school teacher was runover by a speeding car on Tuesday in Sarthana area. His wife sustained injuries and is under treatment. Sanjay Chitar Dabhi works as a teacher in Nagar Parthmik Shikshan Samiti and he along with his wife had gone to attend a get-together arranged by Swadhaya Parivar in his school for Uttarayan. While returning home, he stopped his bike on the roadside at Sarthana canal road. A car suddenly came at full speed towards them and hit Dabhi and his wife and fled the spot. However, people present on the spot chased the car and caught it. They took Dabhi and his wife to the hospital in the car. While Dabhi died during treatment, his wife is stated to be in a stable condition at present.

108 technician displays great humanity

Surat: While he was passing from Palanpur Jakatnaka, Hasmukh Devipujak was injured by a killer manja on the throat. He fell unconscious on the road. He was taken to the New Civil Hospital in an 108 ambulance. Devipujak had Rs 13,900 in cash on him and was wearing a silver bracelet which the ambulance’s medical technician Shabbir Khan removed and kept with him till Devipujak’s wife reached the hospital. Khan handed her the valuables displaying extreme sense responsibility and great humanity.

Alert cops saves minor boy’s life

Surat: Without wasting time waiting for ambulance, Hirit Patni, a policeman rushed a grievously injured 4-year-old child to the New civil Hospital on his bike to save his life. Shivam, the youngest of Pappusinh’s three sons, was riding with his father and mother to Ambaji temple on Parle point on Uttarayan morning. While returning home to Bhatar, a manja got entangled in Shivam’s throat, who was sitting on the tank of the two-wheeler. The father applied breaks, but lost balance and they fell on the road. Police constable Kirit Patni was passing by on his bike. He stopped and asked a pedestrian to sit pillion holding the injured boy on his lap and rode to the hospital. This timely act saved the child from serious complications and was treated with few stitches.

Title: Old secretariat to get facelift before Jan 26
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

PATNA: The state government has decided to renovate several heritage buildings in the city, including the old secretariat . As part of their beautification, their interiors have to be decorated and façades illuminated.

While the renovation work of the old secretariat is in full swing and is likely to be completed before January 26, other buildings like the Raj Bhavan will be beautified during the next few months.

Located in the east of the Raj Bhavan, the secretariat is one of the oldest buildings in the state capital. Apart from housing a number of important government departments, it also has offices of several ministers and bureaucrats. As part of its renovation work, the interior of the 100-year-old Victorian-style building has been decorated with old artefacts as well as paintings and its façade illuminated with lights of different colours and a digital flag on Republic Day and Independence Day.

“The old secretariat will be revamped before Republic Day. It is a great example of architectural brilliance and will be thrown open to common people soon. We want them to know about one of Bihar’s oldest and most prominent buildings as it showcases various aspects of our culture,” chief secretary Deepak Kumar told this newspaper on Tuesday.

Work on beautification of other heritage structures will begin once the old secretariat is renovated. “The city has numerous heritage buildings. We have planned to adorn them so that people understand their importance,” Kumar said.

An official of the state youth, art and culture department claimed that most prominent heritage sites in the city had been built in Greek, Roman and Renaissance styles during the 20th century. “Some of these include the Raj Bhavan, which was built in Renaissance style, and the Bihar Vidhan Mandal whose architecture was influenced by Greek and Roman cultures,” he added.

Title: Mahagathbandhan netas show bonhomie over feast
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

PATNA: The Mahagathbandhan leaders showed solidarity over Dahi-Chura feast organized by state Congress president Madan Mohan Jha at Sadaquat Ashram on Makar Sankranti day on Wednesday. The opposition leaders not only tried to show bonhomie, but also lashed out at the Centre and state government, especially on the Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA), National Register for Citizen (NRC) and National Population Register (NPR) issues.

Leader of opposition in the state assembly, Tejashwi Prasad Yadav, said chief minister Nitish Kumar was not even following his party’s constitution and simply doing what BJP wanted. “He has delayed the discussion on CAA and is even ready for NPR, which is a first step towards NRC. He is doing all these things for personal greed,” said Tejashwi, who advised Nitish to form a human chain on issues like unemployment in the country.

Regarding Union home minister Amit Shah’s pro-CAA rally scheduled in Vaishali on Thursday, Tejashwi said the NDA had time and again tried to disturb peace, but could not succeed in Bihar as it is the land of Buddha. Even Congress state incharge Shaktisinh Gohil rapped at the central government over CAA and NPR and ignoring inflation and unemployment issues.

“Those who think that only Muslims will be affected by NPR are wrong. Poor will be the worst affected. How will they show the documents and birth certificate of their parents to prove citizenship. People should learn a lesson from Assam, where majority of those who failed to show the documents were actually non-Muslims,” said Gohil

“I know both PM Narendra Modi and Amit Shah well. They trap a person by knowing his weaknesses and they have done the same with Nitish, who is not able to speak openly despite winning the last election with secular votes,” he added.

Meanwhile, Tejashwi made the other leaders wait for the delicacies for almost an hour as he reached the venue late. RLSP head Upendra Kushwaha, HAM(S) chief Jitan Ram Manjhi and VIP founder Mukesh Sahni reached Sadaquat Ashram by 12:30pm, but Tejashwi reached around 1:30pm.

While talking to media before the feast, Manjhi once again said the CM candidate will be decided by the Mahagathbandhan coordination committee. He also said his party will remain firm on its previous demand of making one chief minister and two deputy chief ministers and one each should be from Scheduled Caste, minority and extremely backward caste. Also, one of these should be a woman.

Title: Lohri brings people of all faiths together
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Kolkata: At a time when the atmosphere of the city is charged with activism over citizenship issues and protests, people of all faiths got together to celebrate the harvest festival of Lohri .

The programme was organized by IHA Foundation and its chairman, Satnam Singh Ahluwalia curated the event with a message of universal brotherhood.

Lohri, a harvest festival, is celebrated to mark the end of peak winter and is traditionally associated with the harvest of the Rabi crops. Punjabi farmers see the day after Lohri (Maghi) as the financial new year.

The city celebrations followed the tradition of geet, tappe and boliyan by the Malwai group of Punjab, beating of dhol and bhangra, accompanied by bonfire. The traditional Punjabi menu inspired by recipes handed over from generation to generation.

The celebrations were attended by several dignitaries, including Lt Gen R P Kalita, Chief of Staff, Eastern Command, Maj Gen Alok Joshi, GOC Bengal Sub Area, MP Dinesh Trivedi, Consul General USA Patricia Hoffman, Consulate General De France Virginie Corteval, director of Alliance Française du Bengale Fabrice Plançon, representatives of different communities and even a section of Tollywood and Bollywood actors and producers.

Title: Jeff Bezos tries to win over traders
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Amazon founder Jeff Bezos (Photo: ANI)

NEW DELHI: On a nippy Wednesday morning, traffic snarls near Jawaharlal Nehru Stadium in the capital triggered angry expletives from drivers, who were stranded staring at a huge orange balloon soaring against the skyline with Amazon emblazoned all over it.

Small traders, who had threatened to greet Amazon founder Jeff Bezos with vociferous protests for allegedly taking away their business, were nowhere to be seen. Only hundreds of small entrepreneurs, who had coughed up Rs 4,000 to attend a two-day event by the US retailer, stood in serpentine queues leading up to gate number 20.

Some took to social media to vent their ire. “Suited professionals are standing on dusty roads in a long-long queue to register for a paid event. It’s not a free event which entitles Amazon to treat professionals like garbage,” said a seller.

But once inside the smallish auditorium, the expectation of seeing the world’s richest man on stage, turned frustration into excitement. Neither tedious Amazon ads playing on loop, nor a one-and-half hour delay in starting proceedings dampened their spirits. Only Infosys founder Narayana Murthy made his displeasure felt as he abruptly cut short his speech. “I was supposed to speak for 20 minutes but will try and finish it in five minutes because I am not used to delays,” he said, rather tersely.

Bezos’ entrance was preceded by the arrival of his personal bodyguards, who appeared to have been picked straight from the US Secret Service. While they flanked the stage to face the crowd, the flamboyant 56-year-old entrepreneur strolled in to join other senior Amazon executives, in a printed blue Nehru jacket sourced impromptu from a local vendor at the venue. The excitement inside the packed hall was palpable.

Chatting with Amazon India head Amit Agarwal, Bezos spoke about the impact of climate change, the need to create space entrepreneurs, his childhood fantasies, failures and the potential of India on the global stage.

The Amazon boss also made a distinction between different kinds of failures. Some experiments are high-quality failures, he said. “Innovation is about maximising the rate of experimentation,” Bezos said, “Then there is operational excellence failure that you should try to avoid. When you know how to do something, you have to treat that differently.”

Speaking about the aspirations of his space company, Blue Origin, Bezos said, “I want Blue Origin to reduce the cost of access to space by such a large magnitude that we can have two kids in a dorm room start a great space company.”

While the overawed audience, which consisted mainly of small entrepreneurs, broke into a thunderous applause at Bezos’s tips on achieving success, street food vendors outside the venue took the cue and hiked the price of a tiny plate of bhel puri by at least Rs 40.

The billionaire e-commerce tycoon wore Indian attire — topped by a Nehru jacket — and took to flying kites with children as part of his charm offensive leading the US retail giant’s fresh bid of garnering a larger share in one of the most lucrative markets in the world.

Title: Universities told to organize sports & cultural events
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

File photo of Patna University

PATNA: The chancellor ’s secretariat has directed the universities to organize as many as 16 co-curricular and extra-curricular programmes during the next six months with a view to improving the academic atmosphere in colleges and university department and encouraging the students to take part in sports and cultural activities.

Tilka Manjhi Bhagalpur University (TMBU) has been asked to organize a three-day inter-university sports meet ‘Eklavya’ from February 6 to 8. All the universities in the state would send their athletics teams in this competition and the winners would be awarded prizes. An inter-university cultural festival was organized by Patliputra University in the first week of December.

L N Mithila University (LNMU) will organize a workshop on ‘NAAC accreditation’ at Darbhanga in January itself. This workshop holds great significance as a large number of educational institutions are yet to be accreditated by the National Assessment and Accreditation Council (NAAC) and, hence, they are being deprived of financial grants from the UGC and other funding agencies. Besides, the workshop would also train the institutions in making necessary preparations for assessment and scoring better grades following their accreditation.

Recently, the self-study reports submitted by more than a dozen colleges of different universities, including Patna and Patliputra universities, were not accepted by NAAC as they were not properly filled in. NAAC accreditation has now become mandatory for all the institutions of higher education in the country and no institution would get any financial aid from any agencies unless it is accreditated, said sources.

Jayaprakash University, Chhapra, has been asked to organize a quiz competition for students on ‘Role of Mahatma Gandhi in India’s freedom movement’ during the current month itself. Bihar Agricultural University, Sabour, will organize an agricultural exhibition in February and Munger University will organize an exhibition on the latest scientific techniques and equipment.

Patna University will organize a workshop on revision of three-year degree courses as per the UGC-NET syllabi. Universities in Bihar are also preparing for introducing semester system and choice based credit system (CBCS) at the undergraduate level from the next academic session. The universities have already adopted CBCS at the postgraduate level following a uniform ordinance assented to by the chancellor, sources added.

Besides, Raj Bhavan has directed all the universities to organize workshops, seminars and conferences at regular intervals.

Title: Kolkata: Park Circus protesters treated to ‘pithe-puli’
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Protesters enjoy a patishapta or two at Park Circus Maidan on Wednesday

KOLKATA: On the occasion of Makar Sankranti , a citi-zens’ group distributed patisapta among the women at the sit-in at Park Circus Maidan .

Mahasweta Samajdar, one of the members of the group, said, “In every Bengali household, we make pithe with rice flour, coconut, milk and khejur gur on this day and distribute it among friends and relatives. We thought of celebrating this year’s Makar Sankranti with the feisty women of Park Circus who are fighting this battle against NRC, CAA and NPR for all of us.”

Around 200 women and children were present at the maidan when members of the citizens’ group, Sohomon, arrived with packets of pithe. They interacted with them and spoke about the festival and how Bengalis celebrate it in their homes. After the brief interaction, the members of the group started distributing the patishapta to the burkha-clad women sitting in protest against NRC, CAA and NPR.

Topsia resident Tabassum Gulab, who has been coming to Park Circus every day got to taste patishapta for the first time. “I liked the sweet, as well as the gesture of the people who brought it for us. We want to live together peacefully, celebrating each other’s festival for generations to come,” she said.

Fabiha Ahmed, a Class III student who came with her mother, was seen relishing the dish. It was her first experience of tasting a traditional Bengali sweet.

Thakurpukur resident Razia Mondol, who joined the sit-in demonstration on Wednesday, described the initiative as “heartwarming and thoughtful”. She said, “This act shows that no one can divide us in the name of religion. This movement has strengthened the bond between Hindus and Muslims and given us a chance to know each other’s festivals and customs more thoroughly,” she said.

Sumaan Sengupta, another member of Sohomon, said, “It is important to know each other and take part in each other’s festivals to br-idge the differences between us, which are being used to create the chasm among communities. The initiative was taken to send out a message of inclusiveness and peace-ful coexistence.”

Uzma Alam, a homemaker, said, “It is good to see people from different religions coming here to celebrate their festivals. The unseen barrier between communities are finally melting as this is the need of the hour.”

Md Ataullah Khan, a resident of Park Circus, felt this act upheld the secular tenets of the country.

Title: Raghuvansh Prasad Singh flays ‘slip’ system under new RJD state president
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Raghuvansh Prasad Singh

PATNA: Jagdanand Singh, a Rajput, was made the RJD’s state president to woo his caste voters, but his fellow caste man and senior party leader Raghuvansh Prasad Singh is frequently attacking the former over his style of functioning and defeating the purpose of party chief Lalu Prasad behind appointing a forward caste leader as the state unit head.

Raghuvansh went to the extent of comparing Jagdanand’s style of functioning with that of Nazy leader Hitler. “Office gate remains closed and people have to send a slip to meet him (Jagdanand). There is a purza (slip) system now. These things are against the functioning of RJD, which is a party of the poor. He talks of discipline, but that does not mean slavery,” Raghuvansh told TOI on Wednesday.

A party worker associated with the RJD office said after taking the charge of state president, Jagdanand brought many changes to focus on discipline. “Now vehicles are not allowed to be parked inside the office campus. Earlier, any worker could enter the campus and park his vehicle wherever he felt. Since the campus is not huge, it led to chaos. But now the main gate remains closed and even state president gets down from his car outside and walks to the office. Also, people are not allowed to simply sit and waste time inside the office campus. This has irked many who have complained to Raghuvansh Babu,” he said.

Raghuvansh has also written a letter to Lalu while criticizing Jagdanand’s style of functioning. He mentioned in his letter about lack of party’s preparedness to face the assembly election as the committees at different levels had not been formed even after a month of organizational election and just 300 days left for the assembly election.

However, Jagdanand avoids confronting Raghuvansh. He had earlier told TOI that every party member had a right to express his view in a democracy.

A senior party leader said it was a clash of ego between the two Rajput leaders. “Both are senior leaders and close to Lalu ji, who had once kept one in Delhi (Raghuvansh) and another in the state (Jagdanand). But today the situation has changed and Raghuvansh Babu feels sidelined as he thinks Tejashwi is more inclined towards Jagdanand,” he said.

Another party leader added, “This is not for the first time that Raghuvansh Babu is criticizing anyone or pointing out the mistakes in the party publicly. Even while sharing the dais with Lalu ji, he had done so. He had even criticised the functioning of former RJD state president Ram Chandra Purbey. He is a socialist and this is how most of them function.”

Title: Textile worker stabbed to death in Sachin
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Surat: A 24-year old labourer was found brutally murdered in the industrial area of Sachin on January 14.

The man, who was later identified as Aman Pandey, was stabbed multiple times by some unidentified persons and his body was found on the road near Hojiwala Industrial Estate.

Ashraf Ali Mansur, a security guard of the industrial estate, spotted the body in a pool of blood and informed the police. His identity was established from some documents found in the pocket of his clothes. Pandey, 24, was a native of Kharwadi in Chitrakoot district of Uttar Pradesh and was employed in a textile unit in Sachin.

An official from Sachin police station said, “There were at least 12 stabbing wounds in his ribs, chest, throat, left knee, thighs and back. It looks the killers continued to stab him till he died on the spot.”

Police suspect the murder to be a fall-out of some monetary dispute or personal enmity.

“There is no CCTV footage. We are probing all angles and launched a hunt for the assailants,” said police.

Title: Experts back Bihar CM Nitish Kumar on porn ban, call for sex education in schools
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Nitish Kumar

PATNA: Experts in city have hailed CM Nitish Kumar’s call for a ban on pornography , which, they believe, is one of the major causes for rise in cases of sexual assaults on women.

“Sexually explicit videos, photos, audios and games trigger brain cells, which incite the culprits to commit rapes and other forms of violence against women. Pornography also has extremely troubling effects on the mental and physical health of people from all age groups, including children,” they said.

Nodal officer and associate professor of NMCH de-addiction centre, Santosh Kumar, said watching porn is as addictive and dangerous as taking drugs. “Porn has such bad effects on people, especially adolescents, that it hinders their mental and physical health,” he said.

Kumar added, “Explicit contents available on the internet disrupt their ability to differentiate between good and bad. Contents shown on porn websites lack empathy. Children become stubborn and heartless after watching videos of rape and sexual assaults. Thereafter, they tend to commit crimes like rapes.”

He said people commit such crimes due to lack of sex education as well. “Ban on porn will definitely minimize cases of sexual harassment, but it won’t stop the crime. The only thing that can stop it is education. Teachers as well as parents should start giving sex education to children from a very young age,” said Kumar.

Binda Singh, a clinical psychologist, also said parents should start educating their children from young age. “Hiding or making sex look like taboo will only increase their curiosity,” she said, adding schools should organise awareness campaigns and hire experts to give sex education to children.

Teachers too said sex education should be made compulsory in schools. “Almost every year, I find a group of young children watching porn in the classroom in the absence of teacher. I have also caught children of Class III watching such videos. They find it extraordinary and unusual,” said Alka, a teacher.

Parents, on the other hand, said schools should start teaching children in the traditional way. “These days children get their homework on WhatsApp. Even if we try to keep them away from internet and social media, we cannot,” said Rajesh Tiwari, a resident of Bailey Road.

On culprits blackmailing victims by making their videos viral, experts said social stigma and people’s mentality play an important role in this. “Psychopaths blackmail victims by making their sexually explicit videos. The victims avoid sharing it even with people closer to them fearing backlash in society,” Binda added.

Title: Pune police pull up personnel violating traffic rules
Content:
The tweet read, “Inspector sir on bike...Please take necessary action”

They will certainly reach ‘destination action taken’! No matter who does the violation, there will be a lawful acti… https://t.co/IiVINAjbZp — PUNE POLICE (@PuneCityPolice) 1578376978000 PUNE: The city police have said its personnel, just like the regular citizens, were being pulled up for violating traffic rules .Though the traffic police do not maintain separate records of the number of its personnel being penalized for the traffic rule violations, a glance at the department’s Twitter handle reveals that citizens post at least several instances of the men in uniform bending the rules every day.Citizens often draw the Pune police and the commissioner’s attention through Twitter or Satark Punekar towards their personnel either riding motorcycles without helmet or not using the seatbelt and speaking on the cellphone while on the wheel. The Satark Punekar app was launched by the Pune traffic police in January last year to enable citizens to report traffic violations.Traffic police department officials said action was being taken even against personnel found violating the road rules.A week ago, a citizen had called out to the department on Twitter with a photograph of two policemen on a two-wheeler without helmets, stating “Any action on your colleagues?”In response to the tweet, the department wrote, “They will certainly reach ‘destination action taken’! No matter who does the violation, there will be a lawful action taken on them. #RulesForAll. The department “had supported the claim by sharing the e-challan issued for the violation.Speaking with ToI, police commissioner K Venkatesham said, “No matter who is violating the rules, the offenders will be penalized. If a policeman or official has made a violation, he/she will be penalized just like citizens violating the traffic laws.”Ranjit Gadgil, programme director of Parisar, a local NGO working on road safety, said administrative action should also be initiated against policemen violating traffic rules.“I saw a policeman riding a two-wheeler without a helmet in Aurangabad on Tuesday. Such incidents, especially during the National Road Safety Week, show the enforcement agencies in very poor light. Police violating rules send a wrong message to the public,” he said.“Policemen are often seen violating the helmet (especially while riding pillion) and seatbelt rules, parking vehicles on footpaths, crossing the zebra lines at a traffic signal and driving wrong way,” Gadgil said.“A new section added in the Motor Vehicles Amendment Act, 2019, states that ‘Any authority that is empowered to enforce the provisions of this Act, if such authority commits an offence under this Act, shall be liable for twice the penalty corresponding to that offence under this act’. In addition to the provisions under the Act, the police should take administrative action against the staffers violating any rule,” he said.

Title: AIIMS-Patna felicitates road accident survivors
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

All India Institute of Medical Sciences, Patna (File photo)

PATNA: The All India Institute of Medical Sciences-Patna (AIIMS-P) on Wednesday felicitated 10 persons who lost their limbs after undergoing amputation during treatment there after road accidents. It was a part of the road safety week being organised by the institute.

Altogether 25 persons of different places, who met with accidents and had to undergo amputation at AIIMS-P in the last one and a half years were invited for felicitation, but only ten turned up.

Speaking to these road accident victims, AIIMS-P director Dr PK Singh encouraged them to have confidence and lead a normal life. He said everyone needed to be aware of traffic rules and cautious while driving or walking on roads as even a minor mistake could cost someone his or her life.

Head of the trauma and emergency department, Dr Anil Kumar, said out of about 1300 road accident victims who were treated at the AIIMS-P till date, 25 suffered loss of one or more limbs. “In accident cases, time and severity matter a lot. The first four hours are golden hours for survival and effective treatment of those having vascular injuries as delay in reaching a hospital may worsen the case,” he said.

The AIIMS-P trauma department requested the transport secretary cum divisional commissioner of Patna to help in providing artificial limbs to these accident survivors for making their life more self-dependent, said Anil.

Among those felicitated was a six-year-old girl Shipra of Muzaffarpur. She had met with an accident while playing in front of her school and lost both her limbs above the knees. Talking to doctors, her mother said every school must keep watch when children go for outdoor games.

Dharmendra of Patna, who lost his lower limbs in an accident while driving a bike without helmet, thanked the AIIMS-P for saving his life. “Taking a lesson from the accident, I advise bikers never to step out on the road without helmet,” he said.

Others felicitated on the occasion included Rajendra Sharma of Gopalganj, Rajendra of Khagaria, Rajesh Pundit of Fatuha, Kallu Pawan, Tau and Santosh Kumar.

Title: Commercial flights from Darbhanga soon
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Representative image

PATNA: The Airports Authority of India (AAI) is gearing up to begin commercial flights from the Darbhanga airbase as the construction work on the terminal building and re-carpeting of the air strip is now in the final stage and is expected to be ready by March.

According to AAI sources in Patna, final touches are being given to the civil enclave, which can accommodate 200 passengers at peak hour. “Flight operations at Darbhanga airbase will likely begin in next couple of months after all arrangements are put in place,” sources said. The flight operations were earlier scheduled to begin in December, 2019.

Darbhanga will be the first airport in Bihar under the Centre’s ambitious UDAN scheme aimed at improving regional connectivity.

Patna airport director Bhupesh CH Negi told this newspaper that Darbhanga airbase is ready for commercial flights and two more months are need to arrange for basic passenger amenities at the civil enclave. “The bidding process for the required facilities to run the commercial airport has been completed,” Negi said.

“Basic facilities such as ticket counters, CCTV cameras, help desk, installation of baggage X-ray machine, check-in and boarding counters, arrival and departure display boards, signage and transit parking among others, are yet to be put in place,” Negi said.

He added: “The airport operations would be handled by the AAI and the security will be provided by the state government.”

Around 70 security personnel were trained to manage passengers in Patna last month. The training session was conducted by the Bureau of Civil Aviation.

The 15,000sq feet terminal building has been built at an estimated cost of Rs 92 crore. There will be six check-in counters and two aprons. The foundation for the civil enclave at Darbhanga was laid by chief minister Nitish Kumar on December 24, 2018.

Private airline SpiceJet has been selected to operate under the UDAN scheme. It will operate three flights connecting Darbhanga to Bengaluru, New Delhi and Mumbai.

Once the flight operations begin, it will benefit northern Bihar districts, including Madhubani, Samastipur, Muzaffarpur, Begusarai, Bhagalpur, Jamui, Khagaria, Lakhisarai, Madhepura, Saharsa, Sheohar, Sitamarhi and Supaul, among other areas.

Darbhanga airbase will be the state’s third airport operating commercial flights. The state government has allotted Rs 121 crore to acquire 31 acres at Ranipur-Bihatwara area for construction of a new terminal building, cargo, parking space and other auxiliary facilities.
