Title: CCI gets JSW company plaint against Asian Paints
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

(Representative image)

MUMBAI: India’s antitrust agency has directed a probe into alleged competition law violations by Asian Paints following a complaint by new entrant JSW Paints .

In its order, the Competition Commission of India (CCI) said evidence provided by JSW Paints is prima facie sufficient to indicate that Asian Paints denied access to distribution channels to the former by threatening and coercing dealers through various means and the actions appear to be in contravention of fair trade rules.

The competition watchdog has instructed its investigative wing to submit the report in 60 days. JSW, which launched its decorative paints in May 2019, complained to the agency that Asian Paints pressurised dealers to not stock and display the former’s products in their outlets, thus preventing it from establishing a presence in the country. “Asian Paints is not only denying market access to a competing entity but also restricting the freedom of contract to dealers.”

The three-member CCI bench noted that the alleged restrictions on dealers not to deal with JSW Paints can create barriers for suppliers of paints, who compete against each other, besides not allowing the benefit of better prices to consumers.

Title: Kerala Anglo-Indians write letter of support
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Kolkata: The movement of Anglo-Indians against the decision of the Centre to de-reserve their seats in Parliament and the state legislative assemblies, which that started in the city last week, received an impetus on Wednesday when over one lakh Anglo-Indians from Kerala wrote to All India Anglo Indian Association president Barry O’Brien, joining the national movement.

The Anglo-Indians from Kerala joined the movement under the banner Union of Anglo Indian Associations. They had been protesting the decision in Kerala, but after they got the news of all other similar associations uniting after the clarion call in Kolkata, they decided to join in.

“In Kerala, the movement has already attained quite a status and we have been able to make some headway,” said chief of the union Marshal D’Cunha.

The assembly of Kerala had passed the de-reservation bill unanimously, but immediately thereafter, a resolution was taken that the Anglo-Indian reservation in Parliament and the state assemblies be restored.

The association now has 12 representative bodies in the movement. It has written separately to the President, Prime Minister, and the home and law ministers, for an appointment so that a team of Anglo-Indians can meet and explain why the reservation is a must for the community. “We have decided to include a member from the union as well. The movement has definitely gathered more steam now that the Kerala Anglo-Indians have joined us,” O’Brien said.

The letter has stressed that the appointment be given between January 21 and 24 because the reservation comes to an end on January 25.

Title: IMA, IPA differ over PM’s reported remark of ‘pharma cos bribing docs’
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Prime Minister Narendra Modi (File photo)

MUMBAI: There is fresh debate around Prime Minister Narendra Modi ’s meeting on January 1 with pharma industry honchos, where he is reported to have lambasted the medical fraternity over unethical marketing practices.

The Indian Medical Association ( IMA ), the apex lobby representing doctors, has sought a clarification on whether the PM had stated that “pharma companies bribed doctors with women”. However, drug industry body Indian Pharmaceutical Alliance ( IPA ) said the issue of code of marketing practices was not discussed at the meeting.

In an unprecedented “confrontation of sorts”, the IMA issued a communication on January 14 titled ‘Deny or Prove or Apologise’. It said it was skeptical of the government being able to prove allegations of (unethical marketing practices) and, if based on “unverified information, it is only appropriate that PM apologises” to country’s doctors.

Health activists and industry observers feel this has put the issue on the radar, further creating a trust deficit between healthcare stakeholders and the government. “We have now written to the PM”, a senior IMA official told TOI on Wednesday evening.

The January 1 meeting was called to hammer out a strategy for future road map for growth of the healthcare industry, and the next level of innovation, according to an industry executive who attended. The focus of the discussion was research and development, building innovation ecosystem, improve access to high quality medicine and strengthen global competitiveness of the industry. India is rightly described as the pharmacy of the world with a 20% volume share of the global market.

The purpose was to take industry to the next level, and leverage opportunities going forward in pharma sector, besides discussing growth opportunities in medtech and hospital sector, the IPA said in a statement.

Commenting on the development, Anant Bhan, researcher at Bioethics, Global Health and Policy, said, “This has put the issue on the radar, and will further create a trust deficit between healthcare stakeholders and the government, and the public, unless it leads to concrete, urgent regulatory oversight reform of pharma marketing.” Further, the IMA communication said, “The purpose seems to divert the attention from unresolved issues regarding health and medical education.”

Flaying government on the healthcare front, the communication says allocation for health has hovered around 1% to 1.3% of GDP for past few years, with no new investment in infrastructure or human resources. It even criticised Modi ’s ambitious flagship insurance scheme Ayushman Bharat, saying it’s a non-starter, and operates more in government hospitals where treatment is already free. “15% of the money paid to hospitals including government hospitals is siphoned off by insurance companies.”

The meeting was attended by Dr Reddy’s chairman Satish Reddy, Piramal Group promoter Ajay Piramal, Cadila Healthcare chairman Pankaj Patel, Sun Pharma promoter and MD Dilip Shanghvi, Wockhardt chairman Habil Khorakiwala, Cadila Pharma CMD Rajiv Modi, Torrent’s Sudhir Mehta, medtech industry representative Pavan Choudhary, and Apollo Hospitals executive vice-chairperson Shobana Kamineni.

Title: Unsecured consumer loans grow most, credit card dues at Rs 1 lakh crore
Content:
(Representative image)

MUMBAI: Credit card balances and personal loans have recorded the highest growth rates as lenders expand the market, providing finance to those who had not borrowed before. Credit cards and personal loans recorded growth rates of 40.7% and 28%, respectively, year-on-year (YoY) in July-September (Q2FY20).Unsecured loans are growing even as secured retail advances such as auto loans , loans against property (LAP) and home loans saw moderate rates of balance growth at 10.3%, 11.6% and 10.0%, respectively, according to TransUnion CIBIL’s Q2FY20 Industry Insights Report.Credit card balances and number of accounts increased YoY by 40.7% and 29.8% respectively taking total balances to Rs 1,09,000 crore and number of active cards in circulation to 44.5 million (see graphic). Balances of private card issuers increased by 50.7% YoY, while for other card issuers increased by 26.9% YoY.In the case of personal loans, outstanding grew 28% to Rs 4.3 lakh crore, which is now almost on a par with auto loans which have a base of Rs 4.38 lakh crore (10% growth). Personal loans are still less than a fourth of home loans, which stood at Rs 19 lakh crore (growth of 10% again).According to bankers, the growth in unsecured loans is driven by an expansion of the market, given that personal loans (excluding mortgages) as a percentage of gross domestic product is much lower than other emerging markets. Lenders like HDFC Bank have been expanding this market using technology in the form of analytics to automate lending. Besides banks, non-banking finance companies (NBFCs) have a large chunk of unsecured finance loans.“Our findings suggest the shift toward consumption lending categories is becoming more sustained and is supported by a strong demand for these products. Consumer inquiry volumes for personal loans and credit cards increased significantly over the period, whereas we saw inquiries were broadly unchanged or slightly down for loans against property and home loans.” said TransUnion CIBIL vice-president (research and consulting) Abhay Kelkar.“This change in demand might, in part, be driven by consumer sentiment and wider macroeconomic pressures. Flattening demand for large-ticket asset purchases is causing slower asset finance loan originations, while consumers may be increasingly turning to consumption credit products to help finance day-to-day living expenses. This shift in consumer credit demand warrants ongoing monitoring to understand the impact on lender portfolios.”Also, growth in consumer lending is no longer concentrated in metro locations. Lenders have increased credit penetration to less densely populated geographies as part of their expansion strategies. Consumers in semi-urban and rural areas have also shown increased willingness to seek loans from formal lending institutions.The increase in delinquency rates was not uniform and was most pronounced for loan against properties, which was up 52 basis points (100 bps = 1 percentage point), home loans (up 13 bps) and credit cards (up 10 bps). Overall delinquencies actually improved for auto loans (down 22 bps) and personal loans (down 5 bps).

Title: IIT-BHU, road transport ministry ink pact for devpt, safety of highways
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Varanasi: Indian Institute of Technology (Banaras Hindu University) and Ministry of Road Transport and Highways, Government of India, recently signed a memorandum of understanding (MoU) for technical upgradation and introduction of new technology in the field of road safety engineering, development, maintenance and operation of highways.

The 31st National Road Safety Week is being celebrated by Ministry of Road Transport and Highways at Vigyan Bhawan, New Delhi from January 11 to 17. Under this programme, on Monday, IIT (BHU) director Prof Pramod Kumar Jain and Director General (Road Development) and Special Secretary IK Pandey signed the MoU.

Union Defence Minister Rajnath Singh, Road Transport Minister Nitin Gadkari, Minister of State for Road Transport and Highways General (Retd) Dr VK Singh and other officials were present on the occasion.

Giving information about this achievement on Wednesday, IIT (BHU) director said the ministry seeks to foster cultural of industry-academia interaction to introduce new technology and innovation in highway sector and is establishing its chair in this academic institute and funding it in order to facilitate and create interest among student for cunducting their research on highway related topic.

He further said the Institute and Indian academia will simultaneously conduct studies related to road safety, environment and social impacts under the Highway Safety Development Project. Also, the institute will facilitate or undertake dissemination of technology upgrades in planning, design, construction and operation and maintenance for highway development through standards, guidelines, training. Also, the institute will provide input to development/amendment of standards to be adopted on safety/new materials/technology and support the preparation of the codes/manuals of IRC on behalf of the Ministry.

He said that apart from this, Institute will assist in evaluation and introduction of new technology for improving road safety and operational efficiencies, undertake PhD Research programme on the topics selected by MoRTH. Institute will also provide technical guidance to Ministry in any area related to Highway engineering, also advise Highway Research Board of IRC for identification and monitoring of R&D activities and also organize workshops, symposium on awareness related to highway related topic.

Title: Dehradun: IIT team finds new anti-bacteria drug
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Researchers from IIT-R

DEHRADUN: Researchers at the Indian Institute of Technology, Roorkee (IIT-R) have claimed to have discovered a novel chemical compound that can act against multi-drug resistant bacteria. The researchers said that they had “screened a library of 11,000 compounds against ‘gram negative bacteria’ and identified a small molecule ‘IITR06144’ that can kill highly multi-drug resistant strains of Escherichia coli (that causes diarrhea), Acinetobacter baumannii (causing infections that occur due to hospital stay), Klebsiella pneumonia (bacteria that typically colonizes human mucosal surfaces of the oropharynx and gastrointestinal tract) as well as Mycobacterium tuberculosis (bacteria causing tuberculosis).”

The study conducted by a team of 13 researchers from the institute started in 2010 and its report was published in the ‘Journal of Antimicrobial Chemotherapy’ in October last year. Ranjana Pathania, professor at the department of biotechnology, IIT-R, one of the researchers involved in the study, told TOI, “Antibiotics are considered as the cornerstone of both basic and modern medicine and it is difficult to envisage a world without them. However, injudicious over-the-counter sales and excessive use and abuse of antibiotics in poultry, livestock and agriculture has given rise to the global problem of antibiotic resistance. With the ever-increasing rise in drug resistant superbugs and lack of effective antibiotics against them, it has become imperative to search for novel antibacterial molecules.”

She added that “the molecule that we have discovered has a broad-spectrum activity and it can kill all kinds of bacteria including gram negative pathogens which are very difficult to kill because they have a complex boundary outside the cell and molecules cannot get inside them.”

“For the past 30 years, there hasn’t been a new class of antibiotics that has been discovered against gram negative pathogens. We tested our molecule on strains obtained from AIIMS Delhi, Bhopal and a government hospital in Chandigarh, and also on animals, and its performance was found to be better than other similar antibiotics already in the market,” Pathania said. She added that “unlike conventional antibiotics, IITR06144 kills bacteria by targeting multiple pathways in the bacterial cell such as DNA repair and cell division machinery.” “Since multi-targeting antibiotics are less prone to resistance generation, therefore IITR06144 holds immense therapeutic potential. Also, while most of the antibiotics currently prescribed in clinics seem to kill the healthy gut bacteria, IITR06144 did not inhibit them, this being one of its most desirable properties,” the professor said.

Title: Puppalaguda land row reaches apex court again
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Supreme Court

HYDERABAD: Hinting at another round of fresh litigation over 200-acre prime land at Puppalaguda that was accrued to the state just three months ago, the Supreme Court on Thursday reserved its orders on hearing a plea filed by a few persons claiming a portion of the land as protected tenants .

They said that they were tilling the land since the British era as tenants and have hence become protected tenants under law.

A bench of justices L Nageswara Rao and Hemant Gupta opined that the petitioners should first approach the high court rather than the Supreme Court.

The Supreme Court had in October 2019 dismissed the plea of an alleged kin of an evacuee claiming 200 acres of land towards an unfulfilled claim. It also set aside two orders issued by Andhra Pradesh in 2003 and 2006, that were aimed at unduly enriching two private individuals who fraudulently laid claim over the land five decades after the evacuee claims were settled.

The high court too had quashed the allotment orders in 2016.

One of the claimants, Ramesh Malani, approached the Supreme Court challenging the order of the high court. During the country’s partition, Parasram Ramchand Malani left his property in Pakistan’s Sindh and settled in Hyderabad, India.

As per the provisions of the Displaced Persons (Compensation & Rehabilitation) Act and Administration of Evacuee Property Act, the central government and the state government allotted him 323 acres of land at Hyderabad’s Bata Singaram and Boinpally areas in 1956. Ramchand never claimed that he was entitled to any extra piece of land till his death in 1988, but during 2003, an application was made in the name of his alleged son Ramesh Parasram Malani seeking 200 acres more on the ground that they were entitled to get more. Ignoring the bar under the Limitation Act, the state of AP gave two orders in favour of the claimant in 2003 and 2006. However, the Hyderabad high court in 2016 concluded that this was a huge fraud and said that a police probe was needed.

Hyderabad police had also started investigation into these claims and the orders issued in their favour by IAS officials in 2003 and in 2006.

Now, the claims of a group of persons, Kundan Bai and others, in the name of protected tenants, have come to the fore. The SC bench reserved its orders on whether to hear them or to remand them to high court.

Title: Maharashtra women’s panel to seek strict norms on acid sale
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: Maharashtra State Women’s Commission chairperson Vijaya Rahatkar is planning to request the state government to ensure more stringent rules to prevent sale of acid and curb the rising incidents of acid attack.

Rahatkar stated that there were several shops still selling acid. “Easy availability of acid is the primary reason for our failure to prevent such attacks,” she said.

While the Supreme Court had banned over-the-counter sale of acid, it is being done rampantly and this needs to be curtailed. “I shall be writing to the government to introduce checks,” she told TOI.

In 2013, the Supreme Court in the case of Laxmi vs Union of India and Others, had directed state governments and the Union territories to make appropriate rules for the sale of acid. The SC also directed states to implement stringent norms for retail of acid, treating it as a poison under the Poisons Act, 1919. Banning the sale of acid to minors, the court said the corrosive substance could be sold to only those who have valid identity cards issued by the government and that too after specifying the purpose for the purchase in writing.

While National Crime Records Bureau data has shown an increase in the rise of acid attacks, the chairperson said the incidents would continue unless there was strict implementation of the SC ruling.

The commission had earlier arranged a confidence walk. It has helped acid attack survivors find jobs as well. “We helped a girl from north India get re-married as well as provided assistance in meeting the medical expenses. We have also helped the survivors get jobs,” said the chairperson.

In December 2013, the SC directed all states to formulate specific rules regarding the sale of acid and for payment of compensation and provision of free medical treatment for survivors of acid attacks and notify the same before April 2014. The bench asked respective states to ensure that every police station, immediately after registering an FIR about an acid attack should intimate the sub-divisional magistrate concerned, who would inquire how assailant procured the acid.

Title: Pune: FDA seizes gutka, paan masala worth Rs 50 lakh
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Representative image

PIMPRI CHINCHWAD: The Food and Drugs Administration on Tuesday seized gutka and paan masala worth around Rs50 lakh.

SS Deshmukh, the joint commissioner of the Food and Drugs Administration (FDA), Pune, said the drive was conducted after receiving a tip-off. “A four-member team of the FDA raided a godown at Jambhe village of Mulshi taluka, near Pimpri Chinchwad city, and seized gutka/paan masala worth Rs49.75 lakh,” he said.

The banned goods were stored in a rented godown, located right behind the house of the man who had stowed them.

Deshmukh said, “Two rooms of the godown have been sealed to prevent future sale of banned goods from there. A complaint has been lodged at the Hinjewadi police station against the man who sold these goods and the person who rented out the godown.”

He said the samples had been sent to the state government laboratory to confirm if the seized stock comprised banned gutkha and paan masala. If it is confirmed, the accused can be sentenced to life imprisonment and fined up to Rs10 lakh.

Title: Tree authority remains only on paper, last meeting in April 2019
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Aurangabad Municipal Corporation

AURANGABAD: Amid the uproar over the proposal of cutting trees for the Bal Thackeray and Gopinath Munde ’s memorials, which are kept on hold, the tree authority of the civic body has not held a single meeting since April last year.

The multi-member body, comprising nature councillors and nominated members is headed by the municipal chief. They are expected to meet at least after a gap of 45 days.

The body regulates the felling of trees for development work and charts out plans for planting an adequate number of saplings in order to increase the green cover. The tree authority every year is expected to prepare a budget estimate on or before October end and forward it to the Aurangabad Municipal Corporation for the final approval. The tree authority was scheduled to have its meeting after a long gap, early this week in presence of the municipal commissioner , but it was put off due to some reasons.

As many as 31 proposals seeking cutting of over 400 trees in different parts of the city were scheduled to be tabled during the meeting. The proposals included the fate of 110 trees to be axed for raising Munde’s memorial near government milk dairy on Jalna Road and 225 teak wood trees in Nakshatrawadi area.

Environmentalist Pankaj Shakkarwar said it remains a mystery which authority allotted the permission for tree-cutting within the jurisdiction of the AMC in the past nine months.

The city has not witnessed a single tree census within the municipal limits in the history of the AMC and the alleged poor presence of the tree authority is blamed for the lapse.

AMC acting garden superintendent, Vijay Patil, who is the ex-officio member of the tree authority, did not respond to phone calls and text message sent to him seeking his comment on the issue.

Environmentalist Kishor Pathak , who is one of the nominated members of the tree authority, said, “The civic authorities were reluctant to hold the meeting despite repeated follow-ups.”

Municipal commissioner Astik Kumar Pande could not be reached for his comments.

Title: Savitribai Phule Pune University mulls over on-demand exam system for the benefit of students
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

SPPU vice-chancellor Nitin Karmalkar

PUNE: The Savitribai Phule Pune University (SPPU) is contemplating an on-demand examination system to usher in flexibility and allow students to appear for exams as per their convenience.

The vice-chancellor of SPPU Nitin Karmalkar said while the choice-based credit system and an open learning centre were introduced to bring flexibility in the learning process, he had been thinking of taking it a step further by making the examination system “need-based”. This would also enable students, who participate in sports or other activities and are unable to appear for the scheduled examinations, to appear for them when they have the time.

“The choice-based credit system was introduced for flexibility in choosing subjects. The idea was that a science student could take up a humanities course or vice versa if s/he wanted. Unfortunately, that level of flexibility was not achieved. There were problems with rigid timetables and a general mindset against unconventional systems,” he said.

Karmalkar also spoke about how the next step would be to make examinations flexible. “If a sports student wanted to appear for the examinations at a later stage for any reason, it would be easy if there was a need-based examination system in place. We have been thinking about how it could be implemented,” he said.

Arvind Shaligram, controller of examinations at SPPU, said the need-based exam system was only an idea and no committee was working on its execution. It was something the university officials were serious about, he said.

“As per the present system, we prepare a schedule and students appear for the examination. The problem here is that the students who have not prepared for the examination also have to appear for it, which defeats its purpose. Examinations are to check how much a student has understood. A slow learner may require more time and hence s/he should be able to demand examination when s/he is ready. Similarly, a fast learner can appear for the exam early so that s/he can use the time to do something else or opt for more courses. At present, as the examination dates are fixed, it is a disadvantage for both groups of students,” he said.

Shaligram said a small step in this regard was taken during the semester-ending examination of the MBA students in December 2019. “We tried using a computer-generated question paper for MBA students. A question bank was created by the panel of paper-setters and fed into the system. When the paper pattern was decided, the software randomly picked the questions from this bank and generated a paper. This was then approved by the panel and used for the examinations. This was just one step towards on-demand examination system. More needs to be done and the SPPU would look into it,” he said.

Title: CAA row: I’m not a rubber stamp, says governor
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: Governor Arif Mohammad Khan , who has been at loggerheads with the state government ever since the state assembly passed the resolution against the Citizenship (Amendment) Act ( CAA ), has made it clear that he is not a “rubber stamp”.

As a head of the state he has constitutional powers and duties to perform. “The state government had approached the Supreme Court against CAA. But I came to know about this only through the media. As a head of the state, the government should have informed about moving the SC,” the governor said.

“It is a breach of protocol and breach of courtesy. I will have to look whether the government can go to the court without the permission of the governor,” he added.

Khan has also denied the nod for an ordinance to delimit the local bodies ahead of the elections. The governor, who met local body minister A C Moideen on Wednesday, said that the government should have brought out a law for the delimitation instead of coming out with an ordinance.

He was upset over the state government convening a special one-day session of the assembly to pass a resolution against the Centre for passing the CAA.

The governor had openly criticised this resolution and had said that the resolution has no value.

Khan is learnt to have told the local body minister that if the state government has time to convene a special session of the assembly to pass a resolution, then the same should be adopted in passing the legislation too.

“I have not said I will not sign the ordinance. I have raised some queries to the state government on this and they are to come back with the explanation. I need time to go through the ordinance and I will act only as per the Constitution,” the governor said.

Even though he refused to comment on the queries he has raised against the ordinance, the governor said, “Anyway the assembly session is going to be convened this month itself. Then the government can bring out a legislation in that session.”

However, minister Moideen said the government was not ready to go into a direct confrontation with the governor. “The government has no issues with the governor. There is nothing illegal in the ordinance. This is not the first time that the government is going with an ordinance,” he said.

The government had gone for a legal opinion if the government returns the ordinance. It is learned that the government has decided not to send the file back to the governor again. The government is likely to come out with a legislation in the assembly session which is beginning this month end for the budget session.

Title: Protesting anganwadi workers do ‘buddhi shuddhi yajna’ in Dehradun for state government
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

DEHRADUN: As mark of protest against the state government, anganwadi workers in Dehradun performed a ‘ buddhi shuddhi yajna ’ to purify the minds of state government officials who, they alleged, are not acting on their demand of pay hike. Thousands of anganwadi workers from across the state have been protesting in the state capital for almost 40 days now.

Over 100 anganwadi workers took part in the yajna, in which women prayed that the government considers their plight and agrees to their 10 demands .

The state has 20,070 anganwadi centres in 13 districts, in which around 33,850 anganwadi workers, their assistants and helpers, work. Hundreds of anganwadi workers from various districts are sitting in protest at Dharna Sthal for 40 days, leaving their family and children behind.

“Our main demands are accordance of status of government employees, and salaries raised to Rs 21,000 per month. Our helpers, who do no less work than us, should get Rs 11,000 per month. We work 24 hours and in all areas, from health, education to administration. We deserve salaries that ensure minimum living standards at least,” said Rekha Negi, president, Uttarakhand anganwadi workers association.

Title: Explore CSR, crowd funding: HC to govt
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Kochi: State government should explore the possibility of leveraging crowd sourcing and corporate social responsibility (CRS) for extending free treatment to children with rare diseases.

The suggestion was put forward by a division bench comprising Chief Justice S Manikumar and Justice Shaji P Chaly while considering an appeal filed by the government challenging a single bench’s order to provide free treatment to a child suffering from a rare disease. It is estimated that around 200 children are suffering from rare diseases in the state and their treatment requires Rs 1 crore per child annually.

Responding to an affidavit filed by the government stating that its own funds are not enough to extend free treatment, the division bench asked the government to inform whether it can come up with a solution by utilizing the funds allotted by the central government, state government’s own ‘WE CARE’ scheme, funds through CRS schemes of corporate establishments, and crowd-sourcing. Government should inform its views by Monday, the court directed.

Opposing the single bench’s directive to provide free treatment, state government had informed the court that such an option is too expensive and that a policy by the central government as well as central funding is required to extend free treatment.

In order to provide free treatment to children with rare diseases, more than 48% of the budgetary allocation for treatment of the poor has to be set apart, government had pointed out.

Even after providing such costly treatment, the survival rates of children with rare diseases is very low, government had submitted. While the average treatment cost of a single child with a weight of 20kg would be Rs 1 crore annually, around 20 renal transplantations or five liver transplantations or eight bone marrow transplantations can be carried out using such a fund.

These are life-saving medical interventions, government had informed. Thus, it would be highly unethical to divert the limited funds to provide free treatment to children with rare diseases while many kids are waiting for definite medical interventions with proven prognosis, the court was told.

Title: BJP demands probe into issue
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: BJP leader Kummanam Rajasekharan has said the complaints raised by the Synod should be taken seriously and there should be a probe into the allegations.

He said such complaints are increasing in the state and the Synod’s demand that strict action be taken should be welcomed. “However, finance minister Thomas Isaac is learnt to have rubbished the claims made by the Church. This shows the CPM-Congress jihadi nexus,” he said.

The BJP leader said it is a serious allegation and the state government is turning a blind eye towards the issue.

Hundreds of complaints have been filed in various police stations across the state on the Love Jihad. But no arrests have been made so far in such cases, he alleged.

Meanwhile state police chief Loknath Behera said that they do not have any information on the matter. “If there is anything specific, the police will take necessary action,” he said. tnn

Title: Social media influence a huge responsibility, should be handled carefully: HC
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

MUMBAI: The Bombay high court has redirected a social media influencer to take down an allegedly disparaging video of a fast-moving consumer product while impressing upon them that influencing through social media is a responsibility that should be handled carefully.

The bench was hearing a plea by an oil-manufacturer, who claimed that the influencer had denigrated their product on a video. It also directed the vlogger (a person who creates and uploads video blogs) to not put up such posts in the future.

“Today, influencing through social media is one of the most impactful and effective ways of marketing and advertising…but it is a responsibility that must be assumed carefully,’’ said Justice S J Kathawalla.

The HC, after hearing hearing the company’s counsel Virag Tulzapurkar, found merit in the case.

“The defendant (vlogger) cannot, under the garb of educating / bring the true facts to public, provide misleading information to disparage the plaintiff’s (company’s) product,’’ said the judge in an interim ruling in the suit on January 15.

It found no merit in the vlogger’s counsel Abhinav Chandrachud’s plea who relied on a US Supreme Court decision that the company, if aggrieved, could always produce and upload a counter video of its own.

“Any campaign to educate the public by placing before them the true and correct facts may be welcomed. However, under the garb of educating…, no one should put misleading information which disparages or belittles someone else’s product or influence the consumer not to buy it.’

“A social media influencer who has or claims to have a sound knowledge in what they claim is their niche, and uses it to influence people into believing and subscribing to the same set of ideas or thoughts, has the power to influence people, to change attitudes and mindset. This mindset can be changed for the better, and scarily, for the worse,’’ said the judge adding “But first of all, there needs to be a deep awareness about the basic fact that this indeed is a responsibility.”

Title: Kanjirappally, Palghat get new bishops
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Kochi: The concluding session of the first meeting of the 28th Synod of the Syro-Malabar Church here on Wednesday again urged the central government to resolve the apprehensions the Citizenship (Amendment) Act has caused in the country.

The Synod observed that Christians were facing discrimination in the schemes for minorities and condemned acts of violence against Christians in the country as well as around the globe.

In the meeting, major policy decisions, including the appointment of Mar Jose Pulikal as the bishop of Kanjirappally and Fr Peter Kochupurackal as the auxiliary bishop of Palghat, were taken.

Cardinal Mar George Alencherry, the head of the Syro-Malabar Church, signed the declaration of the new appointments after receiving authorization from Pope Francis.

With the debate getting intensified over the two different styles of liturgies existing in the Syro-Malabar Church, the Synod on Wednesday made it clear that they prefer to use the same text through-out the Church. As a result, a revised text of liturgy has been submitted for the approval of Rome.

Other important decisions made, include a demand to raise pension of farmers to Rs 10,000 per month and other schemes for helping farmers who the Synod observed were reeling under a crisis.

Fifty-eight bishops, invited guests, priests, the religious and the laity were present at the meeting when the announcements were made.

Title: Maradu aftermath: ‘Authorities not taking enough steps to control dust’
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

An excavator is used to spray water on the debris of Holy Faith H2O, at Maradu on Wednesday

KOCHI: With the dust pollution near the four demolition sites at Maradu increasing as the steel removal progresses, residents complain that the measures taken by the authorities were not helpful. The agency removing the steel from the concrete debris started pumping water on the rubble pile at the directive of Pollution Control Board, but dust is still spreading to nearby places. Residents said that the authorities are not even distributing multi-layer masks to protect themselves from the unseen dust and they have to buy the masks on their own, which for many are unaffordable.

“Doctors said that the normal single-layer mask will not be of use as the size of the dust particle is very small and can easily enter the body through the pores of these masks. They suggest using the N95 mask, which is around Rs 90 per piece. Even if we buy it once or twice we have to buy new ones as these masks are getting dirty very easily due to dusty winds. We cannot afford buying it for all the family members until the debris is cleared off, which could take at least 60 days. The municipality or health department should distribute the masks for free,” said Antony Joseph, a resident near Alfa Serene.

Meanwhile, municipality officials said that they have started distributing three-layer masks to neighbouring residents of demolition sites and free medicals camps are being organized by the Primary Health Centre (PHC), Valanthakkad. They also said masks will be distributed to more people in the coming days.

“The municipality and health department are coordinating pollution control measures. Two medical camps have been conducted at Alfa Serene and Holy Faith H2O. At Jains Coral Cove, a pulmonologist from a private hospital conducted an awareness class for the residents to clear their doubts about the pollution. We have conducted inspections at all four sites and ensured that water is sprayed on the debris frequently. The demand raised by the residents for wind curtains around the site has been intimated to the agencies concerned and they said it will be done,” said a PHC official.

Meanwhile, the steel-removal work at Golden Kayaloram is yet to be started. Kayaloram has the least amount of debris — nearly 6,900 tonnes. But the amount of brick debris is higher at Kayaloram compared to other three buildings. Sources with the debris removal contractor said that the brick debris will not be of much use, except landfilling, compared to concrete debris which could be turned into M-sand.

Resident have complained that the brick dust from the uncovered site is settling down on their houses and vehicles. “I will have to repaint my house as its colour has changed from white to brown due to the brick dust. We can see orange dust flying in the air whenever wind blows. The work is yet to be started at Kayaloram and hence water is not being sprayed on the debris here unlike other sites. Now we are breathing dust,” said Saju Karukayil, a resident near Golden Kayaloram.

Health officials have been asking people to keep their doors and windows closed. They have been advised to keep their surrounding areas wet to settle dust, frequently vacuum the houses and take bath and wash eyes at regular intervals.

“Risk of throat and chest infection and sinusitis is high. Around two people from the neighbourhood have complained of eczema, a condition where patches of skin become inflamed, itchy, red, cracked and rough,” said Dr Rahul Antony Simon, pulmonologist, Lakeshore Hospital.

Title: Shirdi airport to have night landing infrastructure in place by next month
Content:
Shirdi Airport

The recurrent problem of flight suspension at the Shirdi airport due to poor visibility could be a thing of the past with the facility set to get night landing infrastructure by February

PUNE: The recurrent problem of flight suspension at the Shirdi airport due to poor visibility could be a thing of the past with the facility set to get night landing infrastructure by February.An airport official said, “We shall be giving good news on two projects — night landing and runway extension by February.”“The night landing facility has been delayed by two months, and is expected to be ready by February. The current length of the runway is 2,700 metres. It will be extended to 3,200 metres. This project is almost complete but needs approval from the Directorate General of Civil Aviation . We hope to receive the approval by February. Once it is done, we shall be in a position to handle more flights till the new terminal building is ready,” the official said.“There are four parking bays at the airport now. The apron size will also be increased and six more parking bays will be made, taking the total number to 10,” the official added. Another official said while the construction of the new terminal building would start this year and be completed in next three years, the expansion of the existing terminal building was expected to be complete within the next 6-7 months.A source in the MADC said the design of the new terminal building of Shirdi airport was ready and awaiting approval from the state government. The MADC is currently without a vice-chairman-cum-managing director following the transfer of the previous incumbent, Sachin Kurve. “We are waiting for the board meeting to be chaired by the chief minister, following which tenders for the construction would be floated,” the source said.Valsa Nair Singh, principal secretary, excise and aviation, general administration department, is currently holding the charge of the MADC.

Title: Dehradun: On last day of availing discount, a big rush
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Residents queue to pay house tax at DMC office in Doon on Wednesday

DEHRADUN: On the last day to avail discount on the submission of house tax for residents of old wards, the Dehradun Municipal Corporation ( DMC ) saw a big rush and many residents claim that they had to wait for several hours in queue to file their house tax.

Radhey Shyam, a resident of the Danda Lakhond ward, said, “I came here (DMC office) to submit house tax at 11 am but it took me around six hours to get my work done. As it was the last day to avail discount on house tax, a large number of people came to file their taxes and because of this, I have lost an entire working day.”

Echoing similar sentiments, another resident said that the civic body should have made better arrangements for the people. Joginder Pal, a resident of Karanpur ward, said, “I have been here since 12.30 pm and it seems that I will get free only after 5 pm. The DMC appeals constantly to the residents to submit their house tax but they should also make better arrangements for us. If it is taking them so much money to collect it, imagine how long it will take them to tabulate it.”

Sandeep Sharma, a resident of Race Course ward, said, “It took almost three hours to submit house tax today. The entire system is haywire. Not only there was insufficient stuff to collect taxes but those present were also very confused. They were also not prepared to handle such a big crowd.”

The civic body had announced that the residents of old wards will be given a discount of 25% on house tax if they submit it by January 15, 2020. Originally, 60 wards came under the old ward category but eight of the 40 new wards were also included in the old ward category.

Now, the number of wards coming in the old ward category has gone up to 68 wards. The owners of the commercial properties of the 32 new wards, which previously came under the rural area, can avail 25% discount on property tax if they submit it by January 31, 2020.

Meanwhile, a DMC official said that residents could have availed off the online facility to pay house tax. “If they had paid taxes online, the rush could have been avoided. However, despite today’s rush, our staff managed it well,” said a civic official on the condition of anonymity.

Title: On Makar Sankranti, work on KV Dham project takes off with prayers, rituals
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Varanasi: Construction work in ambitious Kashi Vishwanath Dham (corridor) project took off on the occasion of Makar Sankranti on Wednesday.

Priests performed Neev pujan at the site where land for the foundation of proposed city museum building has been dug-up.

Talking to TOI, divisional commissioner Deepak Agrawal said, “The company, which has been assigned the contract for KV Dham construction under the supervision of PWD, has been given the deadline of 18 months to complete the project.”

PSP, a Gujarat-based company, was awarded contract for quoting lower price (Rs 339 crore) against the only rival Shapoorji Pallonji which quoted Rs 422 crore during the bidding process in December 2019.

The company’s officials reached Varanasi a week ago.

“Before the commencement of construction, the state government had approved the revised budget of project from Rs 318.6 crore to Rs 347.5 crore by including GST cost and some other components,” Agrawal said, adding that the budget of Rs 318.6 crore, which was initially approved for construction work, had been sanctioned without including GST charges.

KV Dham project was approved by the Yogi Adityanath government in December 2017. After purchasing over 70% buildings of 296 structures identified for demolition, Prime Minister Narendra Modi had laid foundation of the project on March 9. The project is proposed to come up in an area of 5.30 lakh square feet.

After the submission of a detailed project report of the Ahmedabad-based firm HCP Designing Planning and Management Private Limited to Sri Kashi Vishwanath Special Area Development Board in July 2019, working agency Rajkiya Nirman Nigam had forwarded an estimate of Rs 461 crore to the state government.

“To examine the estimate submitted by RNN, the state government had formed a three-member committee of technical experts. The panel examined the DPR and RNN’s estimate after which the budget of construction and other work reduced to Rs 318 crore from Rs 461 crore. After approving the revised budget, the state government replaced RNN with PWD to execute the project,” said Kashi Vishwanath temple’s chief executive officer Vishal Singh.

“Over Rs 300 crore has already been spent on purchase of 296 buildings in the project area. With the demolition of all purchased buildings, the ground of entire project area has been cleared and isolated by installing an enclosure,” said Singh.

Title: 13 murders in 15 days, police yet to crack 12
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Allahabad: A total of 13 people, including five members of a family and two minor girls, have been murdered in separate incidents in a fortnight (January 1-15) exposing the deteriorating law and order situation in the district.

The city had recorded 131 murders in 2019.

While highest seven persons were killed in trans-Ganga, four were murdered in trans-Yamuna and two in city areas in the first two weeks of this year.

Police claimed to have only solved the murder case of a minor girl Phulpur arrested two persons. The accused men had allegedly silt the throat of a six-year-old girl in Pahsi village after failing to rape her.

On January 5, five members of a family, including two children (aged 2 and 7 years), were found murdered at their Yusufpur village in Soraon police circle.

Bodies of Somdutt Tiwari (32), who owned a small scale transport business, his father VS Tiwari (60), wife Soni Tiwari (28), and couple’s two sons Kanha (7) and Kunj (2) were found in puddles of blood in three rooms.

Ten days have passed since the incident took place, police are still clueless.

Two minor girls were also killed in Phulpur circle and one of the cases has been worked out.

Four murders have rocked trans-Yamuna pocket between January 10 and 15. Besides the murder of a middle-aged woman in Lohgara Nibi village under Bara police station, cops are yet to solve the killing of a retired cop who was found dead at his under-construction house on FCI godown road in Naini on January 10.

A 16-year-old girl was also found murdered near Mugari village under the limits of industrial area in trans-Yamuna pocket on January 11.

On January 14, a woman was strangled to death in Mavaiya village under Industrial area police station.

A lawyer was also found murdered at his rented accommodation in Roshanbagh area under Khuldabad police station on January 8.

While the police are yet to solve the murder, a 19-year-old man was also found murdered in west city on January 15.

SSP, Allahabad, Satyarth Anirudh Pankaj said: “Police have received vital clues in connection with Soraon homicide case where five members of a family were found murdered”.

He said cops concerned had been asked to take corrective measures to crack unsolved cases.

Title: Delhi assembly elections: Manish Sisodia files papers; family assets valued at Rs 93.5 lakh
Content:
Manish Sisodia

New Delhi: Deputy chief minister Manish Sisodia on Thursday became the first politician from a mainstream party to file nomination papers for the upcoming election. He will be defending his Patparganj assembly seat Sisodia declared family assets worth Rs 93.5 lakh (movable and immovable), more than double the Rs 41.7 lakh cited in 2015. In 2015, he had a four-wheeler, valued at Rs 1.8 lakh. According to the latest affidavit, Sisodia doesn’t does own any car now. His wife, Seema, has a flat in Mayur Vihar Phase-II, valued at Rs 65 lakh that she purchased in 2018.Sisodia does not have any liability. Earlier, he had six criminal cases against him. These are down to three now. He has only Rs 20,000 cash in hand, according to the affidavit.Sisodia said the coming elections in Delhi would be based on the work done by the AAP government in the last five years. Before filing his nomination, he took out a rally in which hundreds of AAP supporters took part. His rally started with a padyatra followed by a bike rally to the election office in Patparganj.Amid chants of ‘Acche Beete Paanch Saal, Lage Raho Kejriwal‘, Sisodia held a padyatra in which he sought blessings of the people. People watched from their houses as the deputy chief minister waved to them and greeted them with folded hands.Exuding confidence, Sisodia said the party would beat its previous record and win more than 67 seats in the upcoming polls.Addressing a gathering, Sisodia said, “In the past five years, the government has not only developed the Patparganj constituency but also the entire city of Delhi witnessed the benefits of our good work and, now, the time has come when Patparganj will grow to new heights in the upcoming five years.”

Title: Kochiites raise dust concerns from the demolition sites at Maradu
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

The dust emerging from the demolition sites at Maradu is not just affecting the people in the vicinity. Mor... Read More KOCHI: The dust emerging from the demolition sites at Maradu is not just affecting the people in the vicinity. More residents in the city are complaining of breathing ailments, asthma, cough and fever. People living in areas like Vyttila, Giri Nagar and Chilavannoor as well as those living along the banks of the backwaters at Edakochi have complained of dust pollution. P D Martin, councillor representing Giri Nagar, said: “The concrete dust is a major concern. However, it is unsure whether the ailments are a result of dust arising from the building debris at Maradu or whether it is due to the prevailing climate conditions.” According to the online live data available on the pollution control board’s (PCB) website, the particulate matter (PM) levels are high. This is the real-time information from ambient air monitoring station situated at Vyttila Hub. It indicates the amount of fine dust particles present in the air. The PM 2.5 standard is 60 microns per cubic meter, and that of PM 10 is 100 microns per cubic meter. According to PCB officials, data over the years indicate that PM 10 levels have been occasionally high, but JPM 2.5 averages have stayed within limits of 60 microns per cubic meter in this station. Meanwhile, those living along the sides of backwaters at Edakochi North division of Kochi corporation complain about increased level of dust pollution. Indira Gandhi Road residents’ association president K A Benny said: “Several people have started complaining about breathing ailments and fever. At least four persons from the region have been admitted at various hospitals in the past couple of days.” District medical officer Dr M K Kuttappan said this being a dry season and with a fall in temperature some people might experience breathing ailments and asthma. Moreover, there can be issues related to the presence of pollens in the air. However, he said local bodies are taking measures to contain the dust arising from the debris at the demolition site. “If people experience health issues because of the concrete waste, they can report it to the local bodies or health officials. Instructions have been issued in this regard. So far no major public health concerns have been reported.”

Title: Antenatal homes in Wayanad to help tribal women avoid home deliveries
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Kozhikode: In a unique healthcare initiative aimed to address the continuing home deliveries and resultant medical complications among tribal women , the health department opened the state’s first tribal antenatal home (Garbhakala Gotra Mandiram) built as a replica of a traditional tribal house in Wayand on Thursday where pregnant woman can come and stay with their family in their final months of pregnancy .

Wayanad district, which has the largest tribal population in the state, has been witnessing around six home deliveries among tribal communities every month. Health officials say that many tribal women still prefer home deliveries mostly due to cultural factors and traditional beliefs associated with pregnancy and childbirth and the reluctance for institutional delivery often came in the way of providing immediate medical care in the case of high-risk births or postnatal complications.

“Tribal communities used to follow their own customs with respect to deliveries like having a dedicated building (pura) for child birth in the colonies. Also, taking delivery used to be responsibility of an elder woman and in many communities husband has to be near the woman during the pregnant days. Moreover, many find it difficult to adapt to hospital settings. Due to such factors many tribal women have been showing reluctance to come to hospitals especially for their second and subsequent deliveries, which made us think of having a tribal antenatal home next to the hospital,” National Health Mission district programme manager Dr B Abhilash said.

He said that there have been instances of tribal pregnant women running away from their homes to homes of relatives and even into the forest when health officials went to meet them to get them admitted to hospitals.

“Once we had to seek the assistance of a woman police officer to get a tribal woman in Vellamunda get admitted to a hospital. She was against hospital admission and the fully pregnant woman ran away when she saw us,” Dr Abhilash said.

The first tribal antenatal home set up next to the Vazhavatta public health centre was inaugurated by state health minister K K Shailaja. Six other such homes are under construction in various tribal areas of Wayanad. The minister said that the infant mortality rate in Wayanad has come down from 12 to 7 during the last four years and she hoped that the initiative would help bring it down further.

Tribal pregnant women can stay in these homes from their eighth month of pregnancy along with their families. The building has two rooms and a kitchen where they can cook and have their own food. Health officials said that the families staying in the homes would be provided rice and other food material if needed.

The building has been built the tribal way using mud by Habitat Technology Group.

Title: CAA will make India Hindu Rashtra: Activist
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Protesters take oath at the rally organised by Muslim Central Committee in Mangaluru on Wednesday

MANGALURU: It was a show of strength against CAA and NRC: Over a lakh people participated in the rally against the Union government’s Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA), and proposed National Register of Citizens (NRC) and National Population Register (NPR), at the Shah Garden opposite Central Juma Masjid in Adyar, Kannur, on Wednesday.

The rally was organised by the Muslim Central Committee and supported by nearly 30 organisations, including the Congress party.

Addressing the gathering from the ‘Shahid Abdul Jaleel Kandak and Nauseen Kudroli stage’, former IAS officer, author and activist Harsh Mander said this was a fight to save the Constitution. “Indian Muslims are Indians by choice,” he said.

Mander said for the Union government the issues of Ram Mandir and Kashmir are over, and that they are trying to convert India into a Hindu nation.

“People are now aware of the government’s agenda. Humanity is my religion. In case the government wants to decide my religion on the basis of documents, I will register as Muslim,” he said.

He asked the people to stay united, and that this movement should be taken up on the lines of Mahatma Gandhi’s Civil Disobedience Movement. The movement will be taken forward, with the Constitution and tricolour in our hands, and loads of love in our hearts, said Mander.

Human rights activist Shivasundar requested the opposition parties, including the Congress, to see that NPR/NRC is withdrawn during the budget session. Several Congress leaders from the district, including MLA U T Khader, were present.

The CAA is pending before the Supreme Court. He criticised the Union government for spreading lies with regard to NRC,NPR and CAA.

He mocked home minister Amit Shah for not knowing Indian history, and called him confused because anti-CAA, NPR and NRC protests are turning violent only in states that are ruled by the BJP.

“When 200 people protested in Mangaluru on December 19, there was firing, and CCTV cameras and DVRs were taken away by the police, because the police are taking orders from Nagpur and Kalladka republic,” he said.

He also called the Prime Minister confused for spreading lies, and called upon RSS leader Kalladka Prabhakar Bhat to follow the ideals of B R Ambedkar as enshrined in the Constitution.

“The hidden agenda of implementing CAA is to convert the nation into a Hindu Rashtra, and the government has been misleading the people by saying that CAA and NRC have no connection. CAA is being implemented to save non-Muslims who have no documents. With implementation of the new rules, the government will follow the ‘3D principle’ that is doubtful citizen, declared foreigner, detention centre and deaths. At least 30 people have died in six detention centres in Assam,’’ he claimed.

Former IAS officer Kannan Gopinathan, hitting out at the Union government, said the government thought it could scare the people, but there is a limit for everything.

“Now that people have taken to the streets, the government is scared. The fight to save the Constitution and secularism must be the responsibility of all citizens, including non-Muslims,’’ he added.

Advocate Sudhir Kumar Maroli questioned why the government is not speaking about the benefits of demonetisation. He said it is important to go to villages and spread awareness against NPR, NRC and CAA.

The protest and awareness rally was carried out under the theme ‘Save Constitution Save India’ and ‘We the people of India’.

Title: Thousands witness ‘Makaravilakku’, peaceful end to pilgrim season
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Thiruvabharanam being received by the tanthri and melshanti at Sannidhanam

SANNIDHANAM: Thousands of devotees witnessed the ‘ Makaravilakku ’ amid reverberating Ayyappa chants on Wednesday.

The ‘Makaravilakku’, which flashed three times from 6.52pm at Ponnambalamedu, marked the culmination of the over two months of Mandala-Makaravilakku pilgrimage season.

Pilgrims thronged Sannidhanam from Tuesday itself for witnessing the ‘Makaravilakku’—or the holy flame—forcing the police to restrict the devotees from Wednesday morning.

Vehicles ferrying pilgrims to Pamba, the base camp, were stopped at Nilackal from 9am. Devotees at Pamba were prevented from trekking from 11 am to evening, to avoid rush at the hill shrine.

Officials of the Travancore Devaswom Board (TDB) received the processing carrying the Thiruvabharanam, the deity’s ornaments and attire, at Saramkuthy at 5pm. Only the 25-member team accompanying the Thiruvabharam from Pandalam palace were allowed to proceed further to Sannidhanam, where TDB president N Vasu received the procession at 6.30pm.

After adorning the idol with the ornaments, the sanctum santorum opened for ‘deeparadhana’ at 6.50pm. Pilgrims with folded palms waited for the ‘Makaravilakku’, and once it became visible, Ayyappa chants, rose from Sabarimala.

Minister for devaswom Kadakampally Surendran, TDB president Vasu, Pathanamthitta district collector P B Nooh, devaswom secretary K R Jyotilal, IGP S Sreejith, and other senior officials were present.

After the darshan, police allowed devotees to trek back in batches to avoid rush.

“We have arranged 750 buses for pilgrims to various destinations from Nilackal. The pilgrimage season went smoothly and was incident-free,” Nooh said.

Violence marred the previous pilgrim season after the Supreme Court allowed women of menstruating age—defined as those aged between 10 and 50—also to offer prayers at the shrine.

Earlier in the morning, minister Surendran presented musician Illayaraja the Harivarasanam Award at Sannidhanam. Illayaraja also had a darshan at the temple after receiving the award, comprising a cash prize of Rs 1 lakh, citation and a plaque.

Title: Uttarakhand: Bhotia dogs' sale down markedly in Uttarayani Mela
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Locals blame tight regulations for the dip in the sale of Bhotia dogs

BAGESHWAR: Shobhram, 50, a local trader, travelled over 130 kilometres with two dozen Bhotia dogs to reach Bageshwar so he could sell them at the annual Uttarayani Mela . But he could only sell a few of them and still has 15 Bhotia dogs left with him.

Shobhram is among the many such traders who make yearly trips to the upper reaches of the Himalayas to buy the Himalayan dog and sell them at the annual fair. However, the sale of Bhotia dogs has been dwindling over the years.

“I bought two dozen dogs this year. They were one to two months old. These dogs came for Rs 5,000 to Rs 7,000 each and on a good day, can sell for Rs 20,000 each,” said Shobhram, ruing the fact that the number of tourists coming to the Uttarayani Mela had been dipping for many years.

Another local trader told TOI that the mela, held every year on Makar Sankranti, has for centuries been a cheap market for purchase of Bhotia dogs. “Tourists from all over North India used to come to this mela but their footfall has decreased in the past few years and so has the sale of Bhotia dogs,” the trader added.

The locals also blamed tight regulations for the dip in the sale of the dogs. “A few days ago, officials told some of us that we cannot sell dogs in the mela as we don’t have registration. They added that we may be booked for selling dogs here,” said BS Mehta, who had been selling dogs in the fair for 15 years now.

Notably, the market isn’t sanctioned by the administration. “I came here to buy a Bhotia dog but locals told me that this market is illegal,” said Aslam, who came to the mela from Moradabad in Uttar Pradesh.

When queried on the issue, a district official told TOI, “The market isn’t registered and we have received several complaints of animal cruelty. We are ensuring that no animal is treated badly.”

Meanwhile, Bageshwar district magistrate Ranjana Rajguru said, “We understand the cultural and the economic value of the market. We are trying to regularise the market and the sellers so that business is conducted fairly.”

Title: A homemaker’s tryst with art
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: In her eighth painting exhibition , Geethkarthika , a Malayali homemaker from Oman , has put on display an array of contemporary figurative paintings at the art gallery at Vyloppilly Samskrithi Bhavan. The exhibition titled ‘Fantasy 2020’ has attracted more than 100 visitors since its inauguration on Sunday.

“It is not easy for a woman, especially a homemaker, to pursue her dreams and aspirations. When I was as a teenager, I used to draw just a hobby. I never thought of making a career out of it because I was busy with responsibilities. But as time progressed, I realised that I could become an artist. Today, I am here hosting eighth painting exhibition of my career,” Geethkarthika said.

“After dispensing my duties as a mother and wife, I guess time has come for me to pursue a career as an artist. I am still a student. I try to learn new things every day and try to bring a difference in each of my exhibitions,” Geethkarthika added.

Geethkarthika said she has made it to this phase of life by constantly motivating herself and taking strenuous efforts to learn and perfect her craft.

After the exhibition of contemporary figurative paintings and murals at Vyloppilly Samskrithi Bhavan, Geethkarthika will be focusing on Indo-Arabic paintings. “The appreciation and criticism that I receive from these exhibitions help me grow as an artist,” she said.

The exhibition will conclude on Sunday. Along with 20 acrylic-based paintings of Geethkarthika, five works of Lucknow-based artist Nirupama Misra are also exhibited from 10:30am to 6:30pm.

Title: Tewari takes charge as AU’s officiating VC
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Allahabad: Prof R R Tewari of the JK Institute of Allahabad University (AU) on Wednesday took charge of the officiating vice-chancellor of the university from Prof PK Sahoo. Prof Tewari’s name was sent by the ministry of human resource and development (MHRD).

Prof Tewari, who had joined AU in 1982 as an assistant professor in the department of electronics and communication, popularly known as J K Institute, would officiate as the VC till the time a regular incumbent is appointed by the MHRD in about three months. AU would be coming out with an advertisement of the same in coming days.

Meanwhile, before handing over the charge to Prof Tewari, Prof Sahoo called meeting of heads of various departments and deans. Prof Sahoo, who was given the charge of AU VC on Tuesday night, retired on Wednesday. However, before retiring and handing over the charge to Prof Tewari, Prof Sahoo took several important decisions foremost being increasing the number of working days in a week.

AU would now function for six days a week against the earlier practice of five days a week. Former VC Prof RL Hangloo had changed the functioning of AU to five days from the earlier practice of six days. “Because of five days of working, courses were getting delayed,” said Prof Sahoo. Among other decisions taken by Prof Sahoo, now the AU website will have a list of teachers as per their seniority. “Before I took over charge, there was much hue and cry over who is senior. That’s why I have ordered that AU website should have a clear list of seniority of teachers,” he said.

Title: 2 dead after motorbikes collide
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Mangaluru: Two youths were killed after the two motorbikes they were riding met with a head-on collision near Kodaje , under Vittal police station limits, on Wednesday evening.

According to police, Parikshith, 19, a resident of Baranikere and Azmal, 21, a resident of Goltamajalu, were killed in the accident. The accident took place around 7pm, when Parikshith was moving towards Kodaje while Azmal was going to Mani. On reaching near a curve at Kodaje, they met with a head-on collision, when one of the riders tried to avoid a dog which was on the road. The victims were immediately rushed to a nearby hospital, but succumbed to their injuries. Padmanabha, 30, who was riding pillion, is being treated at Wenlock Hospital in Mangaluru.

A case has been registered at Vittal police station.

Title: Writing on Wall: After a month of agitation, all roads lead to Jamia Millia Islamia
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Students painted the walls to speak out against the police action on Jamia campus on December 15

NEW DELHI: Students of Delhi University , Jawaharlal Nehru University and Ambedkar University Delhi (AUD) on Wednesday made their way to Jamia Millia Islamia to show solidarity and be a part of the “Jamia Chalo” protest marking one month of the violence that erupted on the campus.

As the protesters raised slogans against CAA-NRC, the Jamia administration called a meeting of the executive council and decided that they would file an application in court under Section 156(3) of CrPC seeking direction to police to register an FIR in the December 15 violence.

Hundreds of students assembled in front of gate number 7 (Bab-E-Maulana Abul Kalam Azad) to raise their voice against CAA and NRC. Traffic on the road leading to Jamia had to be diverted to the opposite carriageway. Along the road, students had set up an open library with a wide variety of donated books and a photo exhibition titled “Hum Dekhenge”. The walls of MAK Pataudi Sports Complex were painted with graffiti and protest art.

“We painted the walls to raise our voice against police brutality and the violence that erupted on our campus. Not just students of Jamia’s fine arts department, but even volunteers joined in to paint the walls,” said Jamia fine arts student Simi Anjum.

Harshita Singh, a BA (programme) student from Lady Shri Ram College said, “Me and others from my college have come here to express solidarity with the Jamia students. If the people in power were logical and could see the struggle of the people, they would not have acted in this manner.” A film studies student at AUD, Anya Ramananujam said the attack on students touched a raw nerve.

Several local residents also took part in the protest march. Holding a banner, Haji Mohammad Zahid, a photographer from Okhla Vihar, said, “I have been a part of the protest for the past one month. We want this black law to go away as it will be good for India. The protests will continue.”

JNU Students’ Union president Aishe Ghosh thanked the Jamia students “for showing love and solidarity” during her struggle. “The women of Jamia are our inspiration. If women of Shaheen Bagh are out on the streets and are not scared, then how can I be scared of the goondas who came to the campus and attacked us? Our spirit is strengthened by our unity,” she added.

Attacking Delhi Police for destroying the Jamia campus and the library, Ghosh said, “It is against law to destroy the property of a university. What is happening in Kashmir is wrong. We must not forget about Kashmiris because that is where the government started their attempt to take away our constitutional rights.”

Meanwhile, as exams were cancelled on January 13, the Jamia administration said that the new datesheet will be declared by the controller of examinations in consultation with all the deans.
