Title: Last seen with friends, 19-year-old found dead
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Allahabad: A 19-year-old youth was allegedly murdered while he was out with his friends near Devghgat Jhalwa area, under Dhoomanganj police station, late Tuesday night.

Police said the deceased was identified as Vishal, a resident of Kalindipuram.

Morning walkers spotted Vishal’s body on Wednesday and alerted the police. The body was found with a slit throat and hidden behind bushes.

SSP (Allahabad) Satyarth Anirudh Pankaj said, “One of Vishal’s close friends Suraj called him around 5pm on Tuesday evening. Suraj asked Vishal to accompany him to Pattupur. While stepping out of the house, Vishal told his family about where he was heading and that he would be back in 10 minutes.”

The SSP said that the deceased youth used to help his father in making furniture and odd plumbing jobs.

After an hour, Suraj reached Vishal’s home and handed over the keys of the latter’s motorcycle to his father Nand Lal. Suraj told Nand Lal that Vishal would return shortly.

When Vishal didn’t turn by 8pm, his family called him and he assured them that he would return at the earliest. However, that was the last time Vishal’s family heard of him as he was was found dead the next morning.

The SSP said that the police have picked up two men for interrogation. A case under section 302 of the Indian Penal Code has been lodged and the body has been sent for postmortem examination. Police said that Vishal and Suraj met with a couple of other friends on Tuesday night and suspect that they might have murdered him.

Meanwhile, a 24-year-old woman was found hanging at her home in Malviya village, under the limits of Industrial area police station, late Tuesday night.

The deceased was identified as Kajal. Her family alleged that her husband and in-laws had strangled the woman to death and then hanged her body to make it appear like a suicide. Police said Kajal and one Sanjeev Nishad had been married for two years. Apart from sending the body for postmortem examination, police have lodged a case under Dowry Prohibition Act.

Title: Five riot accused move bail plea in sessions court
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Kanpur: The five accused, who were arrested by the police during the recent riots in the city to lodge a protest against CAA, moved their bail applications in the sessions court here.

According to the police record, four accused were arrested from Babupurwa and one from Yateemkhana during the riots. They were identified as Pervez Alam, Shahzad Alam, Adil, Mustqim (Babupurwa) and Mohd Tahil alias Mohsin. As their bail applications were earlier rejected by the lower court, they preferred the same in the sessions court.

To recall, the additional district and sessions judge (XII), Kanpur Nagar, Vinay Singh, who had heard the bail applications of the two accused--Pervez Alam and Shahzad Alam--on Monday last, rejected them on the ground that there was no ground to grant them bail.

During the hearing of the bail applications, the police had produced the evidence and the investigation report. On the other hand, the kin of the arrested persons pleaded that the accused were innocent and had been fabricated by the police after using third-degree against them.

The bail applications of three other accused--Adil, Mustquim and Mohd Tahil alias Mohsin--are still pending for hearing and might be heard this week.

According to police sources, more than 20 identified accused are absconding, and efforts are being made to seek a non-bailable warrant from the court against them for further legal proceedings.

The Colonelganj police station too had registered a case under heinous violence offences but no one has been arrested so far. According to police, the investigation was going on and evidence against the accused were being collected.

Title: Two major shore-protection works to be launched
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

The work at Muthalapuzhy includes shore protection at Muthalapozhy fishing harbour near Thazhampally side and ... Read More

Thiruvananthapuram: Kerala state coastal area development corporation(KSCADC) is set to undertake two major shore protection works at Poonthura and Muthalapozhy . The projects will be implemented at a cost of Rs 31 crores. The work at Poonthura involves shore protection and providing beach landing facility at a cost of Rs 16.96 crores. The offshore breakwater will be constructed using geo-synthetic tubes. Tenders have been called for both the projects.

The work at Muthalapuzhy which is being funded by KIIFB includes shore protection at Muthalapozhy fishing harbour near Thazhampally side and Kadinamkulam backwater. The project which will be implemented at a cost of Rs 14.53 crores involves shore protection with rubble mount groynes and river side protection with geo tubes.

The project is proposed to construct rubble mount numbering ten groins of length varying from 95 to 40m. Groins are proposed with different category of granite quarry stones. The shore works near kayal side have been proposed with geo tubes.

As per the document prepared by KSCADC, this area was a vulnerable stretch of beach and was protected with a massive sea wall. The construction of breakwater has restricted the long shore sediment transport resulting in massive accretion on the southern bank of the estuary and severe erosion on the northern coast up to a distance of 3.00kms from the break waters.

The existing seawall is found to be inadequate to withstand the fury of monsoon waves. The seawall is damaged at many places. Already a groin is constructed by the Harbour Engineering Department has constructed a groyne at a distance of 300m North of North break water. This was effective in preventing the beach erosion for a distance of 300 meters. The studies proposed here is to find suitable solution for the beach erosion issue in the region, the tender document noted. Beach nourishment at Poonthura will be done after completing the placement of Geosynthetic tubes. As per the project document, Poonthura sandbank where the Killiyar discharges in to the sea is situated at the south side of the coast line to be protected.

Unprotected beach measuring 750 m lies north of the existing sandbank. This beach is being used by the fishermen community for fish landing operations. High waves resulted during Ockhi and subsequent depressions washed away the beach and the fishermen lost their beach for landing the vessels.

The beach is protected with sea wall for a length of about 400 meters. Beyond this there are 8 groynes of length less than 50 meters. The head portion of these groynes have almost washed away. The existing shore protection systems were found ineffective and in many places the sea wall is collapsed and severe wave overtopping is observed.

Title: Pune: Parked truck stolen in just five minutes from village
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: In a blink-and-miss theft, a truck was stolen within five minutes in the early hours of Tuesday at Somatane village near Talegaon Dabhade , about 30km from the city.

The truck driver, Sohanlal Sharma, had gone out of the vehicle’s cabin for answering nature’s call leaving behind the ignition key. When he returned after five minutes, the vehicle was missing.

Sharma immediately alerted the truck owner, Bahalsingh Bal (50) of Kalamaboli in Raigad. Bal later lodged an FIR with the Talegaon Dabhade police.

Sub-inspector Dnyaneshwar Bajgire of the Talegaon Dabhade police said Sharma was returning to Kalamboli on Monday night after delivering some consignment at Karad. “As Sharma felt drowsy, he stopped the truck near a petrol pump at Somatane and slept inside the vehicle,” Bajgire said.

He said Sharma woke up around 3.20am on Tuesday for answering nature’s call. “He came out of the cabin without removing the ignition key. When he returned, the truck was not there,” Bajgire said.

Sharma searched the truck in the vicinity and then informed Bal. “We checked the CCTV footage from the toll plazas at Talegaon Dabhade and near Lonavla. The truck did not pass through them,” Bajgire said.

Title: Re-investigation ordered in case
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Kozhikode: Vigilance court here has ordered a re-investigation in the case related to corruption in the purchase of equipment for the General Hospital, the First Information Report (FIR) of which had mentioned the name of former PWD secretary T O Sooraj.

Vigilance and Anti-Corruption Bureau (VACB) had registered an FIR in 2007 against Sooraj, who was the district collector when the purchase was made, reproductive and child health (RCH) officer Dr M Vijayan, Sidco manager M G Sasidharan and Oriental Surgicals managing partner T M Vasudevan.

In the preliminary enquiry the VACB had found irregularities to the tune of Rs 34 lakh in the purchase of equipment for the hospital under the World Bank project. But in 2012 VACB filed the chargesheet removing Sooraj and Dr Vijayan from the list of the accused.

The remaining accused moved the court seeking to quash case against them too and the court on Wednesday ordered a re-investigation in the case.

Title: PMPML to get civic body’s Aundh octroi post land
Content:
PMPML is now awaiting the nod of the general body of the PMC

The PMPML is set to get the corporation’s Aundh octroi post land for developing a dedicated parking lot and setting up charging points for new buses to be added to its fleet soon

PUNE: The Pune Mahanagar Parivahan Mahamandal Limited is set to get the corporation’s Aundh octroi post land for developing a dedicated parking lot and setting up charging points for new buses to be added to its fleet soon.The proposal to hand over the land of the octroi post measuring 7,000sqm to Pune Mahanagar Parivahan Mahamandal Limited (PMPML) was approved by the civic body’s standing committee recently. It is now awaiting the nod of the general body of the Pune Municipal Corporation (PMC).The PMPML has been facing shortage of space to park its buses during night hours. It does not have a depot in the Aundh area at present. The buses are often parked on the university road during night hours because of space constraints.The transport utility had approached the civic administration seeking land of the octroi post, lying vacant after the state government abolished octroi. The PMC has not utilized the plot so far for any other purpose.“The PMPML is in process of procuring more buses in phases. It will require more land because the existing depots are proving insufficient. A proposal was tabled before the standing committee to allot the land at the earliest for the next five years and sign a contract with the PMPML for the same,” said an official from the civic administration.The standing committee, while giving a go-ahead to the allotment of the land, said it was a step towards strengthening the public transport system and to improve the PMPML services.The PMC had initially told the PMPML to pay Rs40 lakh against the land and its utilization for five years. The transport utility had expressed its inability to make the payment as it was facing financial challenges. The PMC has now proposed to recover the rent amount through the grant, given to the PMPML to make up for the operational losses.A source from the PMPML said with increasing fleet, it has already started exploring the options of utilizing its existing land more effectively. The PMPML is utilizing the PMC’s land of octroi post in the Hadapsar (Shevalewadi) area. Handing over the PMC’s plots for bus operations would be vital for improving the public transport services, the source added.

Title: Army Institute of Technology students win at hackathon
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: Students of Army Institute of Technology bagged top three positions in the NEC Hackathon at Indian Institute of Technology, New Delhi.

AIT alumni team Drupple, comprising Swastik Srivastava, Rohan Chougule, Rajat Rawat and Anirudh Murali, won the first prize. The third year students’ team WeCode, consisting of Shailesh, Arpit, Shubham and Shivam, won the second prize. The One in Centillion team of Sagar and Ashok won the third prize.

AIT stated the first, second and third teams were given cash prizes of Rs 2.5 lakh, Rs 1.5 lakh and Rs 1 lakh, respectively. The Hackathon was organized by NEC Corporation in collaboration with Common Service Centers. The theme was digitization of rural education.

Title: Delhi: Row over refusal to hold protest at Ramjas arena
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

The programme was finally held on campus

NEW DELHI: Delhi University’s Ramjas College witnessed a major drama on Wednesday when the students protesting against Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA) and National Register of Citizens (NRC) came across a notice that no programme could be held at the institute’s amphitheatre without prior permission.

They accused the administration of trying to disrupt their public meeting and the reading of the preamble of the Constitution while the principal claimed it to be the rule of the college. As large numbers of both pro- and anti-CAA/NRC students gathered on the premises, police were called in to avoid any untoward incident. The programme was finally held after a march inside the campus. The protest was organised by the Young India coordination committee, a student platform that has been organising anti-CAA/NRC events across the country.

Abhigyan, a second-year political science student, said, “We had invited DU teachers Laxman Yadav and Hany Babu but they didn’t come because of the situation. The administration issued the notice on Tuesday though the amphitheatre is used for public meetings. Another group had organised a programme on Swami Vivekananda on Tuesday.”

Principal Manoj Khanna said, “If any department wants to hold a function, it has to take the administration’s permission. Is it possible that anybody can come and do anything at the amphitheatre? If something goes wrong, who will be responsible?” The college would have made proper arrangements if the permission was taken, he added.

The students admitted that they had not sought permission, though they had been campaigning in the college. After reading the preamble and singing the national anthem, “we did a sit-in in front of the amphitheatre as a mark of protest. When police asked us to disperse, we did so peacefully,” said a student.

The principal said, “If you want a debate on anything, there has to be both views. It should be an open debate, where each side gets a chance to convince their audience.”

Title: Delhi elections: Surly over sealings, poor infra and taxing woes, traders are keeping parties guessing
Content:
Among 18-20 assembly constituencies, Karol Bagh is one of the areas populated by a large number of trading fam... Read More

NEW DELHI: Sealed locks, dust-covered shutters and dogs idling on near-empty streets — the lanes of the once bustling Suit Market at Amar Colony in south Delhi are almost deserted today. In a single day on March 8 in 2018, 350 shops there were closed down, making it the site of the biggest sealing exercise since December 2017 when the Supreme Court revived the committee to monitor illegal commercial establishments. But other places too have suffered similarly.The triple whammy — sealing, economic slowdown and infrastructure woes — has Delhi’s traders, considered traditional BJP supporters, in a fix as February 8 approaches and they have to opt for the party to vote to power in Delhi. With estimates of 15 lakh in its fold and another 20-25 lakh as employees, the trader community is a significant ‘influence group’ in Delhi politics, and the parties cannot afford to alienate it.With the Gross State Domestic Product of Delhi logging Rs 7.8 lakh crore in 2018-19, the city bustles with economic activities, both manufacturing and services. There are 18-20 assembly constituencies, among them Karol Bagh, Chandni Chowk, Sadar Bazar, Wazirpur, Rajouri Garden and Rohini, populated by a large number of trading families. And for them, sealing is one among many woes that will sway their thoughts on voting day.Aafter his Defence Colony Market shop’s basements and upper floors were sealed in 2017-18, Jagdish Gupta has been conducting business from rented space at the Defence Colony Flyover Market. “I have shops in a prominent market, but am forced to pay rent. I don’t know how long this uncertainty will last,” said Gupta. “Our hopes were high after DDA amended the rules in June 2018, but nothing has changed.”Brijesh Goyal, national convenor of Chamber of Trade and Industry and also of Aam Aadmi Party’s trade wing, claimed that sealing would be the primary election issue for the traders. “Union urban affairs minister Hardeep Puri says that shops have been de-sealed, but that is not true,” Goyal contended. “Around 9,000 shops remain shut down.”Besides sealing there are other grouses that the traders have against the political system. Praveen Khandelwal, general secretary, Confederation of All India Traders, asserted that merchants also wanted infrastructure development. “While the municipal corporations rake in crores of rupees in parking and conversion charges, no infrastructure has been developed. Traffic congestion and parking affects consumer patterns,” he said.Expressing similar frustrations about the cess collected by the municipal bodies not leading to development, Sanjay Bhargav, president, Chandni Chowk Sarv Vyapar Mandal, added, “Lack of infrastructure in markets is the main issue highlighted by the Supreme Court.”Khandelwal said CAIT was also demanding further simplification of the Goods and Services Tax set-up because complicated forms and monthly filing requirement still rankle. “Small shop owners are forced to spend money on accountants for this,” he said, while pointing out that Delhi’s godown policy too continued to be faulty with storage not allowed in urban areas under Master Plan Delhi 2021.Yogesh Singhal, head of Bullion and Jewellers Association in Chandni Chowk, one of Delhi’s biggest gold markets, too summed up the traders’ woes by stressing on the need for tax reforms and a tax system based on transaction tax. Other problems that traders drew attention to included the absence of functional amenities like washrooms in markets, unfair practices of e-commerce giants, shifting of 14 wholesale markets to new complexes and the notification of 351 streets for mixed and commercial land use.BJP will bank on the support of three lakh petty shopkeepers and small scale industrialists in unauthorised colonies, where land ownership rights have recently been granted. But recent public events have shown that the party cannot take this support for granted. “I participated in the Vyapari Mahasammelan in Talkatora Stadium in April last year when PM Narendra Modi came. The stadium was jam-packed. The recent convention, where two Union ministers were present, had barely a few hundred traders. It is a message for the party,” claimed a trader. Another said most participants left the convention because the Centre didn’t announce de-sealing of shops or further simplification of the GST system.Some traders are dejected with both the AAP government and the BJP-led municipal corporations. Vijay Ishrani of Green Park Traders Association charged the two with leaving thousands unemployed through sealing. “Sealing started only after the corporations and state government failed to submit the report on land-use change on 351 roads in the Supreme Court or notify the changes on time,” Ishrani said. “And then the civic bodies, seeking to recover conversion charges to boost their strained finances, conveniently took advantage of the Supreme Court monitoring committee to seal shops without confirming if these were fully commercial or partly residential.”The manifestos of the parties are awaited. Incorporation of the demands of the trading community could affect loyalties either way.

There are 18-20 assembly constituencies, among them Karol Bagh, Chandni Chowk, Sadar Bazar, Wazirpur, Rajouri Garden and Rohini, populated by a large number of trading families. And for them, sealing is one among many woes that will sway their thoughts on voting day.Aafter his Defence Colony Market shop’s basements and upper floors were sealed in 2017-18, Jagdish Gupta has been conducting business from rented space at the Defence Colony Flyover Market. “I have shops in a prominent market, but am forced to pay rent. I don’t know how long this uncertainty will last,” said Gupta. “Our hopes were high after DDA amended the rules in June 2018, but nothing has changed.”Brijesh Goyal, national convenor of Chamber of Trade and Industry and also of Aam Aadmi Party’s trade wing, claimed that sealing would be the primary election issue for the traders. “Union urban affairs minister Hardeep Puri says that shops have been de-sealed, but that is not true,” Goyal contended. “Around 9,000 shops remain shut down.”Besides sealing there are other grouses that the traders have against the political system. Praveen Khandelwal, general secretary, Confederation of All India Traders, asserted that merchants also wanted infrastructure development. “While the municipal corporations rake in crores of rupees in parking and conversion charges, no infrastructure has been developed. Traffic congestion and parking affects consumer patterns,” he said.Expressing similar frustrations about the cess collected by the municipal bodies not leading to development, Sanjay Bhargav, president, Chandni Chowk Sarv Vyapar Mandal, added, “Lack of infrastructure in markets is the main issue highlighted by the Supreme Court.”Khandelwal said CAIT was also demanding further simplification of the Goods and Services Tax set-up because complicated forms and monthly filing requirement still rankle. “Small shop owners are forced to spend money on accountants for this,” he said, while pointing out that Delhi’s godown policy too continued to be faulty with storage not allowed in urban areas under Master Plan Delhi 2021.Yogesh Singhal, head of Bullion and Jewellers Association in Chandni Chowk, one of Delhi’s biggest gold markets, too summed up the traders’ woes by stressing on the need for tax reforms and a tax system based on transaction tax. Other problems that traders drew attention to included the absence of functional amenities like washrooms in markets, unfair practices of e-commerce giants, shifting of 14 wholesale markets to new complexes and the notification of 351 streets for mixed and commercial land use.BJP will bank on the support of three lakh petty shopkeepers and small scale industrialists in unauthorised colonies, where land ownership rights have recently been granted. But recent public events have shown that the party cannot take this support for granted. “I participated in the Vyapari Mahasammelan in Talkatora Stadium in April last year when PM Narendra Modi came. The stadium was jam-packed. The recent convention, where two Union ministers were present, had barely a few hundred traders. It is a message for the party,” claimed a trader. Another said most participants left the convention because the Centre didn’t announce de-sealing of shops or further simplification of the GST system.Some traders are dejected with both the AAP government and the BJP-led municipal corporations. Vijay Ishrani of Green Park Traders Association charged the two with leaving thousands unemployed through sealing. “Sealing started only after the corporations and state government failed to submit the report on land-use change on 351 roads in the Supreme Court or notify the changes on time,” Ishrani said. “And then the civic bodies, seeking to recover conversion charges to boost their strained finances, conveniently took advantage of the Supreme Court monitoring committee to seal shops without confirming if these were fully commercial or partly residential.”The manifestos of the parties are awaited. Incorporation of the demands of the trading community could affect loyalties either way.

Title: Maharashtra: An adult who has not lost childlike qualities
Content:
On the eve of his visit to Nagpur, here are some nuggets about Chief Justice Sharad Bobde penned by his childhood friend Vijay Dandige

“What’s the real name of Pele?”The question was flung at me by a boyish face as we sat in my friend Vinod’s spacious house in Civil Lines. It was 1965, the first year of college. The question had come from Vinod’s younger brother, Sharad. As I struggled to come up with the answer, pat came the reply from him, “Edson Arantes do Nascimento.”That was my first meeting with Sharadbhau, as we call him now.Although Vinod was my friend, I developed over the years a singular bond with Sharadbhau, even though I was almost a decade older than him.I believe everyone should have a friend with whom one can spend hours discussing, sharing new books and authors, new tenets and philosophies and many other things. That’s the bond I have shared with Sharadbhau.It was only years later that I understood his penchant for asking questions. It was not meant as a prank or a trick. It sprang from his innate nature, his intense curiosity about everything.Today, decades later, he has not changed at all. He is the only adult I know who has not lost his childlike qualities : Insatiable curiosity to know and to understand everything, a sense of wonder, the joy of discovery of new things. He is the only one I know who is passionately driven by a desire to find out why things happen, how things work and how they can be improved. He is like a man who is perpetually in awe of the magnificence of life, as reflected in all beings and things around us, and whose ravenous curiosity impels him to fully drink in and savour that beauty in myriad forms.Sharadbhau’s interests and passions have been breathtakingly vast and universal, astounding in their sheer breadth, ranging from, among others, Oscar Wilde, Jiddu Krishnamurti’s philosophy, Sun Tzu’s The Art of War to the grand vision of the Upanishads, Jim Corbett’s hunting skills, the Beatles to Koran’s teachings, quirks of singer Bhimsen Joshi, dribbling skills of Irish footballer George Best to the dialogues between Lord Shiva and Parvati from Tantra, Harley Davidson bikes, the power of Gayatri mantra to Ernest Hemingway, parables of the Bible, Guru Gobind Singh to bisons and their strength, how Moses wrote the Torah, Ilie Nastase's tennis wizardry, to Sant Tukaram’s abhangas, the secret behind Marilyn Monroe’s stunning impact, the concept of dharma in the Geeta and Scriptures to Chanakya's brilliance, general Rommel’s conquest of Africa, the purifying qualities of gou-mutra to the uplifting vibrations of Rudra chanting, the medicinal qualities of snakes' venom, Colin Wilson's the Outsider to the Japanese ritual of seppuko, the parables of Ramkrishna, the tenets of ancient Indian Nyaya system....just to mention a few. This kaleidoscopic list could go on.Back in the 70s, captivated by the reptile and animal world, he once caused hilarious consternation in his household by keeping a non-poisonous snake in his room as a pet. On another occasion, at the house of a friend who collected snakes, to get a closer look he came within the striking range of a fully-grown king cobra, sending his friend into a panic.Remarkably, he has done this wide-ranging reading of his, in addition to the voluminous legal reading he has had to do as a lawyer and a judge. And he has been a deep reader, his intensely curious mind devouring facts and details. This is evident from his phenomenal memory that enables him to recite verbatim, even today, some lines from a Shakespeare play, an Art of War tenet, a Brahma sutra couplet or Sant Tukaram’s abhanga. He also remembers in exact words, even today, some strange or unique incident narrated to him by a friend decades ago.And this terrific memory of his also serves to make him an enchanting storyteller who embellishes his stories with quaint facts and colourful details. In lighter moments, his delightful sense of humour, too, comes out.Normally, one would expect such a diversely read person to be arrogant and snotty. Not him. If anything, he has a strange, endearing kind of humility. He is, more often than not, likely to effusively praise some accomplishment or special talent of one of his friends to others, sometimes much to the discomfiture of the person being praised.Another extraordinary quality is his fierce drive to improve things, to find solutions. He is not only constantly trying out new ideas, new concepts in his personal life but has no ego or hang-ups about enlisting the help and cooperation of anyone who might contribute to making things better. As he often says, “If it works, what does it matter where it comes from.”Sharadbhau is the only true Renaissance man I have come across, a Universal man — represented as an accomplished man, limitless in his capacity for development who embraces all knowledge and develops his own capacities as fully as possible. He is a true cosmopolite who views all human beings as just that, nothing more and nothing less. He is a deeply spiritual man who is impervious to the allure of the usually sought-after baubles: money, power, prestige, wealth, status, position, name and fame.As for his legal knowledge and expertise, that, undoubtedly, is his forte, both inherited and acquired.As for his integrity, honesty, incorruptibility, those are his inheritance, embedded in his DNA, passed down from an illustrious grandfather and an equally renowned father.And as for his fearlessness, it is the offshoot of his moral values and yogic qualities.And so, I am sure that under Sharadbhau’s stewardship we will see a throbbing, pulsating, questioning, prodding, vigorous, innovative, proactive, avant-garde judiciary.

Title: Late-coming guests add to agony of patients in pain
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

The function was scheduled to be inaugurated by district panchayat president VK Madhu while mayor K Sreekumar ... Read More

Thiruvananthapuram: It was a day meant to make them feel different. A host of cultural programmes, medical care and refreshments awaited them at the venue. However, on Palliative Care Observance Day, more than 1,250 patients under palliative care were made to wait for nearly two hours as the guests failed to turn up on time.

The occasion was ‘Arike-Saanthwana Sangamam 2020’ which was jointly organised by the Thiruvananthapuram Corporation, Aardram campaign, the National Health Mission and the Department of Health Services of Kerala. The function was scheduled to be inaugurated by district panchayat president VK Madhu at 11am in the PKV Memorial Open-Air Auditorium at the Government Higher Secondary School for Girls in Cotton Hill and mayor K Sreekumar was to preside over the function. The organisers were forced to play songs one by one as both the guests were held up due to other commitments.

The patients started arriving at the venue from 10am in various ambulances from different parts of the district. A medical corner was set up to tend to their needs, in case of an emergency. Since the organizers were able to arrange entertainment programs and provide refreshments and food on time, it did not lead to any tense situation. Nevertheless, the long wait wore them out.

“They had told us earlier that the program will be held only in the evening. I cannot sit still for a long time. I don’t usually go out for functions. I am too weak for that, but since I was told it was a government programme, I decided to come,” said Kunjan from Kallara, a patient.

The organisers were left helpless. “The mayor’s office informed us that he had a function at Chackai. I don’t know why he is late. We had planned for a cultural event right after the inaugural function. Now, we will have to postpone the inaugural function after noon,” said Roy Jose, district coordinator of Palliative Care.

However, at 1:10pm, during the lunch break, the panchayath president arrived at the venue and immediately left, assuring the organisers to come back in the evening. When he was asked about being late for more than two hours, he replied: “I had to go to my ward due to an emergency”.

The vice-president of Thiruvananthapuram district panchayat, Shailaja Beegam had arrived on time. Since the function was getting late, she delivered her keynote address and left.

Title: 7-year-old boy found murdered
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Kanpur: A seven-year-old boy, missing since late Tuesday evening, was found murdered in Hamirpur district on Wednesday. According to the complaint filed at the Sareela police station, the boy went missing from near his house. The victim's neighbour Ram Prakash, who is absconding, has emerged as the prime suspect.

Police have launched a hunt to arrest him. The motive of the crime was stated to be personal enmity.

The victim, identified as Awadhesh, son of Mangal Singh, a native of Chandaut village, was last spotted with a village man Ram Prakash. "The accused had an altercation with the boy's father a few days ago," the police said. There were strangulation marks on his throat.

The boy's father told the police that on Tuesday evening, he was working in the fields in the village when he got a call from his wife stating that their son was missing. "He, along with his friends, reached his house and started looking for him. He informed the local police and searched for him in the area with the cops. They found his body floating in a water body with strangulation marks on his throat," the police said.

Title: Hit-and-run case: Cops seize car for forensic test
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

The car was allegedly involved in an accident, which claimed two lives, near Sasthamangalam on December 29

Thiruvananthapuram: Police have managed to track down the mysterious car and its driver who were allegedly involved in the accident near Sasthamangalam, that claimed two lives two weeks ago. The car, a brown Maruti Suzuki Zen Estilo , belongs to Sadanandan (47), a clerical staff of Raj Bhavan, who stays in its staff quarters. On Wednesday, police met Sadanandan and confiscated his car.

Museum SI (Crimes) Syamraj J Nair said that the car was tracked down after an elaborate probe. He also said that the owner turned out to be the same person who was caught on the surveillance camera installed at a shop near the accident spot. Earlier, police had circulated the visuals to locate the suspect. Police are yet to ascertain how the accident happened.

“Sadanandan claimed that his vehicle was not involved in the accident. He told us that he heard a loud noise while passing the spot and slowed down his car. He saw a youth who was flung in the air after a collision. He also saw a motorcycle without a rider rolling in front of his car (left to right) and then crashing onto a lamp post on the median. A passerby rushed to his vehicle and accused him of causing the accident. He claimed that he explained the sequence of events to that person and that person let him go as he was convinced that Sadanandan had not caused the mishap,” Nair said.

“He claimed that he was afraid to speak about the accident as he was afraid of the media trial. News reports had portrayed him as a villain, who knocked down two innocent youths and sped away,” he said.

Police found his car after compiling a list of all Zen Estilo cars registered in city. There were over 1,600 cars in the list. Police filtered the list down to those registered near Vellayambalam and Sasthamangalam region. They found that Sadanandan’s car was registered under the address of his residence at Raj Bhavan staff quarters and it matched the description of the suspected vehicle.

Earlier, police had received statement from witnesses that the car was brown in colour and the registration number started with the KL-20 series. When police approached Sadanandan, he admitted that he was indeed the one who was caught on the surveillance camera.

‘’We haven’t booked him as we need to ensure that his vehicle was involved in the accident. Hence, we have confiscated it. We will be seeking the service of forensic experts to examine it,” Nair said. Sadanandan was let off after his statement was recorded.

The accident occurred at 9pm on December 29. Online food delivery executive Abdul Rahim (44) from Nedumangad and Aditya B Manoj (21) from Sasthamangalam were killed in the accident.

Title: Dehradun: One killed, one hurt after car falls into gorge
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Representative image


DEHRADUN: One person was killed and another was seriously injured after the car they were travelling in fell into a deep gorge near Mussoori-Tehri bypass at Laxmanpuri early on Wednesday. The car carrying two people was heading towards Dhanaulti when the person behind the wheels allegedly lost control over the vehicle near Andakhet. Both travellers suffered serious injuries in the accident . Both injured people were admitted to Mussoorie Landour Civil hospital, from where they were referred to a higher medical centre in Dehradun . Deepak Singh, 24, a resident of Fur club in Mussoorie, succumbed to injuries during treatment at Doon Hospital, while the other passenger Pradeep Rai is said to be critical. Vidhya Bhushan Negi, in-charge of Mussoorie police station, said that the families of both victims have been informed about the accident.

Title: Kerala to introduce skill policy for students, youth
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Labour minister T P Ramakrishnan inaugurates the India Skills Kerala 2020 at ITI Chackai in Thiruvananthapuram... Read More

THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: In a first in the country, the state government will soon introduce career and skill policies to enable the youth and students to develop and take their talents to higher levels and tap job opportunities awaiting them, said labour minister T P Ramakrishnan .

The minister who was inaugurating the district-level competitions of India Skills Kerala 2020 at Government ITI, Chackai, here said, “A seminar was conducted recently to discuss the draft for the career policy. The government is consolidating the suggestions that emerged from the deliberations to give final shape to the policy and announce them at the earliest. Steps are also afoot to draw up the state skill policy to open doors of opportunities for youngsters.”

Seeking to tap job opportunities that require various skills, the connect between the Industrial Training Institutes (ITIs) and the industry has been strengthened. Thousands of placements are expected to be clinched through job fairs, placement cells and entrepreneurship clubs. For ITI trades, Spectrum 2020 Job Fair was conducted in all the 14 districts last week. As many as 641 companies turned up for that and 5,671 candidates were hired by various companies as trainees, he said.

The government’s approach is to find out each individual’s talent and encourage it and create opportunities. India Skills Kerala 2020 will give a fillip to these efforts. Around 16,293 contestants have registered for participating in the district-level competitions.

This marks a big jump from last year’s 7,422 participants. This shows the rising enthusiasm of students for receiving training in trades. The aim of the competitions is to enable the youth to give expression to their skills and encourage them to scale new heights, said Ramakrishnan.

Title: Delhi: Shaheen Bagh takes toll on other border points
Content:
A CRPF officer walks past a barricade at a protest site, in Shaheen Bagh area of Delhi on Tuesday (REUTERS pho... Read More

NEW DELHI: It has been almost a month since traffic coming from Kalindi Kunj toll point has been hampered due to the protests at Shaheen Bagh . Municipal corporation officials say the blockage is now impacting operations at other border points by increasing the congestion.On an average, the border point receives 1,800 trucks every day. This entire traffic volume has now been diverted to other border points since the last month. The stretch between Mathura Road and Kalindi Kunj has been closed for traffic movement since last month over the anti-Citizenship (Amendment) Act protests in the area.A South Delhi Municipal Corporation official —the nodal agency for toll tax collection among three civic bodies — said that the revenue collection is not expected to be impacted as private toll collector is obliged to pay them Rs 1,200 crore annually. “The trucks that arrive in Delhi come on demand basis, as non-destined vehicles have to pay both toll tax and environment compensation cess mandated by the Supreme Court. We are diverting such vehicles to DND border and other nearby entry points. This is causing jams on other toll points,” the official said.Delhi has 124 border points and Kalindi Kunj toll is among the busiest ones. A 15-day long traffic inflow analysis commissioned by the municipal corporation last year had shown that the toll point has an overall weekly tax collection potential of more than Rs 12.4 crore. The study had shown that border point receives 2,963 double-axle trucks and 3,471 triple-axle trucks. It also gets more than 4,038 double-axle light commercial vehicles and 1,871 four-axle heavy trucks. This entire volume is now diverted to other borders.While municipal officials are expecting that the Shaheen Bagh-blockade will not cause any revenue loss for the corporations, the past experiences show that private toll tax collection agency can ask for exemption and reduction in the obligatory amount it has to pay. Last month, the private toll collector had sought similar exemption of Rs 240 crore in the lieu of commercial vehicles running away through free lanes during the enforcement of RFID system.The women’s protest at Shaheen Bagh has attracted nationwide public attention. It had started on December 15 with a group of 50 residents who took to the roads and blocked the traffic. Besides Gate number 7—the main protest point in Jamia university — Shaheen Bagh has served as the second key site for the anti-CAA protests in the region.On Sunday, a large number of people had staged a protest in Delhi’s Sarita Vihar, demanding the removal of barricades that have been placed on the road linking Mathura Road and Kalindi Kunj for the past few weeks.

Title: Delhi assembly elections: Former Congress minister calls on Sonia Gandhi, may rejoin party
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Sonia Gandhi

NEW DELHI: Former Delhi minister Rajkumar Chauhan , who had switched to BJP immediately after the 2019 Lok Sabha polls, is all set to return to Congress.

Chauhan, who represented Mongolpuri assembly constituency four times from 1993 to 2013, met interim Congress president Sonia Gandhi at her residence on Wednesday where he agreed to work for the party in the upcoming assembly polls. He, however, added that no discussion on his candidature took place at the meeting, which was also attended by Delhi Congress chief Subhash Chopra.

“I was called to Sonia ji’s office to meet her. We had a long discussion about the upcoming polls. I told her I will follow her orders and work for the party in whatever capacity she wants me to,” said Chauhan, who held important portfolios in Sheila Dikshit’s cabinet.

Meanwhile, Delhi Congress functionaries also said that he might officially rejoin in a ‘couple’ of days.

Chauhan was tipped to contest the last Lok Sabha election on a Congress ticket from the reserved constituency of North West Delhi but was reportedly denied just before the nominations were to be filed. He joined BJP a month later in May 2019.

Sources said Chauhan was shortlisted by BJP and was set to contest the upcoming assembly election from the reserved seat of Mongolpuri. His sudden exit may disturb BJP’s calculations. He was also made the co-convener of the manifesto committee of Delhi BJP.

While BJP sources said Chauhan was not picking up the phone to clear the air about his meeting, the Dalit leader said he had informed the organisational secretary and Delhi unit chief about his decision to not contest the upcoming polls.

Title: Dehradun: New guest house in Mumbai to keep two rooms for cancer patients
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Guest house has been constructed at an estimated cost of Rs 39.73 crore

DEHRADUN: Chief minister Trivendra Singh Rawat along with Maharashtra governor and former Uttarakhand CM Bhagat Singh Koshyari inaugurated a state guest house and emporium — ‘Uttarakhand Bhawan’ — at Mumbai on Wednesday.

The state guest house, which is located at Navi Mumbai area of Mumbai, has been constructed at an estimated cost of Rs 39.73 crore and has a total of 40 rooms for guests.

Speaking on the occasion, CM Rawat announced that the government has decided to reserve two rooms in the guest house for cancer patients who come to Mumbai for treatment. “The rooms will be reserved round the year for cancer patients,” he said.

He added that products made in Uttarakhand will also be made available in the bhawan. Also, government offices will be set up inside the building to aid tourists and investors having interest in Uttarakhand.

The CM further said that with the opening of Uttarakhand Bhawan, state’s cultural traditions and tourism opportunities will be promoted in the central, western and southern regions of the country.

Title: Dehradun: Ajay Bhatt opts out of BJP state president race
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Ajay Bhatt

DEHRADUN: Nainital MP and incumbent BJP state president Ajay Bhatt opted out of the race and vowed “full support” to the newly elected state party head who is likely to be announced on Thursday.

Speaking to TOI, Bhatt said, “I will work for the party and the new president, the decision on whose appointment would be taken by our senior leaders on January 16.”

The party election wing chief, Balwant Singh Bhauryal, issued the notification for the state chief election and on Thursday two senior party leaders — vice president Shivraj Chauhan and Union minister Arjun Ram Meghwal — would make the final announcement.

BJP insiders said that the party’s central leadership has made its mind to handpick a legislator which means the MPs and contestants having experience of organisation working of the saffron fold are unlikely to be considered.

“The BJP would fight the 2022 election under the flag of the new state president, so those having experience of working in organization wing alone will not cut much ice,” said a BJP source.

Title: Thousands witness Lakshadeepam
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: Thousands of devotees, Vedic scholars and tourists from across Kerala and from neighbouring states thronged Sree Padmanabhaswamy Temple here on Wednesday to witness Lakshadeepam marking the conclusion of Murajapam, a 56-day long and centuries-old ritual.

By 6pm, the temple and its entrance tower shone in golden colour with traditional earthen lamps, revolving oil lamps and electrical lamps.

Being the first Murajapam and Lakshadeepam (lighting of one lakh oil lamps) after Supreme Court took over the management of the temple, there was strict security on the premises.

Despite this, devotees, including elderly people, thronged the temple to have a glimpse of this once-in-a-six-year event and to pay respect to their Lord Padmanabha, the main deity of the temple.

Malathyammal, 82, of Aryasala, who arrived at the temple along with her grandchildren, said she has been witnessing Murajapam and Lakshadeepam from the age of 12.

“Participating in the 56-day-long ritual and witnessing its finale Lakshadeepam was our favourite timepass during my childhood, which now had turned into a serious devotion. At that time, we used to light the lamps. Once you attend the ritual and witness its culmination, I swear next time one cannot resist to be a part of it. Over these years, I have only missed one Lakshadeepam. This year due to health issues, my son asked me to stay at home and see it live on television. But I emotionally convinced him by telling that I don’t know whether I will be alive for next Lakshadeepam,” said Malathyammal.

Nussrath Beevi, 55, from Malappuram said she has been witnessing Lakshadeepam since 1984. “My best friend Thara is a native of Enchaykkal and it was through her I witnessed Lakshadeepam for the first time at the age of 36. Since then, it is kind of a reunion to us and we attend every Lakshadeepam together. This time I took my daughter-in-law too,” said Beevi.

For Kinjal Mehra from Maharashtra, who arrived at the temple along with her five friends, it was the crowd and the chanting of mantras that attracted them to the festival. “On Monday, we reached Thiruvananthapuram to attend my friend’s bachelor party in Kovalam. When we went through the area on Tuesday evening, we saw thousands gathered here for Murajapam. Through an organizer, we heard about illumination of one lakh lamps and didn’t want to miss this opportunity. But we failed to obtain entry pass, but are happy to see it from outside,” Mehra said.

Title: Nagpur: High court asks NMC, NIT, builder and discom to deposit Rs 40 lakh
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Representational image

NAGPUR: The Nagpur bench of Bombay high court on Wednesday directed Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC), Nagpur Improvement Trust ( NIT ), Maharashtra State Electricity Distribution Company Limited (MSEDCL) and Armors Builders to pay Rs10 lakh each towards expenses of its expert committee to study electrocution cases.

The HC also asked both civic bodies and power utility to recover the cost from violators who illegally constructed their homes flouting all rules.

The directives came while hearing a suo motu PIL based on TOI reports on death of 11-year-old twins Priyansh and Piyush Dhar and five-year-old Umesh Pande due to electrocution from HT wires in June 2017.

The experts panel is working under convener Gauri Venkatraman, who’s also president of High Court Bar Association (HCBA). The panel having experts from civic and power entities has so far submitted five reports which bared massive violation of rules.

In last hearing, the NMC informed that it had partially demolished 79 out of 432 illegal structures, whose portions were coming directly under the HT wires. It further informed that it has received as many as 16 applications from 22 violators who have expressed willingness to share the cost of remedial measures.

BJP MLA Sameer Meghe gets notice from court

Bombay high court’s Nagpur bench on Tuesday issued a notice to BJP’s Hingna MLA Sameer Meghe on a plea filed by former MLA Vijay Ghodmare challenging Meghe’s victory in the last year’s assembly polls held in October. He was asked to file reply before February 14.

According to petitioner, large scale bogus voting took place in Hingna constituency which helped Meghe win the seat comfortably. After researching the voters’ list, it came to light that almost 50,000 fake voters cast their vote in the constituency. Even after complaining to election officer several times, no action was taken forcing the former MLA to knock judiciary’s doors through counsels — Anand Deshpande and Alpesh Deshmukh.

Title: Kerala government to acquire 1,350 acres for integrated cluster
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Kanjikode industrial area in Palakkad near the proposed integrated manufacturing cluster for which land will b... Read More

Title: Rumours of action by police spark tension
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

A Delhi police barricade

NEW DELHI: Rumours of police action led to a near standoff between police and anti-Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA) protesters at Khureji village in east Delhi early on Wednesday.

A team of cops had reached the site following information about a scuffle between the protesters and another group which was supporting the implementation of the CAA. Upon reaching the place, the cops found that no such incident had taken place there. But the agitators suddenly started accusing police of high-handedness and this led to a tense situation for a while. Senior officers had to intervene to pacify the protesters.

DCP (Shahdara) Amit Sharma said that the matter was resolved immediately and there were no incidents of violence or attack on the policemen. “We have asked the organisers to maintain peace at the venue,” he said.

Senior police officers said that they are looking for a solution to avoid any further confrontation between the two groups.

Khalid Saifi, co-founder of United Against Hate, said that police had called him to enquire about the protest. “I informed them that the women of the village were the ones carrying out the protest, and then I came back home. Meanwhile, my wife had received a call from a protester who alleged that the lights at the venue were switched off and the cops were trying to break the tent. However, when I reached the site, things were normal,” said Saifi.

Sara Javed, one of the organisers of the protest, said: “We have been sitting here peacefully since Monday. On Wednesday, the lights suddenly went off. Women are staying here with their children and they got scared. Policemen tried to disperse us, but they left after we stood in protest.”

Title: Four arrested for enticing, robbing man in Thiruvananthapuram
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Representative image

THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: City police busted a four-member gang, including two women, who allegedly enticed and robbed men. Police identified the accused as Nazeer (33) and Aslam (25) of Beemapally; Sheeja (35) from Pallithura and Bindu (35) from Rajaji Nagar. Their arrests were recorded at Fort police station on Wednesday.

Police said the accused persons were arrested based on a complaint filed by a young man who fell into their trap. As per the complaint, the alleged crime took place on Sunday night. The women approached him as he was passing by Ajantha Theatre road and invited him into an auto rickshaw. As soon as he entered the vehicle, the two men in the gang attacked and overpowered him, while the auto was on the move.

The gang took Rs 7,500 and a mobile phone worth Rs 11,000 from the complainant and left him near Pulimood Junction on MG Road. He immediately approached the police and filed a complaint.

Police conducted an investigation, examined visuals from surveillance cameras installed along roads and identified the suspects. On Wednesday, police took them into custody. Police recovered the stolen money and mobile phone from the accused. The arrests were made by a team led by Fort station house officer inspector AK Sherry, SI S Vimal and SI B Jaya.

Sherry said the main accused, Aslam, was involved in a few robbery cases. All the four accused used to roam around East Fort region at nights. Hence, police could identify them easily from surveillance camera visuals. They were taken into custody from different parts of East Fort, he said.

All the accused were produced in court and remanded in judicial custody later.

Title: Ban does little as kite flyers’ manja slashes and maims birds, animals
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Vikram Bhosale holds the manja in his right hand that the rescued eagle was entangled in

PUNE: Manja, the banned glass coated kite string, continued to injure birds and animals this Makar Sankranti , city-based wildlife and animal rescuers said.

On Wednesday, the Rajiv Gandhi Zoological Park and Research Centre was swamped with bird emergencies caused by sharp kite strings, a zoo official said.

Vikram Bhosale, a volunteer with Wildlife Welfare Association, Pune, on Tuesday rescued an eagle stuck on a tree after it had got entangled in kite string. The bird was later released.

“I got a call on Tuesday around 1.30pm about the eagle stuck on a 100-ft tree. It was entangled in kite string since 6am. The Chinese nylon manja had cut through its wing and stomach. I called the fire brigade, but their ladder could not reach the height. A woodcutter climbed the tree and lopped off the branch upon which the bird was stuck. We cut the manja and the bird was sent for treatment to the Katraj zoo,” Bhosale added.

He has looked into 16 cases in the last two days involving manja-related injuries to birds, dogs, cats among other animals. He also rescued a cat ensnared in manja in a building in Alandi on Tuesday and another dog entangled in it in Wagholi on Wednesday.

Veterinary surgeon at Indian Herpetological Society Suchitra Suryavanshi Patil, who works at the animal rescue shelter and snake welfare park in Katraj, told TOI that there has been a surge in manja-related bird injury cases since a month.

“We were swamped with these cases on Wednesday. Chinese manja is very sharp and is glass-coated. So it can easily cut through the bird’s wings and skin. We have been receiving cases of injured eagles and black shouldered kites, both Schedule I species,” she said.

Patil said the manja string had cut through the left wing of a black shouldered kite which had resulted in profuse bleeding. “We will have to take an X-ray to check for bone injuries as well. The bird’s survival chances are 50-50 as there has been massive blood loss,” she said.

Arvind Salve, another wildlife and bird rescuer, said he has been receiving over three to six calls each day since the last one month reporting manja-related bird injuries.

“On Wednesday, we tried to rescue a badly injured kite in Gokhalenagar. The manja had cut through her wing and the bird had been stuck on a tree for three days. The kite later succumbed to injuries,” he said. Most manja-related injuries are being reported in birds like kites, eagles, wild pigeons and crows, he added.

Title: Early start to H1N1 season, 40-year old Satara man dies in Pune
Content:
Representative image

It is still too soon to know how severe this season will be, but swine flu claimed its first victim in the city and the state this year on January 10

PUNE: It is still too soon to know how severe this season will be, but swine flu claimed its first victim in the city and the state this year on January 10.The 40-year-old man from the rural parts of Satara died after he tested positive for the contagion at KEM Hospital in Rasta Peth.Currently, a 64-year-old woman of Sangvi in Pune is critical and undergoing treatment at the intensive care unit of Sahyadri Hospital in the city.As many as six patients from Mumbai, Navi Mumbai, Thane and Pune have tested positive for the virus in Maharashtra between January 1 and January 13, this year.Symptoms of swine flu are similar to a common cold and people often take it lightly in the initial stages till it turns critical.In 2019, as many as 2,287 people in the state were diagnosed with the H1N1 infection. Of them, 246 people succumbed to the contagion, accounting for a significant mortality rate of 10% calling for vigilance and also initiation of early treatment for influenza-like illness, say experts.“Scientists at the National Institute of Virology (NIV) confirmed the presence of H1N1 virus in the man's throat swab on January 2. He succumbed to swine flu-induced acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) with septicemia around 5.50am on January 10. He was diabetic,” a doctor from the KEM Hospital said.The deceased man was from Nirgudi village in Phaltan taluka of Satara district. He had developed influenza-like illness from December 24.“Initially, he had fever and cough. Later, he developed high grade fever with breathlessness. He was admitted to KEM hospital in Rasta Peth on December 28. Despite medication, the man's condition kept worsening. He was also kept on ventilator support during the course of treatment,” the doctor said.Experts say that since the symptoms of swine flu are quite similar to common cold, people often don’t take it seriously in the initial stages until it becomes critical.“A swine flu patient usually suffers from a burning sore throat, abdominal pain and cough and the additional symptom of shortness of breath. These symptoms should not be dismissed and need to be treated under the supervision of a medical expert,” infectious diseases expert Mahesh Lakhe of Columbia Asia Hospital in Kharadi said.He recommended a quadriplegic flu vaccine shot before the flu season peaks, especially for those suffering from underlying medical conditions.

Title: Thiruvananthapuram: Rajnath Singh to inaugurate new Sukhoi fighter squadron
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Rajnath Singh

THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: Considering the increasing strategic importance of Indian Ocean Region (IOR), where all major powers of the world have established their bases, Indian Air Force (IAF) has decided to induct a maritime strike squadron – a fleet of Brahmos equipped Sukhoi-30 MKI – under the Southern Air Command (SAC).

Defence minister Rajnath Singh will dedicate the newly-resurrected 222 Squadron to the nation. It will become operational with Sukhoi-30 air superiority fighters, armed with indigenously-built BrahMos missiles, at the Air Force Station in Thanjavur on January 20, said Air marshal Amit Tiwari, also the Air officer Commanding-in-Chief at SAC, said on Wednesday.

Tiwari said it was incumbent upon the IAF to protect and defend ‘the IOR’s natural resources and the sea lines of communication for the nation’. “IOR, the third-largest waterbody in the world with a presence in 28 countries and 35% of world population, makes up 80% of seaborne oil transit. The region has many existing and potential conflict zones, including piracy. India, with a shoreline of over 7,500km and an exclusive economic zone of over 2.1 million sq km, has a huge stake here,” he said.

IOR has an important role to play in regional peace, security and prosperity, and IAF, an intrinsically strategic force, is all set to extend its reach, he added.

Initially, the new squadron under SAC will have four Sukhoi-30 MKIs and their numbers will increase, Tiwari said.

IAF, currently has 272 Sukhoi-30 MKIs (4th generation), ‘which are good as any other fighter’.

The Air Marshall said there were expansion plans in Thiruvananthapuram for which procedures are on to acquire more land. “The expansion could be realized in three to four years and this will be one major base from where we can operate,” he said.

Also present during the news conference were Group captain Prajul Singh, Station Commander, Thanjavur AF station and Group Captain Manoj Gera, Commanding Officer of Sukhoi-30 squadron.

Title: Rajkot: Cop’s revolver goes off while cleaning, kills man
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Police sub-inspector P P Chavda

RAJKOT: Panic gripped city’s GSRTC bus stand when a 30-year-old spa owner died after a cop's service revolver accidentally went off inside the police chowky located within the depot premises on Wednesday.

The incident happened at Shastrinagar where a temporary ST bus stand has been functional for the past one-and-a-half years in wake of the old one being renovated.

Senior police officials said at around 4pm, deceased Himanshu Gohel, who was a friend of probationary police sub-inspector P P Chavda and had gone to hand over tickets for the India-Australia one-day match to be held on January 17.

"Chavda told us that the revolver went off accidentally when he was cleaning it. The bullet pierced through Gohel's forehead and he died on the spot,” said N K Jadeja, police inspector, A-division.

Gohel, who lived in Vrundavan Society on Ankurnagar Main Road, ran a spa in Malaviyanagar Chowk.

PSI Chavda of 2017 batch was deputed at the bus depot police chowky for the past six months. Chavda was immediately detained in A-division police station and the revolver was sent for forensic examination.

Ravi Saini, deputy commissioner of police (DCP), said, "We are investigating the exact reason for the firing."

The bus depot is extremely crowded with at least 1,000-15,00 people being present, especially during the day time. A huge crowd gathered outside the chowky as the news of the firing and death spread.

Title: Pune: Court grants divorce to techie couple in eight days
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: A family court in the city on Tuesday granted divorce by mutual consent to a techie couple barely eight days after they moved the petition.

“The court relied on a 2017 Supreme Court judgment, which held that the mandatory six-month cooling-off period, the norm for divorce by mutual consent, can be waived,” said lawyer Vikrant Shinde, who represented the woman in the case.

“The couple, in the instant case, have been living separately for over a year-and-a-half before they decided to apply for divorce by mutual consent,” he told TOI.

Shinde said, “As of yet, there is no known case prior to this in which a divorce by mutual consent was granted in such a short span. A few months ago, we had a case where divorce was granted in 13 days. The SC directives provide that the first date of hearing of a divorce plea by mutual consent cannot be granted inside eight days. As such, this appears to be the least term in which a divorce order has come through.”

“The couple were working with a leading IT firm in Pune when they got married in 2015. Later, they shifted to Bengaluru. They have no children. The couple had differences over many issues and would often quarrel before parting ways on June 30, 2018,” he said.

“The woman has since returned to Pune and taken up a job with an IT firm. The man continued with his job in Bengaluru. On January 6, they moved the divorce plea and it came up for hearing on Tuesday before family court judge SR Kafre. In between, they also went through a counselling process,” he added.

Title: Flyers frown over delay of SpiceJet flight
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Photo used for representational purpose only

PUNE: A SpiceJet flight from Goa to the city was delayed by over two hours, leaving around 150 passengers stranded at the source airport.

The same aircraft was supposed to fly to Bengaluru from Pune. The delay of the inbound flight frustrated those travelling to Bengaluru, too.

The flight (SG517), scheduled to depart from Goa at 2pm, was airborne around 4.20pm and arrived in the city at 5.15pm. “The flight was delayed because of a technical problem,” a SpiceJet spokesperson told TOI.

“Many passengers were going to Pune or Bengaluru to celebrate with their families and the delay frustrated them. We were told that the engineers were checking a technical issue, which led to a further delay,” a passenger said.

Another passenger said, “The flight from Pune to Bengaluru was to depart at 3.35pm but it took off after 5.45pm.”

This story is from January 16, 2020
