Title: PAC aspirant dies soon after completing 2.4km physical efficiency test
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Bareilly: A 20-year-old girl fainted and died soon after completing a 2,400 metre run during a physical efficiency test (PET) for Uttar Pradesh armed police’s Pradeshik Armed Constabulary (PAC) entrance exam held at Bareilly’s Nakatiya on Wednesday.

The young girl, who dreamt of working in the police, has been identified as Anshika Singh, daughter of a farmer from Fazalpur village in Baghpat district. And not just Anshika, another girl fell unconscious in the middle of the strenuous running discipline and was rushed to a hospital. Her condition is said to be stable.

PAC commandant Vikas Kumar Vaidhya said that Anshika had qualified for PET but collapsed immediately after she completed the run. In PET, female aspirants need to complete 2.4km run in 14 minutes while male aspirants require 4.8km in 25 minutes.

Anshika had arrived for the entrance test with her father Ramveer Singh who was waiting outside the PAC ground. Anshika was healthy and physically fit and she had easily completed the race, but suddenly fell down on the ground. She was provided medical aid by the doctors present at the ground and sent to the district hospital where she was declared brought dead by the hospital’s emergency medical officer. Her body has been sent for autopsy. Anshika is survived by two younger brothers who study in school. She was preparing for the entrance exam for past two years.

Dr Jitendra Singh, one of the doctors who provided immediate aid to Anshika, told TOI, “Anshika suddenly collapsed and we rushed to take care of her. She did not have any pulse. We provided her CPR [cardiopulmonary resuscitation] and took her to the district hospital. She had died on her way to hospital. Another girl named Shalini Singh, 21, also fainted moments before completing the race. Her condition is stable.”

Anshika’s father told TOI, “My daughter’s dream was to wear a police uniform and she was confident of qualifying the physical test. I was waiting outside the ground when someone told me that my daughter fell ill after qualifying the physical test and she had been taken to the hospital. When I reached the hospital, I was informed that she has passed away.”

A total of 272 aspirants took part in the run on Wednesday where a girl collapsed just after crossing the finishing line, said PAC commandant Bikash Kumar Baidhya. “We had kept two ambulances and deployed trained doctors. The girl was provided medical aid but she couldn’t be saved. She had qualified the physical test and was a bright candidate. We have informed her father about her death,” Baidhya added.

Title: Rajasthan: Four arrested for smuggling arms in ambulance from Madhya Pradesh
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

The accused with weapons in Jhalawar police custody on Wednesday. The arms were meant for panchayat electio... Read More KOTA: Jhalawar district special team seized a cache of arms being smuggled in an ambulance from Madhya Pradesh, to supply for panchayat elections in Baran and arrested four at Teendhar-Mandawar Road under Mandawar police station of Jhalawar district on Wednesday. District special team (DST) on Wednesday noon seized 11 pistols, three country-made revolvers, four cartridges from an ambulance and arrested four notorious criminals — identified as Fogmal Meena (58), Hansraj Kushwa (41), Kasturi alias KD (26) and Morpal Meena (37) — all residents of Chabda police station of Baran district, SP Jhalawar Rammurti Joshi said. Acting on a tip-off about a huge stock of arms being smuggled from MP to Hadauti region, the DST, led by inspector Digvijay Singh, carried out operation on Wednesday noon at Teendhar-Mandawar Road where the team stopped the ambulance for checking, but the driver accelerated instead. However, the DST rounded up the ambulance at a distance, he said. The smugglers avoided Indore–Jhalarapatan highway and chose the route that had no police check posts. All the seized arms were sophistically manufactured with fine finishing and four of the nine pistols were marked as ‘Made in USA’, he added. In interrogation, it was revealed that one of the four arrested smugglers Fogmal alias Foggiya, while in jail at Chabda, came in contact with notorious arms smuggler from Gwalior identified as Mahesh Bhadoriya, who was lodged in Chabda jail, the SP said and added that Bhadoriya shared details of illegal arms network in Hadauti with Foggiya, following which he hatched the conspiracy of smuggling the arms from MP with three others of his town, to supply them in Baran for the demand of arms in panchayat elections.

Title: Udaipur: Shelter home in bad shape
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

UDAIPUR: The district and session Judge Ravindra Kumar Maheshwari deplored conditions at Ashadham Ashram, one of the City's destitute home for the mentally challenged people. Maheshwari accompanied by a team, including additional district judge Riddhima Sharma, chief judicial magistrate Brajendra Rawat and medical expert Sushil Kherada, HOD of the Psychiatry department of RNT medical college made a sudden inspection on Monday, also found that the shelter home failed to act as per government norms and failed to relocate inmates who had been living there for long periods of time.

Title: One of the four who escaped from Limbdi jail nabbed
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Ramesh Karu in police custody

Rajkot: Of the four under-trial prisoners who had escaped from Limbdi sub-jail in Surendranagar district on Sunday night, one was arrested in Dhrangadhra. Cops also caught the person who aided the accused in the crime.

Police identified the prisoner as Ramesh Karu, while his helper is Ovesh Pathan who has been booked for the crime. Karu, a native of Bhimasar village of Anjar taluka in Kutch district, was jailed in a suicide abetment case.

“Karu revealed Pathan’s name for allegedly providing him with a cutter. Pathan was arrested after this revealtion. Karu was arrested on basis of a tip-off about his whereabouts in Dhrangadhra,” said Deepak Dhol, inspector with Surendranagar local crime branch.

Karu along with Vijay Karapada, Mayursinh Jadeja and Dinesh Shukla had broken the lock of their barrack with a cutter and escaped at night.

The convicts made good use of renovation work inside the jail and escaped from a ladder lying against the 12-feet high wall. After climbing the wall they cut the barb wires with the cutter, provided allegedly by Pathan.

The four prisoners were booked on the complaint of jailer Parbat Goyal. There are 49 under-trial prisoners lodged in Limbdi sub-jail at present.

Title: Man whose son, niece were killed threatens to fast against UP Police
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Bareilly: A Dalit man whose niece was gang-raped and killed by three persons in 2012, and later his son was allegedly killed by the cousins of the accused, has now threatened to sit on a hunger strike at Jantar Mantar in Delhi.

The man was repeatedly thrashed and forced to leave Bareilly district. In 2019, he was allegedly beaten up and his wife was kidnapped and gang-raped by the cousins of the accused to build pressure on the family.

FIR was registered in that case but the accused were not arrested. Instead, police later booked him for raping the wife of one of the accused. The Dalit man was sent to jail but granted bail by court. Now, he and his family are being repeatedly harassed and threatened to reach a compromise in all the cases by the accused, who were all granted bail, as the court trial in gang-rape and murder case is approaching its judgment.

Police are yet to take any action and failed to provide any security to the family which is why he would be sitting on a hunger protest with family in Delhi from January 22.

The man visited the SSP Bareilly office and shared his grievances with senior cops. He told TOI, “My entire family is scared because the accused are repeatedly harassing and threatening us for a compromise. I was assured by the police that the accused will be arrested soon but no action has been taken so far.”

SP (crime) RK Bhartiya said, “The murder case of his niece is pending in court while the gang-rape case registered by his wife is investigated by circle officer Aonla. This case was registered at Bisalpur police station in Pilibhit district where the concerned circle officer had filed a closure report but the case was later transferred to Bareilly. We will look into the status of the investigation and take necessary action. The family can always seek security if they are threatened by the accused.”

Title: Seelampur: Which way will the electorate go?
Content:
The Seelampur assembly constituency, with a predominantly Muslim electorate, has been a Congress stronghold.

NEW DELHI: The lanes of Seelampur, with posters against the Citizenship Amendment Act and National Register of Citizens on the walls, are unusually quiet. Just a month earlier, the area in northeast Delhi had erupted in violence against CAA, in which 21 policemen and civilians were injured in stone pelting and tear gassing.The apprehensions about the intention of the citizenship laws remain. Abdul Wahab, 33, whose family settled in Seelampur in the early 1970s, said such fears existed, but believed this would have minimal impact on the Delhi assembly polls. The real issue is development.The Seelampur assembly constituency , with a predominantly Muslim electorate, has been a Congress stronghold. Former Congress MLA Chaudhary Mateen Ahmad, who didn’t lose a poll for two decades till 2015, is still a name to reckon with. Ahmad bucked anti-incumbency in the 2013 assembly elections, but couldn’t counter the Aam Aadmi Party juggernaut in 2015, losing to that party’s Mohammad Ishraq Khan by a big margin. AAP has replaced Khan with a fresh face—Abdul Rehman—this year.“Many improvements, such as flyovers came during the Congress government’s tenures,” Wahab agreed. “However, Arvind Kejriwal has done a lot of work for us in the last five years. The road in front of my house used to fill up with sewage whenever it rained, but the government increased the road’s height and improved the drainage system. The MLA doesn’t matter, we will vote for Kejriwal.”Aas Mohammad, 68, spoke of what mattered to ‘poor people like us’. He said, “Most families here now pay zero for electricity. The water quality was somewhat bad earlier, but both quality and supply have improved. This is what is important to us. The smallest saving in our monthly expenses means a lot to us.”The constituency has colonies of all sort — unauthorised, regularised and resettlement — plus a sizeable number of slums. Most people TOI talked to said they did have complaints about improper drainage and broken roads but were satisfied overall with progress in their localities.“Choked sewers are an issue in our area and though new pipes are being laid, it will take time,” concurred Jalaluddin, a resident of Jaffrabad. “But the AAP government has done a lot of other work. CCTV cameras have come up, many medicines are now available for free at hospitals and bus travel is free for women.” After some silence, he added, “The most important change in the last five years, however, is that no one asks for a bribe now.”The Muslim electorate is substantial, but there is sizeable Hindu vote in areas like Brahampuri and Maujpur. Naresh Kumar Sharma, a Brahmapuri resident, pointed out their own problems. “Sealing of commercial spaces is a big issue here. Many shop owners and their workers no longer have work. Many small household industries have also been terminated and though unauthorised, these did provide livelihood to many,” Sharma said.He acknowledged that roads had become better and streetlights had been put up. “This is a lower middle class area and what might seem basic facilities in other parts of the city are big boons for us,” he reasoned.The road from Brahmapuri narrows as one approaches Maujpur and vehicle speed dwindles. It doesn’t help that the potholed road is uneven and slushy. The sentiment also changes. “There may have been development in other areas but roads and drainage in Maujpur are in terrible shape,” grumbled Avnish Kumar, 33, who migrated to Maujpur from Haryana’s Kosi a decade ago.Another resident, Vinit Sharma, muttered, “The AAP government has only distributed freebies, but they haven’t come for free. They were paid for by the taxes we pay.” His assertive declaration: “This election, we are going to vote in Modiji’s name.”

Title: Imam in UP ‘bars’ CAA-backer from offering namaz at mosque
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Representative image

BAREILLY: An elderly man, who had purportedly backed the recently amended Citizenship Act (CAA), alleged that he and his son were barred from offering namaz by the imam of local ‘Chand’ mosque in Siraskheda under Mudhapandey police station limits of Moradabad district . The imam, however, has dismissed the man’s allegations.

Idris Ahmad has now approached the cops in Moradabad with his complaint. Ahmad said after his support for the CAA, the imam has threatened him with dire consequences, if he or his family tried to step into the place of worship. His son, Mohammed Khakan, was also not allowed to enter, alleged Ahmad. The imam claimed that Ahmad had some personal issues with him for which he was being targeted.

Notably, Ahmad reached SSP office on Tuesday evening along with his son and a few friends and demanded action against the imam. In his complaint registered with SSP of Moradabad Amit Pathak, he stated that imam Anees Miyan had been misleading the public on CAA, national population register (NPR) and national register of citizens (NRC). “The imam also instigated locals with his anti-national sermons in the mosque,” Ahmad alleged. SP (city) Amit Kumar Anand said that they were probing the matter.

On Wednesday, the imam made counter allegations, “I have certain differences over theological matters with him. We had an argument once and his son was also present. Upon confronting them, his son started manhandling me.” He also clarified that nobody was stopped from entering the Chand mosque to offer namaz.

Inspector Shakti Singh, the house officer at Mudhapandey police station, said that both complainant and the imam have been asked to pay them a visit on Thursday. “Prima facie, it seems the issue is more about some personal grudge,” Singh added.

Title: 2 detained in double murder case
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Bijnor: A day after two missing brothers – aged 23 and 16 years – were found murdered, police have detained two men for interrogation on Wednesday.

What initially looked like gun shots were found to be injuries due to repeated stabbing with sharp-edged weapons in the postmortem report.

According to sources, two men — Ankit and his friend Salman — were picked up by police on Wednesday in connection with the murders. One of them is a relative of the girl who had earlier filed a harassment case against one of the brothers. Police said that the accused have confessed to the crime.

City superintendent of police Lakshmi Nivas Mishra said, “We have detained two persons in connection with the double murder case at Baankpur village. The deceased were identified as Shubham and Ashish. The former had two cases against him including one related to harassment.”

“We have detained two persons — Ankit and Salman. They have confessed to the crime. The cause of murder is yet to be ascertained. We suspect that more people are involved. The interrogation is going on as they are changing their statements again and again,” he added.

Title: Science-oriented trips must for students: CM
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Panaji: CM Pramod Sawant urged teachers to organise science, technology and research-oriented field trips for students, so children get early exposure and are able to develop an interest in science. He was speaking at the inaugural of the 5th edition of SCI-FFI ( Science Film Festival of India) 2020 organised by Vidnyan Parishad, Goa on Wednesday.

Sawant lauded the work by Vidnyan Parishad, Goa, a unit of Vigyan Bharati, and said science film festival was the need of the hour.

“Science films are a very easy and effective medium to further the cause of science as it has the largest potential to attract students to science with the cinematic experience, visual effects and voice modulation that is fantastical and can feel real in the movie theatre,” he said.

Vice-chairman of Entertainment Society of Goa Subhash Phal Desai, chairman of Dempo Charitable Trust Shrinivas Dempo, director SRFTI (Satyajit Ray Film and Television Institute Kolkata) Dr. Debamitra Mitra, director IIRS (Indian Institute of Remote Sensing) Prakash Chauhan, and National Organising Secretary, Vigyan Bharati, Jayantrao Sahasrabudhe were also present.

Title: Corporators threaten to protest over inadequate water supply
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Kolhapur: Corporators from Rajarampuri and Shahupuri on Wednesday threatened to hit the streets with the locals if the civic body fails to resolve the issue of inadequate water supply .

During the Kolhapur Municipal Corporation’s (KMC) standing committee meeting on Wednesday, the corporators claimed that in Rajarampuri water is being supplied at low pressure for the last 15 days and Shahupuri has got no water for the last five days.

The corporators claimed the locals are angry and despite repeated complaints the civic officials are not doing anything.

Sandip Kawale, corporator from Rajarampuri, said, “Every time we ask the civic officials about the inadequate supply, they ask us to wait for some day. People are angry as they are not getting adequate water even for drinking. We are going to hold protests if the water supply situation does not improve in the next couple of days.”

An official from the water supply department attending the meeting said water level of Panchaganga river has declined and the civic administration has written to the water resources department (WRD) to release the water from the dams.

“The water level has come down. Letters have been written to the WRD to release water. Inadequate pumping of the water is taking place at Shinganapur and Puikhadi. The work of repairing the barrage at Shinganapur pumping station will start soon for which we have to stop water supply for at least two to three days,” the official said.

The corporators, however, claimed that a couple of weeks ago the officials had maintained that the WRD has started the release of the water.

Chairman of the committee Sharangdhar Deshmukh said, “The officials should take an appointment and meet the WRD officials on Monday. Some of us will also remain present and request them to release water. Work of repairs of the barrage and thereby planning for water cuts should not be done before the release of water from the dams.”

The water department official also claimed that the motors at Shinganapur and Aptenagar pumping stations have become old and need to be replaced. The corporators reminded the official that Rs 22 lakh have been allocated in the budget and asked the official to use the same for procuring new motors.

BHOPAL: Two days after a public post on Facebook against CAA and National Register for Citizen (NRC) by Mandla district collector another officer, a deputy secretary took to twitter to express his anguish over NRC.The officer, Niyaz Khan, took to twitter on Wednesday requesting the Prime Minister to give country’s citizenship only to honest people.He posted five tweets in the day….“Believe me, if that is executed with true heart, most of public posts with government authority will be vacant and honest citizens will get an opportunity to serve the nation.”“As a writer and citizen of India, I request the honourable Prime Minister to consider this point. Title: Mayonnaise maker Dr Oetkar eyes Rs 500 cr biz in India
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Kolkata: Dr. Oetker, the Euro 7-billion German conglomerate, is looking at Rs 500crore revenue from its Indian business in the next two years. The MNC which has global presence in food, beer, sparkling wine, banking, entered India in 2008 with spreads and pleasure foods. Currently, the India business of the company is at Rs 300 crore. It is present in peanut butter, continental sauces and other spreads.

Oliver Mirza, managing director & CEO of the company, said that mayonnaise is the biggest and top-growing segment for Oetaker and contributes over 50% of its revenue in India. Peanut butter has a share of 20%-25% followed by other products.

Mirza who was here to launch a variant of peanut butter pointed out that in 2008 when, the German MNC had entered India, mayonnaise was a Rs 8crore market compared to Rs 600 crore for Ketchup. “But, now mayonnaise has become Rs 300crore market while ketchup is now Rs 1,200 crore segment, so the growth of mayonnaise was much more,” added the Oetker MD.

He claimed that the company is the market leader in mayonnaise with over 60% marketshare, while in peanut butter, it has a marketshare of 20%. “These are two biggest categories in new age spreads,” he added. Incidentally Sundrop is another major player in the peanut butter segment.

Commenting on Kolkata market, he added that Kolkata is its 8th largest market globally and could become 6th largest in future.

Title: KMC to appoint expert to monitor solid waste processing plants
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Kolhapur: The Kolhapur Municipal Corporation ( KMC ) is going to appoint an independent engineer to operate the solid waste processing plants and install an online system for continuous monitoring of biomedical waste processing unit.

The KMC is operating several solid waste processing plants and according to a health department official, several technical glitches are being reported now. “The workers at these units and the administration lack the expertise to resolve the glitches,” he said.

Dilip Patil, chief health officer of the KMC, said, “We felt the need of an expertise to keep a close watch on the processing units. We are operating processing plant, slurry units and bio-gas units at several locations and require expertise of an engineer who will help us keep a watch on the amount of waste brought to the processing plant, the quality of the processing and the end product.”

He added, “We are also planning to sell the by-products generated from the waste processing plant. Marketing of the by-products will be carried out with the help of the engineer and selling the by-products will help the KMC earn revenue.”

The KMC is planning to set up bio-gas units at several locations in the city as part of its decentralisation of the waste processing. The engineer will have to ensure proper running and check the wear and tear of the machineries in the plant. “Regular watch and speedy addressing of technical issues will reduce the time and inconvenience to the citizens,” Patil said.

Since the last two years, the civic body is operating the biomedical waste processing plant that is located at Kasba Bawda. The health department has also proposed to upgrade the machineries for processing of the waste generated in hospitals.

At present the waste is subjected to various processing methods such as autoclaving, incineration, disinfection and shredding. “We are going to install online system to monitor each of the process, the amount of green gasses emitted and keep tab on the amount of biomedical waste processed in the plant. The machineries and other systems too will be upgraded soon,” said Patil.

Title: Nationalist Congress Party chief to preside over Shahu Samadhi Sthal inauguration
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Sharad Pawar

KOLHAPUR: Nationalist Congress Party ( NCP ) chief Sharad Pawar is going to inaugurate the Shahu Samadhi Sthal , the resting place memorial of Rajarshi Shahu Maharaj, on Sunday.

Mayor Surmanjiri Latkar declared on Wednesday that Pawar along with the top ministers of the state government will attend the main programme of inauguration. The function will also be attended by Shahu Chhatrapati patron of the institutes set up by Shahu Maharaj and the members of the royal family.

The KMC has spent over Rs 6 crore over the memorial. Rajarshi Shahu Maharaj, the social reformer, had wished to have his resting place memorial to be built at the Nursery Baug. The bust of Shahu Maharaj placed under Meghdambari and the landscaping at the major attractions of the memorial.

“We have invited all the citizens and leaders to attend the ceremony. The functions leading up to the inauguration ceremony will start from Thursday. The events are planned after discussing with the historians. All the events will be held in public,” Latkar said.

The delegation of the KMC has led by the mayor has met Pawar twice to confirm his presence. The officers have been appointed to organise the events.

On Thursday, the students of KMC schools will perform several cultural programmes at Keshavrao Bhosale Natyagruha. On Friday, the art exhibition over the life of Shahu Maharaj will be held at Shirke Udyan and in the evening, shahirs (folk artistes) from the city will perform powadas (ballads).

“On Saturday, we will lead a ‘Shahu Vichar Dindi’ across various points of the city. A heritage walk will be held at Bhavani Mandap and will be guided by historian Indrajit Sawant. The sites and structures associated with Shahu Maharaj will be shown in the heritage walk. On Sunday, before the inauguration ceremony, a Shahu Samata Jyot, the torch lit at Shahu Maharaj’s birth place memorial at Kasba Bawda will be carried out to the resting place memorial,” said Latkar.

This story is from January 16, 2020

Madhya Pradesh high court (File Photo)

Title: Delhi: As JNU agitators pull in different directions, protests’ fate unclear
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

A section of students is learnt to be not very keen on continuing the protests (PTI photo)

NEW DELHI: The leaders of the protests against the hostel fee hike in Jawaharlal Nehru University complained that the increase was decided without consulting the stakeholders. Now they are being charged with the same offence by four independent councillors. This possible divide among the agitationists seemed to be confirmed on Wednesday when the JNU Students’ Union council meeting was postponed.

The letter of dissent was written by councillors Farhat Salim of the Centre for Law and Governance , Himadree Sonowal and Vishnu Prasad K of the School of International Studies and Afreen Fatima of the School of Language and Literature.

“We, the four undersigned councillors, have been forced to take out this pamphlet in deep anguish against the JNUSU following the press meet where they gave the call for ‘original registration’ (with just the registration fee). We are not members of the Left Unity alliance and we want to explicitly state how undemocratically the union has pushed through this mandate without any consultation with us or with the school faculty committee of various centres. The unorganised way with which information is being disseminated presently undermines the trust that students have put in their elected representatives,” the letter said.

The quartet questioned the union about its January 11 stand that students should only pay the semester fee of Rs 108 and Rs 120. “… by paying this fee a day scholar is put in sharp contrast with the campus residents who have to undergo a two-fold process of hostel clearance as well as semester fee payment. Non-resident scholars in a single click can now have themselves registered if they heed the JNUSU’s green light. In most hostels the total dues are inclusive of increased fees (hiked room rent) where distinguishing the registration fees becomes difficult. It goes without saying that a considerable section of students has registered solely out of the sheer confusion manufactured by the union’s message. Does a unilateral step as this one not affect the solidarity which this moment in our sustained movement against fee-hike requires?” the statement said.

It added, “… there remains no clarity on reconvening the IHA (Inter-Hall Administration) meeting at the core of the issue, the proposed 10% annual hike on room rent, demands for rescheduling of end semester assessments and facilitating a buffer period before examinations.”

Speaking to TOI, Salim elaborated, “When JNUSU said it would ask students to register, they did it without going through a democratic process. Many students said yesterday that though JNUSU seemed keen on ending the struggle, they were ready to continue. There is also no clarity for those who are yet to register, while many facing proctorial inquiry are scared.” A call has been given for a sit-in by those facing such inquiries on Thursday.

A senior NSUI leader on the campus added that most student organisations, specifically the leftist ones, did not wish to continue the protests “though the students want to go on till the hike is fully rolled back”.

In response, JNU Students’ Union vice-president Saket Moon said, “All decisions will be taken after listening to the students and GBMs. We will call a council meeting to decide on these issues.” Regarding the uncertainty of students who haven’t yet registered, he said, “Students can still register in the middle of the semester.”

As for the pending proctorial action, Moon assured, “We will ensure the inquiries are dropped and that no registration will take place until those who have been named for questioning have their names dropped. The Union HRD ministry has asked the university administration not to take punitive action against protesters.”

Title: Kolkata woman’s biometrics used for forgery in Rajasthan
Content:
Representative image

KOLKATA: If you are asked to provide your thumb impression to buy a mobile SIM card, be careful lest you fall victim to identity theft. In, perhaps, the first such case in Kolkata, a 58-year-old homemaker from Bhowanipore was shocked when she discovered that her biometric data had been misused to obtain a SIM card and commit crimes in Rajasthan.The victim, mother of a college student from Chakraberia Road, lodged complaints with both Bhowanipore police and the cyber cell. She has now moved court, asking why the mobile service provider should not be held guilty for failing to protect her identity. A local court has now directed the Kolkata Police’s cyber cell to conduct a thorough probe, said her advocate Bivas Chatterjee.“Frauds using data and forms provided by customers are common. But biometric data theft is a sign that the data can be used for many other illegal activities,” said Chatterjee. Police refused to share details of the case saying it was an extremely sensitive case.The woman said that on January 2, officers from Civil Lines police station in Ajmer, Rajasthan, knocked on her door. An officer from Bhowanipore police station, who was with the team, informed her that a mobile phone had been used to carry out cheating and forgery and that the number was registered in her name. “On my repeated requests for further information, the Rajasthan cops showed me a copy of the forged prepaid customer application form. When they left, I lodged two complaints with the police the same day,” the woman stated in her application to the court.The woman recalled that on February 22, 2019, she had gone to a store on Sarat Bose Road to apply for a new SIM card. “The agent there asked me to provide KYC documents. He also asked me to give my register my fingerprint on a biometric scanner for verification prior to activating the new SIM card.“The agent — after taking a photocopy of my Aadhaar card — asked me to provide my fingerprints again, claiming that the first attempt was unsuccessful as the thumb impression was unclear. The gap between taking the first and last thumb expression was at least 10 minutes. Not suspecting anything, I agreed. I believe that is when the manipulation took place,” the woman stated in her petition. Investigators are likely to question the agent soon.An officer said that her identity had been recorded twice on purpose. Her identity was compromised at the source, he said. A total of 164 cases of fraud have been reported since 2011 across India on identity thefts.

Title: Photos at poll booths get one arrested, one booked
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Hyderabad: A voter in Jangaon town was arrested for taking a selfie while casting his vote. An official on poll duty complained against Sampath Kumar who was later arrested. As per norms, carrying a phone inside the polling station is illegal.

“After Kumar got his finger inked, he took the ballot paper. And while he was casting his vote, he took the selfie,” said an official on poll duty. A case has been registered against Kumar at Jangaon police station for violating secrecy. Telangana State Election Commission officials had already instructed voters not to carry mobile phones inside the polling booths.

In a similar incident, Nizamabad III town police booked a case against tiffin centre owner G Santosh of Nizamabad for taking the photograph of the ballot paper after casting his vote. “The presiding officer caught Santosh when he was looking at the photo in his mobile phone while leaving the polling booth. Based on a complaint lodged by the presiding officer, a case was registered against Santosh under the RP Act. “We have issued him a notice under Section 41-a of CrPC and asked him to appear for questioning,” Nizamabad III town SI Santosh said.

Title: Soon, Goa’s colleges will generate their own power
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Representative image

PANAJI: Work to fit solar panels atop all 33 government and aided colleges in the state will begin with Government College, Borda. The Goa Energy Development Agency (GEDA) has already carried out a feasibility report and has found the college buildings suitable for the fitment of solar panels.

First government colleges will be taken up for the work and then aided colleges, officials of the directorate of higher education (DHE) said.

Similarly, solar panels will also be installed at Goa University.

The idea is for institutes of higher education to set an example and create awareness among students and faculty about the process by switching over to a renewable source of energy.

As the government provides subsidy to solar power generators and users, it will reduce electricity costs for the institutes. The initiative will also help the state as it will reduce dependency on state power supply network.

The move is especially important as institutes of higher education are moving towards smart classrooms where gadgets are used in the teaching process, increasing electricity usage.

“Any excess solar power will be sold to the local state grid,” said a DHE official.

The scheme, known as ‘sourya sangath’ or friendship with the sun, will be implemented from the current academic year 2019-20 and will be carried out in a phased manner, officials said.

GEDA will bear the cost of the scheme’s implementation, accessing funds from central schemes. Currently, the ministry of new and renewable energy has central financial assistance of 15% in place for solar rooftop projects built under institutional category.

Such initiatives will also help institutes score brownie points during their assessment for National Accreditation and Assessment Council (NAAC) and if they choose to apply for a spot on the MHRD’s National Institutional Ranking Framework (NIRF).

Title: DM finds government schools’ furniture substandard, instructs DRDA to stop payment
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Bareilly: Chief development officer (CDO) Satyendra Kumar of Bareilly, on Wednesday asked the project director of district rural development agency (DRDA) V K Singh to verify furniture in all schools in the district that have been purchased with MLA and MP local area development (LAD) funds.

This, after district magistrate (DM) Nitish Kumar instructed the CDO to stop payment to suppliers till the survey is complete. Earlier, the DM, through his initiative ‘One Village One Day’ had identified anomalies in the execution of various projects at the ground level, in one of which, he found furniture newly bought with MLA-LAD funds for a school in Majhoa village to be substandard.

“The DM visited village Majhoa-Gangapur on January 11 and found recently-bought school furniture to be substandard. Thereafter, he instructed that all furniture bought for schools with MLA and MP LAD funds be verified,” the CDO said, adding appropriate action will be taken against officials if substandard furniture or other anomalies are found.

According to sources, several government primary schools in rural areas of the districts have bought furniture using MLALAD and MPLAD funds. It is learn that in some cases, the contract to provide furniture was given to suppliers who are close to MLAs and senior officials in the basic education department.

Officials said complaints were received from parents of kids studying in government schools of these villages that their children are forced to sit on the ground in chilling winter as the furniture procured could not be used.

The DM has said that to fix problems related to basic education and panchayat bhavans, he had decided to visit one village every day, so that he has all details of any village in question available first hand.

Title: Nirbhaya case: Litigant playing the system, says Delhi high court
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Delhi high court (PTI photo)

Title: Chief secy orders clampdown on illegal sand mining
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Panaji: Chief secretary Parimal Rai on Wednesday directed officials to ensure that strict vigil is maintained on areas where illegal extraction of sand takes place, and to keep a lookout for the transportation of the sand.

He issued instructions to various departments including transport, police, revenue, mines and PWD, at a meeting held at the secretariat to review the situation. Rai also asked the authorities to strictly comply with orders of the high court on the illegal extraction of sand.

The meeting was attended by the collectors (North and South Goa), the superintendent of police (North and South Goa and coastal), director of mines and geology, director of environment, director of information and publicity, director of transport and deputy director of the captain of ports department.

The control room/ helpline numbers for lodging complaints pertaining to extraction and transportation of sand/ minor minerals, 0832-2225383/2225083 for North Goa district and 0832-2794100 for South Goa district, were announced. Complaints can also be lodged on emergency services number 100.

The chief secretary directed the transport department to initiate action against owners of trucks and other machinery involved in the transportation of banned minor minerals.

Rai also asked the flying squads to be functional around the clock and the police were asked to conduct random checks in areas known for illegal extraction and transportation of sand.

He further instructed that the illegally extracted sand stacked on river banks should be put back in the river as per the directives of the high court, and the public works department to render assistance with regards to earthmovers and excavators to the police and flying squad as and when required.

Title: Bhojpur youth shot with carbine over Rs 1,200
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Representative image

ARA: An 18-year-old youth, Ankit Kumar Singh, was shot dead with a carbine at a village in Bhojpur district after the latter refused to pay the assailant Rs 1,200 for allegedly damaging his motorbike.

Furious over the killing of the youth, villagers caught hold of the assailant, 30-year-old Dharmendra Pal, a resident of the same village, and thrashed him. The accused was admitted to the Sadar hospital with serious injuries from where he was referred to the PMCH in Patna, police said.

Bhojpur SP Sushil Kumar said the carbine and an empty cartridge have been seized from the spot and a probe has been ordered to see if it was procured legally.

“Dharmendra was demanding compensation of Rs 1,200 from Ankit for damaging his bike during the village Makar Sankranti fair on Tuesday. We had assured him that he will be paid. But he arrived again on Wednesday morning and started asking for the money immediately and shot Ankit,” said a family member of the victim.

“Ankit was rushed to a local hospital at Tarari where doctors declared him brought dead,” the SP said.

Title: 12-year-boy running behind kite dies from drowning, many birds injured in city from nylon manja
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Nashik: A 12-year-old boy chasing a kite drowned after he slipped and fell in a well in the Sinnar area on Wednesday morning. The Sinnar police have registered a case of accidental death.

The deceased has been identified as Aryan Nawale, a resident of Sant Haribaba Nagar. The police said that children in the area were running behind a kite when Aryan lost his footing and fell into a well in a farm.

Soon after the incident, Aryan’s friends started shouting for help and local residents informed the fire brigade department in Sinnar. The firemen entered the water and took out Aryan’s body.

Meanwhile, the government veterinary hospital received several birds — three pigeons, one black kite and a cuckoo — that had sustained nylon manja-caused injuries. Officials at the veterinary hospital said that over the past three days, they had received a total of seven pigeons, one black kite and three cuckoos with injuries

The officials said this year, they had received more injured birds than last year. Ahead of Makar Sankranti, they had conducted a workshop with the ‘pakshimitras’ (friends of birds). During the workshop, the pakshimitras were sensitized about administering first aid to the injured birds and were also told to bring the birds to the hospital.

Dhanraj Chaudhary, the assistant commissioner of animal husbandry, said there could be more injured birds. The pakshimitras may have administered medicine to the birds before releasing them.

The fire brigade department said that they had also received five calls about entangled birds.

Ahead of Makar Sankranti, the city police had taken action against a couple of nylon manja sellers.

Title: Cal HC to get ‘Justice Clock’, will display case disposal
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Kolkata: The Calcutta High Court is likely to have a “Justice Clock”, which will display court rankings , based on their rate of case disposal .

The installation of Justice Clock in all high courts across the country was approved by the Committee of Supreme Court in its meeting on February 20, 2018. According to sources, the “justice clock” would be an electronic, LED display message board. This clock will show the ranking of all high courts as well as district and subordinate courts, based on their performance in disposing of cases. It will also highlight citizen-centric services.

According to the National Judicial Data Grid ( NJDG ), 22.8 lakh cases have been pending in various courts in Bengal. Of them, 17.7 lakh are criminal cases and 5.1 lakh civil cases. A total of 6.6 lakh cases, adding up to a percentage of 28.8%, have been pending for anything between one year and three years, while 4.9 lakh or 21.6% cases have been on the wait list for five to 10 years. Nearly 12,000 cases in Bengal are over three decades old. Calcutta High Court itself has 2.2 lakh pending cases.

Title: Come February, experience history like never before with guided tours of Fort William
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Eastern Command GOC-in-C Lt Gen Anil Chauhan at Fort William on Wednesday

KOLKATA: You may soon get to tour the Army’s Eastern Command headquarters at Fort William . On Wednesday, on the occasion of Army Day, Eastern Command GOC-in-C Lt Gen Anil Chauhan flagged off such a tour for select invitees. He said the tour will be opened to the general public soon.

An official said the first tour for the general public is likely to be conducted on February 2. The modalities are now being worked out and people will soon be informed from where they can collect passes for the tour.

“During the Vijay Diwas celebrations of 2019, we had opened up the war memorial — ‘Vijay Smarak’ — to Kolkatans who wanted to pay homage to martyrs of the Indian Army . We now intend to open up selected areas of Fort William to people interested in the history of the city. The history of Kolkata and Fort William are almost synonymous. This will be done through an organized, guided historical walk on Sundays,” Lt Gen Chauhan said after laying a wreath at Vijay Smarak to pay homage to martyrs.

The tour will be organized by an agency. Charges for refreshments that will be served midway through the tour are yet to be fixed. However, sources said that only a limited number of people will be allowed per tour to prevent rush and confusion.

“The new Fort William was constructed nearly 250 years ago after the old structure near the present GPO was sacked by Nawab Siraj ud-Daula’s troops. Unfortunately, history about this fort is sketchy, but we have tried to collate details from some books in our library and various other sources,” an official said.

Areas that will be made accessible to visitors include the famous Dalhousie Barracks that can house nearly 1,000 troops along with their equipment. People can also visit a cell where Netaji Subhas Chandra Bose was supposedly imprisoned for three days.

They would be able to get close to the 100-foot-high Ball Tower which was originally used for semaphore signalling to passing ships on the Hooghly. Later, a large ball was placed on top to mark time for the ships. The ball would be raised at 12.55pm every day and lowered at 1pm for ships to mark the time.

Visitors will also be taken to the magnificent Kitchener House, the official residence of Herbert Kitchener, who became commander-in-chief of India in 1902. The building was later used to house Lt Gen AAK Niazi of the Pakistan Army after his surrender in Bangladesh on December 16, 1971. There will also be a visit to the Fort William museum that has several interesting displays.

Title: DM finds government schools’ furniture substandard, instructs DRDA to stop payment
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

BAREILLY: Chief development officer (CDO) Satyendra Kumar of Bareilly, on Wednesday asked the project director of district rural development agency ( DRDA ) V K Singh to verify furniture in all schools in the district that have been purchased with MLA and MP local area development (LAD) funds.

Title: Vadodara: Man stabbed for stopping two from peeing in open
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Representative image

VADODARA: A labourer living in Angadh village on the city’s outskirts was stabbed in his chest on Wednesday when he stopped two persons from relieving themselves outside his house.

Yogendra Rathod (20) was flying kites at his house when he noticed two persons urinating outside his house. Rathod shouted at them from the terrace and asked the duo not to dirty the surroundings. However, the duo identified as Sanjay Padhiyar and Raghuvir Gohil hit back at Rathod.

As Rathod reached downstairs, the duo first abused him. Padhiyar then held him while Gohil thrashed him. When Rathod resisted the attack, Gohil took out a paper cutter from his pocket and stabbed Rathod with it in his chest. Hearing Rathod’s shout for help, his friends Yogesh Rathod and Hitesh came to his rescue. Meanwhile, the duo fled from there and Rathod was taken to a private hospital for treatment.

In the afternoon, Rathod registered a complaint against the duo at Nandesari police station. By evening the duo was arrested from their homes.

“The victim knew the duo as they live in the neighbouring Nandesari village and often visit Angadh. The accused also work as labourers and stabbed the complainant because they were enraged by his tone of not relieving themselves outside his house,” said a police official.

Title: GB to decide on blacklisting agency fixing streetlights
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

The decision over blacklisting the agency appointed to install LED streetlights will be taken in the Kolhapur ... Read More

KOLHAPUR: The decision over blacklisting the agency appointed to install LED streetlights will be taken in the Kolhapur Municipal Corporation ’s meeting of general body on January 22.

The standing committee of the KMC has recommended blacklisting of the agency. The earlier government had made it mandatory for the civic administration to get into an agreement with the agency to install 22,874 LED bulbs replacing the sodium vapour lamps.

The agency has appointed around 18 months ago. The agency claims that it has completed the task; however, the corporators are not satisfied with the work done and want the agency to be blacklisted .

A senior corporator of KMC, requesting anonymity, said, “In the standing committee, we had taken the decision about the wattages of the bulb to be installed on the poles. The more the road width and distance between the poles, more would be the wattage of the bulbs.”

“However, when we commute on the roads at night, black spots are created on the roads because of the installation of bulbs with less wattage. The black spots are one of the reasons for the accidents. We want action to be taken against the agency for not abiding with the agreement and neglecting the suggestions of the corporators,” the corporator said.

The agency is expected to maintain the LED lights for next seven years. The agency has claimed that the move will help bring down the electricity bills of the KMC.

The corporators had claimed that at the end of seven years, the KMC will end up paying more to the agency that the amount the KMC will spend on its own to operate the street lights. The deadline for the installing the LED lights has ended on December 31.

In the standing committee meeting held on December 12, the corporators had demanded blacklisting. The corporators even claimed that the LED bulbs do not operate properly and they are not replaced even after registering the complaint with the agency.

A senior official of KMC requesting anonymity said, “The GB ’s decision will be referred to the state government’s urban development department. The state government had signed Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) with the agency and it had asked all the urban local bodies to sign up the agency to install the LED lights in their jurisdiction. If the decision is taken for KMC, it may have ramifications for all other civic bodies that had signed up with agency”

Title: Woman helps cops nab her stalker near Mandvi
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Vadodara: A 48-year-old woman living on Old Padra Road used her presence of mind to stave off a stalker near Mandvi on Tuesday. Cops arrested 19-year-old Mahesh Mali for stalking the woman.

In her complaint, the woman said she was waiting for an auto-rickshaw near Mandvi after offering prayers at a temple. Mali, a resident of Wadi, approached her and asked if she would like to befriend him. The woman told the police that caught off guard, the youth’s proposal stunned her.

But she knew that he was up to some mischief and in order to get him arrested, she continued conversing with him. She also took his mobile number and gave a miss call to keep him engaged.

According to the police, shops on MG Road were closed and the road was also deserted due to Uttarayan and so the woman couldn’t seek help from anywhere. However, she noticed some cops near Mandvi and walked towards them. Sensing trouble, accused fled away. A few minutes later, the woman received a call from Mali asking her what she told the cops. The woman made up an excuse and believing her the accused asked her to meet him near old Sadhana Talkies. She agreed but also informed her son about the happenings so far and asked him to reach Sadhana Talkies. Mali in the meantime kept pestering her whether she was coming or not. After she reached the spot, he too reached there five minutes later. Here, he asked her about her family and who all lives with her. He also asked her if she would like to accompany him to a hotel, she told the cops.

However, before she could respond to his proposal, her son arrived at the scene along with two cops from Wadi police station. Cops took the accused to the police station where statements of both of them were taken. Later Mali was handed over to city police station where an offence of stalking was registered against him.

Title: Illegal hoardings: Mirajkar Tickti shopowners lock horns with KMC
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

KOLHAPUR: Shopowners from Mirajkar Tickti obstructed the civic body’s action of removing the illegal hoardings .

A couple of days ago, the Kolhapur Municipal Corporation (KMC) had instructed the shopowners to remove the illegal hoardings on their own. However, very few shopowners responded to the appeal. The KMC then decided to remove the hoardings and fine the shop owners as per the provisions in the Defacement of the Public Property Act. Shop owners can be fined up to Rs 5,000 and they may have police complaints lodged against them too.

A senior official of the estate department, requesting anonymity, said, “We do not allow the hoardings at locations that can obstruct vision of the public or damage public property. Our team went to Mirajkar Tickti to remove the hoardings. But some shopowners obstructed our staff and vehicles. We had police security and warned the shopowners that they will be detained. We had planned to remove illegal hoardings from other places too, however, the obstruction at the Mirajkar Tickti led to delays.”

The shopowners claimed that they had sought some time to remove the hoardings. One of them said the KMC staff damaged his shop while removing the hoarding, which was the major reason for the shopowner’s opposition. The official, however, said the notices were issued at least twice before initiating the action.

The official claimed that they will carry out the action at full force from Monday onwards.

Title: Delhi body slams IMA for trying to defame PM
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

PM Narendra Modi

NEW DELHI: The IMA’s statement demanding clarification from the Prime Minister over his alleged statement that top pharmaceutical companies bribed doctors with women drew a sharp retort from Delhi Medical Association (DMA) on Wednesday.

The office bearers of DMA said they strongly condemned the statement issued by Indian Medical Association criticising the PM as the very basis of the statement was wrong.

“Association of Pharmaceutical Companies has clarified that no such discussion took place at all in the meeting that was convened by the PM on January 1,” Dr Girish Tyagi, president of DMA, said even as others spoke about the misuse of the apex body of doctors by some of its officers for their partisan purpose.

“It is very deplorable that a few IMA office bearers for their political compulsions are carrying out a defamatory campaign against our Hon’ble PM which is against the national interest,” said Dr Harish Gupta, member of National Medical Council and a former president of DMA.

Gupta said PM Narendra Modi had discussed with top people in the healthcare industry about steps needed to take Indian healthcare to a new level in the coming years to benefit the citizens.

IMA had said if the government had details of the companies involved in supplying women to doctors, why it chose to invite them for a meeting in PMO rather than initiate criminal proceedings. The statement, which stood out because of its tough tone, went on to dub Ayushman Bharat, the Centre’s flagship health project, as a non-starter that is confined to government hospitals where treatment is in any case free.

But DMA said, “We applaud the efforts of our PM in reducing prices of drugs, stents, implants, opening Jan Aushadhi Kendras and bringing Ayushmaan Bharat for the welfare of our nation.”

Some members also pointed out how IMA had been issuing statements without due diligence. “IMA had issued a statement condemning the attack on doctors and nurses who went to attend to the injured students at JNU. They had demanded the home ministry to ensure security in such cases. Later, none of the medical professionals levelling such allegations was found to be working in any official capacity,” Dr Tyagi said.

Title: Muslim women start stir in Rampur to demand release of anti-CAA protesters
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Rampur: Similar to several women-led anti-CAA protests across the country, around 200 Muslim women of UP’s Rampur have now assembled at the city’s historical Jama Masjid to protest against the local police and administrative officials.

The women have remained at the protest venue for over 48 hours. They are raising their voices against the alleged police atrocities and demanding an immediate release of their family members and the “innocent protesters” of the anti-CAA violence on December 21. The women protesters had also taken up the issue with the local imam and other ulemas.

Rampur district magistrate Aunjaneya Kumar Singh (DM) told TOI on Wednesday, “A protest is going on inside the Jama Masjid. The people are still being instigated by those who were behind the December 21 violence. We have collected enough materials as well as scientific evidence.”

“When we had asked the Jama Masjid committee to send us a list of the innocent protesters, they had actually sent names of all those accused persons against whom we have evidence. The people were all involved in the crime. So, this makes the task of investigating officer difficult, especially to initiate the process under section 169 CrPC,” added the DM.

The DM further said, “I am working around the clock with the police and other administrative officials so that the innocent people can be released from jail.”

On registering section 302 (murder) and 307 (attempt to murder) against more than 2,000 protesters when the postmortem report of deceased’s Faiz Khan, an alleged protester, revealed that he died due to gunshot injury, the DM said, “We have found evidence against some of the offenders who were involved in Faiz Khan’s death. We have instructed police officials that murder charges should not be slapped against any innocent people. They should be granted bail. People should not be charged without any proof.”

Rampur Jama Masjid committee secretary Mukarram Inayti said, “The police and the administrative officials had assured us that those who were found to be innocent during the probe will be released under section 169 CrPC after the application of release is produced by investigating officer.”

He added that the matter related to the protesters’ release is still pending.

One of the protesters, Soni, said, “My 20-year-old brother Rahil was arrested and sent to jail illegally by the police.”

Social activist Faisal Khan Lala said, “A list of 13 people who were booked and sent to jail had been given to SP Rampur Santosh Kumar Mishra and he had assured that innocents will be released.”

Title: Delhi: 60 per cent JNU students register for winter semester
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

File photo used for representational purpose

NEW DELHI: Jawaharlal Nehru University ( JNU ) registrar Pramod Kumar said that around 5,400 students of the total 8,600 had registered for the winter semester till Wednesday, the last day of registration . The last date is likely to be extended so that the remaining students can complete their registration.

Earlier in the day, officials of HRD ministry had spoken to vice-chancellor M Jagadesh Kumar and taken stock of the situation. “The university will be deciding on the date of registration, but we have asked them to take a considerate view,” said a ministry official.

More than 60% students have registered despite a boycott call by JNU Students’ Union. The administration claimed that classes had also started and the centres had uploaded their time tables. However, students of social science and language schools boycotted the classes.

To register for the current session, students have to clear the mess dues of the previous semester, library dues and pay the room rent for the next six months. They then have to pay the academic registration fees. A folio is generated and the students have to get it signed by the chairperson of the centre and dean and submit it.

There was confusion among students regarding registration as JNUSU had at first asked them to boycott it, but on January 11 told them to just register and pay the academic fees. However, on January 12, the union said the boycott was on as a few students were under academic suspension.

“In most hostels, the total dues are inclusive of the hiked room rent. Because of this, distinguishing between the different charges in the registration fees becomes difficult. A considerable section of students registered solely because of the sheer confusion,” a dissent note by councillors stated.

Title: GlobalLogic to recruit 300 more techies in city unit
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Nagpur: Software engineering company GlobalLogic, which has a unit in the Mihan-SEZ, plans to recruit over 300 techies in the city unit during the calender year 2020. Neeru Mehta, company vice-president, who was in the city, told TOI that the Nagpur unit at present has 600 techies employed, and there are plans to take the number to 950.

“Even with a conservative estimate, the fresh intake will take the numbers to around 800. The company has 8,000 employees all over the country, which will be taken close to 10,000 during the calender year,” she said.

“The company, which has its unit in the central building at Mihan , is now planning to take up larger space in the city too. The recruitment will be carried out on a quarterly basis, including the first quarter,” said Mehta.

With its international operations included GlobalLogic has 15,000 employees, with plans to take the strength close to 20,000 in the coming year, she said.

Mehta said the recruitment will be largely of candidates having around 5 to 10 years of experience, which means the compensation packages would also be on the higher side.

The company is mainly into product engineering services, that still has scope as compared to IT services.

Title: Sanskarinagari soars high with festive fervour
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Vadodara: Kite-filled sky at daytime and colourful firecrackers at night made Uttarayan extra special on every terrace party, on Tuesday and Wednesday. While the breeze played truant on Tuesday, kite flying enthusiasts were in for luck on Wednesday when there gentle breeze nudged the kites to soar high in the evening.

Festivities began early on Tuesday with most enthusiast hitting their terraces early in the morning. On Tuesday, ‘undhiyu’ and ‘jalebis’ remained the pick of the menus across the city with restaurants and shops doing brisk business selling the delicacies. Even those supplying from home kitchens remained busy throughout the day.

Fire crackers compensated the dull kite flying scene on Tuesday night and the atmosphere in the city turned almost into Diwali. Throughout the day, DJ systems playing Bollywood chartbusters dominated the scene.

The favourable wind made Wednesday a better day for kite flying with happy revellers aided by the wind soared high with their kites. With the evenings turning tad chilly, some even lit bonfires on terraces on both days of festivities.

Title: IITBBS to hike UG seats by 70
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Bhubaneswar: The Indian Institute of Technology (IIT), Bhubaneswar, is set to increase its undergraduate seats from 420 to 490 from the coming academic session. Officials said the institute took this step to help students from the economically weaker section (EWS) and women.

IIT Bhubaneswar director RV Rajakumar said, “We had 420 seats while admitting students last year. But this will be increased to 490 after adding 18 seats under the EWS quota and 52 seats under the women quota. We have already implemented the EWS quota.”

The new rule will apply to students belonging to seven schools of the institute. These include the school of basic sciences, school of electrical sciences, school of mechanical sciences, school of infrastructure, school of humanities, social sciences and management, school of earth, ocean and climate sciences and school of minerals, metallurgical and materials engineering.

“We will increase the seats of undergraduate courses. We have not taken any decision on increasing the seats of postgraduate (PG) courses,” Rajakumar said.

The institute has also started recruiting teachers. “The selection of 11 teachers has been completed so far. Once they join, the total number of teachers will be 151. Besides, we have started the recruitment process to appoint more teachers. The first phase of recruitment has been completed and the second phase will start very soon. I hope we get 20 more teachers this time,” Rajakumar said.

He added that the institute has always focused on good teachers for maintaining the quality of education. Last year, he had taken a decision to recruit more foreign faculty to bring international flavor in the teaching and learning module of the institute. In its first attempt, it had succeedein getting six foreign faculty for different subjects.

Title: CESU to snap power supply of defaulters today
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Bhubaneswar: The Central Electricity Supply Utility ( CESU ) will start disconnecting the supply of power to households that have failed to pay the electricity bill from Thursday. It is planning to snap supply of more than seven lakh of its consumers.

The move has, however, invited the wrath of the leaders of BJP, Congress and other parties. They argued that students, who are preparing for upcoming school and college board examinations, will face problem owing to lack of electricity. BJP state secretary Lekhasri Samantsinghar said the Class X and XII examinations of students of different boards will start from next month. “If the CESU were to disconnect the power supply from Thursday, how will the students prepare for the examinations?” she asked.

Congress leader Suresh Routray said he will protest if the CESU will snap power supply to the common people. “We have urged chief minister Naveen Patnaik to not disconnect power supply in villages,” he added.

Title: Tourists will curse Goa if we impose steep MV fine: Mauvin
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Panaji: A day after Goa transport minister Mauvin Godinho said the state government would not be able to reduce fines under the amended Motor Vehicles Act, he expressed fears that the steep fines would damage the state's already-fragile tourism sector.

The minister said that with Goa receiving as many as 75 lakh tourists a year, imposition of fines on tourists could hurt Goa’s image as a tourist-friendly destination. “If we fine them, they will curse Goa and they will not want to come again,” Godinho said. “Yes, they should follow the rules, but it has to be reasonable, and that is something I will try to convince the Centre about,” he said.

This isn't the first time Godinho has spoken about reducing the fines. In September, he said the government would reduce the fines under the Act as the government “didn't want to trouble our people”.

On Thursday, Godinho will head to New Delhi for a meeting of transport ministers, where he said he would ask the Centre if Goa could relax some of the fines.

“We will see if we, in tandem with other transport ministers, can ask the Union transport minister to relax some fines if necessary,” he said.

The 18th road safety council meeting and 39th transport development council meeting will see transport ministers of all states meet Union transport minister Nitin Gadkari to discuss improvement in the nation’s transport network.

Godinho said he had already held informal consultations with transport ministers of other states, particularly Gujarat and Maharashtra, who also expressed concern over the heavy fines being imposed on violators.

“I met transport ministers of Gujarat and Maharashtra and they all said that it is very harsh to implement, and that it has to be done gradually,” he said.

Godinho said that based on the Centre’s response, the Goa government would take a call on implementing the new MV Act . The minister said that he would inform the Centre why Goa chose not to implement the amended act with its steeper fines.

“After the meeting, at the next cabinet meeting, we will take a call on it,” Godinho said.

“Central laws cannot be circumvented. I took it on my personal self, which may not be 100% correct, but we had very bad roads, so bowing to public sentiment, we kept it on hold. I will tell the Centre that we have not implemented it, but that we are implementing it now, and also ask them if they will give us any leeway to reduce the fines.”

Title: Kolhapur district finally gets a guardian in Satej Patil
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Satej Patil

KOLHAPUR: Chief minister Uddhav Thackeray finally solved the issue of guardian minister for Kolhapur district by appointing Congress’s Satej Patil to the post.

Patil was earlier appointed as Bhandara district guardian minister against the wishes of Congress leaders. Vishwajeet Kadam of Sangli district will be the new guardian minister of Bhandara district. Maharashtra government issued a resolution to this effect on Wednesday evening.

Patil’s appointment has brought much cheer to the Congress unit of Kolhapur. His appointment to Bhandara district had surprised supporters. Kadam was the only Congress minister in Thackeray ministry, who was not given the responsibility of district guardianship.

The latest government resolution says it was making some minor changes in the January 8 order by which Patil was appointed as Bhandara district guardian minister. As per earlier order, Balasaheb Thorat was appointed as Kolhapur guardian minister while Patil was given the responsibility of Bhandara district.

Thorat, who is also holding the post of state Congress chief and is the revenue minister, expressed his inability to take the responsibility. Thorat has maintained that he was over burdened and would like to give opportunity to some other minister. Thorat had even expressed surprise over his appointment as he had communicated his decision to Thackeray.

Patil supporters were upset with the developments for two reasons. Firstly, he was not promoted as full cabinet minister and secondly , he was not given the responsibility of his home district.

Kolhapur also witnessed some political drama between NCP leader Hasan Mushrif and Patil. Both were claimants for the post and their supporters were indulged in verbal duals over the issue. Mushrif, however, continues to be in-charge of Ahmednagar district. Congress and NCP had strained relations over the issue but post went with the former as Congress has more number of MLAs in the district.

Title: January 5 probe: SIT quizzes JNU student
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

A glass gate is seen vandalized inside the JNU campus (File photo)

NEW DELHI: The Special Investigation Team ( SIT ) of Delhi Police on Wednesday asked Jawaharlal Nehru University student Dolan Samanta and alumnus Chunchun Kumar to join the probe into the clashes.

While Kumar did not join the probe on Wednesday, Samanta was quizzed for an hour. Both of them might again be called for questioning, as their claims are to be verified, police sources said.

Samanta, who was seen pointing a finger at someone inside the Periyar hostel, was asked why she had entered the hostel premises with her face covered and the conversation she was having with the person she was pointing her finger at, they added.

Kumar, who was allegedly seen pelting stones, will be questioned about the reason of their presence during the clash at the Periyar hostel, the sources said. He would be quizzed on how he had entered the campus and whether he was invited by someone, they added.

The entry logs at the gates are being scanned to find out the reference Chunchun had provided while entering the varsity. The person would also be asked to join the probe.

So far, police have questioned five students— Sucheta Talukdar, Priya Ranjan, Jawaharlal Nehru University Students ’ Union president Aishe Ghosh , Pankaj Mishra and Vhaskar Vijay Mech in connection with the clashes. Notices have been sent to others asking them to join the probe as well.

Meanwhile, a cyber and forensic team visited the university premises and tried to retrieve the recordings of the CCTV footage that was saved on the server which went offline on January 4.

The entire CCTV system at the university premises was affected due to the damaged server. “Once the server is shut down, it has to be completely reset after being switched on. Due to this, the data stored in it is likely to be affected. However, the cops are probing whether an automatic backup had been created,” said a senior police officer.

Title: Dengue cases on decline, courtesy cold weather
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Nashik: Dengue cases in the city have come down for the first time in the last three months.

In the first two weeks of January this year, a total of 26 people tested positive for dengue. In the last three months, around 60-65 dengue positive cases were reported per week from hospitals in the city.

Last year, as many as 1,125 dengue cases were reported in the city and two people lost their lives to this disease. A Nashik Municipal Corporation (NMC) official said that dengue cases have started to come down as rainfall has stopped and there has been no waterlogging in any part of the city.

“Moreover, during winter season, dengue cases are bound to go down,” he said. The city recorded 33% rise in dengue positive cases in 2019 as compared to the previous year (2018). However, number of people falling victim to this disease came down in 2019.

In 2018, as many as 844 dengue positive cases were recorded in the jurisdiction of NMC with three deaths. In 2017, the city had registered 949 people testing positive for dengue with no deaths.

A total of 68 and 82 dengue positive cases were reported in the first and second week of December 2019, respectively. Later, the total number of cases registered in the whole month went up to 253.

Last year, there were only 12 dengue positive cases between January 1 and June 30, but there was sudden outbreak from July onwards. The city had recorded 48 dengue positive cases in July and the number rose to 165 in August. In September and October, the number of positive cases was recorded at 117 and 207, respectively. The cases, however, spiked to 322 in November.

“Continuous rainfall with gaps between July and October were the major reason for rise in dengue positive cases. Such weather is favourable for creation of mosquito breeding spots,” the civic official said.

“Usually, winter begins from November, but it was not the case this time around. This had led to rise in dengue positive cases. We have already increased spraying and fogging activities across the city. We are also checking whether the contractor deployed for the work is doing the job properly and regularly,” he added.

Title: Existing contractor for illegal hoardings removal
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Nashik: The Nashik Municipal Corporation ( NMC ) is planning to continue with the existing contractor to remove illegal hoardings in the city.

Along with manpower, the civic body will provide gas cutter and other machineries to remove illegal hoardings. The contract of the existing the contractor has already ended and NMC administration has sought Standing committee’s permission to give month’s extension to the existing contractor as the process to appoint a new contractor will take time.

The proposal is to be tabled at the standing committee meeting to be held shortly.

During the last meeting, the municipal commissioner Radhakrishna Game had pulled up the civic officials for unable to remove illegal hoardings within the stipulated time. In reply to that, the officials blamed the lack of gas cutter and other machineries available to them. Game in return directed the divisional officers to purchase gas cutters which cost them Rs 1 lakh.

Acting upon the request, the civic administration decided to give a month’s extension up to Feb 4 to the existing contractor.

Presently, the NMC officials are busy with the Swachh Survekshan 2020 and they are expected to start the drive against illegal hoardings once it is over.

The present contractor had been deployed by NMC for two years between December 2016 and December 2018. Apart from this, the concerned agency had also worked twice in 2017 to raze encroachment in scrap markets along the Ambad link road in the city.

The total cost for the work provided by the contractor has increased from Rs 20 lakh to Rs 51 lakh. The the civic administration has also tabled the proposal to give additional payment worth Rs 31 lakh to the concerned contractor.

Title: Delhi: Moderate rain, thundershower with hailstorm likely today
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Moderate rain or thundershower with hailstorm are expected in a few pockets (File photo)

NEW DELHI: The minimum temperature in the capital dropped on Wednesday with the cold north-westerly wind continuing to come in from the hills. However, it will increase over the next two days due to a cloud cover , an expert said.

According to India Meteorological Department (IMD), Delhi recorded a low of 6.4 degrees Celsius, a notch less than normal and around four points below Tuesday’s 10.5. The maximum temperature settled at 19.9 degrees Celsius, normal for the season, said.

Track the pollution level in your city

The maximum and minimum temperatures will hover around 16 and 9 degrees Celsius, respectively, on Thursday. Moderate rain or thundershower with hailstorm are expected in a few pockets.

There was a slight decrease in pollution levels due to the favourable wind speed and the air quality index (AQI) was 218 in the ‘poor’ category, a marginal improvement from Tuesday’s 283.

According to Central Pollution Control Board, Delhi’s average PM2.5 was 97.5 micrograms per cubic metre at 8pm and the average PM10, 160.6. The safe standards for both are 60 and 100 micrograms per cubic metre, respectively.

According to SAFAR, a central forecast organisation, increased wind speed and fairly widespread rain are expected in the Delhi region due to the influence of the approaching western disturbance. AQI may improve to the ‘moderate’ category by Thursday, it said. Although the air quality may deteriorate slightly on Friday, it will remain in the upper end of ‘moderate’ to ‘poor’ categories, it added .

Title: Never asked anyone to describe me as Janata Raja: Sharad Pawar
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Sharad Pawar
