KOLHAPUR: A day after former MP Udayanraje Bhosale, who is a descendent of Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj , said that it was wrong to call anyone other than the Maratha king ‘ Janata Raja ’, NCP chief Sharad Pawar said on Wednesday that he had never asked anyone to describe him as ‘Janata Raja’.

Bhosale had on Tuesday condemned the publication of a book authored by BJP member Jay Bhagwan Goyal calling Prime Minister Narendra Modi as a modern day Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj. He said political parties were using the Maratha king’s name for gains.

Bhosale, without naming Pawar, who is often referred to as “Janata Raja” (a wise and aware king) in political circles, said Shivaji Maharaj is the only one who can be called “Janata Raja”. The former Satara MP, who had switched over to the BJP from the NCP, said he felt dejected about the release of the controversial book.

Addressing a function in Satara, where Bhosale recently lost the Lok Sabha by-poll to NCP, Pawar reiterated that Saint Ramdas was never a ‘guru’ of Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj. “Anybody, who has studied Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj honestly, will come to know that real title of Shivaji Maharaj was Chhatrapati,” he said.

Pawar added that Shivaji Maharaj was described as Janata Raja was Saint Ramdas, who was never a guru of the Maratha king. Pawar said Jijamata was the real guru of Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj.

Pawar said that a few people, who had pen in their hands, wrote such history.

Title: Two die after falling from terraces during kite flying
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Vadodara: Two persons including a teenage boy died in separate incidents on Uttarayan day after falling off terraces at their homes.

According to police, Karan Rathod (16), a resident of Sayajipura, was flying kite on Tuesday morning on the terrace of his building when the incident took place. Karan suddenly fell to the ground floor and died on the spot. Sources said that the teen was taking a selfie when he lost balance and fell off the terrace on the seventh floor.

However, police could not confirm if the deceased was taking a selfie or not. Police officials said that Karan had abruptly stopped studies and was hunting for a job.

The other victim was 45-year-old Narendra Jamdar who fell from a height on his terrace while flying kite. Jamdar, who lived at Shiv Niketan Society near Old Padra Road, fell at around 12.30 pm. Police said that he was taken to a private hospital, from where he was shifted to SSG Hospital late in the evening. Jamdar succumbed to his injuries at the state-run hospital at 9.30 pm.

Accidental death cases were registered at Bapod and JP Road police stations and the bodies were handed over to their family member after post-mortem.

Title: Cop worries come true, five die in Maheshtala
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Representative image

KOLKATA: Five helmetless bikers, including two call centre executives, died in two accidents in west Kolkata on Wednesday. While call centre executives Abinash Kumar Singh (22) and Amit Kumar Jha (23), riding pillion, died after hitting a stationary pick-up van at 6am on Sampriti flyover in Taratala, three people died when two bikes they were travelling in collided head-on near Bata post office. The trio has been identified as Rahul Anam (17) of Rajabagan, Amir Hamja (17) of Akra and Prince Middya (20) of Chandernagore.

During investigation, police learnt that Abinash and Amit worked for a call centre in Salt Lake Sector V. Witnesses said the duo was apparently returning from work early in the morning. They were riding from the Jinjira Bazaar end of the flyover towards the Bata crossing when the accident took place.

Shopkeepers who were just opening their shops below the flyover were stunned to hear a loud bang. Soon after, a tyre of a two-wheeler fell off the flyover and landed on a roadside tea stall, said locals who immediately informed Maheshtala police station. Cops reached the spot and shifted the duo to Vidyasagar Hospital.

Commuters who were driving along the flyover during the accident told police that both were helmetless. The front wheel of the two-wheeler came off after it hit the pick-up van. Police are investigating if the biker’s vision was hindered by fog. Diamond Harbour SP Bholanath Pandey confirmed death of five bikers in two accident.

Title: Bihar: Two excise men held for booze smuggling links
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Representative image

PATNA: In a first-of-its-kind case since prohibition was imposed in the state, two excise officials have been arrested for links with liquor smugglers in Saharsa.

Excise inspector Mohammad Faiyyaz Ahmed and assistant sub-inspector Virendra Pathak posted in Saharsa were arrested on Wednesday, while their district superintendent Mohammad Ashraf Jamal is absconding.

“The inspector and ASI were called at the police station for interrogation after which they were arrested. But the superintendent did not turn up. He will be arrested soon,” Saharsa SP Rakesh Kumar said.

The case relates to a seizure of 2,000 litres smuggled liquor from a truck in Saharsa town on October 12 last year in which the trio reportedly failed to follow procedure while producing accused in court in their bid to shield the culprits.

“An arrested accused Vibhishan Mehta was produced in court after a delay of 72 hours while production must take place within 24 hours,” the SP said.

“The judge was so furious that he refused to forward Mehta to judicial custody and instead ordered the ASI Pathaka, who was the investigating officer in the case, to explain the accused’s illegal detention,” the SP said.

“The list of seized items got prepared at 1.15am on October 13, within two hours of raid. The excise officers had entire day on October 13 to submit the FIR copy before court along with producing the accused. But nothing was done till October 15. The IO turned up in court with the accused on December 16,” the SP added.

Kumar said during an internal inquiry, it also came to light that the excise officers had held a press conference on October 13 and had taken names of three accused for their involvement in the case but none were named in the FIR.

“In addition, seized truck’s registration number mentioned in FIR did not match with the actual vehicle,” he said.

All these irregularities were probed by a team from IG (Prohibition) office. “Later another inquiry was conducted by Saharsa ASP and SDPO. Similar irregularities were found in the case after both inquiries following which orders were given to Sadar police station SHO Raj Mani to lodge an FIR against the trio,” he said.

Title: MMC bypoll: After FIR against seven Cong members, Moradabad police now book BJP functionaries
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Bareilly: After seven Congress members were on Tuesday booked under IPC section 307 (attempt to murder) for allegedly clashing with BJP functionaries during the bypoll for Ward 37 of Moradabad Municipal Corporation (MMC), police on Wednesday registered a counter FIR under the same section against several BJP members based on a complaint lodged by Congress functionaries.

On Tuesday, functionaries of both parties scuffled, severely injuring one member each of both the parties at a polling station under Majhola police station. BJP’s Rahul and Congress’s Anmol were admitted to the district hospital with severe injuries. They were later referred to a medical higher facility.

Majhola SHO inspector Rakesh Kumar said, “On Tuesday, an FIR was lodged against seven Congress members, including the party district head and its candidate. However, a counter FIR was registered against BJP members under the same section on Wednesday.”

The position of Ward 37 councillor has been lying vacant since the death of Nannu Singh Saini who passed away around three months ago. Saini’s son Deepak is the BJP candidate from the ward, while the Congress has fielded Surendra Kumar.

Congress district head Vinod Gumber alleged the BJP of deliberately creating a dispute during the polling. “After getting information about the scuffle, we thronged the polling booth and requested BJP functionaries to maintain peace. But, instead of maintaining peace, they started thrashing Congress supporters. It was a pre-planned move to create a dispute.”

Title: Aadhaar must for student scholarship: Higher edu dept
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Bhubaneswar: The state higher education department has issued a notification making Aadhaar mandatory for students to avail of scholarships under different state-sponsored schemes such as e-Medhabruti, Gopabandhu Sikhya Sahayata Yojana, Kalinga Sikhya Sathi Yojana and Fakir Mohan Bhasabruti.

The notification issued on January 9 said an individual eligible for receiving benefits under the scheme will be required to furnish proof of possession of Aadhaar number. “Any individual desirous of availing benefits under the scheme shall be required to apply for Aadhaar enrolment before registering for the scheme,” the notification read.

Officials of the department said it will offer Aadhaar enrolment facilities to beneficiaries, who have not yet enrolled for it. In case there are no Aadhaar enrolment centres in the respective blocks or taluks or tehsils, the department will provide the facilities at convenient locations in coordination with its implementing agency.

The department has also come up with a few exceptions to ensure that no eligible beneficiary is deprived of the scholarship in case Aadhaar allotment gets delayed. In such a scenario, the beneficiary can show his/her Aadhaar enrolment identification slip. However, the said beneficiary has to show any one of the documents including bank or post office passbook with photo, PAN, passport, ration card, voter identity card, MGNREGA card, kisan passbook with photo, DL, certificate issued by a gazetted officer or tehsildar, along with the Aadhaar enrolment slip.

Title: Goa to procure new vaccine from Unicef at Rs 1.2crore
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Panaji: The state directorate of health services (DHS) is expected to introduce a new vaccine—pneumococcal conjugate vaccine (PCV)—in the state in April . On Monday, the DHS signed a memorandum of understanding (MoU) with United Nations Children’s Fund ( Unicef ) for procurement of PCV .

A DHS official said the orders have been placed for procuring the vaccine and payment has also been made.

“With the introduction of PCV, the state will complete covering 12 vaccine-preventable diseases under the universal immunization program (UIP). It will be administered in three doses,” she said, adding that shipments are expected to arrive in a month or two.

The cost to the government for procuring vaccines will be Rs 1.2 crore. This has been in line with the Union ministry of health and family welfare’s request to facilitate the procurement of PCV for Goa at the Global Alliance for Vaccines and Immunisation (GAVI) price.

Unicef officials will arrive in Goa to examine the cold storage facility for the vaccines. The new vaccine however, will be released for use only after it has been tested. “Testing will be carried out by Unicef itself,” she said.

The DHS official added that they have appropriate storage facility and with regards to storage of other vaccines too, proper precautions are taken. Temperature monitoring is done to optimize vaccine potency and spoiled ones are discarded.

The PCV has already been introduced in some northern states with a high mortality rate. “The Goa government has taken the initiative to introduce PCV on its own and will pay from its pocket,” she said. In December, the cabinet gave its nod to singing the MoU with Unicef.

Title: RSS chief Bhagwat on four-day visit to Moradabad, Bareilly
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Bareilly: Rashtriya Svaymsevak Sangh chief Mohan Bhagwat reached Moradabad on Wednesday evening on a four-day visit during which he will meet RSS functionaries and address a gathering on Saturday.

According to Moradabad RSS spokesperson Pavan Jain, it is for the first time when Bhagwat is visiting Moradabad as the RSS chief. “Twelve years ago, the then RSS chief KS Sudarshan had visited Moradabad. During his three-day stay in Moradabad, the RSS chief will be presiding over a series of meetings with RSS functionaries. Senior office bearers from Meerut Brij and Uttarakhand region will also participate in the meetings,” said Jain.

On Sunday, he will visit Bareilly to participate in a function and also address a meeting of RSS workers.

Title: West Bengal: Cops shoot twin troubles of last year’s book fair
Content:
Representative image

To ensure book lovers visiting the 44th edition of Kolkata International Book Fair in Salt Lake are not extorted by auto operators, Bidhannagar Police has fixed fares of 21 routes around the venue for the 12 days of the fair

KOLKATA: If your were extorted by the auto driver on your way to the book fair last year and couldn’t even vent your frustration over phone to your near and dear ones after reaching the venue, rest assured that both the problems have been taken care of ahead of this year’s edition of the event.To ensure book lovers visiting the 44th edition of Kolkata International Book Fair in Salt Lake are not extorted by auto operators, Bidhannagar Police has fixed fares of 21 routes around the venue for the 12 days of the fair. After a meeting held with representatives of all auto unions, Bidhannagar Police has released an official fare chart and has asked the unions to stick to it.“We had received many complaints from passengers in last two years. This year, we have had a detailed meeting with the representatives of auto unions and they have agreed to stick to fixed fares. If any driver doesn’t comply with it, strict action will be taken against him,” said a senior officer of the Bidhannagar Commissionerate.As per the chart, fares from Karunamoyee to Ultadanga, Beliaghata, City Centre, Kakurgachhi, Phoolbagan and New Town have been fixed at Rs 15, Rs 12, Rs 10, Rs 13, Rs 14 and Rs 13, respectively. These are the usual fares on the routes but passengers claimed they are charged arbitrarily as the night progresses.“Post 7.30pm and during any major fairs or events, autos charge whatever they feel like. Even during the recently concluded Bidhannagar Mela, the auto drivers were charging Rs 25 for a ride from Ultadanga to Karunamoyee,” said Saikat Sen, a resident of DL Block in Salt Lake.Meanwhile, Bidhannagar City Police also held a meeting with representatives of all major telecom companies and have asked them to install temporary repeaters around the fair ground. “Every year, there is a major network issue inside the fair ground with people complaining of frequent call drops and book sellers having difficulty with card transactions. This year, the telecom companies have agreed to work together in managing the situation,” said an officer of the commissionerate.The state urban development department, along with the Bidhannagar Municipal Corporation , has started special maintenance work to spruce up the Central Park fair ground. The fair will start from January 29 this year. The preparatory works include improvement of the flooring, modification of the mela ground gates, relaying of paver blocks and sprucing up toilet blocks. TOI on Wednesday found that work has already started to set up stalls. Other renovation works include cleaning up the entire fair ground, fixing the printed world map flex on the Biswa Bangla globe on the pavement in front of gate 1 and other overall decorations inside the venue.“Work is on to mend potholes and repair uneven spots on the road surrounding the fair ground. The plot opposite the fair ground, which is used for car parking during the book fair, would be cleaned up,” said a senior official of the corporation.

Title: Police arrest footballer for running sex racket in Vasco
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Representative image

VASCO: A former footballer from Kerala along with his associate was arrested by the Vasco police for running a prostitution racket at a spa-cum-massage parlour in the port town on Tuesday.

Nidhinlal, a goalkeeper who has played for leading I-League clubs in the country including Mumbai FC, Shillong Lajong FC, Minerva Punjab FC and even Indian Super League ( ISL ) champions Chennaiyin FC, was nabbed by the Vasco police along with Shyni Joseph.

The raid was conducted after police received information that sexual services were being offered to customers at the establishment under the pretext of spa treatments. A decoy customer was subsequently sent and women were caught red-handed.

Three women — a local, a Nepalese and one from Sangli in Maharashtra — were rescued. Police said the accused lived off of the women’s earnings.

A case has been registered under provisions of the Indian Penal Code and the Immoral Traffic Act. Joseph and Nidhinlal were produced before the Vasco JMFC and were remanded in six days police custody.

A fortnight ago, Nidhinlal was in the news after he accused Minerva Punjab FC of not paying his dues for eight months and denying him the no objection certificate (NOC) that would have allowed him to ply his trade with another club.

The former goalkeeper has been residing in Goa for over a year now and claimed he started a saloon to make ends meet. He also said he was training children from the locality.

Title: Forest dept rescues female leopard from Sinnar
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Nashik: The forest department has managed to trap a five-year-old female leopard from Sinnar area in rural Nashik on Wednesday morning.

Many villagers spotted the big cat along with her male counterpart in the sugar cane field of Vinchur-Dalvi village on Bhagur road around ten days back. Although the six-year-old male leopard was caught a week back, the female big cat was still on the run.

She was finally trapped at around 5.30 a.m. on Wednesday at the Vinchur-Gavli farm of the farmer Ramesh Kanade. Earlier, the labourers working at the farm refused to work on the farm after spotting the cats.

Acting on the complaints by the villagers, the forest department had put up a cage on the farm last week.

The forest department officials conducted a medical examination in which the male leopard was found fit and healthy. The leopard was then immediately released in forest areas following some official paperwork.

Finally, after a week, the five-year-old female leopard was caught by the forest department. “After completing the medical check-up of the female leopard, she will be released in the forest area shortly,” said an official from forest department.

Lately, many leopards have been spotted in different areas of the district.

In November, residents had spotted leopards at four locations in Sinnar taluka of the district. The forest department officials had put up cages and managed to trap them and release in wild.

Residents of Sulewadi village, Harsul village, Kanambe and Vinchur Dalwi village in Sinnar taluka also witnessed leopards in their vicinity.

Title: Make NOC from us must for bldgs near airport: HAL
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Nashik: State-owned aerospace and defence company Hindustan Aeronautics Limited ( HAL ) has sought district administration ’s intervention to ensure that all highrise projects planned near the airport must seek a No Objection Certificate ( NOC ) from the company.

A meeting of HAL’s aerodrome committee, aerodrome emergency committee and airfield environment management committee was recently held with the district administration.

During the meeting, HAL officials reminded that since commercial flights operate from HAL airport at Ozar, all highrise projects coming up near the airport must get prior approval from the local airport authorities as instructed by Airports Authority of India ( AAI ).

The airport runway is 3.5-km-long, starting from Ozar and ends at Janori village. “We had a meeting with the district administration on safety issues. We are in discussion with them to make HAL’s NOC mandatory for construction of highrise buildings, but nothing has been finalised yet,” an official from HAL said.

“Safety guidelines for airports have been laid down by the AAI. It was just a primary discussion with the district administration. The height limit and areas where HAL’s NOC will be required is yet to be decided,” the official said.

The runway is in the east and west direction. “There are Janori and Mohadi villages on the east side of the airport that is a hilly area. Hence, there is not much issue on this side,” the official said.

“There is HAL township and Pimpalgaon area in the west direction of the runway. The issue of NOC will be only for highrise constructions on this side of the runway. Nashik city will not be affected as it is towards south of the runway,” he added.

The HAL will now prepare a proposal as per the civic aviation guidelines that will include the areas where the HAL’s NOC will be needed for highrise constructions.

Currently, TruJet and Alliance Air, a subsidiary of Air India, are operating flights from Nashik airport. Alliance Air is operating on the Hyderabad-Nashik and Nashik-Ahmedabad sectors, while TruJet is operating on Nashik-Ahmedabad route.

Title: Elephant attack deaths in state may cross 100
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Bhubaneswar: The human casualty in elephant attack in the current financial year (2019-20) is likely to cross the 100 mark, the highest ever since man-elephant conflict started becoming alarming in 1982.

Till January 12, 2020, 93 people have already been killed in the attack unleashed by the pachyderms. Last year (2018-19) till March 31, the casualty stood at 92. With more than two months to go for the current financial year to end, more people may fall prey to jumbo attack. This rate of human casualty is not even reported in elephant-rich Karnataka, where the average annual human casualty is 45.

Mostly in Dhenkanal, Angul, Athgarh, Baripada, Deogarh and Keonjhar forest divisions, the elephants have killed more persons compared to other divisions. The reason is that all these areas come under the three elephant reserves of Mayurbhanj, Mahanadi and Sambalpur, which accounts for 77.73% of total elephant population in the state.

In the three reserves, which have 18 divisions, the 2017 census had recorded presence of 1,536 elephants. In Dhenkanal division there are only 169 elephants, the second highest after Mayurbhanj district, which had recorded presence of 330 elephants in Similipal Tiger Reserve.

Sources said the one of the major reasons of the conflict is shrinking elephant habitat, resulting in them straying into human habitation in search of food. In the elephant-rich areas, the pachyderms move in herds and destroy standing paddy. The panicked and aggrieved villagers resort to chasing away the elephants using different means, which backfire.

The elephant show aggression and launch attack. Last year in July, forest minister Bikram Keshari Arukh told the assembly that 369 persons died in elephant attack between January 2015 and June 2019. Maximum deaths during this period were reported from Dhenkanal division.

Biswajit Mohanty, secretary, Wildlife Society of Odisha (WSO), a private body working for conservation of wildlife, said in many cases, depleting elephant habitats and transformation of land pattern in human habitation can be blamed for rise in the number of human deaths due to elephant attack.

“Lack of quality fodder is forcing pachyderms to leave their parent habitat and look for food elsewhere, especially in adjoining areas such as agricultural field in elephant-concentrated areas. This results in elephant confronting human population,” he said, adding the 14 elephant corridors identified are yet to be restored.

“If the government secures the elephant corridors, stop mining activities and building railway tracks, the elephant won’t stray into human habitation.”

The state has lost more than 1,500 elephants since 1990 due to reasons such as electrocution, poaching poisoning, gun shot, electrocution trap, train and road accidents and natural deaths. Despite repeated attempts, none from the forest department was available to comment on the matter.

Title: Goa: Fire services attended to over 8,000 calls in 2019
Content:
Representative image

The directorate of fire and emergency services attended to 3,061 fire calls and 5,714 non-fire emergency calls in 2019

PANAJI: The directorate of fire and emergency services attended to 3,061 fire calls and 5,714 non-fire emergency calls in 2019.Multiple fires at Sonsoddo waste dump in Margao , which took considerable number of days days, personnel, water and mud to douse, were among the major fire calls the directorate attended to.Firefighters were first called in on the afternoon of May 27. To stop the fire at the Sonsoddo dump from spreading rapidly, personnel had immediately sought reinforcement from Margao fire station and brought in additional firefighting tenders from Verna, Curchorem, Ponda and headquarters in Panaji .The massive operation involved eight fire appliances in rotation, 345 fire officials and personnel and 11,39,500 litres of water. In addition, it took 585 litres of microbiological-based enzyme and more than 600 trucks of mud to extinguish the fire that continued for nine days. The overall fire extinguishing operation lasted from May 27 till June 4 forcing the school in the vicinity to postpone its opening.Soon after, another fire erupted, this time, caused by contact with a high tension overhead wire, where a 23-year-old employee of the Margao Municipal Council suffered burns. Fire personnel were again forced to seek reinforcements from Margao, Verna, Curchorem, Ponda and from the headquarters to bring the fire under control.It took eight fire appliances in rotation, 67 fire personnel, 2,88,500 litres of water and 73 trucks of mud to extinguish the fire at the garbage dump which continued from December 5 till 7.With heavy rainfall lashing the state, the directorate assisted by naval personnel and Drishti personnel rescued 183 people from flood-affected areas in eight rescue operations in Usgao, Khandepar, Amona, Sal, Mopa, Dhargal, and Cansarvornem.Fire personnel also doused a number of boat fires. In Calangute, the owner of seven huts and four boats, which had caught fire, faced a loss of Rs 20 lakh. In Vasco, a fishing boat caught fire causing a loss to the tune of Rs 7 lakh. In Pernem, a house boat Bar Ca de Festa was had caught fire at Chopdem causing a loss of of Rs 50 lakh.

Title: JNU violence: It’s not me in video, says ABVP member
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Police say a probe is on to ascertain the identity of the woman seen in the grab

NEW DELHI: The National Commission for Women (NCW) has accepted a complaint from Komal Sharma , a 20-year-old Delhi University student, who has accused a TV channel of allegedly “defaming and identifying her as one of the attackers in the violence at Jawaharlal Nehru University” on January 5. While approaching NCW on Wednesday, Sharma also claimed that she had not been approached by the media company to confirm its information.

TOI had reported that the woman was identified by a television channel after a sting conducted by it appeared to show her admitting to her involvement in the mob attack on students and teachers of JNU. The channel claimed that in a mobile phone photo of the violence in the university campus, Sharma could be seen holding a stick but had her face masked with a blue scarf. Based on the claims made by the TV channel, the student, who is believed to be a member of Akhil Bharatiya Vidyarthi Parishad, was asked by Delhi Police to join the probe into the events of January 5.

While identifying her, the TV channel had played an audio clip purportedly of Sharma admitting that the mobile phone shots of her had gone viral. She was then identified by another student of her DU college, who claimed Sharma was her junior in school. The sting also showed her pleading with the senior student not to disclose her identity.

The senior student has not yet stepped forward to confirm that the conversation between Sharma and her actually took place. The cops will probe this as well.

Police have not named the woman, though it said it had sought the video from the TV channel and will scan it to establish the person’s identity. The video aired by the news channel will also be sent for forensic analysis.

Title: ‘Withdrawal of circular a victory for panchayats’
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Panaji: The government’s decision to withdraw the panchayat department circular is a victory for panchayats and an admission by the government that the circular would not stand the test of judicial scrutiny, the Congress and the AAP said on Wednesday.

Opposition leader Digambar Kamat also welcomed panchayat minister Mauvin Godinho ’s decision to rescind the circular, which Kamat described as illegal.

“Our party had made this demand and it had to be withdrawn as it would have been struck down by the court and various panchayats were ready to approach the court,” Kamat said.

Chairman of Goa Panchayati Raj Sanghatan Joseph Sequeira also welcomed the development on behalf of the Congress. “This is a victory for the Panchayati Raj movement and the local self-bodies. We also warn the government not to play such gimmicks for the purpose of corruption,”he said.

AAP was also of the view that the circular violated the Panchayati Raj Act.

“The reasons adduced by the minister indicated that the government was convinced that the circular would not stand the test of judicial scrutiny and that the BJP risked alienating even their own panchayats,” AAP general secretary Pradeep Padgaonkar said. The party also criticised Godinho’s “intemperate language” against panchayats.

“The minister also says that the government will wield the stick against errant panchayats. He is not the schoolteacher to think that elected panchas are his school boys to wield a stick,” Padgaonkar said.

Our party (Congress) had made this demand and it had to be withdrawn as it would have been struck down by the court and various panchayats were ready to approach the court

Title: CRZ norms relaxed for Blue Flag infra at Miramar beach
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Panaji: Now, infrastructure like portable toilet blocks, changing rooms, cloakrooms, and solid waste management plants will be allowed within the Coastal Regulation Zone (CRZ) at Miramar beach . A new notification by the Union environment ministry has relaxed CRZ norms for Blue Flag certification shortlisted beaches.

The Union environment ministry has listed 18 infrastructural facilities that can come up “maintaining a minimum distance of 10m from the high-tide line (HTL)”, in the January 9 notification. The other amenities for which CRZ norms have been relaxed are shower panels, grey water treatment plant, solar power plant, purified drinking water facility, beach access pathways, landscaping lighting, seating benches and sit-out umbrellas, outdoor play and fitness equipment.

The ministry, with a view to protect and conserve the environment and control and abate pollution in coastal beaches and sea waters, had identified beaches for the internationally recognised Blue Flag certification, which calls for responsible and sustainable amenities and infrastructure development, cleanliness, safety and security services.

The CRZ norms also stand relaxed for CCTV surveillance and control room, first-aid station, safety watch towers and beach safety equipments, beach layout, environment information boards and other signages, fencing (preferably vegetative), parking facilities, entry gate, tourist facilitation centre. Any other associated facilities or infrastructure, as per Blue Flag certification requirement, can also come up provided the minimum 10m from HTL is maintained.

The project is already being opposed by some local groups and fishermen stating that work on raising infrastructure at Miramar for Blue Flag certification should not begin until the draft Coastal Zone Management Plan (CZMP) for Goa is finalised.

Blue Flag certification from the Foundation for Education, Denmark, is a voluntary certification, where countries have to meet 33 criteria for chosen beaches. It is one of the most stringent certification related to sustainable ecotourism development of beaches encompassing high quality standards of water quality, safety of beach goers, public amenities, sound waste management plans, focus on renewable energy and water conservation, environment education, information on biodiversity and beach ecology.

The central government is helping fund the creation of infrastructure at identified beaches to prepare them to meet the certification standards.

Certified beaches are known to have increased footfalls from foreign tourists due to their cleanliness and preservation of the natural beauty.

In India, states were asked to nominate a beach and Goa had nominated Miramar, after an initial selection of Velsao. Goa is the only place where implementation of the project is delayed and Goa is set to ask for extension from the Centre in the two-year period during which central government funds infrastructure on the identified beaches.

Title: Amazon to invest $1bn to digitise small biz in India: Bezos
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

DELHI/BENGALURU: Amazon founder and CEO Jeff Bezos said on Wednesday the US e-tailer would invest an incremental $1 billion to digitise small and medium businesses in India.

He claimed the investment would help boost exports of Make-in-India products on the online marketplace to $10 billion in five years.

Bezos’ announcement comes in the wake of The Competition Commission of India (CCI) ordering an investigation into alleged violations of competition law by India’s largest online retailers, including Amazon and Flipkart .

Indian sellers on Amazon India platform exported goods worth $1 billion in a three-and-a-half year period ending May 2019, according to the company. Last year, Amazon India set a target of reaching $5 billion of exports by mid-2023.

“We are going to use Amazon’s size, scope and scale--we are going to use our global footprint to export $10 billion of Make in India goods by the year 2025,” Bezos said during an event organised by the Seattle-headquartered company in the capital.

As part of this exercise, Amazon will establish ‘Digital Haats’ in 100 cities, villages, and communities. These will provide services like e-commerce onboarding, imaging and cataloging, warehouse space, logistics, digital marketing, and compliance, Amazon said in a statement.

Amazon has emphasized that it is witnessing a steady rise in Indian sellers on its domestic platform selling more during major global events in the US, such as, Cyber Monday and Black Friday.

The company’s exit from China could also be a major reason behind its heightened focus on small businesses in India, where labour costs are relatively cheaper, said a senior industry executive, who did not wish to be quoted.

While the export target of $10 billion is ambitious, Ankur Pahwa, partner and national leader – e-commerce and consumer internet, EY India, said digital expansion through this initiative will certainly help propel the company towards the revised target.

“Globally, this is aligned to their small and medium business strategy which has been mentioned in their shareholder communications. They have a good commerce layer built already and this will help expand it further, including logistics, fintech and services,” he said.

Amazon, which launched operations in India in 2013, had committed an investment of $5 billion in India in June 2016, an amount which it has already surpassed. Bezos, whose personal net worth is currently pegged at $116 billion, has revealed his focus on small businesses even in Amazon’s home market, the US, where regulators are questioning the retailer’s dominance.

Title: Note on nods to mega projects withdrawn
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Porvorim: The state panchayat department blinked first as it withdrew a circular that had made it mandatory for builders of mega projects to approach block development officers (BDOs) and the department for construction nods and occupancy certificates instead of going to the village panchayats directly.

Though panchayat minister Mauvin Godinho claimed that the decision was taken to give panchayats a “second chance”, sources said that pressure, not just from the opposition, but from within BJP ranks, forced Godinho’s hand.

“We thought it prudent to withdraw the circular for the time-being, till we have our system in place, which means a technical cell and two more garbage treatment plants ready and MRF facilities in 90% of the panchayats,” Godinho told reporters at the ministerial block.

The panchayat department circular, dated January 7, had said that residential projects spread across over 200sqm have to submit applications for construction licenses and occupancy certificates to BDOs, who would inspect the project to check if it was compliant with garbage management norms.

Panchayats were up in arms over the move as they saw it as an encroachment on their powers. The real estate sector also expressed concern over the development as the circular could have led to an increase in delays and graft.

“I found out that this procedure will delay files as far as housing complexes are concerned. This will hit the real estate sector, which is the worst affected in the present slowdown,” Godinho said.

Sources said the chief minister’s office issued directions to the panchayat department to withdraw the circular, though Godinho insisted that he had not succumbed to political pressure. “We have not been forced by anyone. The government in its wisdom has decided to withdraw the circular,” he said.

He went on to say that the panchayat department was in the process of amending the Goa Panchayat Raj Act to introduce norms pertaining to garbage management and approvals for large residential or commercial projects.

“I can safely say there will be a proper system in place of the circular. Whatever we have to achieve can also be done by appropriate legislation and this means amending the Panchayat Raj Act. The emphasis is on managing garbage scientificallyand we have to move forward,” he said, adding that the department would release funds to all panchayats to set up material recovery facilities at the village level.

Title: District farmers to get five rotations of water
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Representative image

NASHIK: The district canal advisory committee under the chairmanship of district guardian minister Chhagan Bhujbal has decided that the farmers would be given five rotations of water through the Gangapur Left Bank Canal.

In a meeting held in Mumbai, it was decided that the allocation of water would be given before July 31st, 2020. The committee looking at the availability of water and the demand for irrigation and drinking purposes schedules the tentative dates for releasing of water through the canal – referred to as rotation.

Due to an extensive monsoon season, the committee decided to give five rotations of water for agriculture as the dams also had good water collection in them.

Given the demand for water for irrigation purpose, the Water Resources Department (WRD) has said that there is ample water availability in the reservoirs yet they are taking precautions in the water consumption.

The district collector Suraj Mandhare said that the water storage in the reservoirs across the districts was 65.4 TMC this year during October 2019. The irrigation would get 10TMC water out of the 12TMC excess water in the reservoirs this year.

The advisory committee has said that the two rotations during rabbi crop cultivation would be given through the Gangapur project. And three remaining during the summer which means there would be ample water and thus the availability of vegetables during the summer season this year.

Since there were very fewer rains in the year 2018, there was a drought in the district and the administration had cut down the use of water for irrigation purposes during the summer and it had also regulated the water being used for rabbi crops.

On the other hand, the Godavari Left and Right Bank Canals that provide water to Kopargaon taluka in Ahmednagar and Vaijapur taluka in Aurangabad districts will also get three rotations for irrigation and one rotation for drinking water. Similarly from Palkhed Left Bank canal water will be released once for irrigation and twice for drinking the purpose during rabbi period and during summer season one rotation is being reserved for non-irrigation and contingency purposes. If the rains fail to arrive on time, a rotation of water may be reserved for Yeola, Manmad, and regional water supply scheme for 38 villages.

Two rotations of water for irrigation from Ozharkhed dam and one for drinking purpose has been scheduled during the rabbi season, the WRD officer said.

Title: CRS nod delay may defer Majerhat date
Content:
Photo used for representational purpose only

TimesView A portion of the city, where about a fifth of its population lives, has been choked for several months now. Work needs to be stepped up.

KOLKATA: Whether the new Majerhat bridge meets its April deadline or not now depends on the civil aviation ministry and not the railways.The Commissioner of Railway Safety (CRS), under the ministry of civil aviation, has asked the state PWD to address some crucial construction issues before it approves the launching of the bridge’s superstructure over railway tracks. Delay in the CRS ’s sanction may push back the bridge’s commissioning further. The project has already missed its September 27 and December 31, 2019 deadlines. PWD’s revised internal deadline is April 2020.The commute lifeline for residents of Behala and beyond collapsed on September 4, 2018 and is being rebuilt since last January. It being a road overbridge ( ROB ), the structure needs the zonal railway’s nod at various steps. Certain approvals are also supposed to come from the CRS, which gives safety clearance to any railway project in the country.Last Friday, PWD, which is implementing the Majerhar ROB reconstruction project, gave a presentation to the CRS, which sought clarifications on how the structure would be under vibrations, on the precautions being taken for girder launching, design nitty-gritty of the cables—the ROB will be a cable-stayed bridge with pylons or towers on both sides supporting the deck—and finally, the instrumentation scheme. State officials said they would take some time, addressing the queries. “We may have to make an animation of the vibration analysis on getting accurate calculations,” a state official said. PWD must also prepare the ROB’s instrumentation scheme. TOI had reported in March that the bridge would be equipped with “instrumentation” or sensors to monitor the structure under static and dynamic vehicular load.Some time has already lost preparing the multi-media presentation. It’s been more than a fortnight since the commission asked PWD for the presentation on the Majerhat bridge construction as the latter applied for permission to start building the superstructure. The superstructure will be a continuous girder system spanning the railway tracks, built with the launched-girder erection technique or sequential erection of the girders, using high-capacity cranes.Last month, Eastern Railway (ER) cleared 22 designs related to this launching scheme, after PWD got them vetted by IIT-Bombay. But the final nod must come from CRS.

Title: Functionary of NDA ally quits Goa govt body to protest CAA
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Panaji: Vice-chairman of the State Minorities Finance and Development Corporation Ashma Sayed resigned on Wednesday as a mark of protest against the Citizenship Amendment Act ( CAA ). Sayed is a member of GFP, which is part of the NDA .

Sayed presently heads GFP’s women wing. She was appointed vice chairperson on the reconstituted body in October 2018.

“I have resigned as vice chairman, Goa State Minorities Finance and Development Corporation as a mark of protest against CAA,” Sayed tweeted .

The corporation provides loans and other assistance to members of minority communities for entrepreneurship and education purposes.

GFP was part of the BJP-led Goa government till July 2019 when its three ministers were abruptly dropped from the Pramod Sawant-led cabinet in order to make way for MLAs who switched over from the Congress to the BJP .

GFP has also opposed CAA and National Register of Citizens (NRC).

The Centre has introduced the CAA, which came into effect on January 10, to grant Indian citizenship to refugees from Afghanistan, Pakistan and Bangladesh, except Muslims, who migrated to India in a bid to escape religious persecution.

Massive protests have erupted across the country against the CAA and the NRC since its passage by Parliament in December last year.

A fortnight earlier, three Congress office bearers quit the Congress and joined the BJP in order to show support for CAA.

Title: Soaring kites, sweet til-gul, offerings to the Sun mark Mankar Sankranti & Pongal celebrations
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Nashik: Food, family and flying kites took the centre stage on Wednesday as people in Nashik celebrated the harvest festivals of Makar Sankranti and Pongal with great fervour .

The celebrations for the Maharashtrains had a distinct sweet note with til-gul (sesame and jaggery) being exchanged. People also took dips in the Godavari to mark Makar Sankranti — the day when the Sun begins its Uttarayan journey towards the northern hemisphere.

“The Sankranti festival marks several important things with respect to nature and the Cosmos. The Sun, after winter solstice on December 21, begins its northward journey and this is celebrated as sankrant (transformation) period,” Sanjay Khatale, a school teacher, said.

Meanwhile, the cloudy skies and a warm day failed to dampen the spirits of the kite flyers who started thronging terraces early in the morning. “I have been waiting for the festival for long. I bought a dozen kites about a month ago, but had promised my parents that I would fly them only on Sankranti. Today I am enjoying flying these kites,” said Krishna Nikam, a Class XI student.

Women prepared a mixed vegetable delicacy known as ‘Bhogi’. “It is typically a mixed vegetable dish, but the ingredients are the choicest,” said Sanjeevani Kulkarni. Made using carrots, fresh green chickpeas, flat green beans, tomato — generally all winter vegetables — the dish is the special preparation for the day and is enjoyed with millet bread or bhakri.

The Sun is also worshipped during the period as Ratha Saptami is celebrated 15 days after this festival. During this period, Suryanamaskar, a set of yoga asanas, is practised. “Suryanamaskar is the 12-count exercise and 12 names of Surya (Sun) are recited. It is the best exercise and this period is sort of a campaign for this exercise,” said Ramesh Kadam, a yoga teacher.

Members of the Tamil community, meanwhile, celebrated Pongal by making sweet dishes and offering prayers.

“Today is the first day of the three-day Pongal celebrated by Tamilians. The day beings with traditional prayers and sweets are offered to the Sun before it rises in the morning,” Kannan Murugan Pillai, vice-president of the Tamil Sangam in Nashik, said.

The people get up early, offer prayers, prepare special food and offer the same to the Sun god. Thereafter, people exchange greetings. Sweet Pongal or Chakkara Pongali (Telugu) or Sakkarai Pongal (Tamil) is the sweet dish prepared on the day with moong dal, ghee and jaggery. “The next day will be celebrated as harvest day. We will also have cultural programmes for the community on January 26,” Pillai added.

Title: PIL filed for Rs 1.5cr recovery from EDM fest organiser
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Panaji: A writ petition has been filed before the high court of Bombay at Goa seeking recovery of Rs 1.50 crore from the organisers of Time Out 72 Music Festival, which was held without the security deposit being paid, from December 27, 2017 at Vagator .

The petition also seeks directions from the court for a Central Bureau of Investigation (CBI) inquiry into the affair, which has led to a loss to the public exchequer.

According to the petition filed by Congress media convenor Trajano D’Mello, the three cheques amounting to Rs 1.50 crore had bounced.

“Permission to organise the music festival was given by the State Level Permission Committee (SLPC) on December 26, 2017 where it was decided that security deposit of Rs 1.50 crore, of which Rs 75 lakh to be paid upfront in the form of demand draft and balance amount of Rs 75 lakh as agreed by the proponents would be by post-dated cheque of December 29, 2017 latest,” D’Mello said in a statement.

D’Mello has also obtained documents through RTI Act to prove that the three cheques submitted by the promoter, 17 days after the music festival, had bounced.

Title: South Western Railway proposes underpasses for wild animal safety
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Margao: Apart from a number of road overbridges and subways for vehicular traffic along the Kulem-Vasco route, the South Western Railway ( SWR ) has planned several underpasses and canopy bridges to facilitate safe movement of wild animals . The route cuts across forest areas between Castlerock and Collem.

General manager of Rail Vikas Nigam Ltd, Shashibhushan Sahoo, told TOI that the work of planning and designing suitable engineering structures for animal crossing was under way as per the mitigating measures recommended by the Indian Institute of Science, Bangalore (IISc) which conducted the environmental impact assessment for the Collem-Margao railway line doubling project and submitted a mitigation plan.

The report suggests construction of some underpasses along the railway track on the stretch between Collem and Sonaulim railway stations owing to “concentration of gaur signs” in the area.

“Low fencing can be erected on both sides of the railway track at certain places to funnel smaller mammals towards an underpass. Specific stretches, except for high terrain, may also be fenced where needed to guide larger animals towards a bigger underpass,” the report reads.

To facilitate safe crossing of arboreal species like Malabar giant squirrel and primates such as bonnet macaque and South Indian grey plains langur over the railway track, the IIS report has recommended construction of a canopy bridge using low cost material. The report also suggests designing of appropriate types of structures for allowing animals of different body sizes to cross.

As regards the Collem-Kalay stretch, the IIS, in its report, recommended construction of one large underpass “considering the passage for large mammals such as gaur, and a “suitable engineering structure to allow animal funneling along the adjoining stretch to increase the chances of them crossing the underpass.” Two more underpasses, one for passage of small mammals and the other for passage of large animals have also been recommended.

“Most of the recommendations as regards to construction of underpasses and canopy bridges are being implemented along the route,” Sahoo said.

Title: Squatters have set up slums, shops on green belts: New sector residents
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

The residents alleged that squatters have destroyed the green belt in the area and have also illegally set up ... Read More

GURUGRAM: The residents of sectors 80-92 on Wednesday filed a complaint with the Gurugram Metropolitan Development Authority (GMDA) informing them about the rampant encroachment along the green belt in the area. The residents alleged that squatters have destroyed the green belt in the area and have also illegally set up makeshift shops.

The area houses several highrises that include Mapsko Casa Bella, Sare Homes, Royal Ville, Antriksh Heights, Vatika India Next and Lifestyle Homes and at least 10,000 families are residing there.

GMDA is responsible for the maintenance of the green belts in these sectors. “Encroachments on the green belts is growing at a fast rate. If they go unchecked, the will soon turn into permanent structures. Grocery stores, horticulture shops, smalls markets are coming up on the green belt, slowly turning into a commercial area,” said Praveen Mallik, a resident of Sare Homes.

“The green belts act like a protective layer against the dust pollutants. We need more green cover in the area. As these sectors are still being developed, lots of construction is going on here leading to dust pollution. Some of the vacant plots too have been encroached upon where slums and illegal markets have come up,” said Sandeep Kumar, a resident of Sector 88.

Another resident of Sector 91, Jasvinder Singh, said, “Even as civic agencies had carried out survey in these sectors for development and protection of green belts, no action was taken against the squatters.”

When contacted, GMDA officials confirmed that they have received complaints about encroachments in new sectors and are working towards a solution. “We will soon conduct a survey of the area and remove the encroachments. At present, we are working to develop the green belts in the newly developed sectors,” a senior GMDA official said.

Title: Ambad police arrest one, crack five break-in cases
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Representative image

NASHIK: Ambad police on Wednesday arrested a man, while detaining two juveniles, in connection with five house break-in cases committed in the past two months.

Police have also recovered stolen articles worth Rs 6 lakh from the suspects. “A case of house break-in was registered with us on December 22, 2019. The complainant in the case, a cushion maker, had lost cash and articles worth Rs 1.27 lakh,” a police officer said.

“Subsequently, we plunged into action to trace the suspects. While patrolling the Ambad area on Sunday at 6am, we came across two juveniles moving suspiciously near the Cidco post office. They were carrying sports shoes in their hands. When we stopped and asked them about the shoes, the duo said they had stolen it up from a house,” he added.

Later, the juveniles informed the police that two of their acquaintances were into committing burglaries and they are staying in the Pandav Leni area of Ambad.

When the police scanned the forest area of Pandav Leni, they found some clothes, sports shoes and beer cans. On Monday, police started inquiring about the suspects and got the address of a juvenile in Vaitagwadi slum area of Ambad.

“When the juvenile was detained and grilled, he gave the name of his associates and confessed to have committed burglaries in Bhagat Singh Chowk, Shivaji Chowk, Ashwin Nagar and Ambad MIDC areas,” the officer said.

Police then detained the other juvenile and recovered gold articles, LCD TV, two gas cylinders, copper wires and copper utensils and a pressure cooker. “We later arrested a 24-year-old man from whom we recovered gold jewellery worth Rs 1.15 lakh,” he added.

Title: Sattari locals to protest harassment by foresters
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Valpoi: Villagers of Sattari, under the banner of Sattari Bhumiputra Sanghatna (SBS), have decided to march to the forest department’s office at Valpoi on Friday to protest the harassment meted out to them by forest officials in Sattari.

At a meeting held at a temple in Caranzol late on Tuesday, members blamed the forest department for the tiger deaths at Golauli. “The department has been blaming people from the Dhangar community (for the tiger deaths), when it has not taken the matter seriously despite attacks on livestock by the big cat. This shows that forest officials are inactive,” SBS president Harishchandra Gawas said.

SBS member Antonio Pinho said a chargesheet had been filed against four active members of the group — including Gawas and himself — last year, after unidentified individuals set fire to the Mhadei Wildlife Sanctuary office at Kumthol, on May 28, the same day that SBS held a protest rally over land rights issues. “We have been issued summons to be present before the Valpoi JMFC on Friday. On the same day, SBS will hold a protest dharna in front of the Valpoi forest department office,” Pinho said.

Title: Traffic congestion becomes even more serious at Central Bus Stand after smart road construction
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

NASHIK: The Central Bus Stand (CBS) junction, one of the busiest in the city, has become even messier after the pilot ‘smart’ road project work.

Despite the junction being thrown open to traffic over a month ago, after the smart road ’s construction, incidents of traffic snarls have only increased.

The smart road project, which began in June 2018, is still underway. Currently, work near the Ashok Stambh junction has been taken up. However, the rest of the road has been thrown open to vehicular traffic.

While the place may visually look good, the smart works have done little to streamline the traffic on this busy stretch. Motorists coming from the Trimbak Naka side are finding it difficult to take a free left towards the Sharanpur Road from the CBS junction.

Many commuters said the footpath has been extended too much on the corners of the junction. As a result, the free left has become a 90-degree turn. To make matters worse, autorickshaw operators are also seen waiting for passengers right at this 90-degree turning.

Further, even the free-left from the Shalimar side toward Trimbak Naka has been blocked by an autorickshaw stand. Thus motorists from Shalimar are having a tough time taking a left from the junction.

A senior police officer said about three weeks ago, the signal at the CBS junction was opened. However, taking into account the vehicular chaos it caused, we decided to shut it down. The traffic officer said that motorists coming from the Trimbak Naka side and looking to move towards Sharanpur Road on their left, were continuously honking at the motorists in front of them at the road signal. The situation was the same even for motorists moving from Shalimar towards the Trimbak Naka side. In view of the huge chaos, the traffic signal was closed down.

Police commissioner Vishwas Nangare-Patil said, “A report about the problems being faced at the CBS junction will be sought from our traffic officers to take the necessary measures.”

The police said if needed, they would also speak to the officials of the Nashik Municipal Corporation to take the corrective measures at the junction.

Title: Love jihad making Kerala girls sex slaves: Church
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

KOCHI: Keralite Christian girls are being targeted and killed in the name of “love jihad”, the 28th synod of the Syro-Malabar Church has said.

“Many are even scared to use the term ‘ love jihad ’ but the synod has now come out and said the exact words. There are reports of Christian girls getting converted and taken abroad. They are not living an ideal pious life either. They are made to live with more than one person and some are even pushed into becoming sex slaves,” said Syro-Malabar media commission secretary Fr Antony Thalachelloor on Tuesday.

On Wednesday, the church said it would begin a sensitisation campaign against the issue through Sunday schools. Sources within the church said they were planning to use all their lay organisations to make Christian youth cautious about the “threat”.

Fr Thalachelloor said the recent incidents in Kozhikode in which a 19-year-old woman was sexually abused and blackmailed into converting and instances of Christian women joining Islamic State were examples that got the church worried. “It has also come to our notice that a Christian teenager was brutally stabbed to death after getting lured into an affair. Love affairs used to happen earlier as well, but the church cannot overlook girls, especially Christian girls, getting targeted and later murdered on the pretext of ‘love’,” he said.

The synod said if movements like “love jihad” grew stronger they would endanger communal harmony in Kerala . It pointed out that around half of the 21 youths recruited to IS from the state were Christians. “It is a concern that several girls who are not accounted for in official records are being used for terrorist activities through love jihad. Statistics show that love jihad is not an illusion. It is a sad fact that police are not taking appropriate action in complaints,” it said.

Synod, however, said that they don’t observe Love Jihad in a way that it would affect the friendship between religions in the state. It said the authorities should look at it as a menace that would negatively affect the society.

Title: Dhangar Samaj backs men held in tiger killings
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Valpoi: The Goa Dhangar Samaj Seva Sangh, Sattari has decided to support the five accused, all belonging to the Dhangar community, arrested in the recent tiger killings. President of Dhangar sangh B D Mote held a meeting with the members of the community at Dhangarwada, Ansulem in Sattari on Tuesday night to discuss the case.

However, it was resolved in the meeting that the Dhangar samaj will not interfere in the ongoing investigation by the government but they will not keep quiet if any untoward incidence happens with the accused in forest custody or if any harassment is done by forest officials to them.

Title: Three more arrested in attempt to murder and atrocities case in Dari village
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Representative image

NASHIK: The Nashik rural police have arrested three more people, including the main suspect , in the attempt to murder, sodomy and atrocities case that took place in Dari village — around 14-km from Nashik city, on Thursday night.

The main suspect, a 29-year-old resident of Mataji Chowk, and two others were arrested by rural police from Nandurbar district on the night between Tuesday and Wednesday.

A total of nine people had assaulted the two victims, who had gone to play music at the birthday party of the main suspect organised at a farm house in Dari village.

After the party got over, the suspects picked up an argument with the victims over sound quality of the music system and started assaulting them with sticks and belts. They also administered electric shocks on the victims through a battery like equipment in order to kill them.

After stripping the victims, they were forced to indulge in unnatural sex. Meanwhile, the suspects also made casteist remarks after they came to know that one of the victims belonged to scheduled caste.

The victims managed to escape from the place and returned home after the suspects had fallen to sleep. Later, in the afternoon they got admitted at the Nashik civil hospital.

By Saturday evening, a total of six suspects were arrested who were later remanded in five-day police custody. Under the guidance of SP Arti Singh, four teams were prepared and sent to Dhule, Jalgaon, Thane and Nandurbar districts to arrest the remaining three suspects.

Title: Higher milk rates sought as fodder becomes dearer
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Bicholim: Upset about the Rs 4 rise in cattle fodder costs, dairy farmers have demanded that Goa Dairy increase milk prices by Rs 4 per litre, too.

The farmers told reporters on Wednesday that the sudden rise in fodder costs would lead to losses for them. They demanded that it either be rolled back or the price of milk be hiked. “The government encourages people to take up dairy farming, but the reality is different,” they said, even as they sought CM Pramod Sawant’s intervention. tnn

Title: Petition for night public transport in Panaji support garners support
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Panaji: Over 100 citizens have signed a petition to Kadamba Transport Corporation and the transport minister, by Goa Road Safety Forum seeking public transportation at night in the capital city of the tourist state.

Public transportation is almost non-existent after 8pm in the capital city which hosts a slew of national and international programmes and caters to a large number of tourists.

The forum is pushing for KTC to start regular bus services between 7pm to 11pm along the inner roads of the city which will also connect residential zones.

The petition has also provided a set of routes marked on a map to connect major residential zones with important locations in the city.

“Panaji witnesses several events throughout the year. Several of these events are organised late into the night. Additionally, there are social gatherings and family functions which are mostly organised during the late hours,” the petition reads, adding that attendees are currently left with no choice but to use their personal vehicles.

Several businesses operate that operate late night too require secure and reliable public transportation for their employees. The buses need to have accessibility features as well as sufficient inner illumination for safety reasons, the petition states.

“The use of personal vehicles out of helplessness is resulting in a severe burden on the city in terms of congestion, pollution and overall disturbance of peace. The capital city of a state deserves much better public transport facilities than this,” says founder of Goa Road Safety Forum, Dilip Naik.

“Initially there may not be demand but once people know that public transportation is available late night, they will avail of it,” Naik adds.

The petition with over 100 signatures has been sent to the KTC chairman Carlos Almeida, transport minister Mauvin Godinho and Panaji MLA Atanasio Monserrate, among others.

“A service such as this will prove to be a boon to both locals as well as tourists and help in getting rid of traffic congestion,” the petition further states.

*

Too many accidents take place in Goa and so many people lose their valuable lives. There is an urgent need to do something.

Gustad wadia

Transport and connectivity also increases the economy of a region. Public transport buses should be run till midnight to and from Panaji from key inner roads.

Title: Cong asks CM to explain RSS’ role in independence struggle
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Panaji: The Congress on Wednesday chided chief minister Pramod Sawant for criticising India’s first prime minister Jawaharlal Nehru and asked Sawant to instead study the role played by RSS in India’s Independence movement.

Addressing a press conference, state Congress president Girish Chodankar said that Sawant’s statements had exposed the latter’s ignorance.

“When India got its independence, the RSS was sad because they wanted the British to remain in India. He (Sawant) should explain how many RSS leaders participated in the Independence struggle, and what was their contribution?” said Chodankar.

A day earlier, Sawant blamed the first prime minister of India for the delay in the Liberation of Goa. Curtorim MLA Aleixo Reginald Lourenco also expressed his disappointment with Sawant’s remarks.

“The statement is in bad taste and this speaks volumes of the status to make such a hollow statement. The world knows Nehru’s contribution to independence of India and later Liberation of Goa,” said Lourenco.

Meanwhile, Chodankar also called for Sawant to step down due to his inability to handle the state’s finances, resolve the Mhadei water diversion issue and restart Goa’s mining operations.

“He cannot control the state as he has not studied anything, whether it is finance, mining, Mhadei or law and order, and he should resign in the interest of Goa. He wants to blame Nehru for everything, and soon he will blame Nehru for shutting down mining and for Mhadei,” said Chodankar.

Title: Maharashtra: Two sloth bears rescued from Chimur farm well
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

A net was used to cover the well

CHANDRAPUR: Two sloth bears were rescued from a farm well close to Savri village in Chimur tehsil during wee hours of Wednesday after an overnight rescue operation.

The adult bears, male and female, leaping to pluck berries in the farm of Rajendra Nikose had accidentally slipped into the well having no parapet wall on Tuesday afternoon.

Chimur range forest officer Bhavik Chiwande informed that the well was partially closed and was out of use. After the matter came to the knowledge of Nikose, he informed range forest office.

A team led by RFO Chiwande immediately reached the spot. Rescue was quite easy as the well was just 10 feet deep. Putting a ladder inside the well would have solved the problem and bears would have come out. However, villagers were opposed to this type of rescue, he said.

The villagers claimed that the bear couple was roaming in the area for the last several days and people working in the farms around were terrified, said Chiwande. As the villagers wanted the foresters to capture the bears and release them in a distant jungle, they opposed use of ladder.

“I talked to senior officers in the light of new situation and they agreed to take up capturing operation. However, veterinary doctor refused to tranquillize the bears as there was some water in the well and the beats could have drowned. Hence, we covered the entire well with a net and bamboo mats and slid a couple of ladders inside. Cage was put at the mouth of the well in such a way that when bears come out, they have no other way but to walk into the cage,” said Chiwande.

The bears climbed out during the wee hours of Wednesday and were trapped into the cage. They were removed from the spot and released in a distant forest after mandatory medical examination, he told.

Patrolling team, staff of Special Tiger Protection Force and foresters of Chimur range jointly undertook the rescue operation under the supervision of ACF RM Wakade.

Title: Sankranti horror: 400 birds injured in Jaipur
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

A rescued bird being treated

JAIPUR: Over 400 birds were injured because of kite strings on Makar Sankranti on Tuesday. Throughout Wednesday, bird camps were held in various places with volunteers rushing to help save the avians.

In Jain Pakshi Chikitsalaya in Johri Bazar, more than 350 injured birds including eagles and owls have been brought to their hospital. “Their feathers have deep cuts caused by Chinese manjha that have glass coating. We have advised people to get the birds to our hospital as soon as possible to avoid blood loss,” said Pramod Jain, doctor at the bird hospital. Volunteers rescuing injured birds were ferrying them in boxes to temporary medical camps, but the baskets fell short as the number of injured birds increased as the day progressed. At Ramniwas Bagh bird camp by RAKSHA NGO, volunteers from all over the country were working all day operating the birds. “We have been getting calls for injured birds till late night. At around 10pm on Tuesday, we rescued a barn owl from Raja Park. We have two four wheelers and 15 bike ambulances working in the city. Since, our camp was organised on January 13, we have rescued more than 400 birds,” said Ushma Patel, avian medicine specialist.

Though the birds are grievously injured, strictness on curbing the Chinese manjha by police reduced incidents.

According to different NGO, as compared to last year, the number of birds injured have gone down.

Title: Zila panchayat chief shoots self accidentally
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Zila panchayat president Ajay Yadav, 28, was grievously injured after accidently shooting himself in the thigh... Read More

BAREILLY: Zila panchayat president Ajay Yadav, 28, was grievously injured after accidently shooting himself in the thigh with his pistol at his residence in Niyamatpur village in Shahjahanpur district on Wednesday evening.

He was rushed to the district hospital, where he was undergoing surgery to remove the bullet till the time of filing this report.

Ajay’s father Virendra Pal Yadav said, “The bullet was accidentally fired from Ajay’s pistol when he was sitting in the car and hit him in the thigh. Fortunately, the bullet didn't hit any vital organ. Doctors say there is no threat to Ajay’s life.”

Additional superintendent of police (SP-city) Dinesh Tripathi told TOI, “We rushed to the spot after getting information, where his family told us that the bullet was fired accidently. We have also recorded Ajay’s statement. He also confirmed that the bullet was fired from his pistol accidentally.”

Title: 12 structures razed for NH expansion at Guirim
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Saligao: The authorities on Wednesday demolished 12 structures at Guirim as part of the national highway expansion project.

The exercise was carried out in the presence of engineers of the National Highway Authority of India (NHAI) and the joint mamlatdar. A strong police force was deployed to maintain law and order.

Seven structures located along the stretch from Guirim to Panaji were brought down entirely by heavy earthmoving machinery while a portion of five structures located on the other side of the highway were also demolished.

Demolition notices were served in December last year to the owners of the houses that were demarcated for demolition. They were told to vacate the structures.

Those affected were supported by the local panchayat and Saligao MLA Jayesh Salgaonkar.

“The affected people were promised rehabilitation. But the demolition was carried out beforehand,” Salgaonkar said.

The four- and six-laning project is part of the Union ministry of road transport and highways’ plan to widen NH 66 from Panvel right up to Kanyakumari.

The expansion work includes a 3-kilometre elevated corridor at Porvorim, an underpass-cum-overbridge at Karaswada, two underpass-cum-overbridges at Colvale, one at the Camaracazana-Gaunsavaddo intersection, and one at the Green Park junction.

While one underpass-cum-overbridge structure has already been thrown open for traffic at the Tar-Bastora junction, the structure at Guirim is nearing completion.

The entire project is being funded by the road ministry and the NHAI.

Title: Will use Nabard loans to improve Canacona’s water supply: Pauskar
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Poinguinim: Speaking to Canacona residents during a ‘ Janata Darbar ’ on Tuesday, the first of its type by the public works department (PWD), PWD minister Deepak Pauskar said he will make all efforts to solve the grievances of residents, particularly pertaining to roads and water shortage. Pauskar made a mention of improving Canacona water supply with the help of National Rural Bank for Rural Development (Nabard) loans.

Residents of the Canacona Municipal Council, Agonda, Shristhal, Cotigao, Gaondongorim, Poinguinim and Loliem-Polem panchayats had earlier put forward their grievances about roads and water supply.

Fernandes sought to know from PWD officers present the probable time frame for people in Loliem to get water supply. The officers said that the supply would begin by March. The officers added that payment of contractors’ bills have been pending for more than six months, and they are not ready to carry out emergency works.

Residents of Welwada and Potkem areas of Poinguinim said that they have not been getting water for several days. Pauskar asked the officers to submit proposals for funds to the tune of Rs 90 lakh to each panchayat.

The minister also that the government would not allow financial dearth to affect water supply and that he would see that money is availed through Nabard loans and get the projects completed.

Title: Surla ryots to get balance compensation
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Bicholim: Compensation of Rs 65 lakh has been sanctioned to farmers affected by pollution by various mining companies in Surla in Bicholim, and the funds will be released after verification of documents is completed, deputy collector Sachin Desai said on Monday.

In 2004, farmers had filed a complaint in the high court naming seven mining companies operating in Surla for destroying their farms and for causing pollution. In 2009, the court ruled in favour of the farmers, agreeing with the complainants and ordering the mining firms to compensate farmers for the loss of agricultural farms and for causing pollution.

The verdict pronounced a compensation of Rs 3.4 crore to around 761 farmers. The then deputy collector, Arvind Bugde had distributed Rs 16 lakh from this amount among 34 farmers after verifying their documents.

The balance amount was retained by the high court and this has now risen to Rs 7.8 lakh.

Title: Nagpur: Save Merit Save Nation opposes attempt to register political party
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

NAGPUR: Both factions of Save Merit Save Nation (SMSN) movement, which had originated at Nagpur, have decided to file an objection to the application by an Aurangabad group with the Election Commission of India (ECI) to register a political party named ‘Save Merit Save nation’ under the Representation of People’s Act 1951.

A notice has been published in a local Marathi newspaper at Jalna on January 14. It reads that any organization or individual having objection to this name may register a protest with the ECI. One Meena Avadheshkumar Singh is national president while Shrushti Shivkumar Ram is designated as treasurer of this proposed party. Both are residents of CIDCO, Aurangabad.

The Save Merit Foundation at Nagpur has claimed that the name ‘Save Merit Save Nation’ and its logo are their intellectual property and they will file an objection with the ECI.

“Our logo was designed by creative designer Harshad Bhisikar of Nagpur and we officially purchased it. We are using it till date. We won’t tolerate any misuse of this logo or name to gain political mileage to confuse people,” said Dr Sanjay Deshpande, president of SMSN.

“We have an official bank account in the name of ‘Save Merit Save Nation’ with a nationalized bank. But growth of the movement is bringing in politically inclined people to exploit our goodwill for furthering their selfish political agenda,” said Dr Anup Marar, SMSN secretary.

The SMSN movement was initiated in 2019 to protest excessive reservation in education after the state government implemented SEBC and EWS quotas. In 2019 assembly elections, SMSN forum got divided into two factions. One appealed to its members to exercise NOTA option in election while others preferred to stay apolitical. The political party’s move coming from Aurangabad has surprised both the factions.

“Irrespective of political stand during elections, we are sure that SMSN movement is a social movement and we are not going to fight elections. Some people who want to take advantage of the popularity of this name want to register it as a political party. Our team from Aurangabad will raise objections against it,” said Dr Anil Laddhad, state president of the SMSN faction that had appealed to members to select NOTA option.

Demand for general category census in 2021

Office bearers of SMSN have demanded census 2021 should collect separate information on general category people. “MLAs in state have unanimously asked the Central government to collect data regarding OBCs in the upcoming census 2021. We support this demand.
