In the period of the first three months, 152 cases were reported in 2016, 27 in 2017, and 19 in 2018.The study, carried out by Pranab Chatterjee of ICMR, Bhavna Seth of Johns Hopkins University, and Kolkata paediatrician Tamoghna Biswas says that the five states with the highest number of reported H1N1 cases were Delhi, Telangana, Gujarat, Karnataka and Goa, which accounted for 41% of all cases of swine flu in India. The Top 5 states for reported swine flu deaths were Gujarat, Rajasthan, Maharashtra, Punjab, and Kerala, which accounted for 71% of all deaths from H1N1 in India. An interesting fact that emerged was that in the eight-year period, Lakshadweep and Sikkim reported no cases of H1N1.

Title: HC stays Vadodara activist’s arrest
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Ahmedabad: The Gujarat high court has stayed Vadodara police from arresting an activist, Zubair Goplani, till January 30 in connection with a complaint filed against him last month for his post on social media protesting against the Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA).

Immediately after Goplani posted his comment on social media against the CAA as well as the National Register for Citizens (NRC), the detection of crime branch (DCB) Vadodara issued him and another person a notice. He was asked to give explanation for the post which the cops claimed was intended at spreading enmity among communities.

Goplani, chairman of Minority Development And Protection Foundation, reportedly deleted his post after he felt it was perceived by the administration as one creating rift among communities.

After the CDB, Vadodara filed an FIR against Goplani, and he unsuccessfully approached a sessions court in Vadodara.

Later, he moved the high court seeking anticipatory bail.

The state government took time to reply to the court’s notice. Hence, the HC has posted hearing on the anticipatory bail plea on January 30 and directed police not to arrest him till then.

Title: Kerala: FASTag slows down traffic in Paliakkara
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Around 50,000 vehicles pass through Paliakkara toll plaza everyday and more than half of them were yet to chan... Read More

THRISSUR: The move to migrate entirely to FASTag system of toll collection became a flop at Paliakkara toll plaza on the opening day on Wednesday because of the unprecedented crowding of vehicles on the national highway stretch between Kuttanellur and Amballur.

The toll plaza authorities had to convert six counters to cash payment system by afternoon following traffic block.

According to police, about 50,000 vehicles pass through the toll plaza everyday and more than half of them were yet to change over to the FASTag system even though the decision was announced much earlier.

Many vehicles were opting for cash payment, but the toll plaza authorities had made arrangements to introduce the FASTag system in 10 of the 12 counters from Wednesday.

Police had warned the toll plaza authorities that they would also be held responsible if ambulances and emergency vehicles are not able to move freely because of the traffic block. The queue of vehicles had extended on either side to nearly 3 kms choking the traffic on the main road itself.

The situation became very tense by afternoon as the drivers and passengers started questioning the toll plaza staff.

Even though acute traffic blocks were reportedly witnessed in several other toll plazas across the country, the situation at Paliakkara was worse as local residents were agitated that the toll waiver concession enjoyed by them would be stopped.

Congress district vice-president Joseph Tajet alleged that it was the indifference of the state government that had led to the crisis. He said the government has not taken steps to pay the toll on behalf of local residents, violating the assurance given earlier.

However, the education minister C Raveendranath said smartcard holders in the area will continue to enjoy the toll waiver. But he conceded discussions will have to be held about those vehicle owners whose smart cards have expired.

Title: Ajay Devgn's 'Tanhaji: The Unsung Warrior' declared tax-free in Haryana
Content: Recently, Kareena Kapoor Khan announced the big breaking news of her second pregnancy with hubby Saif Ali Khan. While fans, friends, and family of the gorgeous diva seem to be growing impatient for the upcoming little bundle of joy who’s expected to arrive by late February to March 2021, one must also recall Bebo’s first pregnancy days when she was carrying her munchkin, Taimur Ali Khan. No doubt, she was a complete stunner in her first pregnancy glow, meanwhile, if the actress is looking for some inspiration for her second round, here’s a list of five celebrities from whom Bebo can take fashion inspirations to ace her maternity look once again. From the supermodel, Gigi Hadid to ace singers like Katy Perry and Beyonce, this list covers some of the most fashionable mommies and mummy-to-be.Photo credit: Instagram

Title: GLS student files ragging complaint
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Ahmedabad: A first year BA, LLB course student with GLS University has filed a complaint of causing hurt, use of obscene language and criminal intimidation at Navrangpura police station against three former students. Police registered the FIR after Shyam Chakwawala, the victim, filed a formal complaint with the college authorities on January 12.

According to Navrangpura police, Shyam, a resident of Bodakdev, had come in contact with accused Harshadiyasinh Parmar, a resident of Bhadaj, Umang Rabari, a resident of CG Road, and Digvijay Rabari, a resident of CTM, through his fellow students when he got admission in the course in June 2019.

“His complaint mentions that the trio hit him on the back of his head and also threatened to kill him on January 6. Earlier, the group used to harass him as a junior and also allegedly forced him to pay for their bills. He mentioned in the statement that he was compelled to approach authorities over the issue after the group repeatedly called him on January 10, forcing him to meet them or face consequences,” said a Navrangpura police official.

The formal complaint with the anti-ragging committee of GLS University mentioned that the accused gave impression of strong political connections.

“I have been tortured and harassed and have been subjected to cruelty a lot of times. My entire college days have been depressing and miserable,” mentioned the application. The complaint mentioned that the constant harassment had started affecting his daily activities and also offered to furnish evidence of the harassment.

Title: Illegal banners: Police told to book violators
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Kochi: The high court on Wednesday ordered state police chief to direct station house officers (SHOs) to directly register cases against those violating the ban on illegal flex boards, banners, and flags.

Justice Devan Ramachandran issued the order after noticing that the earlier direction to the secretaries of local self-government institutions to report violations to the police has not been effective in dealing with the menace.

As the mechanism put in place is ineffective, the state police chief should issue necessary instructions to all SHOs to ensure that the court’s order on the ban is implemented in letter and spirit, including registration of cases against violators and also the officials who failed to take timely action, the interim order said. “The state police chief will issue such circular to all the station house officers asking them to invoke necessary provisions of the Road Safety Act, the Indian Penal Code and such other applicable penal provisions, including for violation of the orders of this court; and this shall be done not later than four days from the date of receipt of a copy of this order,” the court ordered.

Through the circular, the state police chief should require all the SHOs to be personally responsible for removal of all unauthorized boards, banners, flags, and such other offensive materials and against all the culprits under the fullest warrant of law and that they are prosecuted, the court directed.

Further, the court asked the government to give wide publicity to the circular by publication in prominent newspapers.

Title: Once brimming with activities, Jawahar Bal Bhavan fades into oblivion
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

MYSURU: More than four-decade-old district Jawahar Bal Bhavan , which used to attract hundreds of children, is currently not only in a pathetic condition, but has also become a den for anti-social activities.

Jawahar Bal Bhavan, which is spread over 13 acres and located opposite to Torchlight Parade Ground in Bannimantap, is maintained by Mysuru Urban Development Authority. Two years ago, the authority took up renovation work at an estimated cost of Rs 4.12 crore but little work has been done on the ground. Due to lack of maintenance, it has become a place for anti-social activities, the residents said.

Earlier, classes for drawing, painting, clay modelling, drama, craft work and dance were conducted for school children during the week-end.

Apart from this, the Bal Bhavan, which was opened in 1979, was also famous for running toy train, art gallery and film screening. Due to quality training and right ambience, children used to attend in large in numbers.

Cut to present: All these activities have been completely stopped.

MUDA, which owns the property, had given 30 years lease to Bal Bhavan Society that lapsed in 2007. Since then, though the Bal Bhavan Society is interested in continuing with it, it is yet to get renewed by MUDA authorities, sources said.

After the criticism, the authority chalked out a plan to upgrade it by adding new attractions. The facilities planned were swimming pool, waterfalls, park and modern amusement games along with facilities to educate children. Development work to the tune of Rs 4.12 crore was initiated and taken up in October 2014. On the ground, after constructing canteen, stage and multipurpose hall, the work has come to a standstill since mid-2015. The constructed buildings too are getting spoiled, putting Bal Bhavan in shambles.

The employees who work there are also in a piquant situation as they are paid just Rs 5,000 even after working for more than 25 years. There are five employees working in Bal Bhavan including the manager, who is working for more than 35 years and getting Rs 7,000. The other staff members who are working for more than 25 to 30 years are paid Rs 5,000 per month.

K Jyothi, CEO Of Zilla Panchayat, assured to bring it to the notice of district minister V Somanna and do her best to both Bal Bhavan and the employees.

Will do best to revive it, says chairperson

Chikkamma Basavaraj from Mysuru, who took charge as chairperson, Bal Bhavan Society, Karnataka, recently assured to do her best to revive district Jawahar Bal Bhavan. “I took charge a few days ago and will definitely pay a visit to Bal Bhavan and take stock of the situation at the earliest. Will also see and look into employee’s issues who are paid a meagre salary,” he said.

Title: Pune: Aditya Birla Hospital invests Rs 45 crore to upgrade facilities
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Aditya Birla Memorial Hospital

PUNE: Chinchwad-based Aditya Birla Memorial Hospital (ABMH) has invested Rs 45 crore to upgrade the healthcare facility from tertiary to quaternary.

“A majority (about 80%) of the investment has gone into equipment upgrade that will enable the hospital to use artificial intelligence, robotics and assist terminally ill patients. The investment is about 6-8 times the usual investment that the hospital undertakes on upgrades every year,” Rekha Dubey, chief executive officer of ABMH, said.

The hospital is designing a new paediatric intensive care unit (PICU) with child-friendly designs and play area elements embedded in the unit, giving a separate entrance to those coming for deliveries (which is a happy occasion), and opening up the gym and wellness centre even to outsiders for preventive care.

“It was not easy in the beginning when we started in 2006. It was too huge for a hospital and all our doctors were not a very known name then. People preferred to go to the doctors they knew,” Dubey said, adding, “Over time, the hospital has managed to retain all its doctors and they are very much known among people, at large.”

She said it had an in-house team of 115 full-time consultants, who do not go to any other hospital. Only 2-3% of its doctors are visiting doctors, which means most of the doctors are available for a longer period in the hospital.

The corporate hospital, she added, is not bound by government regulations as it takes no government aid and is a part of Aditya Birla Health Services. “There is a perception that the services are too costly but on a comparable basis, it is not costly for the kind of cutting edge technology that the hospital uses,” she said.

Title: Kasaragod girl to present project in key science fair
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Kannur: A girl student from Kasaragod has been selected for the IRIS National Fair for her project to extract curcumin from Turmeric and use it as an effective drug to treat cancer .

The student, Arya Ravindran, who is a Class X student from Kolathur Government High School , says that curcumin can be cheaply segregated from turmeric and this could be an alternative for the present system of treatment that is very expensive and also there is concern about side effects, said an official press release.

She said she did the researches in this regard with the help of her brother Ashray, who is doing his MBBS in Kozhikode Medical College.

The IRIS Fair would be held at Bengaluru from January 22 to 24 and this is the only project selected from Kerala under the section of molecular biology.

IRIS National Fair promotes and nurtures science and scientific research among young Indian innovators and also provides a platform for winning students to represent India at the International Science and Engineering Fair (ISEF), the world’s largest international pre-college science competition, held annually in the US.

Title: Suspect in theft case set free after cop says he was in their custody
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Aurangabad: The special railway court at Aurangabad discharged a suspect arrested in a theft case after the investigating officer admitted that the man was in their custody at the time of theft.

Police sub-inspector Mahadev Gopal Kasbe of the railway protection force (RPF) made the confession while evidence was being recorded during his cross-examination before the judicial magistrate first class (railways) P H Joshi.

According to the RPF, a team of led by Kasbe nabbed Gautam Bhimrao Kirtane at around 5.45am on March 21, 2012, when he was spotted moving around suspiciously at the Parbhani railway yard. Police team claimed to have found stolen railway cable on him. The RPF team then recorded the suspect’s confessional statement and produced him in court the same day.

Contesting on behalf of Kirtane, lawyer Akshay Radikar cited police station records that showed that his client was handed over to RPP by Parbhani local crime branch on March 20, 2012 at 2 pm. Records with the RPF police station corroborated that lawyer’s claims.

During cross-examination, Kasbe admitted that the suspect was in the custody of the RPF when the theft was alleged to have been committed.

Taking serious congizance of the development, the court observed ‘It is seen that the accused was in custody of the complainant himself at the time of incident which falsifies the case of complainant.’ The court went on to state that ‘no prima facie case is made out against the accused and there is no sufficient material to proceed against the accused.’

Kasbe further admitted that the accused was produced on next day in the court and also stated that the accused had no opportunity to commit the alleged offence between March 12, 2012 till 6 am of March 21, 2012.

Railway court went on to observe that ‘It is seen that the accused was in custody of the complainant himself from March 20, 2012 till 6am of March 21, 2012. Thus, the said material fact creates serious doubt regarding the allegations of commission of offence by the accused on 21.3.2012 at 5.45 am. Further facts testified in cross-examination is also contrary to the facts deposition that on March 21, 2012, the accused was found in suspicious manner at 5.45 am at Parbhani railway station.’

Title: Ghuge murder case: Two more arrested from railway station
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Representative image

AURANGABAD: The detection branch of Cidco police on Wednesday arrested two key accused in the murder of Amol Ghuge, a murder accused who was out on bail.

As many as four people have been arrested in the case so far. The accused arrested on Wednesday have been identified as Saurav Nana Wankhede (22) a resident of Triveninagar, and Ritesh Bhagwan Phuse alias Vicky (22), a resident of Ayodhyanagar. The duo was on the run since the murder came to light.

Police informed that the accused after being on the run for the past 12 days reached Aurangabad by train. After learning about their movement, a team from Mukundwadi police station was deployed to nab them. The team went to the railway station and nabbed the duo the moment they got out of the train. After being produced before a local court, they were sent to five-day police custody.

Two other accused, Gauram Wankhede and Shubham Vispute, were arrested immediately after the murder came to light.

On December 31, the four accused took Ghuge along with them and beat him to death.

They dumped his body in a manhole, poured petrol and set it on fire. The smell coming out of the manhole on January 3 led to the unwrapping of the murder. After Ghuge went missing, his family had lodged a missing complaint with Cidco police station.

Title: Nagpur: Five injured in deadly manja strike, birds and animals too take a hit
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

In recent past, maximum number of injuries witnessed in a single day was this year

NAGPUR: The kite festival of Makar Sankranti turned out to be a bloody affair in the city on Wednesday with five people and dozens of birds and animals sustaining serious injuries from the manja. In recent years, these are the maximum number of injuries the city has witnessed in a single day.

32-year-old Satyendra Tiwari, who works as an assistant manager in a bank, suffered perilous injuries on the right side of his neck and left hand fingers. The accident took place around 9.30am at Manewada Square when Tiwari, a resident of Narendra Nagar, was on his way to the bank.

Tiwari was driving a two-wheeler when a stray manja inflicted a cut on his throat. According to his wife Rucha, he started bleeding profusely and passers-by rushed him to a nearby hospital.

Later, Tiwari was shifted to Orange City Hospital and Research Institute (OCHRI) where he was immediately rushed to the operation theatre for surgery. “He underwent neck exploration and wound reconstruction of neck along with repair of his left thumb and fingers. He had a close call and is now under observation in the ICU,” said hospital director Dr Anup Marar.

In the second mishap, media photographer Jasprit Tuteja’s lips and tongue got deeply cut from a manja. Driving a two-wheeler, Jasprit’s face was fully covered with a cloth when the accident took place at Mecosabagh flyover.

“The manja was so sharp that it tore the cloth and injured both sides of his lips. He was rushed to a nearby hospital where he received around eight stitches,” informed his family members who suspect that the injury could have been caused by the banned nylon manja.

TOI has been repeatedly reporting that despite multiple bans, nylon manja continues to be sold discreetly in the city.

Fireman Makarand Satpute was the third victim of the deadly thread. Around 9.30am, he was on his way to office when his neck suddenly got entangled in a stray manja at Sanjay Gandhi Nagar. “It came right in front of me out of nowhere and I immediately stopped my two-wheeler. I received a cut in the middle of my neck but thankfully it was not very deep,” said Satpute, who too stated that manja must have been the banned nylon.

It is also learnt that contractor Ramzan Sheikh’s neck got slit by a manja while he was on his two-wheeler near Mahal.

In the fifth case, Adnan Ali, who hails from Chhindwara and is studying BCCA at Ambedkar College, sustained neck injuries near Shatabdi Chowk while he was on his bike.

Apart from humans, several animals and birds too came under the deathly trap of the killer thread. Founder director of Wild-CER Dr Bahar Baviskar, who has set-up a special critical care unit for injured birds at Friends Colony, informed that more than 10 cases of bird injuries from manja have come up till now. “We have been treating barn owl, koyal and other species. Birds get easily entangled in manja which cuts away their feathers or other parts,” he said.

Smita Mire, founder of Save Speechless Organisation (SSO), informed that a cow sustained injuries after its neck got completely entangled in a manja hanging from a tree. “The legs of two dogs got severely cut from manja. Also, we spotted few dead birds,” she said.

Five injured birds were rescued through the ‘Mood of the Group — Safe Birds’ group so far.

As per available records, in 2012 three citizens sustained severe injuries and in 2011 manja claimed 4 lives including that of 2 children.

Title: Panchamasali Mutt seer apologises
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Bagalkot/Belagavi/Shivamogga/Haveri: On a day when he was roundly criticised for openly seeking cabinet berths for members of the Lingayat community, Panchamasali Mutt seer Vachanananda Swami, on Wednesday, apologised.

“I did not mean to hurt anyone. Please treat me as your child and forgive me,” the seer said, seeking to put a lid on the controversy. His apology came hours after BJP MLA and community leader Basanagouda Patil Yatnal and some religious heads denounced his conduct and backed Yediyurappa.

The seer was involved in a spat with chief minister BS Yediyurappa at a public function on Tuesday in Davanagere when he demanded cabinet berths for Lingayat leaders and warned that the community would withdraw its support to the CM if he did not acquiesce. An incensed Yediyurappa responded by berating the seer and threatening to quit the function.

Yatnal criticized the seer saying: “Religious leaders should not interfere in political matters, that too in public, or blackmail a chief minister. Yediyurappa is not the chief minister of the Lingayat community alone. He represents all communities in the state. The seer’s conduct is unbecoming of a religious leader.”

Prominent Panchamasali mutt seer, Basava Jaya Mrityujaya dubbed Vachanananda’s warning “an insult to the entire community”.

“There is nothing wrong in suggesting names or requesting the CM to appoint community leaders to the cabinet,” Mrityujaya said. “Even I have requested the CM to include at least three Panchamasali Lingayat leaders to the cabinet including Nirani and Yatnal. But you cannot dictate terms. Our community is solidly behind Yediyurappa.”

Endorsing Yediyurappa's stand against the Lingayat seer, former KPCC president and legislator Dinesh Gundurao said religious leaders of any community should not threaten a chief minister on political matters. Channamalla Veerabhadra Swami, the pontiff of Nidumamidi Mahasamsthana Mutt and Dingaleshwar Swami, the pontiff of Balehosuru Dingaleshwar Mutt also extended support to Yediyurappa.

Title: IIITM-K to get digital university status, ordinance soon: Kerala government
Content:
Kerala CM Pinarayi Vijayan

THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: The state cabinet has decided to elevate Indian Institute of Information Technology and Management-Kerala (IIITM-K) to the status of digital university.An ordinance in this regard will be promulgated soon, the cabinet decided on Wednesday. The new university will be known as the Kerala University of Digital Science Innovation and Technology. The new university is being set as part of multiple steps and policies being taken by the state government to develop information technology business and digital technology. The university is expected to strengthen the industry-education link and develop entrepreneurship in the state.The university will stress on the latest technologies like artificial intelligence, data analytics, block chain, cognitive science, internet of things, augmented reality, etc. There will be five schools under the university that are being set up with an aim to filling the shortages in high-quality human resources in the digital sector. The schools will be named: school of computing, school of electronics design and automation, school of informatics, school of digital biosciences and school of digital humanities.The focus of the university will be on research in various sectors of digital technology and education. The university is expected to be a major value addition to the Kerala Technological University that has at present no research facility. The university also aims at strengthening the industry-education ties and also cooperate with international institutions on the academic front.According to a study, AI and robotics will lead to a large-scale automation by 2030, because of which 30% of existing jobs will be affected. But it will lead to creation of new jobs that can compensate for the losses.IIITM-K is an autonomous educational institution established by the state government in 2000. It’s a multidisciplinary postgraduate institute under the state IT department. It offers, PG progra- mmes such as MSc Computer Science with various specializations, MPhil, PhD and PG diploma in e-governance.

Title: Kochi residents hit by water crisis, want district collector to step in
Content:
Representative image

KOCHI: The city and its suburbs have been facing severe shortage in supply of drinking water due to the delay in setting up more hydrant points at the Kerala Water Authority’s (KWA) plants at Maradu and Aluva. As the tanker trucks supplying drinking water too have come under the scanner over the quality of water they supply, residents are struggling to get enough potable water.Somanathan VS, secretary, Kerala Apartment Owners’ Apex Association (KAOAA) said: “For the past two days, several apartments have been hardly getting any water supply. The district administration should act on a war footing and come up with solutions.”Residents say tanker truck operators have been demanding increased rates and insisting on passing vehicle tax to consumers. They want the amount paid to the drivers to be passed on to the consumers. VK Shankarankutty, president, KAOAA, said: “The tanker trucks do not want to register with the district administration. They are bargaining by denying water supply to the public.” According to the apartment owners’ association, the tankers have increased the rates for truck with 6,000 litres capacity from Rs 750 to Rs 2,000. “The truckers say that they have to wait in queue for long hours to connect with the hydrant point,” added Somanathan.Chandrika Devi, chairperson, Tripunithura Municipality, said the local body has raised the issue with the district collector. It’s not just apartment complexes that have been hit by water shortage. Even individual houses and commercial complexes face a similar issue.Regions like Mekkara, Chathari, Eroor and Irumpanam are the worst affected due to the shortage in water supply.“One of the reason for the shortage is that pumping force has come down due to frequent power disruption. Damaged pipes can also be a reason. Water should be pumped forcefully, only then will these regions get enough supply,” said Devi.Meanwhile, the district collector has taken measures to temporarily address the crisis in the city and suburbs. Large-scale consumers like hospitals, apartment complexes and residents’ associations, who face shortage of drinking water supply, can submit applications to the collector. The district administration will verify the veracity of the claim and make immediate measures to supply water to the affected people.KWA officials said vending facilities are limited at Aluva and Maradu and more tankers are coming to the treatment plant at Aluva. As the number of vehicles increase, it will take a long time for the vehicles to fill water. “If there are more hydrant points, it may bring down pressure and cause delay in filling the trucks. The KWA will have a tough time meeting the demand at Aluva and Maradu,” said an official.

Title: Nagpur: Govornment Polytechnic staffer throws liquid ammonia on HOD
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Representational image

NAGPUR: Sadar police on Wednesday detained a woman lab assistant at the Government Polytechnic (GP) college, Sadar, for around three hours, after she allegedly threw liquid ammonia on the head of the department (HOD) of IT department. The presence of mind of the HOD saved her, as when the liquid ammonia was thrown at her, she used her dupatta as a shield, preventing any of the liquid from reaching her.

Senior PI of Sadar police station Mahesh Bansode said, “The victim HOD has refused to press charges, so we are not filing any case at this moment. We have recorded the statement of the alleged attacker and let her go.”

In-charge principal Deepak Kulkarni confirmed the incident. “Currently I cannot take any action against the attacker as she was appointed by the joint director. I will be submitting a report about the incident to the joint director. The attacker has not denied the attack in front of our Women Grievance Cell, and also submitted a written reply in which she admitted the attack.”

Sources said Shalu (name changed) used to work as a lab assistant for Deepali (name changed), HOD at IT department, from September till December. Deepali and Shalu were not getting along as the latter used to take unsanctioned leaves. So, Deepali had given a written complaint to Kulkarni.

“After receiving the complaint, I shifted Shalu to the chemistry department, to keep her away from Deepali. We had also held back Shalu’s payment for December as she had not attended college for even one day, without submitting any leave application,” added Kulkarni.

It is learnt that Shalu had on Tuesday submitted a complaint to Kulkarni against Deepali for alleged harassment. Kulkarni had sent the complaint to the Women’s Grievance Cell of the college.

On Wednesday, Deepali was sitting in her cabin when Shalu approached her carrying liquid ammonia in a beaker and threw it at her. Deepali used her dupatta to shield herself. Other teachers rushed to the spot after Deepali raised an alarm. Shalu was taken to a different room.

“Members of our Women’s Grievance Cell also inquired with Shalu, in whose purse they also found a knife,” added Kulkarni.

Soon, Sadar police led by PI Bansode were summoned to the spot and detained Shalu. The cops waited till evening but since Deepali did not show up to file a complaint, they let Shalu go after recording her statement.

Title: Aurangabad: Nine cases against traders in 24 hours
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Representative image

AURANGABAD: Cracking a whip on the illegal trading of banned nylon manja in the market, the city police have registered nine cases in the past 24 hours against the suspect traders.

Most of the cases were registered on Tuesday on the complaints lodged by the officers of the anti-terrorism cell. The police after seizing ‘adequate’ amount of nylon manja, have slapped the traders with charges under section 188 of IPC for allegedly disobeying to the orders duly promulgated by the public servant.

On Tuesday, five offences were registered including one at Cantonment police station and two each at Jinsi and Pundaliknagar. On Wednesday, two offences were registered by the City Chowk police station. The process of registering offences at two more places was under till late on Wednesday evening.

In the past couple of days, the city police have seized nylon manja to the tune of Rs 50,000. About a month back, the Aurangabad city police issued a notification, about the blanket ban on the use of Chinese strings or nylon manja for flying kites in the city limits. Despite the ban, the strings were found to be sold rampantly in the open market.

The city police started acting against them only for the past couple of days. The police authorities have cited the dangers including these strings being good conductor of electricity, are also coated with harmful chemicals and pose grave threat to the flying birds, moving commuters and kids.

Title: Countdown begins, city to get Smart Food Street in 56 days
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Indore: If all goes as per plan, Indore will get its first Smart Food Street in 56 days as the civic body has fixed the deadline to complete redevelopment work of 56 dukaan area.

Vehicular movement in the area has also been restricted and the agency engaged in the project started the groundwork.

A 56-day deadline has been fixed by the corporation for the agency to complete the project, and the countdown started from Wednesday. To make this countdown public, a digital screen has also been installed in the area to display number of days left for completion of this project.

“We have started redevelopment work of 56-Dukaan, and the agency has been instructed to complete the project within the given time limit. It has been proposed to be carried out in a time-bound manner,” said IMC commissioner Asheesh Singh.

On January 3, IMC had announced to re-develop 56-Dukaan area as ‘Smart Food Street’ with façade development of all shops, LED lightings, designer pavement space, plantation and greenery. The entire project would cost around Rs4 crore.

Officials engaged in the work said that they were going to start with removal of paver blocks of 56-Dukaan street starting from MG Road to Chandni Chowk for installation of underground utilities such as electric cables, drainage and water supply lines, and then come reinforced concrete (RC) work on the stretch measuring around 41000 sq ft.

Around 30 electric poles are also coming in way of the project and all of them will be shifted with help of discom.

“There will be complete restriction on entry of vehicles in the area from Wednesday night. However, pedestrians will be allowed to visit food outlets and their movement will be regulated as per the need of development work,” Soni Saluja, an official with the agency told TOI.

Title: For backing Pakistan, trade with Turkey under scanner
Content:
Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan (File photo)

NEW DELHI: After Malaysia , Turkey is on the government ’s radar for possible trade curbs for interfering in India’s internal issues.While concrete measures have been decided in case of Malaysia, with a clampdown on refined palm oil imports already put in place, there is no decision on Turkey, which has sided with Pakistan on several issues, including voicing concerns over its proposed blacklisting by the Financial Action Task Force (FATF).A Reuters report said the government was planning to cut oil and steel imports from Turkey. While there were suggestions on some restrictions on imports from Turkey, things have not moved beyond that stage, said sources.During 2019-20, trade with Turkey was pegged at less than $7.8 billion, with imports of under $2.4 billion. Oil accounted for a bulk of the imports from Turkey.In fact, even in case of Malaysia, the government had discussed the possibility of trade restrictions on a longer list of products that what was finally decided.As reported by TOI last week, checks in the form of standards are planned on refined and crude palm oil as well as electronic goods such as micro-processors and telecom equipment. For the moment, the government is also keeping tabs on mining shipments too but there is no move to restrict their imports immediately, sources said.During 2019-20, India’s trade with Malaysia was estimated at over $17 billion, with exports pegged at $6.4 billion, while imports were estimated at $10.8 billion.After Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad ’s comments on Kashmir , following the government’s decision to remove the special status to the state, trade bodies had shunned imports from the South East Asian countries with the Centre moving in to put in place restrictions only last week.

Title: Earmark seats in court for elderly, set next hearing date at earliest: Bombay high court
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Representative image

AURANGABAD: All the lower courts in the state are set to have seats reserved for senior citizens in each courtroom. A written communication in this regard, citing the directives of the chief justice of the Bombay high court , has been issued to all principal district and sessions judges in the state.

The courtrooms have reserved seats for lawyers representing the litigant and the public prosecutors. “Unless the proceeding is in camera, the court hall is open for all. Mostly, the front row seats are for advocates and the last row for the accused in criminal courts,” said a senior lawyer.

The communication has also addressed the concerns of litigants, who had to wait for an entire day to get the next date of hearing, in case their case failed to reach the board.

To maintain the court decorum and to cure the aforesaid irregularities, the HC has directed the principal district and sessions judges in the state to give the next date at the earliest in cases failing to reach the board on the given date, instead of keeping the litigants waiting for whole day.

The communication citing directives from the Chief Justice, reads ‘To direct the judicial officers to observe the court working hours and to seat on the dais sharp 11 am.

To direct the judicial officers to avoid the practice for keeping the judgment reserved for long time and to upload immediately.’

The directives further states, ‘judicial officers if it is noticed that the matters placed on the board will not reach on the same day, then give the next date to litigant at the earliest, instead of keeping them waiting for whole day. To directive the judicial officers to complete the evidence of the witnesses on the same day, as far as possible. To direct the judicial officers to earmark the seats for the senior citizen in the court.’

And to direct the judicial officers to take prior permission or to intimate the principal district judge and sessions judge or concerned authority, before leaving the headquarters.

Title: KMRL yet to to pull down bund
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Kochi: Though coastal regulation zone violations have been rampant, authorities are yet to get their act together. A bund constructed across Kaniyampuzha, which falls under CRZ -I, for facilitating the work on the Metro’s viaduct along Vyttila-Thykoodam stretch, is still to be demolished even after the completion of the work. The work on the viaduct and the Metro pillars were completed almost two years ago and the Metro began services along the stretch a few months ago.

When TOI brought the issue to the notice of Kochi Metro Rail Ltd managing director Alkesh Kumar, he said: “We will check on it.” The bund has been causing waterlogging in the area. Moreover, the bund obstructs the flow of the tidal-influenced waterbody.

Local residents allege that the authorities have been reluctant to demolish the bund as they want to provide road access to a nearby island, where several realty projects are progressing.

“The bund constructed by the KMRL has the width of a four-lane road. Though the island can be accessed on road from Tripunithura-Vyttila Road, it is a small one. The bund can be transformed into a wider road. So, land value in the island will rise,” a local resident who requested anonymity, said.

“Moreover, the tidal impact on the backwaters will also be obstructed. Over the years, it will help in exempting these areas from the ambit of CRZ rules,” he said.

Title: Yet to decide on next step, says Kerala youth thrashed by police
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Bengaluru: The three students from Kerala taken into custody by SG Palya police and allegedly beaten up on Monday underwent treatment and are recovering.

Saif (name changed), one of the students, told TOI that cops had called him, while adding that he would decide on the next step on Thursday. “I am getting numerous calls and people are asking me about the incident. But I am not in a state to talk,” said Saif, who along with two of his friends spent a day at the hospital.

Saif, 21, and his friends were picked up from the gate of their apartment complex when they were heading out for tea around 1am on Monday. Police allegedly stopped them, questioned them aggressively and manhandled them when they objected to the snatching of their phones.

The patrol police also asked them if they were Pakistani after learning their names and eventually took them to the police station. The students claimed the cops rained lathis on them from 1.30am to 3.30am and they were released only after getting an undertaking signed that they wouldn’t venture out late in the night. The incident went viral on social media, inspiring many others to share similar experiences they’ve had with police in and around the city.

Title: Nagpur: Vidarbha’s first winery uncorks in Bhandara
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Representational image

NAGPUR: In a first of its kind business venture for Vidarbha, a full-fledged winery started its commercial operations a few months ago in Bhandara with port wine bottles being marketed in that district.

SP Wineries is now finalizing its plans to market the product in Nagpur by next month and also to foray into the premium wine segment by next year. Shashichandra Jaiswal, whose family owns retail liquor shops, broke tradition and forayed into wine production just to “follow his passion”.

It all started as an idea almost a decade ago when Jaiswal took up a hobby of ‘home made wines’. Though a teetotaller, Jaiswal was always fascinated with wine as a ‘classy’ drink.

“My home made wines were tasted by friends and the feedback I got was that it tastes better than most commercial products. Finally, in 2015, I got a licence for a winery,” said Jaiswal.

With guidance from his Nashik vineyard-owner friend Rajesh Borse, who is also an office bearer of the All India Wine Producers’ Association (AIWPA), Jaiswal started work on his factory in 2017. Luckily, he had an in-house expert as well. “My nephew Shaurya has done his M.Sc in wine and alcohol technology and that proved to be a major advantage at our small unit in which his father Prakashchandra is also a partner,” said Jaiswal.

The next big question was sourcing of grapes. “I decided to buy grapes from Nashik so that the commercial production of port wine could start immediately. Port wine is made from non-premium grapes and accounts for 95% of all wine sales in India,” said Jaiswal.

In June 2019, the first batch was bottled. Jaiswal prefers taking small steps in this new business. “Right now, we are selling only in Bhandara, but by the end of February, our products will be available in Nagpur. It takes time to scale up the business as the volume of wine sales is very low compared to whiskey and beer,” said Jaiswal.

He has a plan in place to climb the value chain in the winery business. “Premium grapes will be grown here in Pauni in the next few years after which we will foray into the upper segment,” said Jaiswal.

While a bottle of port wine sells for around Rs200-230, a similar sized bottle of premium wine will go for at least Rs750. But to make it commercially viable, Jaiswal can’t rely on grapes coming from other cities.

He is convinced about grapevines flourishing in Vidarbha’s weather. “A few decades ago, I have seen grapes growing in Pauni alongside ‘paan’ leaf plants. So there is no doubt in my mind that the basic ecosystem exists. Of course, I will be taking advice from agriculture experts to further simulate conditions on vineyards for optimum quality of grapes,” said Jaiswal.

Deepak Khanuja, director of Nagpur Wine Club, said, “It is a matter of great pride that wines being made in Vidarbha are available in the market. This will help promote wine culture and moving up the value chain will also prove economically beneficial to farmers.”

Title: Aurangabad SP prevents marriage of minor girl in village
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Representative image

AURANGABAD: Aurangabad rural superintendent of police Mokshada Patil recently swung into action, following a tip-off, and scuttled the marriage of a minor girl at a village in the district.

“The 17-year-old girl, who was being married off by her parents, is a std XI student in a Marathi medium educational institution, and wants to become a police officer after completing her education,” Patil told TOI on Wednesday.

The officer explained to the girl’s parents and family members, as well as the would be in-laws, that they would face legal consequences for forcing a minor girl to get married.

“The girl’s family and others called off the plan to marry her as they were convinced that this is not the right time for it,” said Patil.

Patil personally went to the village and spoke to the girl and her relatives. “The girl’s marriage was being fixed on her grandmother’s insistence. The minor pleaded with her parents to let her study and fulfil her dream of becoming a police officer, but nobody listened to her.”

The officer said the girl’s aunt is works for Accredited Social Health Activist (ASHA), but she too could not do anything to stop the marriage.

“The minor girl even told her teacher that she was not ready to get married, but they too expressed helplessness. The girl seemed to be scared of backlash from her family, especially grandmother,” said Patil.

The officer said that a photocopy of the girl’s school transfer certificate shows that she is a minor.

“The girl comes from a very poor family and her parents, who are illiterate, work as labourers. We did not reveal our source of information to them. Besides counselling her relatives, we also warned them of the consequences.”

The SP said the local area police station has been tasked to keep a close eye on the developments. Moreover, the officer also shared her personal number with the girl so that she can be alerted if she is forced to get married.

Patil appealed to citizens to alert police if they come across any proposed child marriage anywhere, especially in their areas.

Title: Kerala Coastal Zone Management Authority declines nod for Padmasarovaram Project
Content:
KCZMA has denied approval for Padmasarovaram Project, which envisages construction of a cycle track and a walk... Read More

KOCHI: In what can be seen as a big blow to Kochi Corporation authorities, the Kerala Coastal Zone Management Authority (KCZMA) has denied approval for Padmasarovaram Project, which envisages construction of a cycle track and a walkway across Chilavannoor backwaters connecting Subhash Chandra Bose Road and Sahodaran Ayyappan Road. According to the KCZMA , the construction of the cycle track and the walkway across the backwaters will obstruct the flow of the tidal-influenced waterbody in the coastal regulation zone (CRZ) and flood-prone area.The Kochi Metro Rail Limited (KMRL) had begun the work on the project in December 2018 on behalf of the Kochi Corporation. The work on the Rs 9.5-crore project was started without even submitting an application before the KCZMA for getting CRZ clearance. Later, the local body authorities submitted an application for CRZ clearance after environmentalists and local residents raised objection against the project and moved the court. The KCZMA rejected the application as it was filed without following the prescribed specific format. Subsequently, the local body authorities submitted a fresh application for securing a CRZ clearance for the project. “A detailed presentation was made by the project proponent (Kochi Corporation). The authority decided to decline approval since the construction of the walkway and the cycle track will obstruct the flow of tidal influenced waterbody in the CRZ and flood-prone area,” the minutes of the last meeting of KCZMA held in December 2019 states.Cheshire Tarzan, an RTI activist, has moved vigilance court alleging CRZ violations and corruption in the project. “The project was being carried out in violation of CRZ norms. Chilavannoor backwaters fall under CRZ-I. So, no construction can be allowed in the area. The intention of the authorities was to get Chilavannoor backwaters out of the ambit of the CRZ. The idea was to help those who constructed buildings off Chilavannoor backwaters in violation of CRZ norms,” Cheshire said. “The bund constructed across the backwaters will obstruct the tidal influence, and the high tide line (HTL), based on which the CRZ is fixed, will begin from the middle of the backwaters. So, the distance to the HTL from the shore will increase, and as a result, buildings off the backwaters will be exempted from CRZ limits. The authorities began the project after accepting bribe from builders,” Cheshire said.“Moreover, the fund for the project is availed from the Atal Mission for Rejuvenation and Urban Transformation (Amrut). As per norms, Amrut funds should not be used for any projects, which cause damages to the environment,” he said.“The bund was constructed by placing trunks of coconut trees on the backwaters at fixed distances. It will be very difficult to demolish the bund,” Cheshire said.Kochi Corporation authorities said they would appeal against the KCZMA’s decision. “We will file an appeal challenging the decision,” mayor Soumini Jain said. But sources with the KCZMA said the appeal petition is also likely to be rejected. “If the appeal raises any technical problems, there would have been a scope for reviewing the current decision. But the reason for declining the approval for the project is that it was being carried out in violation of CRZ norms,” a source said.
