Title: Jawan gets anticipatory bail from HC in attempt to murder case
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Representative image

AURANGABAD: The Aurangabad bench of the Bombay high court has granted anticipatory bail to an army jawan in an attempt to murder case in Pathardi village of Ahmednagar district in November last year.

Granting conditional bail to Narayan Suryabhan Garje, Justice RG Avachat observed: “The injury certificate rules out an assault with a knife. If the applicant is arrested, his services would be at stake. The nature of injuries suffered were simple.”

Defence counsel NB Narwade argued that Narayan had come to his village on leave. “The complainant and Garje have a dispute over using a road from their farms and the parties have history of registering criminal cases against each other.”

The jawan has been booked under IPC sections 307 (attempt to murder), 323 (voluntarily causing hurt), 504 (intentional insult with intent to provoke breach of peace) and 506 (criminal intimidation).

In the FIR registered on November 20, 2019 with the Pathardi police station, the complainant alleged that Narayan asked him to withdraw the court cases he had filed against him from time to time.

“It was after he refused, the army jawan felt offended and he allegedly assaulted him with a knuckle duster before trying to stab him with a sharp knife,” stated the complainant.

Lawyer Narwade said that after going through the medical records about the injuries suffered by the complainant, the HC observed that “If the applicant is arrested, his services would be at stake. Considering the nature of injuries suffered by the informant, it appears to be a case of bailable offence.”

Title: Police to take murder accused to Valparai
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Kochi: Central police probing the murder of a 17-year-old girl would take the accused to Valparai in the coming days to recover evidence, including the weapon used for the crime.

The accused, Safar Shah (26) of Kumbalam, was sent in police custody on Tuesday and on Wednesday he was taken to his house and the store in Ernakulam where he bought the knife for committing the crime.

“As per our investigation, the murder was pre-planned. The accused had bought the weapon ahead of taking the girl to Valparai and started stabbing her as soon as an argument happened over the nature of their friendship. The girl sustained numerous wounds on her body and bled to death,” said a senior police officer.

Police said the accused had travelled abroad and they have collected documents in connection with his travels on Tuesday. “Evidence collection on Wednesday was basic in nature and was limited to the city. On Thursday or Friday, we would take the accused to Valparai in Tamil Nadu where the crime was committed. The major objective is to recover the weapon, which he had tossed into a deserted location near the tea plantation where he had dumped the body,” said an officer with the investigation team.

The accused took the girl to Valparai and stabbed her to death on January 7. Advocate BA Aloor has said that he would appear for the accused in court.

Title: Nagpur: Minor battle won, bigger green war remains
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Residents of Bharat Nagar celebrated the cancellation of the proposed road going through Bharat Van as they ga... Read More

NAGPUR: It took massive mobilization of people, multiple Chipko movements, year-long agitations, weekly activities and the state’s largest human chain to win the battle of Bharat Van. But a bigger green war still goes on.

Bharat Van is a small manifestation of a much larger problem of city’s depleting green cover. While the festival of Makar Sankranti brought the much-awaited good news of authorities dropping the proposed Bharat Van road, those celebrating are yet not completely content.

Proud of the citizens for “shunning sham development by building public pressure”, ad-guru Sanjay Arora feels that the city needs to be constantly vigilant and build further momentum to ensure that the other green zones too are saved. “Across the world we see two forces lined up against each other; on one side are the governments wanting to roughshod over environmental concerns in their greed and on the other side are citizens rising against it because they can already see the havoc climate change has started to cause,” he said.

Adding that these movements for most part are leaderless and spontaneous, Arora says, “This is just the beginning and we all should continue to fight for our right to a cleaner, greener city.”

According to intensive care physician Dr Abheek Ghosh, the city is now more vigilant than ever. “We have a large section of citizens who are passionate about environment conservation. To win the bigger war, people’s participation is needed,” he says.

Areas like Bharat Van should now be fenced and well-protected, suggests green activist Baba Deshpande. “Agencies like Nagpur Municipal Corporation and forest department should unanimously frame strict policies against tree felling. Hefty fines should be imposed on erring departments,” he adds.

Pointing out that approaching judiciary or organizing mass protests is not always possible, chartered accountant Sandeep Agrawal says that only education can help in winning the real war. “Right from primary level, the inter-dependence of trees and human lives should be stressed upon in curriculum. Why do we need thousands of people to stand in human chain? Isn’t it common sense that such age-old trees should not be cut,” he asks.

Green areas of the city should be converted into ‘no development zones’, said consultant Ashfaque Ahmed. “Like the city’s heritage committee, there should be a body of experts whose approval should be taken before executing any project-threatening green cover,” he says.

Demanding that trees should be given precedence over development, Bharat Nagar resident Shashi Kanoria says, “The concerned authorities should support individuals and NGOs while planning cities to ensure low carbon footprints. Like playgrounds, I hope that the judiciary gives protection to city’s green cover too, be it the green pockets at Empress Mill or Neeri.”

Not wanting to expect much from politicians or authorities, another resident Amit Heda believes that it is for the citizens to understand that “together we can”. “While politicians need to have genuine empathy towards the well being of the public and take care of their ambitions that come in the way of retaining natural resources, authorities should not bow down under political pressure. However, the real game-changers are the people who need to keep fighting to raise their voice,” adds Heda.

Calling the Bharat Van victory “a powerful shot in the arm” for green activists, Supantha Bhattacharyya, associate professor & director of PG English at Hislop College says, “All such myopic projects which cause long-term eco vandalism must be relentlessly resisted till they are withdrawn. We owe it, if not to ourselves, then to our children.”

Title: Mussoorie: Bad roads a blot on the Queen of Hills
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Mall Road was repaired under a year ago but has still developed potholes

MUSSOORIE: Several roads in the Queen of Hills have been badly damaged and are crying for urgent repairs even as roads at several places lack crash barriers and could lead to a risk for motorists.

Of utmost concern to residents and businessmen of the town is the condition of the Mall Road, which is regarded as the heart of Mussoorie .

“The Mall Road was re-laid by the Public Works Department (PWD) in March-April last year but just after the rains, it was damaged and developed deep potholes at several places,” said Pradeep Bhandari, a resident.

In fact, at several places, potholes in the road have been filled by simply paving with bricks. Residents complain that for a tourist town, these brick-paved potholes are a big eyesore.

Other roads similarly affected include the road between Kincraig to Picture Palace, Waverley Convent to Dhumman Gunj, Tehri bypass road and Barlowganj to Jharipani and Gandhi Chowk to Zero point, to name a few.

Another cause of concern is the lack of crash barriers along the side of the road at many places posing a risk of major accidents.

“At several places on the Kincraig-Gandhi chowk road, Tehri bypass road and near Bataghat, the road does not have crash barriers and even the cement parapets have broken down, posing the risk of accidents,” said Vinod Semwal, a former member of Mussoorie Municipal Council.

Moreover, at Kincraig, where a large parking is being constructed, the road has been in a bad shape since several months. Due to construction of the parking, the width of the road has also been reduced, leading to traffic bottlenecks.

After the recent snowfall in the town, the roads have become further damaged during the process of removal of snow by JCBs which residents say has damaged the surface of the road at several places across the town.

Meanwhile, with tourist season expected to commence in a few months, the local businessmen are demanding that the PWD must repair all the roads connecting the town.

“Tourist influx begins to pick up from March onwards and it is desirable that the roads are repaired before the tourist season so that tourists do not face any inconvenience,” said Jagjit Kukreja, secretary of Mussoorie Traders Association.

When contacted, officials of the Public Works Department (PWD) chose to play the blame game.

“The Peyjal Nigam had dug up large stretches of roads in and around Mussoorie several years ago but till date, they have not made the compensatory payment to PWD. It is issues such as these that are causing a paucity of funds for the department,” said Jagmohan Chauhan, superintending engineer of PWD.

When asked about the poor condition of Mall Road which was laid less than a year ago, Chauhan said that damage must have occurred owing to heavy rainfall and waterlogging.

If this is the condition of roads in a premier hill station like Mussoorie, one shudders to think of the state of roads in other hill regions of the state.

Title: IIIT-Raichur may soon shift to its hometown
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

BENGALURU: The International Institute of Information Technology (IIIT) Raichur , currently functioning out of IIT (Indian Institute of Technology)-Hyderabad campus, is likely to come to Raichur, turning the long-cherished dream of the city to have an institute of importance into a reality.

According to Subodh Yadav, regional commissioner and Hyderabad-Karnataka Regional Development Board (HKRDB) secretary, a temporary arrangement has been made at the Government Engineering College, Raichur, to accommodate the institute. HKRDB will fund the renovation of the college besides other additional facilities that are required for the shifting of the IIIT to its hometown.

“We had proposed the same place last year when they were commencing the first batch. However, the institute wanted to go to its well established mentor institute centre and had requested some additional facilities in the engineering college,” Yadav said.

“This included approach roads, additional water facility and some other basic infrastructure. We have added these features. The team from the institute visited the college and were satisfied,” he added.

The Karnataka government is also opening a hostel facility for the engineering college that will have sufficient rooms to accommodate two batches of IIIT-Raichur students.

According to Subodh, the state government has handed over 60 acre land for the permanent campus — complete with basic facilities such as water and electricity. The construction has to be taken up by the Centre. Its first batch of students is being taught mostly by the faculty of IIT-Hyderabad and the institute is also yet to get a full time director.

IIIT-Raichur was announced by the MHRD in 2016. It came as a relief for Raichur which had by then lost to Dharwad in the race for an IIT.

Title: Four decades on, no rules for Maha Irrigation Act 1976 yet
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

In 2015, the government authorities had assured the Aurangabad bench of the Bombay high court that the necessa... Read More

AURANGABAD: More than four decades after its enactment, the Maharashtra Irrigation Act , 1976, still does not have a set of rules for effective implementation.

During one of the hearings of a PIL filed by water management expert Pradeep Purandare in 2015, the government authorities had assured the Aurangabad bench of the Bombay high court that the necessary rules would be framed within one year.

With the new government coming into the power in Maharashtra, experts and activists have demanded that the needful be done at the earliest.

On Wednesday, Purandare said that the Maharashtra Irrigation Act of 1976 (MIA 1976) is considered the parent legislation as it provides for the foundation, framework and structure of water management in Maharashtra. “MIA 1976 has a bearing on other key laws including the Maharashtra Water Resources Regulatory Authority (MWRRA) Act, Maharashtra Management of Irrigation Systems by Farmers Act (MMISF) and Irrigation Development Corporation Act (IDC). These Acts refer to the MIA 1976 in policy wordings. The implementation of these Acts, therefore, depends on the implementation of MIA 1976 — which itself has been without rules for around 40 years,” he said.

The operative part of any law includes a set of rules and the MIA 1976, therefore, is dubbed as least effective in the absence of the desired rules. The MIA 1976 deals with vital areas such as bringing the river water under the legal jurisdiction of water resources department (WRD), issuance of the command area and appointment of canal officers to specify their jurisdiction.

During the hearing of the PIL, the government authorities had told the court that a fresh committee was then set up on December 5, 2014, to suggest amendments in MIA 1976. The authorities had told the court that the government would be in a position to frame rules only after the committee submits a report. The government had specifically said in 2015 that the needful would be done “possibly within a year”.

While no progress has taken place in the legal case, water activists have now pinned their hopes on the new government. Water right activist Abhijit Dhanorkar said the new government must give priority to the framing of MIA 1976 rules. “Climate change manifestations are being witnessed in the form of extreme weather events, including droughts. Marathwada, especially, has witnessed a few deficit runs of monsoon in the recent past. Water could become a major issue in the near future and stoke regional and inter-state disputes. Having a sound legal framework for the government functioning could only prove beneficial in such a scenario — failing which, legal tangles are inevitable,” he said.

When contacted, senior officials from the Godavari Marathwada Irrigation Development Corporation (GMIDC) pleaded ignorance about the issue. Maharashtra water resources minister Jayant Patil could not be reached for a comment on the issue.

Title: Love jihad making Kerala girls sex slaves: Church
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

KOCHI: A day after the Syro Malabar church officially acknowledged that "love jihad wasn't an illusion in Kerala ", it said it would begin a sensitisation campaign against the issue through Sunday Schools. Sources with the Syro-Malabar Church said that they are planning to use all their lay organisations to make Christian youth cautious about the ‘threat’.

On Tuesday, the 28th Synod of the Syro-Malabar Church released a public statement saying that Keralite Christian girls are being targeted and killed in the name of 'Love Jihad'. Priests said that Christian girls who are being converted to Islam and taken abroad are not living a dignified pious life, but are forced to become sex slaves.

“Many are even scared to use the term ‘Love Jihad’ but the Synod has now come out and said the exact words. There are reports of Christian girls getting converted and taken abroad. They are not living an ideal pious life either. They are made to live with more than one person and some are even pushed into becoming sex slaves,” said Syro-Malabar Media Commission secretary Fr Antony Thalachelloor.

Fr Thalachelloor said that the recent incidents in Kozhikode in which a 19-year-old woman was sexually abused and blackmailed into converting and instances of Christian women joining the Islamic State are examples of instances that got the Church worried. “It has also come to our notice that a Christian teenager was brutally stabbed to death after getting lured into an affair. Love affairs used to happen earlier as well, but the Church cannot overlook girls, especially Christian girls, getting targeted and later murdered on the pretext of ‘love’,” said Fr Thalachalloor.

The Synod, in its statement on Wednesday, said that movements like Love Jihad getting stronger would endanger communal harmony and peace in Kerala. It pointed out that around half of the 21 youths recruited to ISIS from the state were Christians. “It is a serious concern that several girls who are not accounted for in official records are being used for terrorist activities through Love Jihad. Statistics show that Love Jihad is not an illusion. It is a sad fact that police are not taking appropriate action in complaints,” the statement said.

Synod however said that they don’t observe Love Jihad in a way that it would affect the friendship between religions in the state. Instead of looking at it religiously, the authorities should look at it as a menace that would negatively affect the society.

BJP demands probe into issue

BJP leader Kummanam Rajasekharan has said the complaints raised by the Synod should be taken seriously and there should be a probe into the allegations.

He said such complaints are increasing in the state and the Synod’s demand that strict action be taken should be welcomed. “However, finance minister Thomas Isaac is learnt to have rubbished the claims made by the Church. This shows the CPM-Congress jihadi nexus,” he said.

The BJP leader said it is a serious allegation and the state government is turning a blind eye towards the issue.

Hundreds of complaints have been filed in various police stations across the state on the Love Jihad. But no arrests have been made so far in such cases, he alleged.

Meanwhile state police chief Loknath Behera said that they do not have any information on the matter. “If there is anything specific, the police will take necessary action,” he said.

Title: Life term convict found hanging in Hazaribag jail
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Hazaribag: A man serving life imprisonment was found hanging in his prison cell at Hazaribag ’s Jai Prakash Narayan Central Jail around 2:30am on Wednesday. Yogesh Kumar Chauhan (32), a resident of Dhanbad, was in prison since 2015, after a local court found him guilty of murdering a relative, the jail authorities said.

Jail authorities said some inmates in the adjoining cell saw Chauhan hanging from the ceiling by a pajama in the early hours of Wednesday. Jail guards have sent the body for autopsy to the district hospital. The body was handed over to Chauhan’s relatives later in the day. Jail superintendent Hamid Akhtar said a case of unnatural death was registered with the Hazaribag sadar police station and a probe has been initiated. Akhtar said Chauhan may have hanged himself due to depression as he was being taken to Ranchi Institute of Neuro Psychiatry and Allied Sciences for treatment since the past few months.

Title: Open to induct JVM-P MLAs if Babulal joins BJP: Oraon
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Ranchi: State Congress president Rameshwar Oraon on Wednesday said the party is willing to welcome JVM-P legislators in its fold if they are willing to come on board, provided “they are willing to agree to certain pre-conditions of the party”.

Speaking at the sidelines of a Dahi-Chuda feast hosted by the grand old party on the occasion of Makar Sankranti at its state headquarters here, the 72-year-old IPS-turned-politician said, “Our party always welcomes like-minded people with open arms. Therefore, if JVM-P legislators want to join, they are welcome, but they must agree to certain conditions.” When prodded about the conditions, Oraon, who is a minister in Hemant Soren’s cabinet, did not divulge anything.

Notably, JVM-P insiders said Poriyahat MLA Pradeep Yadav and Mandar MLA Bandhu Tirkey are in touch with several opposition parties since speculations surfaced that party chief Babulal Marandi is contemplating merging the outfit with BJP. While Marandi has been tight-lipped about the issue, BJP sources said that he is in touch with its national vice-president Om Prakash Mathur. The BJP sources added that Marandi has been offered the post of leader of opposition in Jharkhand assembly if he comes on board.

Tirkey is in touch with Oraon for a possible switch since speculations began earlier this month. Yadav, who claimed he will not join BJP, had met Soren prior to the state assembly polls and sought to contest from Poriyahat on a JMM ticket after he was isolated within JVM-P after being released from jail on bail in a sexual assault case lodged against him in Deoghar in April last year. Yadav was eventually fielded by JVM-P. When contacted, Tirkey declined to comment. “I will speak at the right time,” he told TOI.

JVM-P insiders are waiting for Marandi to return from his overseas trip on Thursday. Marandi, the first chief minister of Jharkhand, had left BJP in 2006 following differences with the state leadership and floated JVM-P.

JVM-P made its electoral debut in 2009 assembly polls and won 11 seats in coalition with Congress. Over the next decade, Marandi and his party’s popularity waned as it won eight seats in 2014 state assembly polls and three in last year’s assembly election. “Realising that his popularity is waning, Babulal Ji has begun thinking of his political future and may be looking for a win-win situation thinking the BJP will project him as its CM face in the 2024 state assembly election,” a JVM-P functionary close to Marandi said on Wednesday.

Title: CM urges Centre to bring back body of man who died in UAE
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Ranchi: Chief minister Hemant Soren on Wednesday sought the Centre ’s help to bring back the mortal remains of Jay Prakash Mahto (30), who died at his workplace in UAE on December 28 after an accident. Mahto’s family members had been running from pillar to post to bring back his body, but to no avail. Mahto was a resident of Manohartand in Dhanbad’s Sindri.

Reacting to an appeal on Twitter by Mahto’s nephew, Hemant Tweeted, “Would like to draw immediate attention of .@IndembAbuDhabi .@MEAIndia & .@DrSJaishankar 'ji to the plight of this family in Dhanbad. State administration through @dc_dhanbad has already sent all necessary documents to expedite the procedure. Our thoughts are with the deceased's family.”

Later, the CM said, “I sought help from the central government to ensure that Mahto’s mortal remains is brought back to India so that his family members can pay their last respects. I have also contacted the Indian Embassy of UAE, located in Abu Dhabi, Union ministry of external affairs and Dr S Jaishankar. The deputy commissioner of Dhanbad has also initiated the necessary formalities with the foreign ministry to expedite the matter.”

Dhanbad DC Amit Kumar said, “We have furnished all details to the Union ministry of external affairs. In UAE, it takes three to four weeks to complete all legal formalities in cases of accidental deaths. We are expediting the matter and I have taken UAE’s contact details. The body will be brought home soon.”

Jay used to work as a pipe fitter in Saudi Services for Electro Mechanic Works Company in Al-Qassim region of UAE. His brother Om Prakash Mahto told TOI: “Jay went to Saudi Arabia on June 24, 2019 through a private agency in Gujarat. He used to work in an industrial unit in UAE as a pipe fitter. While on job, he met with an accident and died on December 28. It has been 18 days, but we are yet to pay our last respects or complete the final rites.”

Mahto is survived by his wife and two young children, aged nine months and three years. Om added, “All our efforts to bring my brother’s mortal remains back home failed. Finally, when my nephew Tweeted on this matter, the chief minister took note. We are hopeful that the body will be brought back to us at the earliest.”

The Mahto family has lost its sole breadwinner in Jay. “I am unemployed and our family of six members apart from our three married sisters used to rely on the money that Jay used to send from there. I lost my beloved brother and we lost our only source of sustenance. We hope the state government comes to our aid and helps us by providing a family member with a job,” Om said.

Title: In Bokaro, village archery champ gets land for a year on Makar Sankranti
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Bokaro: Gupteswar Mahto won a farmland for a year in a unique annual competition organised at Manjura village in Kasmar Block on Makar Sakranti. The village hosts a traditional archery competition with the winner awarded the right to farm on a plot of land for one year. The event draws thousands of spectators from nearby. “A total of 83 villagers took part in the competition this year,” said Dhaneshwar Singh, ward member of Manjura

The competion, called Bhegha Bindana (archery), is being organised for more than 150 years and gives chance to poverty-stricken people to improve their living condition, locals said. The tradition was started by the landlord of the Manjura village.

The winner is awarded a .25 acres of land in which they can do whatever they want for a year. As the land is fertile, the winners usually grow food grains and vegetables. “Any villager, poor or rich, can participate in the event organized in Gend Khela ground on the banks of the Khajo river. The archery competition was started by my ancestor Ritvaram Mahto,” said S N Mahto, the organiser of the event.

Mahto added: “It has now become a part of our tradition. Since this custom was started by my fore farthers, this piece of land keeps circulating between the winners. Apart from any member of our family, anyone can win the land. Even people belonging to Muslim community try their luck in the competition”.

Title: Dry on revenue, government moots lifting Chandrapur liquor ban
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Representational image

NAGPUR: With dwindling revenues and precarious financial position, the Maharashtra government has decided to mop up funds through additional mobilization. A meeting was conducted under deputy chief minister Ajit Pawar on Tuesday where various departments came out with their respective proposals.

Excise Department too, put up its proposal where it suggested to lift the liquor ban from Chandrapur. It was also proposed to stretch wine shops closing time by one hour till 11.30pm in the state.

According to senior excise officials, state was earning Rs242 crore annually from Chandrapur district from excise duty till 2014-15, which it was losing out since last five years. They asserted that the ban failed to serve its purpose as illicit smuggling cases jumped to a new high. On condition of anonymity, they told TOI that Pawar and other ministers responded positively to the proposal and planning to discuss it during next cabinet meeting.

After large-scale demands from women in Chandrapur, the previous BJP-led government led by ex-chief minister Devendra Fadnavis had imposed the liquor prohibition in 2015. It was third district in state and Vidarbha as well after Wardha and Gadchiroli where liquor consumption was prohibited. The large scale resentment due to the ban had led to shocking loss of former union minister and six times MP Hansraj Ahir from liquor baron Suresh alias Balu Dhanorkar, who is demanding lifting of ban since his victory.

Excise officials told TOI that their proposal was discussed in detail where they presented statistics of last five years which included losses suffered and amount of illicit liquor seized. “We informed them on investigations by the cops in liquor smuggling cases, both in terms and number of crimes and as well as amount confiscated which surged in last five years.”

They also pointed out that the revenue figures would have increased in last five years if the ban wasn’t implemented. “We’re losing out on precious revenue of over Rs250 crore since last five years. This amount could have been utilized for better purposes like for farmers. Large-scale smuggling of illicit liquor is defeating the very purpose of prohibition.”

The government’s move however received mixed reactions from the public representatives and other netas from the district.

Social activist Paromita Goswami, the main leader who started the movement to prohibit liquor in Chandrapur through her organization Sharamik Elgar Parishad, said she and her organization would steadfastly oppose any such move by the government. “I am going to conduct a press meet on Thursday in this regard. We will inform on how the liquor ban has immensely benefited the people here and why it should be continued.”

Netas like MLA Kishor Jorgewar stressed on that a thorough review must be conducted before relaxing the prohibition. “The government needs to take a look on pros and cons of the ban in last five years. Not only the revenue losses, but also incidents of illegal smuggling and sale of illicit or spurious liquor should be taken into account. I’ve heard that over 40,000 offences have been lodged against illegal consumption.”

Defending BJP government’s move of prohibition in Chandrapur, former excise minister Chandrashekhar Bawankule said decision was taken after 90% Gram Panchayats passed a resolution in this regard, which was well supported by majority of women. “They can’t lift the ban by simply citing revenue losses. Instead they should strengthen the mechanism to prevent sale of illicit liquor by combining the police and excise force to launch the operations. I think the womenfolk there would strongly oppose any such move,” he said.

Title: Naravane: Junking Art 370 historic step, will help integration
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

NEW DELHI: The abrogation of Jammu & Kashmir ’s special status under Article 370 is “a historic step” that will help J&K integrate with the mainstream, while also disrupt the cross-border proxy war being fuelled by Pakistan , Army chief General MM Naravane said on Wednesday.

He also said the Indian armed forces have “zero-tolerance against terrorism” and are fully capable of exercising “many options to counter those who promote” it. “We will not hesitate to use the options...We will respond in equal measure,” said Naravane, addressing the annual Army Day parade here.

He had earlier told TOI that there were enough viable and effective options to teach punitive lessons to Pakistan for aiding and abetting cross-border terrorism without crossing its nuclear red-lines, as was done during the “surgical strikes” of September 2016 and the Balakot air strikes in February last year.

On Wednesday, he said, “The scrapping of Article 370 is a historic step, which will connect J&K with the rest of the country. The decision has adversely affected the plans of the western neighbour and its proxies.”

The Army chief also said that he would ensure the 1.3-million strong Army continues to be “operationally ready” to meet any challenge of conventional warfare or threat posed by cross-border terrorism.

Title: Saqib Saleem shares a shirtless picture and dedicates it to his '83' co-star Ranveer Singh; the latter comments, 'sharrma gyaa'
Content: Kabir Khan's sports drama has been the talk of the town since the announcement. The film is based on the Indian cricket team's iconic world cup win in 1983. The cast of the film has been sharing the individual posters of their characters on their respective social media handles. Saqib Saleem who is portraying the role of Mohinder Amarnath recently took to his Instagram account to share a shirtless picture flaunting his chiselled physique post a workout session. He dedicated the picture for his '83' co-star Ranveer Singh who will be seen as the then captain of the team Kapil Dev He captioned the post, "Anything for my captain!. This ones for you as promised @ranveersingh#humpdaymotivation #teamplayer #casuallyshowingoff #instamood #abs"Ranveer was quick to comment on his post. The 'Gully Boy' actor wrote, "Hehehehehehe *sharrma gyaa* 🥰"Check out the post here:Meanwhile, the film also stars Tahir Raj Bhasin , Jatin Sarna, Pankaj Tripathi, Jiiva , Harrdy Sandhu, Amy Virk and Deepika Padukone as Kapil Dev's wife Romi Dev.The film has been slated for April 2020 release.

Content:
#Throwback to the first encounter with Yashpal sir. It was one hell of an experience to learn it from the man himse… https://t.co/fQ3qZRkZOT — Jatin sarna (@jatinsarna) 1579093497000

Title: Audi India to sell only petrol cars for now
Content:
Audi India head Balbir Singh Dhillon (left) cricketer Virat Kohli during Q8 launch.

MUMBAI: Audi India will sell only petrol vehicles this year with all Volkswagen Group companies still reeling under the ‘Dieselgate’ crisis that had hit the group in Europe five years ago. With diesel engine powering 70% of Audi cars sold in India in 2019, its absence combined with a severely depleted portfolio as the company migrates from BS IV to BS VI emission regime, may see the German luxury brand’s sales slide to a 10-year-low mark.From a high in 2015 when it sold 11,192 cars, sales have slipped to 4,595 units in 2019. The carmaker had till 2013 led the pack of luxury carmakers, beating both Mercedes-Benz and BMW . However, its sales have plummeted since 2016.Speaking on the sidelines of the launch of premium SUV Q8, only its second BS VI model after sedan A6 launched last year, Audi India head Balbir Singh Dhillon acknowledged that the year would be a challenging one. It is only from 2021 onwards when its portfolio will be replenished and strategy on both diesel and electric firmed up that the turnaround can kickoff.“This year will be a challenging one, not only for Audi, but the entire industry. I see a flat year in the luxury market. The change from BS IV to BS VI cannot happen overnight. These are among the headwinds that we will face. The absence of diesel will also be felt. But we hope to emerge from all this stronger,” said Dhillon.Audi India had 13 models, many of them with multiple engine options. Going forward, it plans to reintroduce all of them but with only petrol as of now. They include the high volume A4, and Q3. The company days the response to A6 petrol sedan has been encouraging. The Q8 petrol SUV priced Rs 1.3 crore will test the waters. But the real indication of whether customers embrace petrol SUVs will come with the launch of Q3, Q5 and Q7.Suspending diesel powertrains is a global fallout of the emission fudging accusations that Volkswagen Group had faced in Europe and the US. The conglomerate decided to drop diesel engines in the short term to emerge from the crisis. Dhillon said that the brand had not given up on diesels and was still evaluating its diesel strategy for India.Dhillon said Audi would launch one product every quarter. “Not only will they all be BS VI, they will also be either new generation vehicles or refreshed versions of the current ones.” The company had firming up a strategy for 2025 based on four pillars: Customer centricity, products, network and digitalisation.Audi is also set to launch the pure electric SUV e-tron in 2020. It will, however, continue to focus on petrol-driven cars.

Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Audi India head Balbir Singh Dhillon (left) cricketer Virat Kohli during Q8 launch.

MUMBAI: Audi India will sell only petrol vehicles this year with all Volkswagen Group companies still reeling under the ‘Dieselgate’ crisis that had hit the group in Europe five years ago. With diesel engine powering 70% of Audi cars sold in India in 2019, its absence combined with a severely depleted portfolio as the company migrates from BS IV to BS VI emission regime, may see the German luxury brand’s sales slide to a 10-year-low mark.

From a high in 2015 when it sold 11,192 cars, sales have slipped to 4,595 units in 2019. The carmaker had till 2013 led the pack of luxury carmakers, beating both Mercedes-Benz and BMW . However, its sales have plummeted since 2016.

Speaking on the sidelines of the launch of premium SUV Q8, only its second BS VI model after sedan A6 launched last year, Audi India head Balbir Singh Dhillon acknowledged that the year would be a challenging one. It is only from 2021 onwards when its portfolio will be replenished and strategy on both diesel and electric firmed up that the turnaround can kickoff.

“This year will be a challenging one, not only for Audi, but the entire industry. I see a flat year in the luxury market. The change from BS IV to BS VI cannot happen overnight. These are among the headwinds that we will face. The absence of diesel will also be felt. But we hope to emerge from all this stronger,” said Dhillon.

Audi India had 13 models, many of them with multiple engine options. Going forward, it plans to reintroduce all of them but with only petrol as of now. They include the high volume A4, and Q3. The company days the response to A6 petrol sedan has been encouraging. The Q8 petrol SUV priced Rs 1.3 crore will test the waters. But the real indication of whether customers embrace petrol SUVs will come with the launch of Q3, Q5 and Q7.

Suspending diesel powertrains is a global fallout of the emission fudging accusations that Volkswagen Group had faced in Europe and the US. Dhillon said Audi would launch one product every quarter. “Not only will they all be BS VI, they will also be either new generation vehicles or refreshed versions of the current ones.” The company had firming up a strategy for 2025 based on four pillars: Customer centricity, products, network and digitalisation.

Audi is also set to launch the pure electric SUV e-tron in 2020. It will, however, continue to focus on petrol-driven cars.

Title: China tries to raise Kashmir issue at UNSC again, hits French wall
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Indian Envoy to UN Syed Akbaruddin at UNSC in New York

NEW DELHI: In yet another bid to raise Kashmir at UN Security Council, China on Wednesday gave notice for discussion on issue. The discussion was slated for late in the night after informal consultations on other issues.

However, the move is likely to be thwarted again with French diplomatic sources saying the issue could only be resolved bilaterally. French sources said France knew a UNSC member wanted to raise the Kashmir issue but it was opposed to it. “France’s position has not changed and is very clear: The Kashmir issue must be settled bilaterally — as we have stated on several occasions and will continue to reiterate it to our partners on the UNSC,” a French source said.

Last month, France, the US, the UK and Russia had foiled an attempt by China to discuss Kashmir at a closed-door meeting of the UNSC. A closed-door meeting had been called to discuss an issue relating to an African country. China made a request to deliberate on the Kashmir issue under the agenda of “any other business points”.

Title: Mangaluru City Corporation council will be constituted soon, says Vedavyas Kamath
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Mangaluru: The council of Mangaluru City Corporation ( MCC ) will be constituted soon, said Mangaluru City South MLA D Vedavyas Kamath . The delay in this regard was on account of byelections to assembly constituencies across Karnataka, he said. He said the government could not take a decision in this regard earlier due to the byelections, and not any other reason, hitting back at the Congress leaders who had demanded that the government constitute the council soon.

The MLA wondered if the Congress had forgotten the past when the last time it came back to power and elections to the post of mayor and deputy mayor for the first term of the council’s five-year term was delayed by a year. Congress leaders must also admit to their failure to mop up much needed revenue to shore up the civic body’s finances when it was in power from 2014 to 2019, he said, adding they can’t shift the blame on the BJP for this.

The Congress leaders have alleged that the civic body that was ranked sixth or seventh in the All India Swachh Survekshan rankings had slipped to the 152nd position. This is a tacit admission of its failure to meet the benchmarks set up by the Union ministry or urban development department that determined nationwide Swachh Survekshan ratings during its tenure. The BJP that is yet to take charge of the council has no connection with this accusation, he said

Asserting that the people of this coastal city will witness a qualitative change in administration once the BJP-led council assumes power, Kamath said the party being in power at the state and Centre will help make this difference. The BJP had won more than two-thirds majority in the election to the council held on November 12, winning 44 out of the 60 wards for which the election was held, with the ruling Congress winning only 14 wards and SDPI two wards.

Title: Joshi upset with trees being chopped at entrance of Nehru Stadium
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

HUBBALLI: The chopping of as many as seven Ashoka trees, and the pruning of branches of Gulmohar trees at the entrance of Nehru Stadium purportedly for security purposes has irked Union minister for parliamentary affairs Pralhad Joshi . The minister reprimanded the officials of the Hubballi-Dharwad Municipal Corporation ( HDMC ) for allowing the trees to be felled.

Terming the loss of trees ‘unfortunate, Joshi told the officials, “You do not have any concern for trees that take more than 10 years to grow. You have completely disregarded the fact that they too have life.”

Directing officials of the forest department to initiate stringent action against the errant HDMC officials, Joshi clarified that chopping of trees was not part of the BJP’s preparations for Union home minister Amit Shah ’s rally at the venue. “The forest department must ensure that those responsible for the loss of trees, regardless of what influence they have and the seniority of their positions, are held accountable. We are not here to organise rallies by cutting trees, and disrupting the ecological balance,” the minister said.

When Joshi questioned the police inspector entrusted with making security arrangements for Shah’s rally about the chopped trees, the cop replied that police had suggested that a few branches be pruned. “We were not aware that entire trees would be felled,” the inspector said.

HDMC commissioner Suresh Itnal said that the civic agency had decided to prune some of the branches of trees at the entrance of Nehru Stadium in order to ensure hassle-free movement of Shah’s convoy. “I had no idea that trees would be chopped. I have directed the zonal assistant commissioner concerned to look into the incident and submit a report,” Itnal added.

Shettar, Bommai take stock of preparations

Meanwhile, Dharwad district in-charge minister Jagadish Shettar, accompanied by Joshi, visited Nehru Stadium to take stock of the preparations for the Union home minister’s rally scheduled on Saturday.

Karnataka home minister Basavaraj Bommai too paid a visit, before Shettar and Joshi, to the venue and inspected the arrangements being made. Expressing satisfaction with the preparations, he said, “Adequate arrangements have been made to keep order during the rally.”

Title: Build subway, restrict movement of buses to decongest Rani Channamma Circle, says study
Content: HUBBALLI: Restrict bus movement , divert long-route ones, improve pedestrian infrastructure and enforce parking norms strictly: these are some of the recommendations of a team from the North Western Karnataka Road Transport Corporation to decongest Rani Chennamma Circle.The intersection is one of the busiest in the twin circles, marking the convergence of eight major roads. The proposal for a flyover to decongest traffic is still on the backburner.The team of Vivekanand Vishwadanya, divisional controller of HDCTD; Mahadev R Munji, divisional controller, Belagavi; Ashok Patil, divisional traffic officer, and assistant traffic manager RL Kumarswamy; have prepared the report as part of their one-year programme on leaders in urban transport organised by IUT, New Delhi.Their study has suggested long-term, short-term and immediate steps, including regulatory and enforcement measures. The study factors in data provided by different departments such as public works, RTO, NHAI and police.The team suggested restricting the movement of buses based on demand, performance and time. Many buses can be diverted and long-route ones kept off the busy intersection, they said. While curbing bus movement, adequate public transport facilities have to be provided. The study also called for a clampdown on unauthorised parking and improving pedestrian infrastructure. No-parking and one-way rules must be strictly enforced, it said.The call for better public transport facilities comes on the finding that private transport makes up 84% of the traffic at the circle while the share of intermediate public transport (autos, cabs) is 7.3%. Public transport makes up barely 2%, says the study. More than 70% of the private vehicles are two-wheelers while four-wheelers are 14%. Auto-rickshaws and cabs have a share of 6.3% and 1% respectively.Poor traffic planning, the study points out, has caused multiple and overlapping movements, leading to congestion at the meeting point.Another major factor is encroachment of roads and footpaths by hawkers and illegally parked vehicles. Too many public and commercial activities are also held at the circle, leading to crowding.To improve the lot of pedestrians on the Dharwad, Niligin and Bijapur road – on average there are 35 pedestrians a minute, the study found – the NWKRTC team said a subway was required to ensure smooth flow. Pick-up and drop-off zones for auto and cab passengers should also be demarcated to ensure vehicles don’t lurk at all points.

Title: Angadi bats for naming Belagavi airport after Rani Channamma
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

BELAGAVI: Union minister of state for railways Suresh Angadi on Tuesday wrote to the deputy commissioner (DC) of Belagavi requesting that the Belagavi airport be renamed Veer Rani Kittur Channamma.

His communication comes in the wake of state government’s letter to DCs of five districts -- Mangaluru, Mysuru, Kalaburagi, Dharwad and Belagavi-- on December 13 and a reminder on January 7. However, the central government had rejected the name for Belagavi airport in 2018.

On December 13, 2018, the then chief minister answering a question of then chief whip of the opposition in the legislative council, Mahantesh Mallikarjun, said “the state had sent a proposal to rename the airport as Veer Rani Kittur Channamma. But the proposal was rejected by the Union civil aviation ministry.”

Suresh Angadi in his letter (copy available) stated that “it is requested to initiate necessary measures towards the naming of Belagavi Sambra Airport as Veer Rani Kittur Channamma Airport and fulfil the long-standing dream of Belagavi district residents. But, so far, no steps seem to have been initiated.”

C T Ravi, Minister for Tourism, said the state government is gathering feedback from all these districts for renaming of airports and the cabinet will sit and deliberate on the same. The finalised names will be sent to central government.

Ashok Chandaragi, a pro-Kannada activist pointed that Angadi in his letter has mentioned that so far, no steps were initiated to rename the airport. This is blatantly untrue, he added. “The previous coalition government headed by H D Kumaraswamy had made a proposal and it was rejected. The statement of Angadi suggests he is trying to take credit for the renaming, if it happens,” he claimed.

Angadi was unavailable for comments when ToI contacted him while Congress leader H K Patil said Rani Channamma is a deserving name for the airport.

Title: ‘Muslims have sacrificed themselves in cause of freedom struggle’
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Dharwad: The Citizenship (Amendment) Act ( CAA ) is a ploy by the BJP to divide the country on religious lines, charged social activist Kavita Reddy here on Wednesday. Participating in a protest at Anjuman-e-Islam Grounds, Kavita sought to remind the BJP of the sacrifice of the members of Muslim community in the cause of the Freedom Struggle.

Pointing out that neither the BJP nor the RSS had participated in the struggle for independence, Kavita set the martyrdom of Muslim freedom fighters in stark relief. “The BJP is using the CAA to invoke hatred in the minds of youngsters, and provoking them to render the social fabric of our country weak,” she said.

Kavita said that, regardless of differences in traditions and customs, all religions stressed the tenets of humanity. “It is interesting that the Indian Flag is seen flying high at all events organised to protest the CAA, while in those rallies organised to endorse the law, we only see BJP flags. The BJP is adopting divisive policies to garner political mileage. The people must come forward and express their opposition to the CAA and the National Register of Citizens most vehemently,” she added.

Najma Nasir, an activist who participated in the rally, underscored the marginalised position of Muslims in Indian society. “Muslims are even more suppressed than Dalits. They do not want our Aadhaar cards, but are asking for the birth and domicile certificates of our forefathers. Collecting documents is not an easy task, which is why opposing CAA and NRC has become compulsory,” Najma said.

Basirat Mulla, meanwhile, pointed out that all citizens of the country were the children of Mother India. “The people are being patient with the government despite the economy being in the doldrums. The government must not discriminate between people based on religion and must ensure that everyone has equal opportunities,” she said.

Bhavya Narasimhamurthy, Isabella Xavier, Rajeeja Begum Sangolli were among those who participated in the protest.

Title: Road deaths: Mangaluru worst among tier-2 cities
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Representative image

HUBBALLI: Overturning notions of literacy, road sense, road condition and traffic management, data shows among tier-2 cities in the state, Mangaluru was the worst on rash and negligent driving leading to deaths, followed by Belagavi, Mysore and Hubballi-Dharwad .

Overall, though, predictably, congested Bengaluru city led the pack, registering four times the number of deaths in Mangaluru due to rash and negligent driving between 2015 and 2017.

Across the state, nearly 30,000 people were victims of rash and negligent driving in that period, data from the State Crime Records Bureau shows. Data for 2018 and 2019 is yet to compiled.

A comparison of the five top cities shows 2,164 people died in accidents in Bengaluru caused by rash driving while 536 people were killed in Mangaluru.

Mysuru has shown a spike between 2016 and 2017, from 102 deaths to 132 while it dropped sharply in Bengaluru (794 to 629) and Hubballi-Dharwad, from 104 to 87.

“It has been observed that most drivers, whether driving others’ vehicles or their own, are rash in the coastal region and Kerala. Probably private buses, which have been synonymous with rash driving due to intensified competition, have contributed to this,” said Dr Shivanand Hiremath, a psychiatrist at KIMS. “This shows that the people of North Karnataka may be seen as brash but they are diligent drivers compared to their coastal counterparts.”

However, Dr MC Sindhur, a medical practitioner and civic rights activist, said even these figures must be questioned. “Where are the roads in Hubballi-Dharwad? Road digging and repair works have been going on for the past 5-6 years and people are struggling to reach their destination in time. It’s good to know that such incomplete roads are saving lives at least,” he quipped.

Vijay V Mayya, former national vice-president of Association of Consulting Civil Engineers in Mangaluru, said roads in the city do not have any technical or civil engineering faults. “Almost all roads have been widened enough and have met all technical requirements. Road accidents are more here because of behavioural issues among drivers,” he said. “Though the education level is high in Mangaluru, on road rules, it is a city of educated illiterates. Wiser people are not behaving wisely on roads and becoming a threat for themselves and others.”

Title: Nagpur: Water in Laxmi Nagar, Dharampeth ‘unfit’ to drink
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Representative image

NAGPUR: Contrary to the popular perception about Laxmi Nagar and Dharampeth zones being tony localities, 27 out of 31 water samples found unfit for human consumption in all 10 zones in the city were from these two areas.

The Nagpur Municipal Corporation’s water works department, however, can heave a sigh of relief as nearly 92% of 381 water samples collected from across the city in December last year have been found fit for drinking.

The water works department (WWD) had carried out the exercise against the backdrop of water testing in metro cities last year by Bureau of Indian Standard (BIS).

NMC water works department executive engineer Shweta Banerjee told TOI that the department carried out the tests with the help of Regional Public Health Laboratory and Government Medical College and Hospital in the city.

As a first step, the department identified 381 water sampling points in the city’s 10 zones covering entire city. Subsequently, the team collected samples from five sources of raw water, covered 184 slum areas and outlets of 64 elevated reservoir storages and 128 localities other than slums strictly following the standard operating procedures. The samples were tested in the RPHL on 19 parameters including turbidity, hardness, fluoride, colour test and odour etc, she said. “Out of the 381 samples, 350 were tested satisfactory and 31 proved unsatisfactory,” said Banerjee.

“Water supplied by the NMC is potable and if residents ensure their sumps or tanks are regularly cleaned, they can drink water straight from the tap,” she added.

Though Ashi Nagar, Satranjipura and Lakadganj zones are infamous for illegal connections, samples tested from these localities were found perfectly okay. The highest number of contaminated water samples were found in Dharampeth zone. Here, the tests revealed 17 different spots where residents are getting contaminated water in their taps. It was followed by Laxmi Nagar zone. Here, 10 locations were found where residents received contaminated water from the taps when the samples were collected.

In Dharampeth zone, the samples were collected a day after shut down announced to carry out some repair work. In all the 17 samples, the tests found no chlorine content. About Laxmi Nagar zone, Banerjee said the source of contamination was leak in the sewerage network and water pipeline.

One each unfit water sample was found under Gandhibagh zone, Nehru Nagar zone, Hanuman Nagar zone and Dhantoli zone, respectively. The test also showed that most slum dwellers are getting safe water. Of the 184 samples, only 12 were found unfit.

Besides this, Orange City Water – the company entrusted with 24x7 water supply and maintenance — regularly collects water samples and tests the quality. To a query, Banerjee claimed that the response time to every complaint of contamination that was received has been reduced significantly.

“Whenever a complaint is received, we immediately collect samples, supply to the area is stopped and water is being supplied through tankers. After rectifying the fault, we flush out the network and then charge it. Samples are collected once again and only if the contamination has been removed, we restore the supply,” she said.

Title: Nagpur: MSEDCL proposes astronomical Grid Support Charge for solar rooftop
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Representational image

NAGPUR: Even as solar rooftop consumers were celebrating the relief given to them by Maharashtra Electricity Regulatory Commission (MERC), MSEDCL has dropped a bombshell. It has proposed astronomical grid support charges, which will make solar power costlier than its own power.

The discom, it seems, is hell bent on scuttling the nascent solar sector in the state. MERC will have to once again reject its petition to save solar consumers.

MERC had recently dismissed the discom’s petition to make net billing compulsory instead of net metering. It had, however, allowed MSEDCL to levy grid support charge (GSC) for consumers having load more than 10 KW.

The discom has proposed GSC ranging from Rs 4.46 per unit to Rs 8.66 per unit for domestic consumers, between Rs 5.06 and Rs 8.76 per unit for commercial consumers and between Rs 3.60 per unit and Rs 4.08 per unit for industrial consumers.

A senior MSEDCL official admitted that if these charges were allowed by MERC, it would make solar rooftop power costlier than the discom tariff.

MSEDCL, in its petition submitted to MERC for making net billing compulsory, had stated that it has incurred a loss of Rs 224 crore so far. Moreover, solar rooftop load had increased from 20.44 MW in 2016-17 to 288.80 MW in 2018-19. The company feels that if paying consumers go out of its net, it will have to increase the tariff for remaining consumers.

The discom conveniently forgets that solar rooftop power is only 0.3% of its total power purchase. In 2018-19, solar rooftop consumers generated 330 million units (MU) against 1.2 lakh MU purchased by it.

More importantly, MSEDCL is unable to meet its solar renewable purchase obligation (RPO) target. It was able to meet only 40% of its RPO solar target in 2017-18.

MSEDCL itself is not getting any response to its bids to buy solar power. It had recently floated a tender for buying 1,350 MW but only one generator supplied a bid for 5 MW.

On the other hand, MERC has increased MSEDCL’s solar target from 2.5% in 2019-20 to 13.5% in 2024-25. MSEDCL has protested this increase and told MERC that it is unachievable.

Commenting on the GSC, solar expert Ajit Ganguly said, “MERC had allowed MSEDCL to levy GSC so that it does not incur any losses. However, the proposed charges are so high that solar power will cost between Rs 14 and Rs 15 per unit. This is ridiculous. No other state in the country has done this.”

An industrialist said on the condition of anonymity, “MSEDCL wants to land the new government in trouble. Industries are finding it difficult to survive in the state due to high power tariff. Solar was the only option but MSEDCL wants to make it unviable.

Title: Nagpur: Central team quietly begins Swachh survey
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

NAGPUR: The team appointed by the Union ministry of housing and urban affairs arrived in Nagpur on Monday to inspect the city’s cleanliness based on various parameters of the Swachh Survekshan 2020. Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC) officials remained completely unaware about the number of people in the team and the locations they visited.

Nagpur is one of over 4,000 cities in the country which would be ranked on cleanliness in the survey. Some of the previous surveys witnessed poor ranking for the city. The parameters of the survey include segregation of waste, waste processing facilities, treating and reusing of waste water, and cleanliness at community and public toilets among others.

“The team is seeking information about the NMC’s measures based on all parameters of Swachh Survekshan 2020,” said a senior official of NMC’s solid waste management department.

It is learnt that the team is visiting markets and localities in the corporation limits to collect necessary information about the works or projects undertaken and completed by the NMC. The members are expected to continue their survey for the next 2-3 days, the official said.

Nagpur did not perform well in the Swachh Survekshan 2019 as its ranking had dropped from 55 in 2018 to 58.

The team will also collect citizens’ feedback which accounts for 1,500 marks in the survey. According to the data compiled by the Union ministry of housing and urban affairs, there had been a fair response from Nagpur citizens about their feedback related to cleanliness and sanitation status in their areas. Besides, the NMC has already secured 200 marks as over 20,000 citizens had downloaded Swachhta App.

“The NMC is taking all necessary measures to improve sanitation in the city and its ranking in the upcoming survey. However, it is impossible without citizens’ feedback,” the official said.

Mayor Sandip Joshi has warned owners of open plots in the city to ensure their properties remain clean or else the NMC will seize it. Currently, open plots across the city have turned garbage vulnerable points.

There is a rule under which the NMC can seize such plots, the mayor said during Walk and Talk with Mayor at Jijamata garden in Chhatrapati Nagar .

Title: Nagpur: Anglo Indians stand up to prove they aren’t going extinct
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Barry O' Brien ( President of AIAIA)

NAGPUR: Amid the protests over NRC and CAA , the micro minority of Anglo Indians too is gearing up for what it calls a struggle to keep their identity alive. A recent statement in Lok Sabha by Union law minister Ravi Shankar Prasad , that only 296 members of the community are left in the country, has left the Anglo Indians worried.

A bill that proposes to do away with the reservation for Anglo Indian community, two seats in Parliament and one in each state assembly, has been moved on the grounds that not many of the community are left.

As Anglo Indians prepare to prove their numbers, and show their tribe is not on the way to extinction, they say there are easily over 300 in Nagpur alone, leave aside 296 across the country.

The All India Anglo Indian Association (AIAIA) has written a letter to Prime Minister Narendra Modi saying that a section of the community is feeling that a second betrayal is at hand, this time by the country’s elected government. The first is a reference to what happened after independence, when the British left them to their own fate. An appointment has also been sought from Modi, apart from Union home minister Amit Shah and the law minister.

Barry O’ Brien, president of (AIAIA), said a general estimate in the community is that there must be at least 3 lakh Anglo Indians in the country. “The Constitution defines any person whose father was a European and mother an Indian to be Anglo Indian. Despite the varied descent from father’s side, all types of Anglo Indians have a single culture and a common mother tongue, that is English,” he said.

The AIAIA is now bringing all state and city-level associations on one platform, so that a confirmed number can be reported. Brien, who was in Nagpur, also attended one such meet of the city unit of Anglo Indians association.

“After the developments, we have been approached by an association in Kerala, which has over 40,000 members. So far there had not been much coordination between the different associations spread across the country, which are now coming together for the cause,” he said.

Antony Besterwitch, president of the Nagpur unit, said the association here has 110 families as members. This means the number easily crosses 297 here in Nagpur itself. Apart from this, there are 25 families that are not members of the association, yet part of the community.

“Some choose not to be part of the outfit only because of reasons like lack of time to attend meetings or they stay far away,” said Besterwitch. There are Anglo Indian pockets in other cities like Bhusawal, Pune, Jabalpur and Bilaspur too, he said.

Title: Maharashtra: Excise revenue up 10% as liquor sales increase
Content:
Liquor sales in the state have increased since last year. (File photo)

More dry days but liquor sales rose

MUMBAI: The economic slowdown has impacted many sectors, but liquor sales in the state have increased since last year. State excise collections have risen by almost 10% in the nine-month span between April and December 2019-the first three quarters of the 2019-20 financial year -compared to the same period in 2018. But the collections remain short of the target and by the end of the financial year, the shortfall could amount to Rs 810 crore.The sale of Indian-made foreign liquor (IMFL) rose by 5.8%, country liquor by 4% and beer by 2.5% in 2019, latest data shows. Wine sales in the state rose by 1.2% during this period.The highest volume of sale was from country liquor, which was 2,713 bulk litres, followed by beer sales at 2,342 bulk litres. IMFL sales were 1,624 bulk litres and wine sales were 54 bulk litres in April-December 2019.State excise collections during the first three quarters of 2019-20 totalled Rs 11,555 crore, up from Rs 10,546 crore during the same period in 2018. Sales rose despite additional dry days on account of the Lok Sabha and state assembly elections.But the fact remains that excise collections have fallen short of the target for the cash-strapped state, for which this is a key revenue earner. The state excise collection target for 2019-20 is Rs 17,477 crore. But the collections by year-end are expected at Rs 16,667 crore, amounting to a shortfall of Rs 810 crore.Although excise collections have grown by nearly 10% since 2018, the annual growth target was 14%. Indeed, state excise collections grew by this much during the previous financial year, when the highway ban on liquor shops was lifted, resulting in a surge in alcohol sales.Between April and December 2019, the monthly excise collection was Rs 1,284 crore as against a target of Rs 1,456 crore. That’s a shortfall of Rs 172 crore per month. To meet the annual target, excise revenues for the remaining three months of the financial year will have to rise to Rs 1,974 crore per month.State excise commissioner Prajakta Lavangare says excise collections are likely to pick up in the coming months. “Liquor sales have gone up compared to 2018 and we expect an improvement in excise collections in the remaining three months of the financial year,” she says.Officials say while sales may not have met the excise target so far, the target needed to be more aligned to the sales trend. They also say the main factor affecting liquor sales in the state was the higher tax rate than in neighbouring states like Goa, which have much lower MRPs.

Title: CBI team in J&K for Patnitop probe
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

NEW DELHI: The CBI has dispatched a special team of 30 officers to probe alleged violations of the master plan in the Patnitop area in Jammu & Kashmir, a fortnight after the state high court directed the agency to complete the investigation within eight weeks and submit its report.

Sources said the role of a former minister was under the scanner and he may soon be asked to join investigation. The agency had registered a preliminary enquiry to probe complaints that 59 hotels and resorts were violating the master plan, officials said.

The special team was rushed to cover the “exhaustive probe” even as the agency faces a tight deadline. The officials are learnt to be stationed in Patnitop, Udhampur and Jammu and have collected documents of 50 properties in question from various authorities of the newly created Union Territory.

It has been alleged that 70% of hotels in Patnitop were running without registration and authorisation from the competent authority. “Non-compoundable deviation by property owners in Patnitop area was illegally compounded by a special tribunal which was not challenged in most of the cases by the Patnitop Development Authority,” an official said.

The authorities took no action despite non deposit of compounding fee by the hoteliers, he said. The tribunal compounded violations even in instances where no permission was taken for raising buildings , he said. Hotel owners had put electricity and water connections obtained for domestic use to commercial use and the properties were being run on the licences for guesthouses, the official added.

On December 31 last year, a Jammu & Kashmir high court division bench of Chief Justice Gita Mittal and Justice Rajesh Bindal had directed the CBI to start an investigation into all aspects of the case, including issue of licences and permissions granted within the jurisdiction of the Patnitop Development Authority. The bench, taking note of a report prepared by the CEO of Patnitop Development Authority on its October order, had said the report detailed the permitted land use, existing use, violations as well as encroachments.

The bench was hearing a PIL filed by Harcharan Singh, owner of Krystal Hotel and Restaurant in Patnitop, seeking demolition of illegal and unauthorised buildings raised in the green buffer areas of the hill resort.

The bench noted that the report showed several of these guesthouses and hotels were misusing the land, which was earmarked for agriculture and where the Jammu and Kashmir Agrarian Reforms Act, 1976, was applicable.

Title: Indo-Pacific a divisive concept meant to contain China: Russia
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Describing the Indo-Pacific as a divisive concept, Russian foreign minister Sergey Lavrov on Wednesday said the initiative was meant to contain China.

The new Indo-Pacific concept being pushed by the US, Japan and others was an attempt to reconfigure the existing structure, he said. “Why do you need to call Asia Pacific Indo-Pacific? The answer is evident — to exclude China. Terminology should be unifying, not divisive. Neither SCO nor Brics is exclusionary,” Lavrov said. The Russian minister also backed India and Brazil to be permanent members of the UN Security Council.

Speaking at the Raisina Dialogue, he also said an equitable democratic order should not be influenced by use of brutal force. “When we asked the initiators how Indo-Pacific is different from Asia Pacific, we were told it is more democratic. We don’t think so. It is rather tricky. We have to be careful about the terminology which looks benign but is not,” he said.

The Indo-Pacific has been a major focus area of India’s foreign policy in the last few years as the country pushes for peace and stability in the region.

Lavrov later called on PM Narendra Modi and conveyed to him that President Vladimir Putin looked forward to the PM’s visit to Russia in May to participate in the 75th anniversary celebration of Victory Day, and in July for the Brics and SCO summits.

“The PM noted that several important decisions and outcomes were reached between the two countries in 2019. He suggested that the year 2020... should be the year of implementation of those decisions,” the government said in a statement.

Title: Maya names first-time MP, a Brahmin, as BSP’s LS chief
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

LUCKNOW: Making the fifth change in the leadership of her party in Lok Sabha in less than a year, BSP chief Mayawati has now appointed first time MP Ritesh Pandey (38), a foreign educated Brahmin from Ambedkarnagar, to head the party in the lower house.

Pandey has replaced Danish Ali, who joined BSP ahead of the 2019 Lok Sabha elections and was being perceived as the party’s Muslim face.

While announcing Pandey’s appointment, Mayawati said that since a Muslim was already heading BSP’s state unit, she needed to give representation to other communities. Incidentally, with Pandey’s appointment, two Brahmins are now heading the party in Parliament — Ritesh Pandey in Lok Sabha and SC Mishra in Rajya Sabha .

Ali’s removal, his second since August, comes in an apparent bid to ensure “equal representation” of all communities within BSP, though sources in the party said Mayawati was unhappy with his frequent challenging of her hold over the party. “To bring about social equality in BSP, we have had to make some changes in the party since the Lok Sabha leader and UP state president are both from the same community. Ritesh Pandey is now the leader of the party in Lok Sabha while Malook Nagar is the deputy leader. BSP state president Munqad Ali will remain in his position,” Mayawati said. Ali, who was earlier the Janata Dal (Secular) general secretary in Karnataka , has experienced a rocky ride in BSP. Appointed leader of the party in Lok Sabha in June, he was first removed in August 2019 when he reportedly disagreed with the party’s support to the Centre on revocation of Article 370 .

Title: Left-Congress to hold dharna on January 26
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Representative image

Enthused by the support Left and secular forces have been getting against CAA-NPR-NRC, Bengal CPM has decided to continue with the stir. Left parties will observe deshaprem divas on Netaji’s birthday on January 23.

The Left and Congress will jointly conduct a dharna programme for two hours on January 26 in all municipal wards and panchayats. The CPM state committee has also taken up campaign programmes against BJP-RSS on January 30, the day Mahatma Gandhi was killed.

At the same time, the Left will step up pressure on the West Bengal government demanding withdrawal of NPR exercise when the state government has put it on hold.

Title: Bigg Boss 13: Rashami Desai sacrifices her cup of tea for Sidharth Shukla; the latter calls her 'meri jaan'
Content: In the latest episode of Bigg Boss 13 , the limelight was attracted by former lovers Vishal Aditya Singh and Madhurima Tuli for their violent behaviour towards each other. While everyone was busy taking sides there was something else that caught our eyes, it was Rashami Desai and Sidharth Shukla 's cute banter.Rashami, who is friends with both Madhurima and Vishal, was first seen comforting Madhurima Tuli where even Shehnaz Gill was present and busy applying makeup on her face. Sidharth Shukla comes in and tells Rashami that she is supporting Madhurima. He also tells her that for the first time, she is taking a stand for somebody or else, she needs somebody else's support to take a stand for her own self.Sidharth tries initiating a conversation with Madhurima to understand what exactly happened and Rashami kept answering on her behalf. To which, Sidharth asked Rashami if she was her mouthpiece. Rashami agrees and Sidharth jokes saying since when did you get such a bad face.The Uttaran actress asks him that he is noticing her a lot these days and asks Shenaz Gill to keep an eye on him. Sidharth says that yes he has been noticing Rashami Desai since past three months now.Sidharth then goes in the living area and tries speaking to Vishal and ask where is he hurt. Rashami asks him to not irritate Vishal and make a fun out of it. Rashami brings two cups of tea and offers one to Vishal and keeps the other cup for herself. Sidharth asks Rashami if he can get a cup of tea. To which, Rashami Desai sacrifices her tea and says this time she isn't throwing it but handing it to him sensibly.Sidharth says that she has given the tea to him with so much love. Later, Rashami reveals that Asim Riaz has made the tea. Sidharth then gives the tea to Rashami and thanks her for the sweet gesture.While he returns the tea to Rashami, she tells him that he always instigates her. Her Dil Se Dil Tak co-actor then calls her "meri jaan" and asks her to prepare a list of dos and don'ts while speaking to her, and he would keep them in mind henceforth.

Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Mamata Banerjee speaks at her party’s dharna mancha at Esplanade

Title: Domkal BDO wants to suspend social audit
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Behrampore/Barrackpore: A block development officer in Murshidabad’s Domkal has written to the district magistrate to suspend social audit phase II in 151 gram panch-ayats across 15 blocks fearing ground-level resistance to the audit over “NRC scare”.

The audit is a mandatory programme conducted by the district administration to examine entries of beneficiaries of central schemes PMAY, MGNREGA and NSAP. The programme was scheduled from January 12 to March 20 in Murshidabad district.

The BDO’s letter said: “Village pradhans of my block have informed me that the situation is unstable due to the NRC issue. People are scared about NRC and are not cooperating with the administration. In some areas, we are not able to run government schemes sm-oothly. I request you to put the social audit on hold till the situation improves.”

The letter came a day after villagers in Birbhum’s Nalhati mobbed the BDO, who had reached out to households to find out what went wrong when a Delhi-based NGO asked them for some documents.

But the letter issued by the district nodal officer (social audit) to panchayats on January 10 doesn’t mention household survey. The officer instead asked pradhans and upapradhans to come to the block office with beneficiary lists.

CPM’s Domkal area committee secretary Mustafijur Rahman is not buying the BDO’s plea. “Why are the pradhans scared of furnishing beneficiary lists? At a time Trinamool has been speaking about corruption-free implementation of schemes, its pradhans don’t feel safe presenting the lists. Watch out for the panchayats where the audit was planned up to January 16: Farakka, Domkal, Kandi and Samserganj,” he said.
