Title: New year, old problem: AQI tops 350 in Kolkata
Content:
The city woke up to a very smoggy morning on Wednesday, with the AQI shooting past the 350-mark (indicating ve... Read More

The city woke up to a very smoggy morning on Wednesday, with AQI shooting past the 350-mark (indicating very poor quality air) across most monitoring stations for the first time this year

Avoid strenuous exercises early in the morning: Docs

KOLKATA: The city woke up to a very smoggy morning on Wednesday, with the air quality index (AQI) shooting past the 350-mark (indicating very poor quality air) across most monitoring stations for the first time this year.A combination of meteorological factors — thermal inversion, low vertical air movement and low radiative temperature of the ground — caused pollutants to hang low in the atmosphere, turning the air quality foul. This is typical winter condition — when the ground is cool and there is no or little heat transfer from it, West Bengal Pollution Control Board officials said.Track the pollution level in your cityVertical air movement, for example, was as low as 2 m/s on Wednesday. In such calm conditions, dispersion of particulate matters — PM2.5 and PM10 — become very slow. As the particulate matters linger in the lower atmosphere, the next day’s pollutants are added to the already toxic air. There is unlikely to be any respite from the spiralling pollution in the next few days as the wind speed will continue to be between 2m/s and 1m/s on Thursday as well, the officials said.Untimely rain on January 2 and 3 had done the city immense good, with the AQI moving within the satisfactory-moderate range. But the meteorological conditions rapidly changed from Tuesday night, affecting the ambient air quality.At Ballygunge monitoring station, the AQI shot past 400 after 10pm.At stations like Victoria Memorial, Rabindra Bharati University and Fort William, the air quality remained severe with the PM2.5 index staying over 400 between 3am and 7am.This is particularly alarming because Kolkata’s AQI is primarily driven by PM2.5 — particulate matter of diameter less than 2.5 micrometre — which are about 3% the diameter of a human hair and travel straight into the blood stream causing severe respiratory diseases.Worried doctors have advised citizens to avoid strenuous exercises in the open during early mornings when the ambient air quality is particularly foul.“Such ambient air can trigger a series of health issues even for a healthy person and worsen pre-existing conditions like asthma and COPD,” said Dr Debasish Basu, a preventive medicine expert.“We are hoping for a change in the meteorological conditions from next Monday,” a WBPCB official said.

Title: Kolkata: Helmetless bike stunt lands TikTok teen under police lens
Content:
Representative image

KOLKATA: A TikTok sensation , who commands over 27.1 million followers on this platform and another 5.8 million on Instagram at the age of 16, has found himself on the wrong side of traffic laws. A social activist has uploaded a video of the young actor violating traffic rules while riding a two-wheeler, which has a Bengal registration number, and urged Kolkata traffic police to act on it.In the video, the actor is seen riding a bike for a very short distance before bringing out a flower even as the song ‘Chale Ride Pe’ played on in the typical TikTok style. The video has already garnered over 6 lakh ‘likes’.The complainant, Aman Zaidi, has also tagged chief minister Mamata Banerjee in his complaint and provided a link to the TikTok video . “@MamataOfficial @KPTrafficDept He is a young famous Indian Tik-Tok star. He was born on 27 October 2003 and his age is 16 years. His nationality is Indian,” he wrote, adding: “He’s riding a Bullet and he isn’t wearing a helmet.” The two traffic violations are all too apparent — a minor riding a bike, that too without a helmet.Kolkata traffic police reacted to the complaint and stated in Twitter: “Thanks for info. Your complaint will be examined by our dedicated cell and adequate action shall be taken.” The social media cell of Kolkata Police has forwarded the case to Kolkata traffic police.“We have found in our preliminary investigation that the bike has been registered in February last year and it has been registered at the Alipurduar RTO in North Bengal. However, the video is inconclusive. It shows the actor riding a short distance, which can well be inside a compound. Even if this might be bad advertisement for safe driving, it does not mean that there was a crime prima facie. The possibility of the video being shot outside Kolkata is high since the actor hails from a neighbouring country and is now settled in Mumbai with Indian citizenship. In fact, several of his other videos show him wearing a helmet. We are waiting for clarifications before we proceed further,” said an investigator from the Special Raids Section. An IPS officer said they would comment only after they come up with some substantial leads.Cops have been using memes and spoofs for raising awareness on safe riding and the results have been phenomenal last year. The number of deaths due to bike accidents has fallen significantly from 82 in 2018 to 58 in 2019. Even among the victims who lost their lives, just 20 were found without helmets.“It has been over two years that Kolkata police has taken to memes to send across their message on the Safe Drive Save life campaign. The memes have been planned and designed by a social media team. But if such videos become popular, it sends the wrong message,” said the investigating officer.

Title: Irritated of boob sweat? It's time to buy boob sweat powder
Content: Boob sweat in not just a summer thing and all the ladies experience it during their lifetime. Well, if you are fed up of sweat running around your assets, then here's help. A new innovation has hit the market in the form of boob sweat powder to tackle hyperhydrosis or excessive sweating.Global beauty market has been flooded with boob sweat powders of anti boob sweat sprays that are basically dusting powders designed to prevent boob sweat.The product started trending when Busy Philipps, an American actress and writer took to her Instagram to talk about the problem women with particularly large breasts suffer from, which causes irritations, allergies and skin problems among the skin folds. Moreover, Philipps confessed to using the powder to ace her Golden Globes look. Well, she looked sexy and so can you, but all you need is the boob sweat powder for your rescue.According to various product descriptions doing the rounds on the cosmetic shopping websites, the powder is completely and is totally parabens free. In fact, it contains lavender and chamomile, which is perfect to soothe irritated skin and fights bacteria at the same time. Most of the powder bottles come with easy applicators and one can simply apply the powder by spraying it underneath the boobs.While we still await the unique product's entry into the Indian market, here's a look at some tips you can use to tackle the problem till the time you get hold of your own boob sweat powder.Use deodorant regularly in the area between the breasts. Wipe the folds of your skin, especially under the breast area on a frequent basis.Keep the area clean, wash at least twice a day with medicated soap.Use anti-fungal powder to get rid of any kind of heat rashes or fungal infections.Use an absorbent pad in the bra to soak the sweat. As far as possible, avoid wearing padded bras, and opt for bras that are made of cotton, which is a breathable fabric.Wear no-cling, flowy tops so the material doesn’t stick to the skin.

Title: In outreach, Bengal BJP to clear air on CAA proof
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

KOLKATA: The Bengal BJP will begin a campaign telling people they do not need to show any documents to prove citizenship under the Citizenship (Amendment) Act. The party will reach out to nearly a crore people in the state to spread awareness about CAA over the next fortnight, starting Thursday.

The campaign, which comes on the heels of a “we won’t show our paper” campaign by a section of intellectuals in the city, will help dispel myths about the amended citizenship law, BJP functionaries felt.

An 87-second video, in which actors such as Sabyasachi Chakraborty, Swastika Mukherjee, Konkona Sen Sharma and Dhritiman Chatterjee declined to show any document, went viral after it was released on Sunday. This prompted Bengal BJP to launch an intense counter-campaign.

“No one has to show any paper during CAA drive. Neither will they have to show proof of the fact that they were subject to religious persecution. They will need to give a declaration that the person was subject to religious persecution in Bangladesh, Pakistan or Afghanistan,” a BJP office-bearer said.

Union minister Babul Supriyo tweeted a dig at the video. “Nobody will ask for a paper. What kind of a paper? Why would anyone ask for a paper? Are you an immigrant?”

Bengal BJP chief Dilip Ghosh, who felt the video was part of the Left’scampaign, said: “A section of intellectuals is campaigning against CAA. One of them unfortunately has a tainted background. Such campaigns will become counter-productive for Leftist outfits,” he said.

Title: Saradha, Narada and Rose Valley CBI cops shifted
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Kolkata: In a major reshuffle in Bengal, CBI has transferred officers holding key charges in the Saradha , Rose Valley and Narada case investigations. After a reshuffle of superintendent-rank officials a few days ago, the agency has now made changes at the DSP-level and of inspector-rank officers looking after daily developments in the Ponzi probes.

DSP Tathagata Bardhan, who has been playing a key role in the Rose Valley and Saradha cases apart from other Ponzi investigations, has been transferred to Delhi. Bardhan had played a major role in the Rose Valley probe in interrogating key accused such as Trinamool MPs Sudip Bandyopadhyay and Tapas Paul. He had also quizzed former Kolkata police commissioner Rajeev Kumar in Shillong.

Inspector Bratin Ghoshal, who has been involved in Saradha and other Ponzi case investigations, has been transferred to Bhubaneswar. Ghoshal had played a crucial role during the interrogation of Saradha accused such as Trinamool’s Madan Mitra.

Chuzom Sherpa, investigating officer in the Rose Valley Ponzi probe, too was transferred to Bhubaneswar. Sherpa was part of the team that quizzed Rajeev in Shillong. CBI sources indicated these two officers might continue with the Rose Valley probe while stationed in Bhubaneswar.

The investigating officer in the Narada sting probe, Ranjit Kumar, has been transferred to Delhi.

Earlier this month, the agency had transferred DIG Abhay Singh, who was looking after Special Crime Branch in Kolkata, to the Economic Offences Wing in Delhi. Partha Mukherjee, who was SP of Economic Offences IV in Kolkata, was posted as AIG (policy).

On Wednesday, CBI sources indicated that the transfers were a routine exercise. The rejig decision was taken last month when the agency’s director, Rishi Kumar Shukla, had held a meeting to take stock of the cases in Delhi. “Some of the new officers have already joined (in Bengal). Others will be replaced soon, making the team stronger. The transfers will not, however, impact the progress of the investigation,” an official said.

Title: Lt Gen Anil Chauhan : Army to withdraw some troops from northeast
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Lt Gen Chauhan pays tribute at Vijay Smarak on Wednesday

KOLKATA: Given the improved law and order situation in insurgency-hit northeastern states, the Army has decided to withdraw some troops from active counter-insurgency/counter-terrorism (CI/CT) duties and move them to the barracks, Eastern Army commander Lt Gen Anil Chauhan said on Wednesday. He was speaking after paying homage to martyrs at Kolkata’s Vijay Smarak on the occasion of Army Day .

This decision has far-reaching implications because the Armed Forces Special Powers Act (AFSPA) is also likely to be withdrawn from areas as troops withdraw.

“So far as the operational situation is concerned, the northern border remained quiet last year due to the Wuhan Summit of April ’18 and the Chinese Summit of October ’19. Now peace is being maintained without compromising on legitimate claims or positions on the Line of Actual Control (LAC). I am also happy to say that the situation is rather stable in insurgency-affected states,” Lt Gen Chauhan said.

“Incidents of violence have come down drastically and a decision has been taken to withdraw some troops from active CI/CT duties and move them to barracks. The focus for the coming year will be to maintain a high degree of operational preparedness and train ourselves to fight in a technologically intensive environment,” he added.

According to him, nearly two battalions have been withdrawn from the CI/CT grid in districts of upper Assam. The Eastern Command GOC-in-C also said that there has been significant improvement in the situation in Manipur and Nagaland from 2016. While AFSPA is in place in several parts of upper Assam and Manipur, it was extended to the whole of Nagaland for another six months in December 2019.

The Army has maintained that the act is crucial for its proper functioning whenever it is deployed in a ‘disturbed area’. As troops are withdrawn, there will no longer be any need for the act that curbs certain civil rights.

Speaking on how Integrated Battle Groups (IBGs) would come in handy in the Eastern theatre, Lt Gen Chauhan said: “Our Army follows the legacy of the British army that prepared for longish wars in distant lands. An effort was made in the 80s to prepare the Army for modern conflict. That is when infantry divisions were converted to rapid divisions. Not much happened after that. Now, we are concentrating on organisation of formations that are more deployable, employable and capable of performing tasks. This can be effective along our northern border. We are looking at the 17 Corps (Brahmastra Corps) for this and some exercises have been held to validate the concept, organisation and deployment.”

Title: After Arthur Road, Taloja jail too doesn’t want to house Ejaz Lakdawala
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

File photo of Ejaz Lakdawala

MUMBAI: No jail wants to lodge Ejaz Lakdawala . Taloja jail authorities have requested that the gangster be not lodged with them. This comes a day after Arthur Road jail authorities wrote to the magistrate and Mumbai police commissioner saying Lakdawala, who was arrested by Mumbai Police from Patna on January 8, be kept at Taloja jail as they feared he could be attacked by members of Dawood or Chhota Rajan gangs lodged there.

“On Thursday, we will write to the 37th metropolitan magistrate court as well the Maharashtra Control of Organised Crime Act (MCOCA) court requesting them not to sent Lakdawala to Taloja jail as hardened criminals—Abu Salem, Ashwin Naik, Kumar Pillai, J Dey killers Satish Kalai and D K Rao, Pune gangsters Gajya Marne, Sharad Mohol Pappu Nair and many others— are lodged here,” said an official of Taloja jail.

Superintendent of Taloja jail Kastubh Kurlekar confirmed that they will be writing to the court regarding this matter, but refused to divulge further details.

On January 14, TOI had reported that Dawood or Chhota Rajan men may attack Lakdawala inside jail.

With Arthur Road and Taloja jails raising safety issues on lodging Lakdawala, police are likely to explore the options of sending him to either Thane or Kalyan prison.

There is time for the final decision as Lakdawala will be in the police custody for a while as he is to be arrested in 26 different offences, including MCOCA offences registered in Mumbai alone. An accused is sent to jail once the court remands him to judicial custody.

Meanwhile, the 37th metropolitan magistrate on Wednesday granted bail to Lakdawala’s daughter Shifa Shahid Shaikh in a fake passport case. However, she will continue to remain in police custody in an extortion case in which she has been booked along with her father. Lakdawala had allegedly called up Bandra builder Khalid Qureshi and threatened him to pay Rs 25 lakh. The father-daughter duo is likely to be booked under the MCOCA.

Lakdawala was originally a member of the Dawood gang, but later joined the Rajan gang and killed one of the 1993 bomb blasts accused, Razi, at Rajan’s behest. He later left Rajan’s gang and began operating independently from 2001.

Title: Theft rules Mumbai’s crime chart, but drops 6% over a year. Rape cases increase 14%
Content:
Representative image

MUMBAI: Theft is the most prevalent crime in Mumbai, according to data for 2019 released by the city police on Wednesday, though it has dropped by about 6% from the year before. Causing hurt too figures high on the list, occupying the second spot (4,372 cases in 2019), followed by vehicle theft (2,693) and molestation (2,678).In all, 41,932 cases of crime were registered with Mumbai Police in 2019, a 0.1% increase from 41,901in 2018. Though rape forms a fraction of the cases, its absolute reported number is disturbingly high: 1,015 in 2019, up from 889 in 2018. The police have also shown a high rate of cracking cases, having solved 28,802 of the total 41,931 cases in 2019 and 28,812 of the total 41,901in 2018. In both instances, the police’s rate of solving crime cases is around 69%.Disturbingly, like for rape, there has been an increase in other serious offences. Molestation rose from 2,586 in 2018 to 2678 the next year, robbery from 931 to 987, extortion from 228 to 253, attempt to murder from 280 to 343. Murder cases remained more or less the same: 165 in 2019, up by just one case.Offences that registered a dip included theft (from 6,260 cases in 2018 to 5,888 in 2019), hurt (5,198 to 4,372), vehicle theft (3,203 to 2,693), and house breakin (2,244 to 2,058). Chain snatching (171 to 157) and dacoity (32 to21) dropped too, but the figures are not high enough for a city as populous as Mumbai to establish a trend in any statistically significant way.Joint commissioner of police (law and order) Vinay Choubey said the force has come out with several initiatives to tackle street crime and to solve cases. “The dip in some crimes is the result of prompt action, added with the use of technology to solving crime. The installation of CCTV cameras at various points in the city has also been a deterrent to criminals.”However, RTI activist Jeetendra Ghadge said that the crime data doesn’t reflect financial wrongdoing and real estate fraud. “We need to reform our criminal justice system to make sure such crimes are also taken seriously,” he said.

Title: 'Mumbaikars lose 85 minutes a day in traffic jams'
Content:
Mumbaikars spend an average 85 minutes a day stuck in traffic snarls and the situation gets worst in the eveni... Read More

MUMBAI: Mumbaikars spend an average 85 minutes a day stuck in traffic snarls and the situation gets worst in the evening with over 90% people being affected, found a survey conducted by a non-profit as part of a study on effects of congestion on people.The study, which covered 1,200 respondents including private car users, motorcyclists, office car users, kaali peeli taxi and app cab drivers, found that 75% of the respondents supported congestion pricing-a tool to decongest clogged roads by charging a fee that is sufficient to deter some motorists from taking out their private vehicles. For those not willing to pay a congestion charge, 27% of car users and 18% of motorcyclists showed willingness to shift to high-quality public transport.While 42% respondents said they suffered health issues due to congestion, 46% said they compromised on personal time. Productivity loss was a concern for 52% people. The survey showed that 65% of the trips were for work and the average distance travelled by an individual was 20km a day. The study was conducted by ITDP India, a non-profit, along with Symbiosis School of Economics. It also aimed at understanding Mumbaikars' views on congestion pricing."In Mumbai, private vehicles and taxis account for just 19% of total trips, but occupy 82% of road space. This creates a huge imbalance in road space distribution," said Vaishali Singh, senior associate with ITDP India. Western Express Highway (WEH) and S V Road in the western suburbs and most parts of island city are the most congested areas, according to the study, with 55% of the traffic travelling at less than 20kmph during peak hours and going as low as 6kmph in some areas. "A small reduction of trips-about 3% in the island city and 17% on WEH-for a few hours during weekdays can improve travel speeds for motorcycles, cars and buses," added Singh.Presently, the city needs 1,100km of complete streets and 6,000 more buses, apart from 192km of proposed Metro corridors, to make travel comfortable.Mumbai has the highest car density in the country at 530 cars per km as compared to Delhi with just 108 cars per km. "Mumbai can save up to Rs 3,600 crore through fuel and productivity increase after implementing congestion pricing. It can also help the city improve its air quality," said Singh.In London, Singapore and Stockholm, congestion pricing has improved the quality of life and encouraged a shift to walking, cycling and public transport, pointed out experts.

Title: Navy to rejig acquisition plans with eye on technological advancements & fiscal prudence
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

NEW DELHI: In keeping with futuristic weapon technologies, coupled with the need for fiscal prudence, the Navy has gone in for a major rationalization and re-prioritization of its long-term force level plans and arms procurement projects.

Defence ministry sources say the Navy is the first among the armed forces to finalize a rationalization plan for its capital acquisition projects, which ranges from withdrawing some tenders or Request for Proposals (RFPs) to reducing numbers in other mega programmes. “The Defence Acquisitions Council (DAC), to be chaired by defence minister Rajnath Singh on January 17, will discuss all this,” said a source.

Navy chief Admiral Karambir Singh had himself recently declared his force was “committed to progress modernization using available resources optimally”. The Navy would endeavor to get the “maximum bang for the buck, with prioritization, rationalization and economy of expenditure”, he said.

The maritime force currently has 125 warships and 15 diesel-electric and two nuclear submarines, along with 235 aircraft, helicopters and drones. Given the budget constraints, it would be reasonably happy to become a 175-warship force by 2027 despite the earlier 212-warship plan.

For starters, the RFP for the construction of four large amphibious warfare warships or landing platform docks (LPDs) at a cost of over Rs 20,000 crore by the Indian private sector is going to get scrapped. “The Navy requires LPDs but the existing RFP was based on technical parameters drawn over 12-13 years ago. New up-to-date technical specifications will be drawn for a fresh RFP,” said a source.

The long-pending mega project to build 12 Mine Counter-Measure Vessels (MCMVs), or warships designed to detect, track and destroy enemy mines, at the Goa Shipyard for Rs 32,000 crore will also get slashed. “The project will be limited to eight MCMVs now. A hunt for unmanned minesweepers will also be launched in keeping with technological advancements around the world,” said the source.

Another step will be to cut down the Rs 3,621 crore acquisition of 10 Kamov-31 AEW (airborne early warning) helicopters from Russia to six choppers, while the force will also drop the case for a survey training vessel.

TOI was the first to report last November that the Navy’s case for 10 more Poseidon-8I long-range maritime patrol aircraft from the US had also been reduced to just six planes for around $1.8 billion. These six P-8Is will add to the 12 such “submarine-hunting” aircraft already ordered from the US at a cost of over $3.1 billion.

The reduction in the P-8I aircraft will be offset by the proposed acquisition of 30 weaponized Sea Guardian or Predator-B armed drones from the US, with 10 drones each for Navy, IAF and Army to hunt and destroy targets on land and sea.

Title: GST messy, disruptive in short run: Finance panel member
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Ashok Lahiri (File photo)

KOLKATA: Member of 15th finance commission and former chief economic adviser to the Centre, Ashok Lahiri , has slammed the goods and services tax ( GST ) as it could be "messy and disruptive in the short run". He has also indicated that the economy needs some corrective action.

"While GST will prove to be a game-changing reform over medium to long term, in the short run, it has proved to be messy and disruptive and poor in revenue performance," he said while speaking at a conclave organised by the Bengal Chamber of Commerce & Industry (BCC&I).

Lahiri pointed out that the GST Network (GSTN) was not fully ready when the new tax regime was launched in July 2017. This has assumed significance because some of these points are often raised in the last two years by Bengal finance minister Amit Mitra, who used to be the head of the empowered committee of state finance ministers during the GST rollout and a strong critique of the hasty rollout of GST.

Barely six weeks before the launch of GST, the tax rates were not decided and the specific rule needed to enforce the CGST, SGST and IGST laws were not settled, he said. Lahiri came down heavily on the hurried decision of providing compensation package for the states, which is now being considered as one of the lifelines for many states following a slow GST collection.

Lahiri, however, argued that even a deferred rollout could not have been better, as claimed by the Opposition parties.

Title: Bengaluru: Man kills wife by injecting pesticide
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Deepa T was killed by her husband Venkatesh G after she questioned him about his affair with another woman.

BENGALURU: A 30-year-old employee of a district government hospital was arrested on charges of murdering his wife by injecting pesticide on Monday night.

Ijoor police said Deepa T, 24, a resident of Ramanagara town, was killed by her husband Venkatesh G after she questioned him about his affair with another woman. Venkatesh is an on-contract data-entry operator with the hospital. "He poisoned her when she was asleep," the police said.

According to police, the incident took place around 11pm on Monday and Deepa was declared dead on arrival by doctors at the hospital around 1am on Tuesday. "Her parents had taken her to the hospital after learning that something was amiss," p olice said.

Deepa's father Timmaiah filed a murder case against Venkatesh, suspecting he may have injected poison. Based on the complaint, Ijoor police brought in Venkatesh for questioning and he confessed to the crime. "He told us she'd cheated on him," police said.

Venkatesh and Deepa got married on March 23, 2019. Police said she learnt about Venkatesh's illicit relationship and told her parents about it in July.

"Both their parents met and advised him to discontinue the illicit relationship. But Deepa recently found out he hadn't done so and questioned him," police said, adding that they were yet to determine the chemical, syringe and other items used.

Title: Karnataka: Man suspects minor girlfriend, forces her to consume poison
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Venkatesh Kumar

BENGALURU: Chikkaballapura police have arrested a 21-year-old man on charges of murdering his 17-year-old girlfriend. Investigation revealed the minor was forced to consume poison to prove that she did not have an affair with another man.

Chikkaballapura superintendent of police (SP) Abhinav Khare told TOI they arrested Venkatesh Kumar of Kamalapura village after he confessed to the crime. Earlier, the family of the minor had thought the girl had committed suicide and police had registered a case of unnatural death.

“They were in a relationship for two years. Kumar, who had recently started suspecting her, took her to Tondebavi in Chikkaballapura on January 6 under the pretext of discussing some personal matter,” police said.

There, he repeatedly interrogated the girl about her alleged affair with another man from her village. “...Kumar had seen the girl speaking to a man and assumed that she was in a relationship with him,” Khare said, adding that when the girl denied the charges, he forced her to consume poison.

“While she kept saying she wasn’t in any other relationship, Venkatesh pulled out two plastic bottles from his pocket and asked her to drink from one of them. He told her that both bottles had poison mixed with the drink and that he would kill himself if she refused to oblige,” said Khare.

However, he had mixed poison in only the bottle he gave her. “The girl consumed the drink laced with poison,” Khare said, adding: “Kumar was shocked too and couldn’t stop her in time.”

Kumar then brought the girl back to her home on his two-wheeler and she told her family that she had consumed poison. She was first rushed to a local hospital and then shifted to Victoria Hospital in Bengaluru. She died on January 8.

“Just to give an impression that he too had consumed poison, Kumar laced his lips with it. However, when we found the second bottle that had only the soft drink, he confessed to his crime,” Khare added.

Title: Noida: 17 developers seek stress fund to complete projects
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Supertech, for instance, has alone sought Rs 1,500 crore for the completion of 20,000 flats across 12 housing ... Read More

NOIDA: As many as 17 builders in Noida and Greater Noida, including Supertech, Ajnara and Mahagun, have applied for the stress fund offered by the Centre to complete their stalled real estate projects in the twin cities.

Besides Supertech, Ajnara and Mahagun, other builders who have applied are Capital Infra, Earthcon Constructions, Fusion Buildtech, La Residentia, Newtech, Nirala India, RG Group, Rudra Buildwell, Sikka Group, Royal Gold Link Projects, Skytech, Rajhans, KV Developers and Jyotirmoy Infracon, TOI has learnt. While some have asked for funds through their lenders to complete a single project, others for the delivery of a few of them. Supertech, for instance, has alone sought Rs 1,500 crore for the completion of 20,000 flats across 12 housing projects in the twin cities, sources said.

According to builders’ body Credai, these realtors have prima facie declared that they are eligible for the last-mile funding from the Union finance ministry as the value of their assets is more than their liabilities. The applicants are now waiting for their proposals to be approved.

Amit Modi, vice president, Credai-western UP, said, “The builders have placed their requests through financial agencies which invested in them. Now the applications will be up for scrutiny to see if the builders are actually eligible for the central funding. The assets and liabilities would be weighed.” “With the applications sent, the builders are now waiting for a response from the government on the same,” he added.

In November 2019, the Centre announced a Rs 25,000 crore stress fund to help complete over 1,500 stalled housing projects in India, including those that have been declared non-performing assets (NPAs) or facing insolvency proceedings.

However, only Real Estate Regulatory Authority (Rera)-registered projects that fall in affordable and middle-income group segment with positive net worth are eligible for last-mile funding. And the maximum funding a developer can avail for one project is Rs 400 crore. “The last-mile fund has come as a great relief to those builders who are stuck for want of cash flow and have completion deadlines to meet. The sooner the funds are disbursed, the better,” Modi said.

This came as a ray of hope for several homebuyers who have invested in projects of embattled developers in the twin cities. “We finally see a light at the end of a tunnel after a wait of nearly 10 years,” said Abhishek Kumar, president, Noida Extension Flat Owners Welfare Association. Developers said they are looking forward to this fund not only to bail out the ailing real estate sector but also to help boost the sluggish demand in residential property market, particularly across NCR.

Title: In this Bundelkhand hamlet, an ‘aashiqon ka mela’ celebrates Makar Sankranti
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Nat gypsies of Sarbai in Banda celebrate Makar Sankranti with the ‘aashiqon ka mela’, a tradition that has bee... Read More

LUCKNOW: Ever since the birth of their daughter a couple of months ago, Suresh and Pinki had been waiting for the auspicious occasion of Makar Sankranti to visit a deity very special to them.

On Wednesday, they finally prayed to Natbali Baba, thanking him for their union as a couple.

Like hundreds of devotees who had queued up to seek Baba’s blessings, they offered flowers to Natbali Sarkar and sought his blessings for eternal togetherness, after a dip in the river Ken. Every year on Sankranti, the tiny hamlet of Nat gypsies, Sarbai, in Banda breaks into a celebration. For 160 years, a colourful ‘aashiqon ka mela’ or fare of lovers is being hosted here to celebrate the eternal love between Natbali Beeran and the nameless daughter of Arjun Singh, the commandant of Bhuragarh Fort, which stands a few kilometres away.

According to folklore, Nat artist Beeran fell in love with the daughter of Singh but the commandant objected to the prospective union. On his daughter’s insistence, Singh mellowed but offered to agree on one condition. He told Beeran to make a rope of cotton (a weak thread) and walk over it across his village, crossing the river into the fort. Beeran’s success would mean ‘yes’ to the marriage. The Nat gypsy agreed and worked very hard to make several attempts, recalls Bhan Singh, a resident of the town.

“After failing many times, on Makar Sankranti, he attempted again and seemed to be nearing success. As he proceeded, the entire community sang and danced along the river to boost his morale. However, just as Beeran was about to reach the fort, the adamant father cut the rope. Beeran fell into the river, cracked his head on a rock and died on the spot.

Shocked and broken, the commandant’s daughter jumped after him.

Memorial now an icon of true love

Members of the Nat community built a memorial for Beeran and the woman. With time, this memorial became a temple of the icons of true love.

It is believed that while Beeran and his beloved could not unite, they bless young couples with eternal companionship and togetherness.

“Our families were against our wedding because we were relatives. But we prayed in this darbar and our marriage was finalised,” says Suresh.

“Beeran and his beloved are like Heer-Ranjha or Laila Majnu for this region. Newly married couples, especially from the Nat community, visit the temple and participate in the fair for blessings,” says Ruksana Hashmi , a social activist.

Banke Ram and his wife Ratna, who were at the temple, had come to ask for togetherness too.

“He stays in Mumbai while I stay in the village. I prayed to Babaji to bring us together,” says Ratna.

Title: Lucknow University student molested near Gomti riverfront
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Representative image

LUCKNOW: A 26-year-old student of Lucknow University was allegedly molested and assaulted outside a mall opposite Gomti Riverfront.

The incident occurred on Saturday but the student could not muster courage to lodge a complaint out of fear of stigma. When her family members came to know about the incident, they encouraged her to report the matter to the police.

The woman lodged a named FIR at Gomtinagar police station on Tuesday night against two men.

The Niralanagar resident said that two men-—both residents of an apartment building in Mall Avenue—had been harassing and stalking her for a few days. On several occasions, they had also tried to intercept her and asked her to accompany them.

On January 11, she said, she was in the mall with her friends. When she came out around midnight, the two accused were standing outside the mall, she said.

They allegedly grabbed her hand and when she objected, they punched her multiple times before snatching her phone and throwing it away, she said in the FIR.

“The entire incident has been recorded in the mall CCTV camera. When I called the police on 112 through my friend’s phone, they fled, threatening me with dire consequences,” she said.

The woman added that she was initially scared to file a complaint or tell her family, but after the two accused continued stalking her, she told her family on Tuesday.

Her family members then encouraged her to lodge a complaint.

Gomtinagar SHO Amit Kumar Dubey said, “We are investigating the incident and collecting evidence.”

Gomtinagar sub-inspector Sanjay Gupta said, “A medical examination of the woman is being done.”

Title: Noida executive Gaurav Chandel’s murder: Stolen SUV found in Ghaziabad
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

The car was found nine days after Gaurav Chandel was found dead

GHAZIABAD/NOIDA: Investigators have finally recovered the stolen SUV, belonging to murdered 39-year-old senior healthcare executive Gaurav Chandel, from Ghaziabad’s Masuri area, some nine days after his body was found near his house in Greater Noida’s Gaur City.

The grey Kia Seltos was found abandoned in Akash Nagar area under the jurisdiction of Masuri police station on Tuesday night by a retired cop, Jagveer Singh Nehra, who stays in the area. Only on Wednesday morning did the investigators confirm it belonged to Chandel through a slip of the vehicle’s high security number plate.

“I spotted the SUV around 10.15 pm on Tuesday. My suspicion was raised when I found that the number plates of the SUV missing. I soon informed the police control room,” said Nehra, the former cop. “However, I didn’t see who all left the SUV there.” Police said they had found a receipt of a shop in a Noida mall in the car, which could eventually turn out to be a vital clue.

Naresh Kumar Singh, SHO of Masuri police station, said, “Even as there was no number plate on the vehicle, the slip of the high security number plate affixed to the glass of the vehicle helped us in identifying the car as well as its owner, Gaurav Chandel.”

Subsequently, Noida police, a forensic team and a dog squad reached the spot and collected several evidences from the spot. Investigators later towed the car to Noida. Cops said they were checking the CCTV cameras in the area to identify who had parked the vehicle in Akash Nagar.

When contacted, Noida police commissioner Alok Singh said, “Our teams have got some crucial leads, including the missing car, the investigation is certainly going in the right direction and we are hopeful that the case will be solved very soon.”

Title: 65-year-old barber shot in salon over kite flying dispute
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Representative image

LUCKNOW: A 65-year-old barber was shot dead while his customer suffered gunshot injuries over a trivial issue in Sultanpur on Wednesday night. The barber, Ashfaq, died on the spot after sustaining bullet injuries in his head while customer Dilshad (37), who was getting a haircut, sustained multiple injuries.

Police said the incident came to light after Ashfaq’s son Naushad informed UP 112 that Mohammed Shaan and four others had shot his father inside Shubham Deluxe Salon in Haneefnagar locality of Sultanpur. Police found Ashfaq and Dilshad lying inside the shop in a pool of blood. The victims were immediately admitted to a nearby hospital.

“Ashfaq was declared brought dead while Dilshad was referred to KGMU,” said CO Kotwali (Sultanpur) Satish Shukla.In his complaint, Naushad said that Azam, Aman, Shekhu, Shaan, and Sonu had murdered his father. Naushad also claimed that the accused had had a dispute with his father over kite-flying on January 5.

The five accused had competed in a kite-flying match with Naushad’s younger brother Shamshad, who had lost to them. Shamshad had reportedly not honoured a bet after losing, police said. “This resulted in a brawl between the two sides. Ashfaq had intervened to protect his son and also threatened the accused with a police complaint,” said Shukla. An FIR is being registered against the five accused.

Title: New two-km road promises to ease Hinjewadi congestion
Content:
The Pune Metropolitan Region Development Authority is set to build a 2 km road in Hinjewadi to reduce traffic ... Read More

Deputy chief minister and guardian minister Ajit Pawar has asked the PMRDA to build alternative roads to reduce the traffic congestion as soon as possible

The Pune Metropolitan Region Development Authority is set to build a 2 km road in Hinjewadi to reduce traffic congestion along the notoriously busy Wakad-Hinjewadi stretch.Speaking to TOI, Vivek Kharwadkar, a planner with the PMRDA, said set a of alternative roads has become a priority project for the agency. “Deputy chief minister and guardian minister Ajit Pawar has asked the PMRDA to build alternative roads to reduce the traffic congestion as soon as possible.”The Wakad-Hinjewadi road, from Wakad chowk on the Mumbai-Bengaluru highway to Shivaji chowk in Phase I of the Hinjewadi IT park area is the main road, which currently has two to three lanes. Nearly 4 lakh IT workers use the road daily for their commutes. As a result, Hinjewadi has some of the most gridlocked junctions in Pune. A year ago, then Pimpri Chinchwad police commissioner RK Padmanabhan had set in place a one-way rule on the road to ease congestion. But there are fears that urbanisation could further impact the carriageway width. A more immediate worry is the Metro project.The PMRDA’s Shivajinagar-Hinjewadi metro route is set to come up along this road and commuters said the work will only increase congestion on the road.“Even the smallest roadwork can throw traffic out of gear here,” said Vishwas Kaul, who works with a startup in the IT area. “So imagine how much chaos a giant Metro project can cause. Hinjewadi definitely needs more roads.”Officials said plans for the alternative road are afoot.Giving details of the project, an official from the PMRDA said: “A meeting between farmers, officials from the Maharashtra Industrial Development Corporation and PMRDA was held on Wednesday, during which discussions were held about the project. About 1.5 km of the proposed road lies within PMRDA limits, while the remaining 500 metres are within the neighbouring Pimpri Chinchwad Municipal Corporation limits. According to the development plan of the PCMC, the road is 18 metres in width, so we wrote to the civic body to increase it to 30 metres.”The official added that the agencies will get consent of farmers for land acquisition within the next 20 days.“We also plan to invite bids for the road project in March this year,” he said.Nagesh Sakhare, a member of the Hinjewadi gram panchayat said: “Around 200 to 300 agriculture families are expected to be impacted by the road project. The exact number will be known when the demarcation process is completed by the agencies.”An MIDC official said as per preliminary discussions held on Wednesday, the PMRDA will provide land while the MIDC will bear expenditure for this project.Dnyanendra Hulsure, president of the Hinjawadi Employees and Residents’ Association (HEART) said: “Around 47,000 vehicles pass through the Wakad-Shivaji chowk during the peak morning hours. There will be severe traffic congestion when the Metro work starts along this stretch in March this year. The proposed alternative road from Surya hospital to Hinjewadi post office will take at least two to three years to be built. So we quickly need an alternative road to reduce traffic congestion.”Others said the alternative roads were key to reducing Hinjewadi’s infamous traffic jams. Jaydeep Soni, an IT worker said: “Smaller lanes can be developed to accommodate cars and other light vehicles. Buses can use the main roads. Smart planning can ease congestion in Hinjewadi. With each passing day, it is starting to resemble congested cities like Bengaluru and Mumbai.”

Title: Weight loss: Guide to using battle ropes in the gym
Content: If you are a fitness enthusiast, you would have surely tried out all the complex equipment available in the gym. But the complexity of the exercise or equipment you use does not guarantee you a fit body. Sometimes even simple things like a rope can help.If you are looking for something dynamic, fat-busting, full-body workout then pick a rope. Battle ropes workout is simple and has gained limelight recently. You might have seen videos of professional and athletes performing this workout on different social media platform. If you are a beginner, then here is a right way to perform battle rope workout:If you are looking to get six-pack abs then you must include battle rope workout in your routine. It works on each arm independently and also helps to strengthen your back, chest, legs, and core muscles.Battle rope can be a killer cardio exercise, depending on the type of exercise you are performing. It is a great exercise to burn tones of calories and recommended for people trying to lose weight.The ropes come in different thickness, length and material and you can choose as per your requirement. The training ropes generally come in three lengths (30, 40 or 50 feet) and two thicknesses (1.5" and 2"). The right one depends on your need, capacity and the amount of space you have.: This is a typical battling-rope exercise, which works on each arm individually.Directions: Take two ropes and tie one end of each rope to 2-3 heavy kettlebell. Now hold both the ends of the rope at arm's length in front of you. Keep your hands shoulder-width apart from each other. Now start raising and lowering each arm alternatively (like waves).: In this exercise, instead of making waves, you have to slam the rope to the ground.Directions: Hold the ends of the rope at arm's length. Now lift both the hands above your head and slam the rope on the ground with force. Again lift your hand and repeat the same.Battle ropes might look like a simple workout, but you have to keep some things in mind while performing these exercises.-Try not to take too much stress while performing this exercise. Holding the ends of the rope too tightly and performing the workout under a lot of stress will make you exhausted quickly. Grip the rope lightly, relax your body and look forward.-Do not forget to breathe while performing this exercise. Breathing maximises your output.To make the workout more challenging, you can do any of the following things:-Fold the rope over to double the size. This will make the rope heavier and make it more challenging to hold the grip.-Decrease your distance from the anchor. By doing this, you will have to put more force to make the waves.-You can get into different poses like squat or plank to make battle rope workout more challenging.

Content:

GREATER NOIDA: A team of officials from Zurich AG visited Jewar airport site on Wednesday and held discussions on pending formalities related to the project. They also spent time at Yamuna Expressway Industrial Development Authority (YEIDA) office. A presentation was made by the project consultant.

The nodal officer of Noida International Airport Limited (NIAL), Shailendra Bhatia, said: “The senior-most executives of Zurich AG went around the airport site. They wanted to discuss some aspects related to forming of a special purpose entity and obtaining security clearance from the central government. They are eager to start work by January 31. The papers would be in place (by then).”

The team was particularly interested in the infrastructure projects planned around Jewar to boost connectivity between the area and other parts of NCR and Delhi, said officials.

Title: Plot nod: Religious trust’s reputation will be examined
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

GREATER NOIDA: From now, reputation of a religious trust will be evaluated before it is given permission to start operations in Greater Noida. The Greater Noida Industrial Development Authority (GNIDA) has revised the rules for allocating institutional land to religious trusts in the wake of limited availability of such plots in the city.

Apart from reputation, the trust will also have to convince the Authority as to why religious activity needs to be promoted in a certain part of Greater Noida, officials said. Till now, land allotment to religious trusts was done as per availability on a first-come-first-serve basis. Some 13 religious trusts are currently operational in Greater Noida.

Deputy general manager (institutional) of the Greater Noida Authority, AK Sharma, said that rules for allotting plots to religious trusts were revised on January 10. “Among other changes, a committee will take an interview of the trust’s management to gauge the needs,” Sharma said.

The 13 trusts had taken up land in Greater Noida before May 31, 2016, the day the last institutional scheme comprising 60 plots closed, while five more trusts are interested in opening a centre in Greater Noida. However, these five may have to compete with each other as GNIDA does not have that many plots to offer at the moment.

Depending on the size of the plot , GNIDA charges between Rs 8,700 and Rs 15,005 per sqm from institutional allottees. Larger plots command lesser premium, while the smaller ones cost more. The rates are same for trusts, societies or educational institutes, said Sharma.

The Authority would also ask the interested applicants to submit their income certificates and annual income tax returns. The officials would then run background checks on the key members of the trust’s management to ensure that they were not involved in any controversy in the past.

The committee would also try to ascertain how many members of a particular community stay in the vicinity of the proposed religious centre before taking a decision.

“The purpose of the centre and general perception of the trust would be taken into account as well. The religious centre would be allowed only after the district administration and the police department issue no-objection certificate to the trust,” another official said.

Title: Donald Trump: Book claims Trump has no idea India has a border with China
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

US President Donald Trump (file photo)

WASHINGTON: US President Donald Trump , a “very stable genius” by his own account, is so clueless about history and geography that he does not know India and China share a border, according to a new book chronicling his howlers in what is presented as a chaotic, unhinged presidency.

One of the gaffes featured in the 417-page “A Very Stable Genius: Donald J.Trump’s Testing of America” by Washington Post reporters Philip Rucker and Carol Leonnig involves the US President and India’s Prime Minister Narendra Modi early in the Trump presidency. Trump is quoted telling Modi during a meeting "It's not as though you have China right on your border..." prompting then Secretary of State Rex Tillerson to cover part of his face with one hand so as to signal something to Modi without Trump seeing it.

For the record, India and China share the ninth longest border (at 3380 kms) between two countries, longer than USA’s 3,141 kilometers border with Mexico. The border dispute also led to a war between the two countries in 1962.

According to the authors citing people familiar with the incident, "Modi’s eyes bulged out in surprise" at Trump’s remark. His "expression gradually shifted, from shock and concern to resignation," according to excerpts from the book in the US media. One Trump aide concludes that Modi probably "left that meeting and said, ‘This is not a serious man. I cannot count on this man as a partner.’?"

The aide also explains that “the Indians took a step back in their diplomatic relations with the United States,” although from all accounts, ties between Washington and New Delhi, and the personal relations between Trump and Modi, have gotten even closer since then, leading to the "Howdy Modi" rally in Houston last year and a prospective Trump visit to India in February.

The book also suggests Trump is clueless and "at times dangerously uninformed" about history, citing an anecdote from Trump's 2017 trip to Asia which involved a stopover in Hawaii and a tour of Pearl Harbor. The authors relate how, while en route to the memorial for US service members killed in the December 7, 1941 attack that brought the US into World War II, Trump "pulled Chief of Staff John Kelly aside for a quick consult."

"Hey John, what's this all about? What's this a tour of?" Trump reportedly asks him. Kelly, the authors say, was momentarily stunned. Trump had heard the phrase 'Pearl Harbor' and appeared to understand that he was visiting the scene of a historic battle, but he did not seem to know much else.

From all accounts, Trump knows very little about geo-politics, including issues relating to India. He repeatedly interjected himself in the Kashmir issue last summer, offering to mediate between India and Pakistan , and in a public repudiation of Washington’s stand that it is a bilateral matter, claimed Prime Minister Modi had invited him to do so.

US officials had to contain the fallout from the clumsy public grandstanding, and one US lawmaker apologized for the President’s amateurish and embarrassing mistake.

Title: Noida: Residents hit the road to protest tree-felling plan
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Sector 22 residents have asked the Noida Authority to find an alternative way to build the school without remo... Read More

NOIDA: Residents of Sector 22 have started a campaign against the plan to cut several trees on a plot that has been allotted for the construction of a school.

Residents said the mature trees are essential for the area and they help prevent the stench from a nearby sewer line from reaching the sector. They alleged that the Noida Authority had earlier promised to earmark the plot for a park. But it was later given to a school. “The plot is earmarked for a school according to the master plan. But since 1987, multiple CEOs of the Authority have been promising that the area will be earmarked as a park and the trees will not be cut. However, the allotment was suddenly done in 2016 and the allottee is now trying to cut all the trees here,” said Pradeep Vohra, president of residents welfare association (RWA), Sector 22.

The 2, 500 sqm area is a vacant plot used by the local residents as a park and a common area. There are 25-30 large trees lining the boundary of the plot.

The allottee has been given permission by the forest department to remove 26 trees, of which nine can be cut and 17 have to be transplanted.

However, residents are demanding that either the school be allotted a different site or the construction be done in such a way that the trees are not removed. “The trees are very close to the boundary wall and the allottee has to leave a gap of around 10 ft for construction, according to the norms. This way the trees can also be spared. But they said that the trees will affect the building’s foundation even if they are not very close. We have asked the Authority to intervene and find a way so that these trees are not removed. People living here have planted these trees and seen them grow,” Vohra added.

The Authority has now put a hold on the plan to cut the trees. Officials said, the matter will be discussed with the school owner.

“We have called the allottee to discuss the matter. However, they have not turned up yet. We will talk about how the building can be designed so that fewer trees are affected,” said SC Gaur, the general manager (planning) at the Noida Authority.

Meanwhile, residents’ bodies like FONRWA, sector RWAs and environmental groups have also joined the protest and are asking the Authority to find a middle ground so that the trees can be saved.

Environment activist Vikrant Tongad said, “It is unfair that over 25 fully grown trees are being removed from a busy locality within the city without looking at an alternative. Even if it is legal, we need to consider the environmental cost of this move, when we are facing constant challenges of air pollution in Delhi and NCR.”

Title: 'Rapunzel' grows 20cm hair in a year, retains Guinness crown!
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Nilanshi Patel of Modasa with Guinness Book of Records 2020 for being the teenager with longest hair.

AHMEDABAD: For Nilanshi Patel, a 5'6" teenager from Modasa in north Gujarat , her crowning glory is eight inches longer than her physical frame!

Modasa-based Nilanshi, a class XII (science) student who aspires to become an engineer has broken her own record by growing 20 cm hair in a year. Nilanshi has recently recently been named in the Guinness Book of Records 2020 for being the teenager with longest hair measuring 190 cm (6.2 feet).

Last year, Nilanshi had found a place in this record book with 170.5 cm (5.7 feet) long hair. In general parlance, the annual growth of 20 cm hair recorded by Nilanshi is an addition of just a tiny bit short of the shoulder length hair! "I'm blessed with good genes. Most people I meet want to know the secret to my luxuriant air growth but I rarely do anything out of ordinary. I wash my hair once a week which is a two hour long ritual," says Nilanshi who has to spend half hour drying it and an hour to comb. Nilanshi confesses she uses a home-made oil by her mother, a secret-recipe, which she does not reveal! She mostly wears her long tresses in a bun or braid, not keeping it open lest she trips on it!

Title: Uttar Pradesh: Nine senior IPS officers to make policing people-friendly
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Now, the team will have nine senior IPS officers and experts from different fields

GREATER NOIDA: The first police commissioner of Gautam Budh Nagar, Alok Singh, took charge at the Surajpur police station on Wednesday.

The state government had approved the upgrade of the Gautam Budh Nagar district to a commissionerate on Monday.

“The new system will be like that in Delhi. The 25-lakh-strong population of Noida is a mix of the rural and the urban, which is why there was a need for change. With the new system in place, senior officers who usually supervise from a distance will get to work on the field to ensure implementation of community policing,” Singh said.

Under the previous system, he said, there was only one SSP to look after the day-to-day tasks. Now, the team will have nine senior IPS officers and experts from different fields. “These officers will ensure that policing becomes citizen-centric … The team’s major objective will be ensuring the safety of the floating population of Noida and Greater Noida, including the 4.5 lakh working women who travel to Delhi and Gurgaon,” he said. Traffic management will also be a priority, which will start by identifying points that have structural and enforcement problems.

Restructuring under the new system is under way, with three SPs redesignated as additional DCPs and seven circle officers named assistant commissioners of police. More officers reached Gautam Budh Nagar to join the team. “Once the new officers settle in, a meeting to finalise the structure and responsibilities will be held,” Singh said.

Title: Assault, threat cases to be lodged as FIRs
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Representative image

GHAZIABAD: All cases related to assault and criminal intimidation will be lodged as FIRs from now on, instead of non-cognizable offence reports (NCRs) for which a magistrate’s permission is needed to carry out probe.

Ghaziabad SSP Kalanidhi Naithani said the current system of lodging such cases as NCRs stalls probe and also fails to redress the complainants’ grievances. “In Uttar Pradesh , except for Ghaziabad, cases related to IPC sections 506 (criminal intimidation) are registered as FIR. This should not be done and I have directed all police stations to register FIRs under IPC sections 323 (voluntarily causing hurt), 504 (intentional insult with intent to provoke breach of the peace), besides IPC Section 506, and start the investigation immediately,” he said.

Police officers said that in NCR cases, a preliminary inquiry is conducted to check if the allegations are correct and if it is found that further probe is needed, a permission is sought from the magistrate. A complainant can approach the magistrate and seek a directive on the basis of an NCR for police to register a case.

Naithani said the move is aimed at providing comfort to the complainants, who have already suffered injuries and had been threatened.

The SSP has also directed all SHOs to lodge cybercrime cases at police stations and not make complainants go to cyber cells.

Title: Only one underground station for Ghaziabad’s RRTS corridor
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Representative image

GHAZIABAD: The National Capital Region Transport Corporation (NCRTC) has floated a tender for the construction of a tunnel on the Regional Rapid Transit System (RRTS) route between Delhi and Ghaziabad .

The 5.8km-long tunnel will start ahead of Anand Vihar station and terminate near Bharat Electronics Limited, near Sahibabad station. It is part of the 17km priority section of the corridor — from Sahibabad to Duhai — for which NCRTC has set a March 2023 deadline.

“Work on the underground tunnelling system will start shortly as the global tender for it has been floated,” said Sudhir Sharma, the chief public relation officer, NCRTC. “Unlike tunnels on other metro corridors, the diameter of the tunnel here is bigger at 6.5 m, as it will have the rapid rail travelling at 100kmph. Along the 5.8km tunnel, there will be one station, Anand Vihar,” he added.

The broad parameters of alignment and station will be dictated by the NCRTC but it is for the company to decide on the design and structural operations that it may wish to employ while carrying out the work. “The tender will be awarded under design and built mode, which means that the company will have free hand in designing the route and proposed station and thereafter, it will construct on its own,” Sharma added.

Along the total 82 km Delhi-Ghaziabad-Meerut RRTS corridor , only 11.5 km will be underground, which will have four stations — Anand Vihar in Delhi, and Meerut Central, Bhaisali and Begum Pul in Meerut.

“The other underground section (5.7 km) is in Meerut and tender for that will be floated later,” said Sharma.

The entire corridor is likely to become operational by March 2024 and the estimated cost of the project is Rs 30,274 crore .

According to a detailed project report, the daily ridership is expected to be more than 8 lakh and once completed, the 82km distance between Meerut and New Delhi via Ghaziabad can be covered in less than 55 minutes.

Title: Mystery shrouds death of central jail inmate
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Ludhiana: An inmate died under mysterious circumstances at Ludhiana Central Jail late on Tuesday night.

Sumit Sachdeva, 28, a resident of Sahnewal, was brought to the jail on January 5 after Doraha police arrested him in a drugs case.

Deputy jail superintendent Iqbal Singh Dhaliwal said, “As Sumit was a drug addict, he was admitted to the prison’s de-addiction centre. Around 10am on Tuesday, his health deteriorated. The other inmates took him to the jail hospital, where he was treated. After taking medicines, Sumit was fine. But minutes later, he complained of severe pain in body. The jail hospital doctors then referred him to civil hospital.”

Sumit was taken to civil hospital around 10.20pm and he died about an hour later.

On receiving the news, his kith and kin gathered at the hospital on Wednesday morning.

Sumit’s brother, Sunil Sachdeva, said, “The jail authorities did not ensure my brother’s proper treatment, which led to his death.”

A judicial inquiry has been marked into the incident.

Title: ASI shoots at friend’s wife, threatens her two daughters
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Ludhiana: A Ludhiana Police assistant sub-inspector (ASI) shot at the wife of his friend with his service revolver in front of her two daughters at her house in the city on Tuesday afternoon.

ASI Sukhpal Singh, who was deputed at Jamalpur police station, then took her to a nearby private hospital in his car and threatened her daughters to keep mum.

The family informed the police on Wednesday morning.

Jamalpur SHO inspector Harjinder Singh said ASI Sukhpal Singh was present on duty on Tuesday. Thereafter, he left the police station and did not return.

Police said the ASI was a family friend of the 45-year-old woman for the past 10 years.

The woman’s elder daughter, 18, who is an eyewitness, said her father worked at a firm here as a supervisor. On Tuesday, her father was at work while she, her 16-year-old sister and mother were at home. In the afternoon ASI Sukhpal Singh came home and her mother prepared tea, which they had in the lobby. She and her sister were inside their room.

“I heard them arguing, but ignored it. Minutes later, I heard a gunshot and rushed out with my sister. The shot had missed its mark. In front of our eyes, the ASI again shot at our mother. When we raised the alarm, the ASI flashed the weapon at us and threatened to kill us all. He then took our mother to a hospital,” she added.

Out of fear, the girls did not even call their father. At night, they informed him and he rushed to the hospital.

“The ASI has threatened my wife that if she gave a statement against him, he would kill our daughters. We want strict action against him. He remained in the hospital with us till 2.30am to ensure that we do not call the police,” the woman’s husband said.

Assistant commissioner of police (east) Devinder Chaudhary said, “The family informed the police on Wednesday morning. The woman, in her statement, said the family had good relations with the ASI and they also borrowed money from each other. On Tuesday afternoon, the ASI told her that he wanted to purchase a new car for which he needed money. The woman told him that they didn’t have money and this triggered an argument between them. The ASI then opened fire. According to her daughters, they heard two gunshots. However, we have not found any bullet shells from the spot… the ASI may have taken those along. We are trying to trace the accused.”

The Division 7 police have booked the ASI for attempt to murder on the statement of the woman.

‘The two had an affair’

Later in the day, the police claimed that the ASI had an affair with the woman. “After her husband learned about it a few months ago, he asked the ASI to stay away from his wife,” said a cop.

Commissioner of police Rakesh Agarwal said, “The ASI had an affair with the woman for long. At the hospital, he had deposited Rs 2 lakh for her treatment. A Special Investigation Team, comprising ADCP-4, ACP (East) and Division 7 SHO, has been formed to look into the case and arrest the accused, who has been suspended.”

Title: Not a safe city for children
Content:
This story is from January 16, 2020

Ludhiana: Crime against children in Ludhiana commissionerate grew by more than 12% from 2017 to 2018, according to the National Crime Records Bureau (NCRB) report.

Among the various cities and districts of the state, Ludhiana commissionerate topped the list with the highest number of cases of crime against children reported in 2018. As per the NCRB report released last Thursday, the number of such cases in Ludhiana commissionerate in 2018 was 352; the figure was 312 a year before, indicating a 12.8% increase.

Chief minister’s home district Patiala stood second with 169 cases in 2018, Jalandhar came third with 167 cases and Mohali witnessed 125 cases. Analysis showed that kidnapping (sections 363, 363A, 364, 364A, 365, 366, 366A, 367, 368 and 369 of the IPC) topped the sub-categories with 197 cases. Of these, maximum cases (180) were of kidnapping of minor girls to compel them for marriage (which is also part of crime against women) and 17 cases were of abduction.

Ludhiana also witnessed 21 cases of rape, nine cases of rape bid and 10 of assault on girls with intent to outrage modesty. The commissionerate reported 65 cases under the Protection of Children from Sexual Offences Act, of which 60 were of girls and five related to unnatural offences with boys.

The NCRB data suggested that Ludhiana also recorded six cases of murder of children in 2018, one of attempt to murder and 13 of exposure and abandonment. The city registered 18 cases under the Juvenile Justice (Care and Protection of Children) Act and eight under Child Labour (Prohibition and Regulation Act).

Social activists underline the need to make the city safe for children. “There is a sizeable rise in the crime graph. It is both a social and a security problem. Police have a greater role to make Ludhiana safe for children,” said Keemti Rawal, a social activist. “We understand that police are facing shortage of staff. The state government should provide adequate personnel for better security,” he added.

Ludhiana police commissioner Rakesh Aggarwal said, “We don’t pay heed to figures while controlling crime. For, it can affect registration of cases. Our focus is to provide a secure atmosphere to people and arrest criminals. We have cracked most of the crime cases even as we are grappling with acute staff shortage.”Area — Number of cases of crime against children (2018)
